HEADLINE: Baghdad Now Seen Exerting Economic Pressure on Kurds

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The Government of President Saddam Hussein is applying economic pressure against the 3.5 million-member Kurdish minority in northern Iraq, apparently to force its reconciliation with Baghdad.
The pressure campaign over recent weeks has reduced gasoline deliveries to at least two major cities, Erbil and Sulaimaniya, and may also be interrupting some food and electricity supplies to the region, Kurdish and relief agency officials said. The campaign also has included a threat to the civil-service jobs of thousands of Kurds. 
 A United Nations official in Baghdad said he had witnessed a food truck being turned away from Sulaimaniya at an Iraqi Army checkpoint during a tour of the north last week. While the Kurds have not retaliated, Kurdish guerrillas control and could cut Baghdad's key highway route to Turkey, from which hundreds of food trucks arrive every week.
Referring to Baghdad's actions, a Kurdish spokesman in Washington said, "I think this is Saddam Hussein saying that if you don't deal with me, you will all starve to death."
 
Autonomy Talks Under Way
 Kurdish leaders have engaged in difficult autonomy talks with Baghdad since Mr. Hussein's forces crushed a Kurdish uprising in March in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war and United States-led forces occupied part of northern Iraq to insure the safe return to Iraq of hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees.
Kurdish leaders met in nothern Iraq today over whether to negotiate or go to war with Baghdad.
The new pressure from Baghdad comes at a crucial time both for the Kurds and for Mr. Hussein. Over the summer, most of Iraqi Kurdistan once again slipped out of Mr. Hussein's control as Kurdish guerrillas pushed, cajoled and intimidated Iraqi security forces to relinquish their ground.
This has been possible in part because United States and allied warplanes are the omnipresent power in the skies over northern Iraq, and Mr. Hussein's armed forces have been unwilling to risk another allied intervention by challenging the Kurdish guerrillas' gradual expansion of control.
 
Tanks Seen Pulling Out
 Ten days ago, a reporter touring the north observed Iraqi tank brigades pulling out of positions in and around Erbil and Sulaimaniya. The redeployment appeared designed to cede control of these cities to Kurdish guerrillas while perserving Iraqi control over the main highways to Kirkuk, the northern oil center that Mr. Hussein insists on keeping out of Kurdish hands.
In effect, the Kurds have been able to accomplish incrementally and bloodlessly much of what they failed to gain through their uprising in March after the allied victory over the Iraqi Army in Kuwait. And the question of what should be the next step for the Kurds has divided its leadership council.
Kurdish officials say the most alarming aspect of Baghdad's pressure campaign for thousands of wage-earning Kurds was a notice sent around Oct. 22 to civil servants throughout the region informing them that to keep their jobs they would have to relocate to cities under Government control, like Mosul and Kirkuk. No one has been dismissed yet, officials said.
The Kurdish chieftain Massoud Barzani said in an interview in Dohuk on Oct. 26 that he had asked Baghdad to rescind the order.
 
Already Suffering Deprivation
 Government salaries for teachers, police officers and local utility employees are often the principal income in many homes in the region, which is already suffering the deprivations of postwar Iraq and the effects of the United Nations trade embargo.
Jalal Talabani, who leads one of the two largest Kurdish parties, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, declared last week that the steps taken by Baghdad represented the onset of "economic warfare" by Mr. Hussein's Government.
Mr. Talabani said he was headed for a political showdown with Mr. Barzani over whether to continue negotiating with Baghdad for Kurdish autonomy in northern Iraq, or to take a more confrontational approach such as establishing a provisional independent government for all Iraqi opposition groups in northern Iraq.
This step would in effect mark the beginning of civil war in Iraq, and Mr. Barzani has said he will oppose any attempt by Mr. Talabani to establish a rival government in Kurdistan.

HEADLINE: A Soviet Correspondent Goes Home Again

 BODY:
Viktor A. Linnik arrived in New York City four years ago as a foreign correspondent who sought to immerse himself in United States culture and write articles for his newspaper, Pravda, that described everyday American life for his Soviet readers.
Roaming across the United States, he sent reports to Moscow about the struggles of farmers in the American heartland and about the immigrants who were flooding into the cities of a country that had fascinated him since his days as an American literature major at Moscow State University. 
 But Mr. Linnik's tour of duty in the United States has been cut short, an indirect victim of the failed hard-line coup in the Soviet Union in August. Pravda, the once mighty Communist Party newspaper, has flirted with bankruptcy as it tries to survive at a time when the party has been outlawed and the Soviet economy is in shambles.
Mr. Linnik, 47 years old, said he has received little money from his editors since August, forcing him to curtail his travels and pushing him nearly $15,000 into debt. With little means to keep up its staff of foreign correspondents, Pravda is closing its New York City office, and Mr. Linnik is to return home this month.
For now, though, he trying to gather money to pay off his loans so he can board the plane for Moscow. He feels, he said the other day, like a sailor stranded at sea.
"I've been essentially living on whatever I can manage to scrape here and there," he said in perfect American English with only the faintest of accents.
"I can't use my car," he added, explaining that he had not been able to make payments on his car insurance in months. "What life is there for a reporter if he can't use his car?"
Other Soviet correspondents in the United States, like those from Tass, the Soviet press agency, and Izvestia, the Government newspaper, have not been as seriously affected by the fallout from the failed coup. Being the official organ of the Communist Party, Pravda received the brunt of the ire from the Moscow leaders who stood against the coup plotters. President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic closed the newspaper for a week after the coup.
Mr. Linnik's voice was tinged with bitterness as he spoke about the upheaval in his country and the shock waves that reached as far as his apartment and office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Even though he had been a party member since 1977, he said he did not mourn the death of Soviet Communism. But he stressed that the leaders who were empowered after the failed coup were little different from their predecessors.
"One thing that needs to be understood: the democrats, the reformers back home come from the same roots -- the party," he said. "They have the same vindictiveness, the same unscrupulousness. People now have stopped realizing this."
Mr. Linnik came to New York in the early days of the reforms instituted by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, when journalists were beginning to test the boundaries of the censorship that had defined the Soviet press for so long. During the cold war, Soviet reporters in the United States usually filed home reports that sought to trumpet the failings of capitalism through reports that emphasized America's problems -- the unemployed, the drugs, the racial strife.
"What happened after 1985 was another extreme," Mr. Linnik said. "Everything that was written later was shown through rosy glasses. Everything was beautiful about America. This was the ideal country."
Mr. Linnik does not know what awaits him when he returns to Moscow with his wife and two young daughters. Because of his ties to the party, he fears he may be blacklisted and will be unable to work at Pravda or another newspaper.
"I'll have to see whether the country is changing for the better," he said. "It's a very depressing time -- for the country, for me personally. We're in a period of great instability, with the worst yet to come."
But Mr. Linnik said he leaves the United States buoyed by four years of memories.
"I've learned a lot," Mr. Linnik said of his tour here. "I will miss it."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
On MTV, Talking About the MTV Generation

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
They are the twentysomethings and, between the ages of 21 and 25, there are some 22 million of them. Sometimes they are called the MTV generation. Now MTV is devoting an hourlong special report to these young adults struggling to establish a cultural niche for themselves, something that will distinguish them from the hippies and baby boomers and yuppies of times past. Skittishly provocative, the program, "MTV Generation," can be seen at 10 tonight.
Produced and directed by Lauren Lazin, who also co-wrote the program with Kurt Loder, "MTV Generation" makes a broad sweep of the country and finds a youthful landscape of enormous diversity and troubling doubts. These are the young men and women, we are told, who "grew up with a feel-good President and a Wall Street boom that's now bottomed out." 
 More than a few are cynical. Most television is dismissed as propaganda of one sort or another. Among their most vivid memories are Watergate and the Challenger explosion, described here as "a symbol of our nation going up in flames."
Perhaps more than anything else, there is uncertainty. About 40 percent of them come from a background of divorce, which might account for "The Brady Bunch" being their "most liked" television series. A fan of that show notes, not entirely sarcastically, how the mother had no job and "just went shopping." Among the more positive portraits gathered for this documentary is that of a close-knit Miami family of Colombian immigrants in which the mother and daughters work together to realize their dreams.
Dreams, in fact, seem to be in short supply. All of those interviewed want to do better than their parents, but that prospect, once so ordinary, is no longer assured. One Wisconsin man, struggling to support a wife and child, says he wants only "a nice steady job with good hourly pay." The auto plants in his area, however, have been shut down in recent years and nothing has emerged to replace them.
Diversions have become crucial. In Boston, one young man has a day job in an insurance agency "to pay the rent" and then spends most nights and weekends performing in a rock band. "You should be loud and boisterous and do whatever you want," he says. "And make big ugly mistakes and learn your lessons." The unemployed Wisconsin man has more limited options, one being to take the family out for a four-wheel-drive spin in a muddy field. "Makes me feel I can do anything," he says, pulling furiously at the steering wheel.
And then there is this generation's fascination with the past, evidenced in everything from the careful reconstruction of 1950's diners as hangouts for James Dean wannabes to 1970's discos bouncing with old recordings like the Village People singing "Y.M.C.A." Psychedelic 1960's? Catch the Doors revival. Exasperated with the retro-mania, John Kinney, a 25-year-old, became a founding member of the Association for the Advancement of Time, urging "people our age" to "just say now" and concentrate on the present.
There are no prototypes in this group portrait. One man in Boston sees the world as divided into pimps and whores, the former being the bosses. Another in Eugene, Ore., raised in a hippie commune and speaking warmly of his family of radicals, says he is for peace and against large companies. But he says he also believes that money is important because it "plays an important part in what people can achieve." He's interested in real estate.
On the subject of the Persian Gulf war, opinions are predictably divided. Some take a proud "we're No. 1" stance; others note wryly how the world now knows that the United States can destroy 100,000 lives with maximum efficiency. Despite President Bush's speeches about a new world order, many younger people interviewed here don't seem to detect much change, at home or abroad. A sense of drift, of uneasiness, is reflected on the documentary's sound track as Michael Jackson sings "Man in the Mirror."
There is also mention of how young adults seem to be able to take in more information in a shorter time than could their counterparts in the past. MTV, of course, is a major force in this phenomenon with its hourly bombardments of rapid-fire editing. In that sense, "Generation" is pure MTV, tailored to short attention spans and packaged as tightly and energetically as any music video. In this instance, subject and style are remarkably compatible.
 
MTV Generation
 
Produced and directed by Lauren Lazin; written by Ms. Lazin and Kurt Loder; Bill Richmond, co-director and editor; Linda Corradina, executive producer; narrated by Mr. Loder. At 10 tonight on MTV.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION;
WOFFORD WINS SENATE RACE, TURNING BACK THORNBURGH; G.O.P. GAINS EDGE IN TRENTON

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5

 BODY:
In a stunning upset that will raise the hopes of Democrats and the fears of Republicans facing elections next year, Harris Wofford, a little-known Democrat with an anti-Bush message, today trounced former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.
Mr. Wofford, who was appointed to the Senate in May, was initially given almost no hope of winning the election. But in a trial run for themes that are certain to be important next year, he concentrated on the need for national health insurance and the problems with the economy and offered general pledges to help the middle class. In the last month he climbed in the polls by an average of almost a percentage point a day, and today he leapt ahead. 
 With 87 percent of 9,428 precincts reporting, the vote was:
 
Wofford . . . 1,594,443 (56%)
Thornburgh . . . 1,270,355 (44%)
As about 500 campaign workers and friends roared "Harris! Harris! Harris!," Mr. Wofford stepped to the microphone at 11:30 P.M., saluted the group and said "The first Democratic Senator in 23 years reporting for duty!"
 
'It's Time for Change'
 In his 15-minute minute speech in the ballroom of a Philadelphia hotel, he choked up as he thanked his wife, Clare, and every member of his family as well as his extended family, which he said included every Pennsylvanian. He said he had just received a "gracious" telephone call from Mr. Thornburgh conceding the race and wishing him well. Mr. Wofford responded in kind, telling the group that Mr. Thornburgh was a "true Pennsylvania gentleman and a good public citizen" who has "contributed much to this commonwealth and this country."
He said of his election: "I thank Pennsylvania for sending me as its messenger, and the message is it's time for change. The people of Pennsylvania on this glorious day have used the power of the ballot to send a wake up call to the President and to the Congress and Republicans everywhere."
 
'Hard-Fought Victory'
 And echoing a former boss, President John F. Kennedy, he said: "Let the word go forth from this place on the the Delaware to our nation's capital on the banks of the Potomac. We want national health insurance!"
Across the state, Mr. Thornburgh came to a ballroom in the basement of the William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh with his four sons, two daughters-in-law and his wife to make his concession speech.
He told the crowd he had called Mr. Wofford and congratulated him on a "hard-fought victory." Mr. Thornburgh said that voter concerns about the economy and the cost of health care "obviously commanded much greater attention in the campaign than we anticipated."
He made no references to President Bush, who had campaigned for him in the state.
At Thornburgh headquarters, State Attorney General Ernest D. Preate Jr., a Republican, told reporters, "Things have got to improve in Washington, or it's going to be a difficult future for Republicans in Pennsylvania."
Mr. Wofford will serve the remaining three years of the term of Senator John Heinz, a Republican, who was killed in a plane crash over Philadelphia in April.
By defeating Mr. Thornburgh, who was a popular two-term Governor of Pennsylvania, Mr. Wofford becomes the first Democrat elected to the Senate from Pennsylvania since Joseph Clark in 1962. He was the state's Secretary of Labor and Industry when he was appointed in May to fill Mr. Heinz's seat until the election.
In recent weeks Mr. Wofford's campaign had swayed many voters, and the latest polls, made public last week, showed he had closed the gap with Mr. Thornburgh, who had emphasized his ties to Washington.
Republican strategists asserted that the election was not a referendum on President Bush's domestic policies, even though Mr. Wofford laid the blame for much of the nation's economic woes, social problems and political embarrassments on Mr. Thornburgh, who was also chairman of the President Bush's Domestic Policy Council. But Democratic strategists disagreed.
There is little dispute that the election showed how vulnerable incumbent Republicans are in this recessionary period and that Democratic proposals for national health insurance are tapping into voters' anxieties about the troubled economy and the fragility of their jobs.
Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG Inc., a market and social research firm in New York, said: "This sends a very dramatic message, first to the White House that Bush is not invincible and that health care is one of the cutting edge issues of the 1992 elections. This race in Pennsylvania is a rehearsal of it."
A supporter of Mr. Thornburgh, Barbara Hafer, the state Auditor General, said Mr. Thornburgh was hurt by his failure to enunciate a message that connected with voters. "Democrats have to cross over in Pennsylvania for a Republican to win and we didn't give them a reason," Ms. Hafer said. "There was no compelling reason for them to break ranks."
The race may also give some insight into the conventional wisdom that Democrats who have voted Republican in recent national elections will come home to support their own party's candidates in a recession.
"There are many lapsed Democrats in Pennsylvania who voted for George Bush in 1988," when Mr. Bush carried the state with 50.9 percent of the vote, said Sandra Featherman, a political analyst and a vice chancellor of the University of Minnesota at Duluth. "They are Republicans on social issues and Democrats on economic issues."
 
Debate Over Health Care
 But precise reasons for people's votes may be hard to come by. Exit polls would have provided answers, but poll takers did not take an interest in the Pennsylvania race until after it had become a dead heat last week, and by then it was too late to organize the surveys.
 Conversations with voters indicated that many Wofford supporters were taken with his ideas on national health care. "Health care costs have ballooned at a ridiculous rate and poor people are shut out," said Dan Levitt, a 33-year-old independent film producer who lives in West Philadelphia.
But other voters were repelled. Standing outside the Spruce Hill Community Association in West Philadelphia where she had voted for Mr. Thornburgh, Eva L. C. Higgins, a 45-year-old biophysics researcher, said that she was voting against Mr. Wofford and his health plan. "Who is going to pay for it?" she said. "I come from Denmark where it's not working there anymore. It's too expensive."
At the same community center, Jim Mosetter, a 58-year-old paint salesman, said he had voted for Mr. Thornburgh. "I think he did a good job as governor and attorney general," he said.
But Jim Hoffman, a dairy farmer in North Annville Township in Lebanon County, said he was voting for Mr. Wofford, who he thought would be more sympathetic to farmers and their economic problems. "I hope he can help us," he said, adding that milk prices had sunk to 1972 lows.
Today, both candidates stayed near their home bases, Mr. Thornburgh in Pittsburgh and Mr. Wofford in Philadelphia. Both voted early and then roved on foot and by car in a low-key day of campaigning with their families.
Mr. Thornburgh toured a home for disabled children; Mr. Wofford spoke with students and faculty members at Temple University in North Philadelphia before having lunch at Day's Deli in downtown Philadelphia. Both candidates urged their campaign workers to get out the vote.
After Mr. Heinz's death, Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat, spent a month searching for a temporary replacement, someone who would wage a strong campaign against Mr. Thornburgh, who was even then expected to be the Republican candidate. In May after several people, including Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation who is a Pennsylvania native, rejected the overture, Governor Casey appointed Mr. Wofford.
The 65-year-old Mr. Wofford, who was also an aide to President Kennedy and a former president of Bryn Mawr College, had never run for elected office. Most political analysts minimized his chance of winning when he began campaigning this summer, and the candidate's own polls showed him running more than 40 points behind Mr. Thornburgh.
But by Oct. 1, polls showed Mr. Wofford's campaign was taking hold, dealing a setback to Mr. Thornburgh, who was campaigning on his record and his familiarity "with the corridors of power" in Washington.
Mr. Wofford and his campaign managers were able to set the agenda for the rest of the campaign, calling for an extension of unemployment benefits, a greater effort to keep jobs in this country and tax cuts for the middle class. But more than anything else, his campaign was a crusade for national health insurance, although it provided few specifics. The latest polls, made public last week, showed that Mr. Wofford had nearly closed the gap and that the race was too close to call.
Mr. Thornburgh spent most of his 70-day campaign reacting to Mr. Wofford's platform, calling the health plan "untried, untested, radical and costly." But political analysts say he failed to present a clear message. The campaign was largely waged on television with 30-second advertisements that grew negative after the Thornburgh campaign in mid-October released a commercial portraying Mr. Wofford as a "liberal college president" who was partly accountable for Governor Casey's $3.3 billion tax increase this year.
The Wofford campaign responded with advertisements criticizing Thornburgh's performance as Attorney General, and were widely considered more effective and more damaging.

A1); Former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh conceding defeat in his race for the Senate. With him in Pittsburgh was his wife, Ginny. (Terry Clark for The New York Times) (pg. A22)

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
Symphony Of Grace And Grit: The Detroit

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
One has to admire the tenacity of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, which has struggled to stay alive in the face of a sharply deteriorating Michigan economy. Determination, of course, is not sufficient reason to keep an orchestra with a $17 million budget afloat. But at its Carnegie Hall concert on Monday evening, the musicians showed that what is at stake is a first-class ensemble with a sound that is impressively polished and warm. Its lower strings, in particular, provided a rich, glowing foundation in Arvo Part's ruminative "Cantus in Memory of Benjamin Britten." And the transparency of the wind and brass playing gave the last two movements of the Ives First Symphony an alluringly springy, Romantic sound.
The orchestra was conducted by Neeme Jarvi, who is now in his second season as its music director. Mr. Jarvi is not a flashy conductor, but his gestures are clear and expressive, and sweeping when they need to be. 
 He began the concert with the Part, a mysterious and passionate work in which a simple descending string theme is treated as a mensuration canon, with each entry set in a different meter and at half the tempo of the previous entry.
But the effect is greater than a description of its materials would suggest. After a moment, the repeated, metrically varied theme creates a rich, hypnotic effect, and by the end of the six-minute work, one hears an interesting amalgam of Part's Minimalist accent and the lush string textures common to many of Britten's string orchestra works.
Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, the soloist in the Sibelius Violin Concerto, gave what seemed, at first, to be a more conventional performance than listeners have come to expect of her. Although she tinkered with the score's dynamics from the outset, some of the detailing she brought to the solo line early in the opening movement was thoughtful, sharp-edged and provocative, but not unreasonable.
By the time the movement ended, though, the eccentricity index had increased considerably, as did the quotient of pitch problems. Those problems increased in the final two movements. Intensity and inventiveness are qualities to be prized, but when they come at a cost in coherence and technique, the enterprise is devalued.
On the other hand, sometimes recasting a work's shape does it wonders. After the intermission, Mr. Jarvi took the Ives First, a patchwork of Brahms and Dvorak influences, leavened with Ives's own ingenious twists, and went a long way toward shaping it into a likable, cohesive piece. The orchestra responded to his efforts admirably, and played the symphony as if it were a top-drawer masterwork.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

President Bush canceled plans for a trip to the Far East as he faced mounting pressure to speed the end of the recession and to demonstrate his concern about domestic issues.

ROBERT MAXWELL FOUND DEAD
 The body of Robert Maxwell, the flamboyant publisher whose worldwide holdings include The Daily News, was discovered floating in the ocean off the Canary Islands. An autopsy will be performed to determine the cause of his death. Page A1 
 Mr. Maxwell, 68, fled the collapse of Czechoslovakia to become a brash and powerful businessman. D23

HEADLINE: The Law That Ate the Future

 BODY:
The Budget Agreement. It was the Holy Grail of 1990, the painful compromise between a Republican President and a Democratic Congress. It was holy because both sides solemnly pledged to abide by the deal for five years, and grail because the quest for honest deficit reduction took so many elusive turns. "Read my hips," President Bush gibed -- before finally accepting new taxes after all.
The same agreement has, in a different world, become the hair shirt of 1991, scratching at members of Congress who think the deal has gone sour yet feel a duty to stick with it. The truth is, however, that to preserve the 1990 budget agreement, it must be scrapped. 
 That's not sophistry. The budget law was designed to lower the deficit by $500 billion over five years, thereby spurring investment and economic growth. Had the world stayed put, it might have worked.
But 1990 was a light-year ago. Then, the Soviet Union was a military menace; now it barely survives as one country. Huge military programs justifiable a year ago make no sense today. And, compared with a year ago, the estimated cost of financing the Administration's defense program has soared so fast as to break the spirit of the budget agreement. To meet the deficit target now would force savage, unanticipated gouges in domestic programs.
It's easy to forget that deficit reduction is not an end in itself. Its purpose is to slow Washington's raid on private capital markets, freeing funds for investment. But viewed a year later, the budget law now threatens to protect private investment by trashing public investment in education, job training, transportation and research. That's why Congress must change the law.
The 1990 law called for reducing the deficit gradually. The cuts were backloaded, that is they bite especially hard after 1993, in order to avoid punishing the sluggish economy. And the law imposed an unprecedented pay-as-you-go discipline that would force Congress to pay for new entitlements with tax hikes or spending cuts.
So far so good. But the leadership imposed -- without consultation or debate -- a pernicious condition. For three years, non-entitlement spending would be capped in a way that would keep Congress from switching defense savings into domestic programs. Not until 1994 could non-entitlement spending be raised. What kind of sense does that make in this post-Communist world when Americans urge their Government to look homeward?
One remedy would be to collect the peace dividend now and use it to reduce the deficit, as the budget law would allow. But that's unlikely. Congress won't spit in the eye of defense contractors and workers on behalf of abstract virtue. If the choice is deficit reduction versus defense, defense will win every time.
Another remedy would be to stick with the budget agreement until 1994 before cashing in the peace dividend, letting unnecessary defense programs survive temporarily. But that turns out to be masochistic. New weapons systems, once started, can't be instantly stopped. The wasteful expenditures will roll along well past 1994, a course ruinous to worthy domestic programs.
The Congressional Budget Office provides a frightening estimate. If military spending proceeds as agreed last year, come 1994 and 1995 all non-entitlement spending will have to be sliced by a whopping 10 percent. Such cuts would brutalize investments in education, job training, technological research and every other public investment -- unless the country starts collecting the peace dividend now. That means renegotiating the budget agreement.
Broadly speaking that's hardly a novel idea. In recent weeks, members of Congress have rushed to propose that defense reductions be used for neither deficit reduction nor public investment. They want -- an election year's coming up -- tax cuts. This is a dangerous, cynical game.
Because the budget law was backloaded, the largest share of spending cuts was scheduled for 1994 and 1995. Even if taxes were not reduced one dollar, all manner of domestic programs would have to be savaged just to meet the modest deficit-reduction goal.
Preserving desperately needed public spending will require the entire peace dividend, and then some. To give it away in tax cuts borders on the unconscionable. Still deeper cuts in defense are needed; every cent of tax revenue is needed; the budget agreement is not.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Foreign Aid Follies

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Representative Dante Fascell is an old lion, gruff and friendly, and much liked by his House colleagues. Many of them wanted to vote for the new foreign aid authorization bill mainly out of respect for the long-serving chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee. The Democratic leadership did a private head count before the vote and said all was O.K. But last week after dozens had risen to orate and fulminate on the House floor, the bill was defeated by 262 to 159.
There's nothing terribly unusual about not passing the bill to authorize foreign aid. Congress has not approved any such bill since 1985, while it went on to pass less conspicuous resolutions and appropriations bills to spend the aid money anyway. This quaint arrangement allows many legislators to say they opposed "foreign giveaways" even as the aid continues to flow. Most likely the story will heed that same script this year. 
 And yet there was a certain deep rumble in last week's vote. Call it fear, fear of a voter backlash for approving foreign aid in the face of economic hardships at home. Most Republicans generally oppose the aid bill, for reasons of party tradition and outlook. But this time they were joined by nearly half the House Democrats, an almost unprecedented number.
The Democrats are the traditional backbone of unpopular foreign aid bills. Were they contemplating realignment? Representative Howard Berman seemed to think so. The California Democrat scolded his colleagues during the floor debate for making "the antidote for George Bush's mistakes [on the economy] . . . a return to isolationism."
The Republicans sensed Democratic confusion and panic and moved in for the kill. Representative Gerald Solomon, Republican of New York, wielded his familiar rhetorical ax. Either vote against this "giveaway" measure, he taunted the Democrats, or "knock off your criticism of President Bush" for not doing enough for Americans.
Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, saw this political haymaker coming before it landed in the House. Which explains why he began advocating taking funds from foreign aid to pay for extended unemployment benefits. His stratagem would put the burden back on Mr. Bush, who badly wants the aid money to conduct his foreign policy.
Here the story takes a complicated turn. Though Mr. Bush yearned for the aid money, he said he would veto the bill anyway. Why? Because the Senate-House bill provided funds for family planning abroad, including abortion counseling. Mr. Bush found that provision intolerable, as did most Congressional Republicans.
But, and here the tale becomes still more intricate, most Republicans would have rejected the bill even without the abortion provision. Why? Because over and above the regular two-year $25 billion aid package, it also authorized a $12.2 billion increase in the U.S. contribution to the International Monetary Fund. And who requested this extra money? None other than Mr. Bush himself.
This $12 billion kicker might also drive the Democrats off the aid reservation. But wait, there's yet another wrinkle that is almost certain to hold Democrats in the foreign aid camp. Remember the $10 billion loan guarantees for Israel? The Congress-White House deal, after Mr. Bush faced down the Israeli lobby, was to defer the issue until February. When that bell rings, Democrats will support the bill in order to get the guarantees, which could add $1 billion more to the aid tab.
But will Mr. Bush back those guarantees? Yes, if Israel suspends new settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. No, if the settlements continue. But if he opposes the guarantees, the Democrats might not support the rest of the foreign aid bill he desperately desires.
And don't forget the $1 billion in emergency relief for the Soviet Union that House and Senate conferees just tacked onto the Pentagon budget bill. This soon will be voted on by both houses.
So everybody wins, or loses, or wins and loses or something, as official Washingtonians work themselves into a classic shaggy dog story. They can cut foreign aid and give the money to the unemployed. Or they can propose increases in aid, then vote against the aid bill. Or they can approve everything and just increase the deficit. However they choose, the nation will stand in awe.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
THE first thing I noticed was an occasional blurriness when I perused medical journals, especially when the print was small and light. Then the New York City street map became increasingly difficult to decipher while driving in less than bright daylight. But it was not until I had trouble reading my own cookbooks and had misread and therefore misdialed several numbers from the phone book that I finally decided to have my eyes checked.
Though I feared the worst -- cataracts or maybe retinal damage from the sun -- the diagnosis was "normal" presbyopia, the natural and unavoidable effects of aging on the lens of the eye. The solution was simple, too: reading glasses to help bring close objects into better focus.
 
A Universal Fate
 I was 49 years old when I sought help for my vision problem, and the ophthalmologist who examined me said I was lucky, since most people are for 40 to 45 when they first come in with the same complaint. He also emphasized that nothing I had done had caused it, nor was there anything I might have done to prevent it. 
 Presbyopia occurs when the lens, the convex disk that sits over the colored portion of the eye, loses its flexibility. Normally, muscles change its shape by contracting or relaxing, determining where light rays passing through the eye converge. If, as they should, they converge on the retina in the back of the eye, you get a clear image. If they converge in front of or behind the retina, the image will blur.
Youthful eyes have no trouble making the needed adjustments. But by the late 30's or early 40's the lens begins to lose its flexibility. The muscles still tug, but the lens is less and less able to assume a rounder shape that permits a clear focus on nearby objects. Instead the rays converge somewhat behind the retina.
To compensate, many people begin holding reading matter further and further away from their eyes or step back from it, changing the angle of the rays enough to permit them to focus on the retina. But eventually one's arms become too short. Or the print is simply too small to be seen from the needed distance. Other interim solutions include reading in brighter light or using a magnifying glass to see fine print, as in maps and phone books, where 3, 5 and 8 may become impossible to distinguish.
Eventually, however, usually by the age of 45, comes the day when glasses are needed to read with clarity and comfort. Among symptoms that send people to a vision professional are headaches and discomfort around the eyes toward the end of the day or after reading for a long time.
Dr. George Garcia, associate chief of ophthalmology at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary in Boston, pointed out that when presbyopia develops in people who are nearsighted (myopic), they often have to take their glasses off to read clearly. In the nearsighted eye the rays converge in front of the retina. However, when such an eye ages, the focal point for close objects is shifted further back toward the retina. Eventually, however, they will need glasses for reading as well as for distance vision.
People who start out farsighted usually need reading glasses sooner than others. As they get older, they may also need correction for distance vision because the lens can no longer make the accommodation that allows the distant image to focus on the retina; instead, light rays converge behind it. Farsighted people often end up needing bifocals or trifocals to get clear images at various distances.
The degree of stiffness of the lens gradually increases over 10 or 15 years, then usually stabilizes by the mid-50's.
 
What Can Be Done
 No exercise, medication, food or nutrient has been proved to slow or reverse this normal aging process. Going without glasses for as long as you feel you can get away with it or starting to use glasses sooner rather than later will neither forestall the problem nor make it worse. Eyes are neither strengthened nor weakened by corrective lenses; all that correction does is enable you to see more clearly without discomfort.
Nor does struggling to read fine print or reading a great deal injure your eyes. You may experience eyestrain if your vision is blurry, but your eyes will not get worse from such abuse any more than a camera would wear out sooner because it was used to take sharp or blurry pictures.
But the good news is, most people with simple presbyopia can get by very well with inexpensive reading glasses purchased over the counter at drugstores and other retail outlets. "Ready-to-wear reading glasses are effective, safe and economical," the American Academy of Ophthalmology's committee on ophthalmic procedures assessment, concluded in a statement published in September.
Such glasses are sold with a range of magnifications, from a correction of 1 diopter to up to 4 diopters in most states. Federal law specifies that they be made from impact-resistant glass or plastic (almost all are plastic ), and most meet or exceed national standards for both lenses and frames. Look for an endorsement on the label.
Over-the-counter reading glasses typically cost $10 to $15, instead of the $100 to $200 many pay for prescription glasses. Weaker lenses can be replaced as presbyopia advances. Most presbyopic eyes eventually stabilize at a correction of 2.50 to 3.50 diopters.
The academy committee pointed out, however, that if you started out with a significant refractive error (an astigmatism, or irregularity of the lens), or if your eyes differ considerably in focusing ability, over-the-counter glasses will not correct the problem.
In choosing the right magnification, Dr. Ben Ho, a San Francisco ophthalmologist, suggested using the guide that is mounted on the glasses' display case. Consider your usual work distances, for example, when reading or working at a computer terminal, when you try the various lenses for clarity. Or, Dr. Ho said, you might want to purchase two different pairs, one for reading and another for word-processing. Also consider the distance between your eyes; be sure the glasses let you see out of the center of the lens with each eye.
If you happen to choose wrong, you will soon know it because things will not be quite in focus and you will begin to experience eyestrain -- tiredness or achiness around the eyes.
It is important, too, to have a complete medical eye examination before buying over-the-counter glasses, to be sure there is no underlying disease contributing to your vision difficulties. Even if you have no problem seeing clearly, you would be wise to undergo a thorough medical eye exam by the age of 40. Thereafter, exams are recommended once every two to four years until 65, and then every year or two.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 7, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Personal Health column yesterday, about a loss of flexibility of the eye's lens in middle age, misstated the lens location. It is behind the iris, the colored portion of the eye, not over it.

HEADLINE: Ah, Smell the Gifts! Will Pizza and Buns Be Under the Tree?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
WHEN gingham dogs and calico cats replace frills and furbelows in the nation's decorative psyche, it must be time for retrofood. Handmade brownies and wood-smoked barbecues now have more cachet than architectural desserts rising out of spun sugar and a crown roast of lamb.
Cost has something to do with it: $50 will buy you a lot more brownies than fancy sugar creations, more barbecue than crown roasts. For anyone who must cut costs on holiday gift giving but doesn't want the recipients to notice, experts recommend food. 
 "Food is the perfect gift that cannot be priced," said Jay Walker, chairman of Catalog Media Corporation, a marketing and promotional agency. "If I am trying to save money and I buy you a sweater you'll know what I spend. If I buy you a dozen figs from Israel do you have any idea what I spent?"
Expounding on his theory that mail-order food is a no-risk gift, Mr. Walker said: "You'll pay $18 for 14 pears not because they are worth $18 but because 14 pears is a really neat gift. It's better than a sweater because it's unique and I never met anyone who didn't like a pear or a pie. Nine out of nine people like pears; two out of nine people like the sweater you bought them."
Those people who are willing to spend $18 on pears apparently have more money than time; at least three million to four million of them shop by mail. Despite the recession, Mr. Walker said there are more mail-order shoppers now, enough to provide many mail-order companies with a tidy living.
With spice cakes and lemon cakes, pizzas and chutneys, granola and sticky buns, this year's mail-order gift list is down-home, but not so down-home that there are no blockbuster presents. There are three pounds of very large, very fresh shrimp, for example.
The mail-order packaging may not be elaborate, but the quality of the food is as high as ever. To find the best products, all the gifts considered for our list were purchased under names that would not be recognized by the companies. Companies unable to fill the orders properly or in a timely manner or whose product arrived in poor condition were eliminated from consideration.
The shipping costs for some items, often as much as the product itself, made several gifts impractical. Both the United States Postal Service and United Parcel Service have raised shipping rates in the last year, in some cases as much as 40 percent.
Endorsement of one product made by a company does not mean that everything that company sells is of comparable quality; only products tasted are on the list. In some cases, different combinations of products are available for gift packages. For the most complete information, telephone or write the company. Most have toll-free numbers.

 Miss Grace Lemon Cake Company, 422 North Canon Drive, Beverly Hills, Calif. 90210; (800) 367-2253 or (213) 274-2897.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Esther B. Fein

 BODY:

From Page to Screen
When CBS paid a record $8 million this week for the American television rights to "Scarlett," people both inside and outside the movie and publishing industries gasped. But it was only the price that shocked them. Hollywood and the television producers have been on a mad shopping spree through bookstores and publishing houses lately, elbowing each other to pick up titles like shoppers at a holiday sale. 
 A glance at the television listings and movie pages these days is like looking at a book catalogue. Among the films currently playing in theaters are "Billy Bathgate," based on the E. L. Doctorow novel and starring Dustin Hoffman; "Rambling Rose," starring Laura Dern, based on the novel by Calder Willingham; "Shattered," a feature film based on the novel by Richard Neely, and "Year of the Gun," based on the novel by Michael Mewshaw.
Among other books that have led to television movies recently been broadcast or now in production are Danielle Steel's "Daddy" for NBC (which has bought a number of the author's other best-selling novels), Scott Turow's "Burden of Proof" for ABC and James Neff's "Mobbed Up," about Jackie Presser and the teamsters, which HBO is producing.
Movie producers have always looked to books for material, but the trend has taken off recently, as production costs have risen and the numbers of independent producers and cable television stations grow, increasing the competition.
"There is a growing stream of production types who come to your office, looking on your shelves to see jackets for books that are not due out for eight months, hoping to get a jump on the competition," said Esther Newberg, a New York literary agent who has negotiated film rights for many clients' books. "There are just so many more outlets, the competition is much stiffer and, frankly, the better ideas are coming from books. Screenwriters seem to be getting lazy. They are coming to us for books to turn into screenplays instead of coming up with original ideas."
Adapting a book can also cut development time by as much as six months, said Ruth Slawson, senior vice president for movies and mini-series for NBC Entertainment. "Economics plays into everything," said Ms. Slawson, who added that she believed it was comforting for viewers to see a familiar title in these days of overwhelming television choices.
One book clearly not destined for the screen is "The Devil's Candy: 'The Bonfire of the Vanities' goes to Hollywood," by Julie Salamon, soon to be published by Houghton Mifflin, about the debacle of producing the film based on Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel.
 
Penguin's Nobelists
 For years people at Penguin Books had been hearing that one of their authors, Nadine Gordimer, was on the short list to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. Each year the publishing house geared up for the announcement, and each year it was disappointed. The rumors surfaced again this year as Penguin prepared to published the paperback edition of "My Son's Story." This year however, Miss Gordimer won the prize, though not in time to add "Winner of the Nobel Prize" to the cover.
Then, after finally getting one current Nobel laureate on its list, Penguin discovered that it had two. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese opposition leader who is under house arrest, won this year's Peace Prize, and Penguin plans to publish "Suu of Burma: Symbol of Hope," a collection of her writings, in the spring.
Penguin also publishes the works of John Steinbeck, who won the literature prize in 1962.
 
Double Strategy for North
 The spine of Oliver North's new book, "Under Fire," written with William Novak, gives a one-word hint about one of the publisher's strategies for marketing the book: Xondervan.
In an unusual joint venture within its own company, HarperCollins simultaneously published Mr. North's memoirs under both its adult trade division and Xondervan, a religious imprint within the company that one employee described as a "real Bible-Belt, serious God" division.
The company has used the same strategy only a few times before, most recently with the autobiography of Tom Landry, the Dallas Cowboys' coach. But William M. Shinker, senior vice president and publisher of the adult trade division, said he jumped to do it again with "Under Fire" because Mr. North is an evangelical Christian and book publishing is a fiercely competitive business.
Having the North book in both regular and Christian bookstores -- especially in The Family Bookstore, the largest chain of Christian bookstores, which is owned by Xondervan -- could really raise sales, Mr. Shinker said.
Xondervan is distributing and promoting about 10 percent of the 500,000 copies of "Under Fire" that have been printed. And in a true separation of church and state, the two branches are handling their promotions and sales independently.
"They don't know how to sell to our customers," Mr. Shinker said, "and we don't know how to sell to theirs."

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in the Book Notes column yesterday about a work by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, this year's Nobel Peace Prize winner, included an erroneous title and publication date supplied by the publisher. The book is to be called "Freedom From Fear and Other Writings," and is to be published by Penguin on Dec. 10.
A brief report in the Book Notes column on Wednesday omitted CBS's partners in the purchase of the American television rights to the novel "Scarlett." They are Robert Halmi, the chairman of RHI Entertainment Inc.; the Kirch Group, a German communications conglomerate, and Silvio Berlusconi, an Italian newspaper owner and broadcaster.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY ELECTIONS;
With Anti-Florio Voting Wave, Republicans Win the Legislature

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

 BODY:
Riding a tide of anger over a record tax increase enacted by Gov. Jim Florio and the Democrats 16 months ago, New Jersey Republicans seized control of both houses of the Legislature last night for the first time in 20 years, possibly with veto-proof majorities.
 Some races remained in doubt early today, but decisive returns gave the Republicans at least 26 seats in the 40-member Senate, just one short of the 27 needed to override any veto by Governor Florio, a Democrat. The Republicans also appeared to have won 56 seats in the 80-seat Assembly, enough to override a veto, and possibly as many as 59 once close races are decided. 
Even Steven DiMicco, executive director of the Democratic State Committee, said the best the Democrats could hope for was a slim hedge against a veto-proof Republican majority.
 By that assessment, he said, the Assembly majority would be 52 to 28 in the Assembly and 26 to 14 in the Senate. The worst case, he said, would be a two-thirds majority, enough to override any Florio veto -- 56 to 24 in the Assembly and 27 to 13 in the Senate.
 The Republican sweep also included victories in 16 of the 21 races for county freeholder boards, including one in Middlesex County not controlled by Republicans for 62 years.
 Going into the election, the Democrats held a 43-to-37 edge in the Assembly and a 23-to-17 lead in the Senate. Setback for Florio Program
 The Republican victory bodes ill for the sweeping program that Governor Florio pushed through the Legislature last year, which included tax increases, more spending on education in poor districts and the nation's toughest ban on military-type assault firearms. Republicans have pledged to repeal or drastically revise all of them.
 In a statement released at Democratic headquarters in Trenton, Governor Florio said: "I congratulate the winners from both parties and I'm looking forward to working with them to steer our state safely through a national recession and deal with issues like controlling health-care costs."
 Issued with the statement was a second page labeled "Divided Government in New Jersey," tracing the history of the legislative sessions over the last three decades when Governors had one or both houses controlled by the other party.
 The breadth of the Republican victory also could spell trouble for Mr. Florio's own bid for re-election in 1993 if he chooses to seek a second term.
 And the outcome in New Jersey, a swing state whose voters have a reputation as barometers of national electoral attitudes, is sure to be sifted for its significance elsewhere as Republicans and Democrats prepare for the 1992 Presidential election.
 While Mr. Florio's troubles -- particularly his difficulty in justifying his harsh fiscal program -- were uniquely his, they also had meaning for many Democrats elsewhere, and for not a few Republican Governors as well, in his struggle to balance the books of an economically pressed state and then explain his drastic measures to the public.
 "Thus far we have heard no bad news," said the New Jersey Republican state chairman, Bob Franks, at a temporary party headquarters at the Somerset Hilton Hotel in Somerset. "It appears there is a landslide working its way across the state."
 The Democratic state chairman, Philip M. Keegan, conceded a little more than an hour after the polls closed at 8 P.M. that the Democrats would have difficulty holding onto their majority.
 
Some Bitterness
 Mr. DiMicco of the Democratic State Committee unofficially conceded the loss of the Legislature with some bitterness. "Clearly, I guess there is some percentage to acting as an irresponsible minority," he said. "And I hope that now that a new Republican majority is established, they understand the burdens of governing in difficult times."
 Democrats have accused Republicans of irresponsibly pledging to roll back at least part of the tax package enacted by Governor Florio and the Democrats last year.
 Last night, the Republican minority leader in the Assembly, Chuck Haytaian of Hackettstown, who is almost certain to replace Joseph V. Doria Jr., a Bayonne Democrat, as Assembly Speaker, reiterated a pledge to roll back the one-cent increase in the sales tax that was part of the Democrats' tax package.
 A number of Democratic names went down to defeat in the rout. The Senate Appropriations Committee chairman, Laurence S. Weiss of Middlesex, was defeated by a Republican, Randy Corman, in the 19th Legislative District.
 Others included Senators Gabriel M. Ambrosio, Paul J. Contillo and Francis J. McManimon, along with Assembly members Marlene Lynch Ford and Anthony J. Cimino. Assemblyman John Paul Doyle lost to a Republican, Andrew R. Ciesla, in the 10th District in Ocean County.
 Mr. Haytaian said the sales-tax reduction was "the first priority."
 The Democrats have said that such a rollback would reduce revenues by at least $550 million, and possibly as much as $1 billion, a cutback they say is impossible in the face of a projected shortfall in next year's budget.
 Also at issue is Congressional redistricting, in which New Jersey will lose a seat in the United States House of Representatives. Republican leaders say they expect the lame-duck Democratic Legislature to attend to the matter rather than give the Republicans the opportunity to draw the new district lines.
 With 283 candidates in the field and campaign costs reaching $14 million, it was among the most crowded legislative races in New Jersey history, and certainly the costliest.
 And it was a bitterly fought contest. From the first day to the last, Republican candidates, incumbents and challengers alike, ran not against their opponents but against Governor Florio and taxes, neither of which was on the ballot.
 Besides the anger over the $2.8 billion tax increase rammed through the Legislature last year, Republicans benefited from the advantage normally held by the minority party in midterm elections and from redistricting -- a result of growth in the Republican-leaning suburbs -- that hurt Democratic urban areas.
 Republican radio and television commercials, newspaper advertisements, billboards, fliers and mass mailings -- whether the race was for courthouse or statehouse, the mayor's office or the Board of Chosen Freeholders -- all carried a common theme.
 Thus, newspaper ads for Bob Prunetti, a Republican candidate for Mercer County Executive, read as if he were running for the Legislature. He "opposes the Florio tax plan," "opposes higher salaries for state legislators" and "supports initiative and referendum -- the right of citizens to place proposed laws on the ballot."
 On the other hand, his opponent, Joe Bocchini, bought a full-page Election Day ad in The Trenton Times noting that he was "born and raised in Mercer County," "taught school in Hamilton" and "learned the values of hard work, honesty, loyalty and commitment."
 Nowhere in the ad did Mr. Bocchini mention one aspect of his "loyalty and commitment," his party affiliation. He is a Democrat.
 
Accent on Distance
 Indeed, putting distance between themselves and the Democratic Governor seemed a preoccupation for some Democrats. In the 13th Legislative District in Monmouth and Middlesex Counties, the Democratic incumbent in the Senate race, Jim Phillips, who was not in the Legislature when the Florio tax plan was passed, grew tired of being linked to the taxes by his Republican opponent, Joseph Kyrillos. Mr. Phillips went so far as to cart around a cardboard cutout of Governor Florio and "push it aside" during campaign appearances.
 Not to be outdone, Republicans circulated a picture of Mr. Phillips with the cutout in a brochure labeling him "the real tax-and-spend Democrat."
 Republicans made no bones about the fact that they were running against the Governor. "We definitely ran on the anti-Florio theme," said Jeffrey Michaels, executive director of the Republican State Committee. "It's the first time in many years that Republican candidates, top to bottom, have been running on the same issue. All Republicans are fighting Florio -- that doesn't happen all the time."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Safeway Ratings Raised by S.& P.

 BODY:
Safeway Inc., the big supermarket chain based in Oakland, Calif., has announced that the Standard & Poor's Corporation has raised the rating on its senior secured debt to BB, from BB-.
The company also said Tuesday that the rating on its senior unsecured debt had been raised to BB-, from B+. 
 S.& P. also assigned a preliminary B+ rating to the company's shelf registration of $750 million in senior subordinated debt securities. In all, the ratings affect about $1.6 billion of debt.
The ratings service noted that the company's operating performance and financial flexibility had improved because of past and prospective refinancings. S.& P. also cited the company's recession-resistant business.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed After Fed Lowers Its Discount Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other major currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered its discount rate.
Gold prices were also mixed, rising modestly in New York after falling overseas. 
 The financial markets were surprised by the timing of the Fed's decision to drop the discount rate -- the interest it charges commercial banks -- half a percentage point, to 4 1/2 percent. While Fed action to stimulate the economy was widely anticipated, the central bank was not expected to move until later this week at the earliest.
The early morning announcement knocked the dollar down to 1.6300 German marks, from 1.6330, but the dollar rebounded in a "quick rubber band movement," said Walter Simon, a vice president with Bank Julius Baer & Company.
The dollar closed at 1.6370 marks in New York, down from 1.6385 late Tuesday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6395 marks from 1.6425.
A drop in United States interest rates undermines the dollar because lower rates reduce demand for American investments. But because the Fed was expected to push rates lower at some point, the immediate damage to the dollar was short-lived.
Mr. Simon said the dollar moved aimlessly for much of yesterday's session.
"A lot of people are trying to square their books ahead of the long weekend," he said. Monday is Veterans Day, and many traders are expected to take the day off.
The dollar also fell against the Japanese yen in New York, slipping to 129.90 yen, from 130.025 late Tuesday. The dollar was quoted at 129.88 yen in late London trading.
In Tokyo overnight, before the discount rate cut, the dollar rose 0.52 yen, to 129.90.
The British pound gained against the dollar. Sterling rose to $1.7750 in New York, from $1.7725 late Tuesday, and to $1.7718 in London from $1.7695.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, include: 1.4475 Swiss francs, up from 1.4460; 5.5970 French francs, down from 5.6020; 1,227.25 Italian lire, down from 1,228.00, and 1.12335 Canadian dollars, up from 1.12065.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.4495 Swiss francs, up from 1.4490; 5.6090 French francs, down from 5.6130; 1.8485 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8510; 1,229.50 Italian lire, down from 1,230.50, and 1.1238 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1208.
Gold rose 50 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $354.60 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $354.50, up 40 cents.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $354.35 a troy ounce, from $356.40 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $354.15 an ounce from $356.50.
Silver rose 0.6 cent, to $4.054 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Breakfast Cereals Lose Some Luster

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
CHECKED the coupons in a Sunday newspaper lately? There are enough in one day's offerings to save shoppers more than $12 on breakfast cereals from General Mills and Kellogg. The recent costly marketing battles between the largest ready-to-eat cereal makers, while good for consumers, have taken some snap and crackle out of several analysts' views on the stocks.
"The competition clearly has intensified," said John M. McMillin, an analyst with Prudential Securities in New York, who is advising investors to hold the cereal stocks. One reason is the drag on earnings from the costly marketing battles. They added $100 million, a 25 percent increase, to Kellogg's selling and administrative expenses in the third quarter. 
 Some analysts also believe the stocks are fully valued, having risen sharply in the last year as the industry fared better than expected. Kellogg's closed yesterday at $104.25, up from a 52-week low of $68; General Mills closed at $63.75, roughly 50 percent over its 52-week low of $41.62. Several analysts estimate the companies' price-earnings ratio will be about 18 in 1992.
Despite the short-term caution, some analysts note the cereal business's long-term growth potential, both domestically and abroad. Many are recommending the companies as long-term investments.
Although Americans already eat a yearly average of 10 pounds of breakfast cereal, their growing appetite is fueling the $7.5 billion ready-to-eat cereal business. The industry has regained its historical 3 percent growth rate after two near-flat years. Analysts say a bowl of cereal, at about 20 cents a serving for consumers, is perceived as a solid value in a recession, and generous coupons may also be sending more shoppers down the cereal aisle.
Kellogg is the No. 1 cereal maker, with 37.4 percent of the American market. Some analysts say they admire even more the marketing smarts of General Mills, which derives about a quarter of its sales and almost half its earnings from cereal. Its other businesses include Red Lobster restaurants and Betty Crocker products. While Kellogg is seen as relying too heavily on its core brands of Corn Flakes and Frosted Flakes, General Mills has introduced several "flanker" cereals that spin off its core products, like Apple Cinnamon and Honey Nut Cheerios. These helped drive General Mills' domestic share to 24.5 percent from 21 percent in 1988. Mr. McMillin believes Kellogg, whose primary business is cereal, is spending heavily in part to block its competitor from increasing its share.
The battle between Kellogg and General Mills is also eating into the market share of second-tier cereal producers, including Post, Nabisco, and Quaker Oats and Ralston Purina, which makes many private label brands. Given the marketing and distribution heft of General Mills and Kellogg, Mr. McMillin predicted the strongest would get stronger at the expense of smaller cereal makers. But because cold cereal is a smaller portion of the second-tier companies' business, the industry's prospects should not drive investment decisions for those companies, Mr. McMillin said.
The international market is more dynamic than the domestic one, with steady growth rates of 6 to 10 percent. The amount of cereal eaten in the sizable Japanese market, for example, has doubled in three years to a still small six-tenths of a pound of cereal per capita per year.
Internationally, Kellogg is considered the Goliath to General Mills' David. More than half of Kellogg's tonnage is sold outside the United States, and it has an aggregate market share of more than 50 percent in the 130 countries in which it sells cereal. It has plants in 17 foreign countries, and recently broke ground on a plant in Latvia. The company will build a plant in India next year, and has expressed interest in manufacturing in China.
But General Mills is also marketing heavily in Europe with its new partner Nestle. The company wants the joint venture, Cereal Partners Worldwide, to control $1 billion of the European market in the year 2000, when General Mills predicts it will reach yearly sales of $6.5 billion. It currently owns roughly 7 percent of the European cereal market.
In the cereal business, profit margins of 20 percent are not uncommon, and margins improve with volume gains. Given projected growth rates internationally, many analysts predict the companies will achieve yearly double-digit earnings growth through the year 2000. "It's very hard to find companies growing at such a rate," said Nomi Ghez, a Goldman, Sachs analyst in New York.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
With Soviet Aid in Limbo, Wheat and Soybeans Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wheat and soybean futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as more traders gave up hope that the Bush Administration would announce a new Soviet food-aid package soon.
Wheat for delivery in December settled at $3.57 1/4 a bushel in Chicago, 5 1/4 cents below Tuesday's settlement; December corn fell 2 3/4 cents, to $2.46 1/2 a bushel; December oats fell 1/2 cent, to $1.29 3/4 a bushel, and November soybeans dropped 6 cents, to $5.57 a bushel. 
 The crop markets opened lower and remained weak all day after President Bush said Tuesday that the United States' ability to help feed the Soviet Union was limited by Federal budget constraints.
Although Mr. Bush said he was still studying the Soviet Union's request for $3.5 billion in loan guarantees and direct aid, "it's clear we are not on the brink of any credit decision to the Soviets," said Rich Feltes, research director with Refco Inc., a Chicago commodities brokerage.
Grain prices rallied last week amid signals from Washington that an announcement on Soviet food aid was imminent. But analysts say President Bush appears to have grown more hesitant about helping the Soviets after Tuesday's election defeats of incumbent politicians and criticism that he has focused more on foreign policy than the domestic economy.
President Bush's failure to mention any possible Soviet aid yesterday was "very disappointing," said William Biedermann, research director with Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill.
Elsewhere, oil prices fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid signs that supplies are adequate for the time being.
Prices for refined petroleum products fell because home heating oil supplies are high as a result of a relative lack of cold weather earlier this fall, traders said.
Light crude oil for delivery in December settled at $23.40 a barrel, down 38 cents; December home heating oil fell 0.82 cent, to 71.02 cents a gallon; December unleaded gasoline fell 0.88 cent, to 66.28 cents a gallon, and December natural gas slipped 0.8 cent, to $2.063 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempts Mixed; Taxable Funds Off

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt money market funds were mixed in the week that ended yesterday. Taxable-fund yields continued to decline, according to IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, said total assets of the tax-exempt funds rose by $361 million, to $89.9 billion, in the week. The average days to maturity of holdings in the tax-exempt portfolios remained at 60. 
 "Money fund yields clearly will continue to decline," Mr. Frank said. "We also expect for the next few weeks we will see large institutional inflows into the money funds, coming out of money market holdings, such as Treasury bills and overnight money.
"We would expect," he said, "that unless the economy responds in the short run, which is unlikely, we may get further easing by the Federal Reserve in addition to the easing today."
Yesterday's cut in the discount rate by the Fed, Mr. Frank said, will start to show up in yields beginning next week.
Competing rates for bank products like certificates of deposit will drop faster than money fund yields for next three or four weeks, he said.
The seven-day compound average yield for tax-exempt funds was 3.98 percent, up 4 basis points. The seven-day simple yield was 3.90 percent, up 4 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The compound yield for 30-day funds dropped nine basis points, to 3.93 percent, while the 30-day simple yield was 3.86 percent, down from 3.94, a decline of eight basis points.
 
State-Specific Funds
 Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities in the area, the top New York fund once again was the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.59, compared with 4.51 percent the previous week.
In Connecticut, there was a tie for the lead between the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, and the Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market series -- each showing a yield of 4.28 percent.
Calvert Tax Free Reserves led the way in New Jersey once again, with a yield of 4.54, compared with 4.49 a week earlier.
The highest-yielding tax-exempt fund among those with assets greater than $100 million continued to be the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 5.05 percent, up 4 points from 5.01 percent last week.
 
Taxable Funds
 Assets of taxable funds, Mr. Frank said, rose $1.5 billion in the week, to $463.7 billion.
"Virtually all of the increase," he said, "came from institutional investors seeking the higher yield of money market funds as market yields dropped in respose to the Federal Reserve's recent easing action, not including today's action."
Average maturities of portfolio holdings were unchanged at 63 days.
 
7-Day Taxable Yield: 5.05%
 The seven-day compound yield of taxable funds dropped to 5.05 percent from 5.10, while the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds dropped by 4 basis points, to 4.93 percent.
The average compound 30-day yield was 5.11 percent, down 5 basis points. The 30-day simple yield was also down, to 4.99 percent from 5.03.
The top-yielding fund among the taxables was Merrill Lynch Ready Assets Trust, with a seven-day compound yield of 7.18 percent. Explaining the extremely high rate, Mr. Frank said it was the result of the fund's unusual accounting method.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.86 percent, from 4.92 a week earlier, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
U S West Taps Digital For Financial Officer

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
U S West said yesterday that it had hired as its new chief financial officer, James M. Osterhoff, who recently resigned from the Digital Equipment Corporation, the big computer maker that has been hurt by the recession.
Mr. Osterhoff said in September that he had planned to resign from Digital but left his departure date open. U S West said yesterday that he would assume his new post on Dec. 6. 
 Mr. Osterhoff, 55 years old, replaces Howard P. Doerr, 62, who will remain as a U S West executive vice president until he retires on Dec. 30.
This is the second time that Mr. Osterhoff has switched to a completely different industry. Before joining Digital, he had worked for 20 years at the Ford Motor Company, where he had been an executive in Ford's automotive, credit, tractor and corporate staff divisions. "I was almost born and raised at Ford," he said in an interview yesterday.
When Mr. Osterhoff became Digital's chief financial officer in 1985, he had been the chief financial officer at Ford's credit unit. He presided over Digital's boom in the mid-1980's, but also over the company's sluggish profits in the late 1980's, as well as the losses posted this year.
Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., has about $14 billion in revenues for the fiscal year that ended on June 30, while U S West's revenues totaled about $10 billion in 1990.
"As far as finance, there is not a great deal of difference between automobiles and computers," Mr. Osterhoff said. "But they were completely different businesses as far as poduct cycles. You've got a five-year product cycle for cars, but for computers, it's often a year or less."
He said he wanted to go to U S West for a similar challenge of learning a new industry. "I'm 55 and I've been at Digital for nearly seven years," he said. "This is my opportunity to make that last big career change."
He denied a recent report in The Wall Street Journal that he had quit Digital after clashing over the company's financial restructuring plan with John F. Smith, a Digital senior vice president. Mr. Smith is close to Kenneth H. Olsen, Digital's 65-year-old founder, whom The Journal portrayed as autocratic and unwilling to appoint a successor.
"Nothing in that story struck a responsive chord in me," Mr. Osterhoff said.
A native of Frankfort, Ind., Mr. Osterhoff received a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from Purdue University and an M.B.A. from Stanford University in 1963.
Although Mr. Osterhoff plans to move before December to the Englewood, Colo., area, where U S West is based, his wife, Marilyn, and their teen-age daughter, will move in June. The Osterhoffs have two other daughters who have graduated from college.
