HEADLINE: Comptroller Rejected for A 2d Term

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The Senate Banking Committee killed President Bush's nomination of Robert L. Clarke to a second term as Comptroller of the Currency today, first rejecting the nomination and then blocking further consideration of it by the full Senate.
Both 12-to-9 votes were strictly along party lines. They came a day after the President and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had lobbied the Democratic members of the committee in the hope that they would be able to turn two of them to join the Republican minority and approve Mr. Clarke's nomination to serve another five years as one of the nation's senior banking regulators. 
 After the vote, Mr. Brady accused Democrats on the committee of crass politics and character assassination and persecution.
 
Supervises 4,000 Banks
 "On a practical level, it makes no sense to take this action when credit availability is lacking, the economic recovery is sluggish and the American people ask for leadership," Mr. Brady said.
The Comptroller supervises more than 4,000 nationally chartered banks, including many of the country's largest institutions, holding about two-thirds of the industry's assets.
With President Bush expected to use Congress's rejection of his banking legislation as an issue in the next election, analysts said today that the Democrats were likely to seize upon the Clarke vote to blame the Republicans for the industry's problems.
"The Clarke vote suggests to me that what's happening to banks will be an issue in the next Presidential election," said James Barth, a former Government economist who now teaches at Auburn University in Alabama.
 
First Term Expired
 Mr. Clarke's first term expired in December. He was nominated for a second one in January and has continued to serve in the post. Through a spokeswoman, Mr. Clarke declined to comment on today's vote. Under law, he can stay on the job until a successor is confirmed by the Senate, although today there was considerable confusion about how long he would stay.
Treasury officials said they were surprised that the full Senate would not be able to consider the nomination and that senior Administration officials had not yet begun to consider a replacement for Mr. Clarke. One choice mentioned today was T. Timothy Ryan Jr., who is director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the agency that regulates the nation's savings associations.
Two of the largest failures in banking history, at the Bank of New England and the First Republic Bank of Texas, came during Mr. Clarke's tenure. Critics have contended that he did not act promptly to discourage banks in the 1980's from making excessively speculative commercial real estate loans and to avert failures.
Mr. Clarke did not dispute a General Accounting Office conclusion that his regulators limited the scope of its examinations of the Bank of New England and took no enforcement actions until 1989 when it was too late. That banking company failed in January and may ultimately cost the bank insurance fund $2.5 billion.
 
Took Office in Boom
 "He took office in the middle of a boom and was very much deregulatory -- he did not flash a yellow light when all the banks went into real estate," said Robert E. Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution and a staff member of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration. "He basically got religion on the tough supervision in 1989, at a time at which everyone got religion. I view him as a victim of circumstance. I don't think he was a bad Comptroller. He just got caught in events beyond his control."
During today's debate, Republicans insisted, as they have in previous hearings on the nomination, that Mr. Clarke was a scapegoat who was no more responsible for the plight of the banks than Congress, the Administration and the other regulators.
Privately, some Republicans also said the campaign against him, led by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Banking Committee, was intended to cleanse Mr. Riegle's own record. Mr. Riegle was rebuked by the Ethics Committee for having intervened with regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., who ran one of the largest savings associations that failed.
"I guess we all assume that politicans are exempt by God from the sin of hypocrisy," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, shortly before the vote.
 
Sending a Message
 Democrats again maintained that Mr. Clarke's deregulatory approach depleted the insurance fund that protects bank deposits. Then, they said, he overcompensated by adopting standards that have contributed to what they have called a credit crunch.
"We have to send a message," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, whose local economy has been battered by scores of bank failures, high unemployment and a wave of business bankruptcies. "I've never before cast a vote on the basis of a message. Unfortunately, Bob Clarke must be the messenger."
Mr. Clarke, a 49-year-old Texas lawyer and Republican fund-raiser who is a native of Tulsa, Okla., came to Washington near the end of 1985 on the recommendation of a fellow Texas lawyer, James A. Baker 3d, who was then the Treasury Secretary. But Mr. Clarke's position in the Adminstration has not always been secure. Both the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher argued strenuously against renominating him.
In May, after criticism in Congress for his investments in high-yield junk bonds, he decided to put many of his personal assets in a qualified blind trust. The Comptroller of the Currency also serves as a director of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the savings-and-loan bailout agency that holds an enormous portfolio of junk bonds that have been taken from failed institutions. An Office of Government Ethics investigation cleared Mr. Clarke of any wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE CONTINUES PUSHING LOAN COSTS DOWN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
With the economy at a standstill and political pressure mounting, the Federal Reserve today reduced the interest rates it controls to levels not seen since the 1970's.
Banks across the country responded immediately and reduced their prime rate, the rate that determines the cost of many mortgages and other consumer and commercial loans, to 7 1/2 percent from 8 percent, the lowest since 1987. Credit card rates will probably not be affected, but the lower bank rates could save money for people who plan to borrow money to meet Christmas expenses. 
 Some analysts on Wall Street expressed surprise that the lower rates were announced in the middle of the Treasury's quarterly sale of securities and suggested that the move might have resulted directly from Republican losses in Tuesday's elections.
 
Decision Before the Election
 But a Federal Reserve official said that the key decisions were made at Tuesday's meeting of the central bank's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, before the election results were known, and that they were announced at the first opportunity this morning.
The Fed's actions had been so widely anticipated in the financial markets in light of recent economic data that the demand for new Treasury securities remained very weak, and the stock market hardly responded. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,038.46, up 7.15 points. [Page D10.]
The Federal Reserve Board met at 8 A.M. today and voted, 4 to 1, to cut the discount rate, the rate it charges banks for loans, to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent. This is the lowest rate since January 1973. Wayne D. Angell was the only member voting against the cut. There are two vacant seats on the seven-member board.
 
Quick Reaction by Banks
 As soon as they opened for business, big banks, led by J. P. Morgan, Citicorp and BankAmerica, cut their prime rate, and economic policy makers say they hope that portends increased consumer borrowing and spending during the Christmas season.
Finally, late in the morning, the Federal Reserve in New York bought large quantities of Government securities to indicate that it wanted to reduce the Federal funds rate to 4 3/4 percent from 5 percent. It was the second reduction in a week in this critical rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, putting it at a level last seen in early 1977. The decision to cut the funds rate was made Tuesday afternoon at a meeting of Federal Reserve Board governors and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks, a Fed official said.
The flurry of activity this morning came shortly after President Bush left for Rome for a two-day meeting of the leaders of the countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Bush has faced mounting criticism from his political opponents for concentrating on foreign affairs at the expense of dealing with the sour economy, and the White House announced Tuesday night that he was canceling plans for a two-week trip to the Far East after Thanksgiving.
At a news conference on the White House lawn just before he boarded his helicopter for a flight to Andrews Air Force Base, the President said he hoped lower rates would encourage consumers to borrow and spend. "I think when you look at historically low interest rates," the President said, "a lot of people will suddenly wake up and say this is a good time to buy a home, a good time to buy a car."
Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview, "It was clearly a responsible move in the right direction and should help the economy in the months ahead."
The economy has hardly grown during the Bush Presidency, a fact that is increasingly worrisome to top officials as the election year approaches. With the budget deficit forecast to be about $350 billion this year, far and away the highest ever, there is little room for the Government to lower taxes or increase spending, the normal responses to stimulate the economy before an election. So the Administration has become unusually dependent on the Fed to bolster the economy by reducing interest rates.
Since December, the discount rate has been cut by two and a half percentage points, from 7 percent, and the Federal funds rate has been reduced by two and three-quarter percentage points in 10 different installments.
 
Economic Malaise Persists
 So far, however, that has done little to stimulate lending, and in recent weeks, just when it seemed to be rebounding from the recession that began in the summer of 1990, the economy took a turn for the worse.
On Friday, for example, the Labor Department reported that payroll jobs fell slightly in October after two straight advances and that the unemployment rate edged up to 6.8 percent. And the Commerce Department that day disclosed that its index of predictive indicators turned down by one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the first decline since January.
Other recent grim statistics were an 8 percent drop in sales of cars and trucks during the final 10 days of October, a nose dive in consumer confidence for the month and drops in orders for durable goods and in sales of new single-family homes.
One of the few positive figures, a 2.4 percent rate of increase in third-quarter gross national product that broke a string of three quarterly declines, provided little comfort. Economists maintained and Commerce Department officials acknowledged that the strength was concentrated in the early summer and that most of the momentum had been lost by September.
 
Unusually Tight Credit
 In its official announcement today, the Fed said it had cut the discount rate because of slow growth in the money supply and unusually tight credit conditions.
In fact, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is known to believe that what he repeatedly refers to as "the credit crunch" is the main cause of the weakness in the economy.
The demand for business loans at banks has been declining for a year, and bankers around the country said in interviews today that they doubted the lower rates would make much difference.
The comment of Douglas K. Freeman, chief corporate banking executive at Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla., was typical. "The demand for credit is not driven by half-point changes in interest costs; it is driven by businesses' expectations of future demand for their products," he said. "Right now, that demand is just not there. I don't expect any line around the bank tomorrow."
 
Lower Rates on C.D.'s Seen
 While the lower rates could benefit borrowers, savers can expect a drop in the rates paid on certificates of deposits and money market accounts.
The main reason so little money is being borrowed, Mr. Greenspan agrees is that consumers lack confidence and businesses do not want to expand. But part of the reason -- perhaps 10 percent, he holds -- is because banks are tightening their belts unnecessarily and are not willing to lend to credit-worthy customers. That 10 percent, he feels, could be the difference between a healthy and a struggling economy.
Federal Reserve officials said a vote to reduce the discount rate could have been taken as early as last Friday when the latest data about a weak economy were released. But with an Open Market Committee meeting scheduled for Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan, who prides himself on maintaining a collegial atmosphere at the central bank, decided to wait and discuss the matter with the bank presidents.
 
Fed Tries to Keep a Grip
 Action on the two rates was needed because the Federal Reserve avoids letting the funds rate fall below the discount rate. If that happened, there would be little reason for banks to borrow from the central bank, and the Fed would thus lose some leverage over the economy.
Mr. Angell gave no reason for voting not to cut the discount rate. But in the past, he has expressed concern that cutting the short-term rates the Fed controls was having little effect on long-term rates, suggesting that the markets still fear inflation.
The difference between short-term and long-term rates -- what economists call a steep yield curve -- is unusually large. Three-month Treasury bills are selling at about 4 3/4 percent, and 30-year bonds are selling at about 8 percent.
Private economists generally welcomed the Fed's actions today, but many of them attributed the decisions as much to politics as to economics.
"The perception in the market was that this move was a result of extreme political pressure from the Bush Administration," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a securities firm. "The Fed may not have intended it that way, but that is the result."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
10-Year Note Sale Disappointing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board's decision to reduce the two interest rates it controls did not help the Treasury sell $12 billion worth of new 10-year notes yesterday.
Given the economy's poor performance and low levels of inflation, analysts and traders had little quarrel with the Fed's decision to cut the discount rate to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent and cut the target on the overnight Federal funds rate to 4 3/4 percent from 5 percent. But some analysts said the timing of the moves was strange. 
 "One of the rules of thumb has been that you don't change policy in the middle of a refunding, if only because it adds to uncertainty in the market," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president at S. G. Warburg. "I have a real problem understanding the timing of this move."
The Fed's moves had little positive impact on the auction, but they did help to raise prices of outstanding short-term Treasury notes and bills. But long-term bond yields, which are higher now than they were the last time the Fed cut the discount rate on Sept. 13, moved only modestly lower.
 
Second of Three Auctions
 The 10-year note sale was the second leg of a three-part auction of debt securities the Treasury conducts four times a year.
It was also the second auction conducted under bidding rules that have been revised by the Treasury in the wake of the Salomon Brothers scandal. The disappointing 10-year auction followed by a day a disastrous three-year note sale. Both auctions pushed up borrowing costs for the Government.
Changes in monetary policy have been considered ill advised around refunding auctions because until recently these debt sales addressed the bulk of the Government's quarterly financing needs.
But the sharp rise in the Federal budget deficit has forced the Treasury to issue more debt more frequently, thereby reducing the importance of the quarterly auctions.
Still, the Fed's decision to reduce the discount rate during the refunding yesterday was the first such step in 11 years, said James Fralick, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
"The market is still very uncertain of the auction dynamics," Mr. Fralick said. "And the Fed's move didn't help matters."
Traders said that bidding at the auction was sloppy, and that demand for the new securities, which were sold at an average yield of 7.53 percent, was weak. At the last 10-year note sale in August, the securities were sold at an average yield of 7.94 percent.
"What we are seeing is dealers that are playing things very cautiously, because there is less information about where the market is." Mr. Liro said. "That means that if you have an order book, you cover those orders and don't buy as much on speculation."
The fact that the market's price discovery system is not working as efficiently as in the past was visible in the discrepancy between where the new securities were trading seconds before the auction, and the levels at which bids were submitted.
 
Costly for the Taxpayers
 Just before the 1 P.M. bidding deadline, the new notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.51 percent.
But bids were placed as high as 7.56 percent for the securities, and as low as 7.50 percent. Analysts said the wide spread cost the Treasury at least $250 million in higher borrowing costs over the life of the issue.
After the rise in interest rates on the securities on Tuesday, an increase touched off in large part by the very poor sale of new three-year Treasury notes, some market participants said they had expected the 10-year note sale would have gone better.
That did not occur, and today the Treasury will sell $12 billion of 30-year bonds, the most speculative securities they issue.
Late yesterday the bonds to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.98 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the outstanding 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 13/32, up 6/32, to yield 7.99 percent, compared with 8.02 percent late Tuesday.
But, not surprisingly, the Fed's move to lower short-term interest rates helped to increase prices of shorter-term notes and bills.
By late in the day, for example, the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 100 23/32, up 6/32, to yield 5.611 percent. And the 6 percent three-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.95 percent. Shortly after the auction on Tuesday, those securities were offered at a price to yield 6.05 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell sharply.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.60 percent late yesterday, down 14 basis points, or one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 12 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.67 percent. And rates on one-year bills fell by 11 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.69 percent.
Despite the heavy issuance of new Treasury securities, corporations continued to price new debt issues.
Among the issuers yesterday was J. P. Morgan & Company, which offered $250 million of seven-year subordinated notes through an underwriting group led by Kidder Peabody & Company.
The 7 5/8 percent notes were priced at $99.882, to yield 7.647 percent, 50 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of new 10-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 7.15 in Light Volume

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks made mild gains yesterday in light volume, as trading kept within a narrow range. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.15 to close at 3,038.46.
Confusion reigned, as investors held off from doing any meaningful buying, traders said. They focused more on a sputtering economy and weak corporate profits. 
 The Treasury's quarterly refunding, always a distraction to the stock market, was a disappointment at the 10-year note auction yesterday, the second bad auction in two days.
"Once the Government is done with its refunding, fundamental factors will again reassert themselves on the stock market," said John H. Shaughnessy, the senior vice president and director of research for Advest Inc. "With all the money there is around, this market has a shot at new highs before the end of the month."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 167.4 million shares, down from 172.1 million on Tuesday, with gaining issues outpacing losing ones, 896 to 728. The Big Board composite index rose 0.62, to 215.30.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up by 1.26, to 389.97, and the American Stock Exchange index rose by 1.71, to 386.65.
Trading on the Nasdaq moved the composite index up by 0.66, to 539.48, as the Russell 2,000, a measure of smaller company stocks, rose by 0.40, to 184.36.
After initially opening higher on news of a cut in the Federal discount rate, blue-chip issues retreated, as investors shifted their focus to a sluggish economy. Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, picked up two buying and three selling programs that had a dropped the Dow by about 13 points. When news that the 10-year note auction did not go well reached the market about 2:30 P.M., a buy program already in progress, flipped into a sell, the firm said.
 
Amsco Up to $19.375
 In the market yesterday, Amsco International, which makes infection-control equipment, rose 3/4, to 19 3/8. Traders said Jean Queally, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, upgraded her long-term rating to "buy," from "above average," based on several new products. One is a vaporized hydrogen peroxide product that is expected to bring strong demand from dentists needing to sterilize hand power tools.
Unum Corp., whose business is in disability insurance, employment benefits and pensions, rose 2 3/8, to 72 1/8. David Seifer, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, reiterated his "recommend" rating, after an analysts' meeting on Tuesday with company officials, in which the insurer discussed its decision to pull out of the 401(k) market and take a $16 million charge in the fourth quarter.
U.S. Healthcare, which expects sales to be about $1.7 billion this year, rose 1 1/2, to 33 1/4. Traders said Joyce Albers, an analyst at First Boston, repeated a "buy" recommendation after analysts met with company officials on Tuesday. She said U.S. Healthcare was working on several new products for the self-insured market, particularly those that would expand into the $61 billion worker's compensation market.
A Shearson Lehman analyst, Edward White, lowered the 1992 earnings estimate on Adaptec, a manufacturer of computer data-flow systems. The stock fell 2 5/8, to 13 5/8.
Analysts said AST Research and Dell Computer were down yesterday amid concern that their dominance in the low-end market for personall computers would be threaten by Compaq Computer. AST was off 1, to 19 3/4, while Dell Computer fell 1 3/8, to 23 1/2. Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said he saw the low-end market as much easier to penetrate, so there was room for more players.
Meanwhile, Compaq, fell 5/8, to 27 1/4, after analysts lowered their 1992 earnings estimates following their meeting with company officials on Tuesday.
Lower earnings estimates by analysts on Weyerhaeuser, based on continuing prospects for the pulp and paper market, dropped the stock by 1 3/8, to 25 3/8.
On the heels of a new business strategy announced by W. R. Grace, which may include the sale of certain assets, the stock was up 2, to 40 1/4, as investors responded positively to the divestiture news.

HEADLINE: Maxwell Family Sees No Financial Upheaval

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Robert Maxwell's heirs and their investment bankers insisted today that the family-controlled publishing empire faced no immediate financial crisis and that they would not have to go beyond existing plans to sell some operations.
"I don't see any change in strategy," said Kevin F. H. Maxwell, who has been chief executive of the Maxwell Communication Corporation and who today became chairman, succeeding his father, who died on Tuesday. 
 He spoke in an interview in a ninth-floor office of the Daily Mirror building, where his father had presided over the empire.
 
Senior Family Member
 Kevin Maxwell, who is 32 years old and has emerged as the most prominent family member in the businesses, talked after a meeting with his investment bankers: Samuel Montagu & Company of Britain and Salomon Brothers and Rothschild Inc. of the United States.
Mr. Maxwell said the family's collection of private and public companies would not need to ask bankers to restructure its billions of dollars in debts, and he was clearly irritated by rumors of a pending financial crisis. He also said he did not think estate taxes posed a threat to the family's control of the group. "I don't envisage any issues of that nature," he said.
But investor jitteriness was apparent even though trading did not resume today in the shares of the two flagship companies controlled by the Maxwell family, Maxwell Communication and Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C. Trading had been suspended on Tuesday. Analysts said nervousness about loans to Maxwell companies caused the stock prices of several large British banks to drop.
 
'One More Thing to Worry About'
 "It may not be as big a problem as people think, but it's one more thing to worry about," said Julian Robins, an analyst at Barclays de Zoette Wedd Securities Ltd. He noted that bank stocks had already fallen in recent weeks as banks informed analysts that their second-half results would be worse than many had expected because of problems stemming from Britain's recession.
In interviews, several lenders to the Maxwell empire said they were not panicking about Robert Maxwell's death but wanted assurances that the planned divestitures would proceed. They were eager to meet with Kevin Maxwell and his 35-year-old brother, Ian, who together formally assumed control of the group today.
A spokesman for Goldman, Sachs & Company, a lender whose loans are backed by big blocks of shares in Maxwell companies, gave no sign of being worried. This suggests that the American investment firm is confident that the price of the shares will not plunge to levels approaching a default when trading resumes.
"Those margin loans are entirely manageable in size for us," the Goldman, Sachs spokesman said. "We're quite satisfied with the collateral we've got." The collateral consists of 24.2 million shares of Maxwell Communication and 40 million shares of the Mirror Group.
 
Two Deals Seem Imminent
 It appeared today that the consummation of two deals that had been in the works before Robert Maxwell's death was imminent: the sale of Maxwell Communication's computer books division and of all or part of its 56 percent stake in Berlitz International Inc., the language-product and services group.
There was speculation today that a $160 million deal for the computer books unit was near completion. And trading in Berlitz's shares has been halted on the New York Stock Exchange, pending an announcement.
"There are other sales in process," said Robert S. Pirie, president and chief executive of Rothschild. "But I don't think Bob was heading towards selling core businesses and I don't think there's any rush to dump that policy."
In a statement, Ian Maxwell said that approach certainly applied to the Mirror Group, which he now heads. "We are not going to be taken over or sold off," he said. In May, the Maxwell family sold to the public 49 percent of the shares in the Mirror Group, whose properties include The Daily Mirror and four other British tabloids, racing newspapers in the United States and Britain, two free Scottish newspapers and minority interests in printing and forest-products companies.
 
North American Spinoff
 Kevin Maxwell said a decision would be announced later this month on how to proceed with a proposed spinoff of the North American operations of Maxwell Communication as a separate company, and to offer part of it to the public. Those businesses -- which include the book publisher Macmillan Inc., Official Airline Guides and Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing -- account for the vast majority of Maxwell Communication's assets and earnings.
So far this year, divestitures by companies owned or controlled by the Maxwells have totaled more than $1.9 billion. Analysts and British newspapers have estimated that the group has net debts of 2.2 billion to 2.6 billion, or $3.9 billion to $4.6 billion at the current exchange rate.
When asked about the 2.2 billion debt estimate that was mentioned today in The Financial Times of Britain, Kevin Maxwell replied, "I've seen so many numbers I wouldn't comment on that."
But he confirmed that the debt of the family's private companies totaled about 1 billion, or roughly $1.77 billion, early this year. He indicated, though, that this amount and the total debt of the public companies had fallen. "We've gone a long way towards reducing the indebtedness of the group," he said.

HEADLINE: Woolworth Profit Falls 49%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings skidded 49 percent as the continuing slump in consumer spending took a heavy toll on the retailer's business.
The variety and discount retailer said it earned $41 million, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 26, down from $80 million, or 62 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenue fell 1.9 percent, to $2.42 billion from $2.47 billion. 
 Woolworth said revenue from its chains, which include Kinney shoe and Foot Locker outlets, rose 7.6 percent. But revenue from general merchandise stores, including Woolworth and Woolco branches, was off 9.9 percent.
The company's revenue from its foreign operations was down 7.5 percent.
Woolworth's chairman, Harold E. Sells, said the sluggish economy, which has prompted consumers to curtail their spending, sliced into the company's sales in the United States and Canada. A new tax on goods in Canada also affected results.
The company's stock dropped $1.75, to $26.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Japan, in Rare Move, Charges Price-Fixing of Food Wrap

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Attempting to show it is getting tougher in enforcing long-neglected laws against monopolies, Japan's Fair Trade Commission charged eight major chemical companies today with fixing the price of plastic food wrap, the first criminal charges the commission has brought in 17 years.
Although some described the charges as more symbol than substance, since the food wrap business is much smaller than other industries where price fixing is said to be rife, most agreed that the symbol was a potentially powerful one. The commission also conceded that the charges had resulted from United States pressure to open the Japanese economy. 
 "This can be described as a sign of our tougher stance," said Fumio Noguchio, deputy director of the commission's investigation division. "It won't be another 17 years before we file more criminal charges."
 
Agency Called Toothless
 The Fair Trade Commission has long been reviled both inside and outside Japan as a toothless lapdog to industry that tacitly sanctioned the many cartels that control large sectors of the economy and keep consumer prices at or near the highest levels in the world.
The heads of sales at each of the eight companies were also charged, which added sting to the announcement, for it was an almost unheard of instance of executives being held responsible for carrying out corporate policies. They face prison sentences of up to three years and fines of up to about $3.85 million if convicted.
The companies are parts of most of Japan's major keiretsu, or industrial groupings held together with inter-locking share ownership, and included one manufacturer that is half- owned by Borden Inc. of the United States and half by the Hitachi Chemical Company.
The seven others are Mitsui Toatsu Chemicals, Mitsubishi Plastics Industries, Shin-Etsu Polymer, Gunze, Nippon Carbide Industries, Denki Kagaku Kogyo and Riken Vinyl Industry. The Government said they secretly agreed to raise prices twice last year, increasing the bulk price of the plastic wrap by 40 percent.
The companies have not yet had to file a plea to the charges, and they said they had not decided how they would respond.
 
Termed an Important Move
 "Today's announcement involves only one case, and it will take more to convince people that the Fair Trade Commission will really enforce the laws strictly," said Masahiro Murakami, an expert on monopoly law at Yokohama National University. "But most companies are going to realize clearly that they cannot continue with their old practices. This is an extremely important case for that reason."
The Japanese Government has never suggested that it intends to break up the cartels, which critics say exist, for instance, in the beer, construction and industrial materials industries. The Finance Minister recently characterized the securities industry, which is dominated by four large firms, as an oligopoly.
But after facing heavy criticism and pressure from the United States, the Government finally agreed last year to stiffen enforcement and increase penalties for violations of the antimonopoly laws to insure greater openness in the economy. After a series of trade talks known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, Japan agreed, among other things, to apply its antitrust laws more rigorously.
At times the attempts to demonstrate a new toughness have bordered on the ridiculous. Last year, the commission ordered some travel agencies to withdraw brochures on summer trips near the Arctic Circle that promised visitors they would see the midnight sun; the commission said that some of the travelers went to areas where there were actually only a few hours of darkness.
 
Civil Cases Filed
 But there have also been recent civil cases against construction companies for bid-rigging, a practice that is believed to be endemic, and against cement companies, charging that they agreed to reduce supplies to some areas to maintain high prices.
Mr. Noguchi said the commission sought criminal charges against the chemical companies because their actions were so blatant, because five of the companies had faced sanctions earlier for other antimonopoly violations and because consumers were directly affected by the conspiracy. Gunze, for instance, was penalized two years ago for cutting off supplies of underwear it manufactures to discount retailers.
The last criminal case was filed against 12 oil companies in 1974, charging that they rigged prices after the first energy crisis. Although the Government fined the companies, consumers never won compensation, and it is doubtful that they will this time. The Supreme Court held in the oil price-fixing case that consumers could not prove that the existence of a cartel increased prices beyond what market forces would have done.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
London Venture Tests JMB Skills

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
THE partnership that owns Randsworth Trust P.L.C., one of the most closely followed investments in European real estate by Americans, has stopped paying interest to Citibank on a 185 million loan and is negotiating with the bank to recapitalize Randsworth, people close to the negotiations said.
The troubles with Randsworth underscore how treacherous it can be for even the most knowledgeable real estate investors to put together foreign deals, especially with substantial leverage. With the venture not meeting its heavy debt payments, it now appears that a Dutch pension fund, which is already the largest Randsworth investor, will come to the rescue with a cash infusion. 
 Some of the American pension funds in the deal, including the Pension Reserve Investment Management Board, in Boston, have seen their multimillion-dollar equity investments wiped out as the value of the portfolio has dropped. Pension Reserve, for example, has written its $25 million investment down to zero.
In 1989, the purchase of the Randsworth Trust portfolio by the partnership of pension funds and the JMB Realty Corporation, the privately owned Chicago-based property giant, was heralded as the most significant entry of American institutional money into the European real estate market. But since 1990, the Randsworth partnership, which carries a large amount of debt, has been battered by high interest rates in Britain. More important, the partnership has not been able to sell off parts of the portfolio to pay down the debt it took on for the acquisition, because almost nothing is changing hands in the London market. The troubled deal has been a great embarrassment to JMB, which has a wide following among institutional investors and manages more than $22 billion worth of property for its own account and its clients.
The properties in the Randsworth portfolio are widely regarded as a good buy. But in the West End of London, where most of the property is, vacancy rates are around 10 percent, and in the City, the London financial district, the vacancy rate ranges from 18 percent to 20 percent and values generally are falling. The portfolio, which is now generating about a 4 percent return, has debt service that starts at 10 percent and goes up. At the end of 1990 the portfolio was written down 11 percent.
"It was a very good buy, but in hindsight the market turned bad and they made a strategic mistake in terms of leveraging the deal," said one executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Some real estate executives who are unconnected to the deal have expressed dismay at its failure because they fear it will now be more difficult to get pension funds to invest overseas. Neil G. Bluhm, JMB's president, acknowledged that negotiations to recapitalize Randsworth were under way, but he would not elaborate.
"We are negotiating and analyzing it with the investors and the bank to come up with a deal," Mr. Bluhm said. "We are a lot further along with discussions of specific ideas, but at this point nothing has been agreed on by anyone."
JMB Acquisition Partners, the limited partnership that holds about 16 percent of Randsworth, is trying to reduce the company's senior debt by replacing some of it with additional money from all of the equity partners. The largest equity holder, a Dutch pension fund known as A.B.P., or Algemeen Burgerlijk Pensioenfonds, is expected to be a key contributor of fresh capital, but just how much and under what terms has not been settled. JMB is now negotiating to determine what interest payment concessions Citibank would grant in exchange for paying down the loan.
The existing capital structure of the company consists of 135 million of publicly traded notes that pay a fixed 10 percent rate and mature in 25 years; 185 million in senior debt from Citibank; about 190 million of initial equity contribution, and an additional 57 million of equity contributed by some of the pension funds when JMB made a capital call last year, shortly after the deal was closed. About half of the Citibank loan has been fixed at an average rate of roughly 12 percent, but last year much of the debt was floating from 14 percent to 16 percent, further hammering the deal.
The Dutch fund, which already owns 25 percent of the equity in Randsworth, is likely to acquire an even larger position. Some of the other pension funds in the deal, which balked at making additional contributions when JMB made last year's capital call, are expected to refuse to contribute more money this time as well.
Meanwhile, the London commercial property market continues to soften, with new buildings still being added to the glut of office space.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Federal Reserve cut the discount rate, the rate it charges banks for loans, to 4 1/2 percent, from 5 percent. This is the lowest rate since January 1973. Banks responded immediately and cut their prime rate to 7 1/2 percent, from 8 percent. The Fed also bought large quantities of Government securities to indicate that it wanted to reduce the funds rate to 4.75 percent, from 5 percent. [Page A1.] 
 Robert Clarke's nomination was killed by the Senate Banking Committee, which first rejected the nominee's bid to a second term as Comptroller of the Currency, then blocked further consideration of it by the full Senate. [D1.]
A scaled-down version of a banking overhaul measure was approved by the House Banking Committee. [D8.]
D. L. (Danny) Faulkner and three others were convicted of looting $165 million from five savings and loans near Dallas. [D5.]
 
After Maxwell
Robert Maxwell apparently died before he fell into the sea, a Spanish judge in charge of investigating the case said. [A1.]
Kevin Maxwell, the new publisher of The Daily News, plans to visit the newspaper later this week. [B5.]
Maxwell's heirs and their investment bankers insist that the publishing empire faces no immediate financial crisis. [D23.]
 
Companies
A revised bid to buy Executive Life was rejected by the California Insurance Commissioner, who said he would choose instead between two other competing offers. [D1.]
Salomon Brothers announced a large management shake-up under which the firm's board will be replaced and power will be spread across more divisions of the firm. [D1.]
Pepsico will invest $1 billion in Spain to build soft-drink plants, open fast-food restaurants, and set up an elaborate computerized system to track snack-food sales. [D1.]
I.B.M will announce a 10-year technology agreement with Intel today to cooperate on the design of computer chips. [D1.]
Philips has licensed the patent for a computer on a chip that was developed by Gilbert P. Hyatt, a California inventor. [D4.]
John Deere will join with Fiat and Hitachi Construction in a joint venture to make construction equipment in Europe. [D4.]
Two members of Congress asked the F.D.A. to explain why the agency was seeking to close Barr Laboratories. [D23.]
 
International
Japan's Fair Trade Commission charged eight chemical companies with fixing the price of plastic food wrap, the first criminal charges the commission has brought in 17 years. [D2.]
 
Markets
Stocks made mild gains in light volume. The Dow rose 7.15, to close at 3,038.46. [D10.]
The Fed's decision to reduce interest rates did not help the Treasury sell $12 billion worth of new 10-year notes. [D16.] Yields on tax-exempt money market funds were mixed in the week. [D9.]
The dollar was mixed against other major currencies after the Federal Reserve lowered its discount rate. [D18.] Wheat and soybean futures prices fell sharply. [D18.]

HEADLINE: NATO CHIEFS SEEK TO DEFINE ITS ROLE

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 6

 BODY:
With NATO still looking anxiously for its place in the post-cold-war world, leaders of the 16-nation alliance who meet in Rome on Thursday are expected to point once again to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe to justify the 42-year-old pact's continued existence.
This time, though, with the Soviet Union no longer posing a credible military threat to the West, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be responding to requests by Moscow and its former satellites that the alliance expand its political role and become a security pillar for all of Europe. 
 At their two-day summit meeting this week, President Bush and other NATO leaders therefore plan to approve creation of a new 25-nation cooperation council as a way of giving a formal structure to growing links between the alliance and the former Soviet bloc, including the three newly independent Baltic countries.
Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, in particular, have been seeking security guarantees from NATO, even signaling their desire to join the alliance, while only last week President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he strongly favored turning NATO into a broad political organization.
 
Meeting Planned for Brussels
 The council, which should hold its first meeting at the foreign ministers' level in Brussels on Dec. 20, will have a mandate to discuss regional security issues and promote confidence-building measures at a time of growing nationality disputes across the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
But while NATO seems agreed on how to deal with its former enemies, there is no such consensus about its own military and political future and, above all, its relationship to other competing European organizations. And this debate is certain to continue well beyond the Rome meeting.
The military side of the issue looks relatively simple, with the NATO leaders due to endorse an 18-month-long strategy review under which the alliance will reduce its troop strength and create a new rapid reaction corps.
 
Decisions Already Made
 In practice, though, NATO leaders will be formalizing decisions that have already been made, including the gradual cutback of American troops stationed in Europe and the elimination of all but 700 warheads of the alliance's current arsenal of 3,600 nuclear weapons in Europe.
The unresolved question is whether NATO should lift its ban on "out of area" operations, a rule that prevented the alliance from playing more than a consultative role in the Persian Gulf war, even though many of its individual members participated.
Far more complicated, however, is the political profile that NATO should adopt, specifically whether it should acknowledge that the collapse of Communism in Europe has removed its principal reason for existence or whether it should redefine its role.
The United States has repeatedly stressed that it sees its place in Europe in the context of a strong NATO. Its European allies are eager for some American troops to remain here as a shield against instability in the former Soviet bloc and as a counterweight to Germany's growing power.
 
Europeans Seek Greater Role
 But as the European Community moves toward increased economic and political union, many European governments believe they should play a greater role in their own defense.
The demand by former Soviet bloc nations for closer ties to NATO reflects disappointment that the European Community has discouraged them from seeking membership and their recognition that the European Security Conference has little real power.
"We regard NATO as our long-term partner and we intend to develop our relations with this organization on a solid and wide-ranging basis," the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Yuri Deryabin, said recently after a visit to NATO's headquarters in Brussels to discuss closer ties.

HEADLINE: In Congress, Calls for a Caucus for Area's Goals

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Bridge closings. Higher bus and subway fares. And, ultimately, slow economic strangulation. That was the apocalyptic picture painted this spring as lawmakers from the New York metropolitan region mobilized opposition here to an ambitious Bush Adminstration proposal to rebuild the country's transportation systems.
In a rare show of unity over what is expected to be the country's largest public works program for the rest of the century, Republicans and Democrats from the region worked together on House and Senate versions of the transport bills to get millions of additional dollars for the area. 
 The success of the lawmakers in shaping the two bills, which will soon go before a conference committee, is fueling a new effort to create a regional Congressional caucus. Supporters hope it can add muscle to the area's efforts to grab a bigger piece of the Federal financial pie.
"It's desperately needed," said Representative James H. Scheuer, a Queens Democrat. "In unity there's strength. If we get together and do a little trading, we've got a lot of clout. We're sending tax dollars down there as if it's going out of style. But the Reagan and Bush Administrations have just about closed up shop when it comes to urban programs."
A variety of studies show that the difference between what the region pays to the Federal Government in taxes and what it gets in Federal spending is the largest in the country.
The 31 counties within 100 miles of New York City, including parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, last year sent $110 billion, which was $32.8 billion more than they got back, according to the Regional Plan Association, a research organization for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. That is enough, for example, to pay for the entire New York City budget -- $28 billion.
The most recent annual survey of Federal spending and taxing done by the office of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, found that New Yorkers last year paid $1,178 more in taxes than they received in Federal outlays; New Jerseyans fared even worse, suffering a per-capita deficit of $2,487; Connecticut residents had a $2,011 deficit. New Mexico residents, by comparison, received $2,776 more per person than they sent to Washington.
"If I were a voter looking at these delegations," said a regional official, "I would have to say, 'Hey, what are you doing down there?' " The official asked not to be identified because he works with the area's lawmakers.
 
Social Engineering
 Traditionally, Mr. Moynihan says, lawmakers from the Northeast have focused on everything but bringing home the bacon. He says that unlike other regions' legislators, who have approached the Federal budget as a scavenger hunt with billion-dollar prizes, the area's lawmakers more often have used the Federal purse to shape national priorities in what amounts to social engineering. While the country may have benefited, he says, the region was shortchanged.
Lawmakers from the region say it also is a victim of bias. Any bill viewed as favoring New York City starts with two strikes against it, they say, while legislation that hurts the city rides a current of natural support.
"The prevailing attitude appears to be wishing New York wasn't here," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association. "New York has a lot of needs that should be addressed on a collective basis."
There have been a number of previous attempts to set up a New York metropolitan region caucus. But all have collapsed amid regional competition and jealousies.
So far, Mr. Andlerson said, about a dozen of the 47 legislators from the region have committed themselves to the idea of a regional caucus or shown active interest in it.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION: The Loser;
The Search for a Culprit In Thornburgh's Defeat

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6

 BODY:
For Murray Dickman, the chief political adviser to Dick Thornburgh, Tuesday, Oct. 29, was an ominous sign of things to come.
On that morning, a poll by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette showed that his boss's lead over Senator Harris Wofford, Mr. Thornburgh's Democratic opponent in the race for the United States Senate, had been sliced one percentage point. Then, after Mr. Dickman had dropped off his boss at the airport, Mr. Dickman's car broke down. 
 "It was one of those days and times when the lightbulb goes on and you know things are going badly," he said.
 
A Warning for Others
 In remarks after his loss, Mr. Thornburgh suggested that things could go badly for President Bush if he did not respond to a tide of voter discontent and economic worries that drowned his Senate candidacy.
But other experts pointed out that Mr. Thornburgh could also blame himself. Republicans and Democrats agree that Mr. Thornburgh presided over a slack campaign and that he became a victim of his own hubris as he migrated across the political spectrum from Republican centrist to hard-nosed Reaganite.
"This election result has dated Dick Thornburgh fatally," said Kevin Phillips, a Republican and the publisher of the American Political Report. "He had been an independent Republican and a moderate when he was Governor of Pennsylvania. The 1980's turned him into a galvanized Reaganite, a pin-striped insider and a defender of the status quo. I don't see how he gets back that which first made him successful."
Other Republican strategists say it is too early to write his political obituary, though he is expected to go into political hibernation in the near term.
"I would not pronounce Dick Thornburgh politically dead," said Eddie Mahe, a Washington-based Republican strategist. "But he certainly is wounded."
 
Pointing Fingers
 As is often the case in the wake of losing campaigns, fingers are being pointed everywhere and reasons for this defeat are being proffered that have nothing to do with the campaign. In this case, Mr. Thornburgh and his aides blame a general mood of anxiety and discontent among the voters.
"We were smashed by a tidal wave that was bigger than Dick Thornburgh and Harris Wofford and the health-care issue put together," said Greg Stevens, president of The Media Team, a subsidiary of Ailes Communications and the company that handled Mr. Thornburgh's electronic-media campaign. "There was a tremendous confluence of dissatisfaction, anti-incumbency and anti-Washington mood that is driven by the state of the economy."
Even when their candidate had a commanding lead in the independent polls, Mr. Thornburgh's aides say, their own polling showed that 72 percent of the voters in the state felt the country in general was on the wrong track.
Although the Thornburgh camp lamented the state of the economy, unemployment in Pennsylvania has not changed greatly from the time that President Bush and the Republicans were riding high in the polls. Last month the state's jobless rate, seasonally adjusted, was 6.5 percent, slightly below the national average. In February, when President Bush's approval rating was rocketing in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, the rate was 6.7 percent.
Yet some of Mr. Thornburgh's aides do concede that his campaign must accept its share of the blame for its failure in taking Mr. Wofford too lightly and in not seizing upon a theme that would evoke a visceral response among the voters.
Mr. Thornburgh, who served two terms as Governor of Pennsylvania and was Attorney General under Presidents Reagan and Bush, had not run a campaign since 1982.
"We were rusty," Mr. Dickman said. "For example, in 1982, we were never as dependent on television as we are now."
Surrounded by a group of reporters eager to hear his view, Mr. Thornburgh said, "While I may style myself as a casualty of sorts of the gelling of these feelings in Pennsylvania this year, in the longer run it will cause a re-examining by all those who hold high office in Washington of precisely what they have to do to fulfill their responsibilities to the people."

HEADLINE: Election Cited in Push for Jobless Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Buoyed by Harris Wofford's victory in Pennsylvania, Senate Democrats moved today toward trying to freeze foreign aid and using the money saved to pay for extended unemployment benefits for people out of work at least half a year.
Even without committing themselves to that way of paying for the $5.6 billion bill, they were using it as a political club to swing at President Bush. 
 The President's budget director criticized the plan as a violation of last year's budget act. But Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, retorted, "Why is the President so ready, eager and willing to help people overseas and so reluctant to help people in need in America?"
 
Hesitancy on Effort
 Republicans and House Democratic leaders were wary of the Mitchell approach, which would limit foreign-aid spending in future years to the level being spent in the current fiscal year. But they agreed that it might carry overwhelmingly in both houses, perhaps at veto-proof levels, if allowed to get to the floor. And the savings of $7.7 billion would easily pay for the extra benefits of as many as 20 weeks that Senate Democrats have insisted on.
The unemployment benefits issue, which seemed on the verge of agreement just last week, remains bogged down not only over this bluntly partisan question of a freeze in foreign aid but also in a swirl of personal rivalries and arguments over numbers and the sanctity of the budget act.
Even though both parties in both houses seem agreed that the time has come to find a way to get an unemployment bill passed, negotiations have continued day after day without clear evidence of progress.
Last week House and Senate Democratic leaders agreed on one approach to financing: higher estimated taxes from high-income taxpayers with sharply fluctuating incomes. But the agreement dissolved after the House Ways and Means Committee balked at endorsing the plan with only 45 minutes' notice, and complained that it would be too harsh on taxpayers who depended on income from mutual funds and partnerships.
Following Mr. Mitchell's lead, the Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee met Tuesday, and again today, and coalesced behind the approach of freezing foreign aid, even though their own chairman, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, proposed using the increase in estimated taxes.
As for the Republicans, they signaled last week that they were ready to deal, and Mr. Bush, who had killed two earlier bills to help the jobless on the ground that the measures would raise the Federal budget deficit, began calling for quick action.
That appeal was renewed today by Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, who complained of "the two parties' vying for political position," and by Labor Secretary Lynn Martin, who issued a statement saying: "The Democratic Congress has fiddled long enough. By waiting for the right moment for political one-upmanship, they have lost sight of the need."
But the Democrats were listening todifferent drums today -- the ones from Pennsylvania, where Mr. Wofford, having forged a campaign in which he portrayed Washington as indifferent to the nation's domestic needs, retained the Senate seat to which he had been appointed against the Republican challenge of Dick Thornburgh, the former United States Attorney General.
For example, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, in joining a number of floor speeches calling for extended unemployment benefits, said, "Yesterday the people of Pennsylvania sent a message that they're no longer going to tolerate the absentee-landlord approach of the Administration."
And, using a news conference hailing Mr. Wofford, Mr. Mitchell attacked Mr. Bush over foreign aid and promised to keep the Senate in session until extended benefits become law.
One uncertain factor is the stance of Congressional Republicans. Their leaders have said they want to negotiate but have not made clear publicly whether they agree with the insistence of Mr. Bush and his budget director, Richard G. Darman, that in the process the budget act must be complied with completely.
Mr. Mitchell's plan would clearly violate the act, as Mr. Darman said. First, it would not pay for itself in each year, because most of its costs would be paid out in the current fiscal year and the foreign aid savings would occur in future years. Second, it would take money from foreign aid spending and use it for domestic purposes, a shift the act forbids before Oct. 1, 1993.
In addition, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, denounced the plan as "capriciously irresponsible" because it would slash foreign aid without first studying how the cuts would affect American policy.
 
Assessing Plans
 Generally, Republican lawmakers find the Bentsen plan more enticing on its own merits and because they consider it easier to deal with its backers, Mr. Bentsen and Representative Dan Rosentowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, than with the more partisan Mr. Mitchell.
But the Bentsen plan, too, would fall short of paying for itself in its first year and Mr. Darman has made that point while also calling for a reduction of the benefits it would provide. Mr. Bentsen's plan also includes retaining a $900 million employers' unemployment insurance tax in 1996, when it is scheduled to expire. Mr. Darman has also labeled that measure unacceptable.

HEADLINE: A Soviet Company Offers Nuclear Blasts for Sale to Anyone With the Cash

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A new Soviet trading company is trying to market the power of underground nuclear explosions for commercial application to anyone in the world who has the cash.
It is the first time that nuclear blasts are known to have been put up for sale, but the venture is surrounded by great uncertainty given the political turbulence in the Soviet Union and rising opposition around the world to nuclear blasts. 
 The atomic exposions are being marketed by the International Chetek Corporation of Moscow, a private trading company tied to the Soviet arms complex. Its initial goal is to carry out blasts in the Soviet Union for the incineration of toxic wastes. But the company says it will eventually try to do whatever the customer wants, as long as it is commercial and peaceful in nature, including conducting nuclear explosions in other nations.
 
Dangers Cited
 The move has startled Western experts, who say nuclear blasts could damage the environment and that the nuclear devices would be at risk of falling into unfriendly hands. Other experts, however, say the Soviet ideas may have technical merit and should be evaluated.
There apparently are no international accords that bar one country from selling nuclear devices to another for peaceful purposes.
The nascent marketing effort shows the lengths to which the crumbling Soviet bloc will go to acquire hard currency by converting military industries to civilian ones.
"We're willing to entertain all ideas," said Danny Wolfson, an agent for Chetek at Ph.D. International Trading Inc., a small concern in Montreal, Quebec. "It doesn't matter who, where or when. We have all the technologies and they're going to be used."
Mr. Wolfson said Chetek is owned by shareholders that include company officers, private Soviet enterprises, a scientific center, and most importantly, the Soviet ministry charged with production of nuclear weapons.
 
Has Many Uses
 Of the world's nuclear nations, only the Soviets have an extensive record of using underground nuclear blasts for civil ventures. Applications have included the creation of underground storage vaults, seismic exploration of geologic formations and the stimulation of gas and oil production.
Opposition to the fledging effort at commercializing the blasts is widespread among environmentalists and arms-control experts who know of it.
Dr. William C. Potter, an official of the Monterey Institute of International Studies in California, tried to foster public debate over the marketing effort after visiting Chetek's office in Moscow last month. He wrote an article appearing on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times today.
"Chetek is representative of a general danger," Dr. Potter said in an interview. "Soviet weapons scientists are faced with tremendous economic hardships and are going to be tempted to sell their services to anyone who is prepared to provide hard currency."
Tariq Rauf, a senior associate with the Canadian Center for Arms Control and Disarmament, in Ottawa, has also investigated and publicized Chetek and similar Soviet ventures that are getting under way.
"Everybody in Moscow wants to make a deal," he said. "These people are not really concerned about the consequences of the sales. They only want the dollars."
Dr. Ray E. Kidder, a weapons expert at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, said the notion of using nuclear blasts to incinerate hazardous wastes and even nuclear warheads had technical merit.
"It would be cheapest way to dispose of them, by far," Dr. Kidder said. "But lots of environmental questions would have to be settled. You'd also have to find ways to make sure the blasts would not be used covertly for the further development of nuclear arms."
Underground detonations are essential for perfecting new warheads. Thus, their cessation is often seen as a way to halt the nuclear arms race.
The Non-Proliferation Treaty, ratified in 1970, has no apparent prohibitions against commercial sales, as long as the blasts are for peaceful purposes. Its only conditions are that transfers from a nuclear power to a non-nuclear one occur "under appropriate international observation and through appropriate international procedures," and that the price be fair.
For decades the Soviets have led the world in applying nuclear detonations to civilian efforts, conducting more than 120 blasts. The United States also investigated such peaceful applications of the atom, but dropped the effort in the 1970's as fears arose about the contamination of the environment with radioactive residue from the work.
The Soviet Union used the blasts to create underground cavities for storing fuels and disposing of chemical wastes such as the brine produced by oil fields. Another use was to stimulate the production of gas and oil fields by shattering rock and releasing trapped pockets. They also used blasts to extinguish stubborn fires in gas wells, and to generate powerful shock waves that helped geologists learn more about the earth's crust and mantle.
Chetek, an acronym formed from the Russian words for man, technology and capital, was formed late last year to try to sell these and other nuclear technologies to the world. In particular, it has promoted the novel idea of using nuclear blasts to vaporize all kinds of extremely dangerous wastes. The destruction would occur a little more than a half mile beneath the earth's surface, where a nuclear bomb was surrounded by waste and then exploded.
 
Marketing Campaign
 The company's president, Vladimir B. Dmitriev, began a quiet marketing blitz in early April, hailing the process at an international scientific conference in Moscow on the elimination of chemical arms. "It will be possible to export services," Mr. Dmitriev told the conference. "The problem of chemical weapons and highly toxic waste products destruction is urgent for many countries of the world."
Later in April, Mr. Dmitriev traveled to Ottawa for a scientific meeting on the environmental consequences of underground nuclear testing, sponsored by the Canadian Center for Arms Control and Disarmament, a private group. There he startled the audience by detailing his company's plans and suggesting that a trial waste-elimination blast be conducted in the Soviet Union under international supervision.
Also at the meeting and backing the waste plan was Dr. Alexander K. Chernyshev, a department head at Arzamas 16, the principal Soviet bomb-design laboratory.
"Everybody in the room thought they were nuts," recalled John M. Lamb, executive director of the Canadian center and the meeting's chairman. Later Mr. Lamb objected strongly when Chetek sought to say in a promotional brochure that the Canadian meeting had "discussed and approved" the nuclear technology.
 
Moscow Backed Plan
 The commercial effort did, however, soon get boost from Viktor N. Mikhailov, the Soviet deputy minister of atomic energy and industry. He wrote the United Nations to endorse Chetek and the notion of using nuclear weapons to incinerate all kinds of wastes.
On Oct. 7, Mr. Dmitriev of Chetek signed an agreement with Ph.D. International Trading to have the exclusive rights in North America for any waste destruction, and the international rights, excluding Europe, for all other nuclear services or technologies. "This process will be carried out by the company together with the ministry of nuclear energy of the U.S.S.R.," said the agreement.
Mr. Wolfson said that he has had preliminary discussions with companies in the United States and Canada about the destruction of chemical wastes as well as other peaceful applications of nuclear blasts.
Mr. Wolfson played down the idea that bombs would be traveling between countries, saying there would probably be strong political objections to such transfers. Even though such exports are envisioned by Chetek, he said, they might never materialize.
For the waste-incineration plan, he said, the initial strategy is for waste material to be shipped to the Soviet Union for destruction there. He said his company has already made arrangements for special canisters, trucks and ships that could safely transport even radioactive wastes.
 
Price Range
 The cost for waste destruction, he said, ranged between $300 and $1,200 per kilogram, or 2.2 pounds. "It goes by the danger," he said. "We just can't take a back loader and go after it. You need specialized equipment. The actual transport is done at night because you don't want to bother anybody.
"People may not like it," he added, "but it's the cheapest, easiest way to get rid of really dangerous wastes."
Opposition to such blasts is great and growing, however, even in the Soviet Union. Last month, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced a unilateral, one-year moratorium on underground nuclear tests and urged other nuclear powers to follow suit.
Mr. Wolfson, without being specific, said the moratorium posed no difficulty. Private arms experts say that Chetek and the Soviet Defense Ministry are pushing to have the moratorium interpreted as applying only to blasts for arms development.
Christopher E. Paine, a senior research associate with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group in Washington, said the whole idea of marketing nuclear blasts was dangerous.
"It's, 'Have bomb, Will travel,"' he said. "It's serious and has huge implications for weapons proliferation. The largest nuclear establishment in the world is undergoing a process of financial and political disintegration."

HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION: The Winner
Man in the News: Harris Llewellyn Wofford Jr.;
Backstage No Longer

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania toiled for decades in obscurity as a backstage political operator and idea man, gaining the ears of figures like President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
But his election to the Senate on Tuesday marked Mr. Wofford's ascent to center stage as a political giant slayer. 
 It is an unlikely role for Mr. Wofford, who, with his courtly, professorial disposition, was portrayed by opponents as a 65-year-old remnant from the 1960's who was more ready for retirement than the Senate: an unabashedly liberal former law professor who seemed more at home mulling over abstract ideas than dealing with the politics of Capitol Hill.
But Mr. Wofford fooled the Republicans and many in his own party. By packaging himself as an outsider, and underscoring the reputation of Dick Thornburgh, a former Attorney General in the Reagan and Bush Administrations, as a purveyor of Washington's "inside the Beltway" mentality, Mr. Wofford tapped an apparent unhappiness among voters about politics as usual, winning his first election.
 
'I Am the Messenger'
 In keeping with his unpretentious demeanor, Mr. Wofford asserted at a news conference in the Capitol today that voter discontent was as significant in his election as his own qualities as a candidate.
"I am the messenger of a message that came through strong and clear," he said. Sounding themes of his campaign, Mr. Wofford declared that people are "fed up and they want action to get our economy off dead center and get us moving out of this recession and they want national health insurance and they want it now."
John P. Coyne, a friend of Mr. Wofford since he worked for him in the Peace Corps in 1962, said he was by his side in a Philadelphia hotel when the returns came in. "I told him, 'You've always been the bridesmaid and now you're the bride,' " said Mr. Coyne, a novelist who lives in Westchester. "One side of Harris is the philosopher-theologian and the other side is the very cool and capable political operative. Now he's in the position of having the ideas and having the opportunity to make them work."
Mr. Wofford said he made his first telephone call this morning to Teresa Heinz, Mr. Heinz's widow, assuring her, "I will do my best to carry on that legacy, which is one of a Senator who reached out beyond his party and beyond his region to represent all of Pennsylvania."
But his critics say they fear Mr. Wofford is too ensconced in an ivory tower to be responsive to his constituents.
"I have the sense that he's not liable to be taken seriously -- he's liable to be taken as a relic of the 60's," said Abe H. Frumkin, a Philadelphia lawyer who was Mr. Heinz's campaign treasurer. "He's too unconnected between his ideals and the reality of accomplishing them."
Mr. Wofford has had little time to make a mark in the Senate, but he was careful to behave like an outsider, refusing to accept the pay increase that was approved in July as well as some free mailing privileges. His Democratic colleagues did their best to pull Mr. Wofford into the limelight that benefits an incumbent, repeatedly including him in news conferences on extending unemployment benefits although he was not a significant player in the legislation.
Mr. Wofford's campaign against Washington in some ways echoed that of Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat who was the only candidate to defeat a Senate incumbent last year, and who looks on the Pennsylvanian as a political soulmate.
"Other senators viewed him as kind of professorial when he came here," Mr. Wellstone said. "He proved to be an extremely good politician. He intuitively understood that the only way to win was to express just outright indignation with politics in Washington. No holds barred. And he did."
Harris Llewellyn Wofford Jr. was born on April 9, 1926, in New York City. He spent his early childhood in Johnson City, Tenn., where his parents owned an insurance agency, and his teen-age years in Scarsdale.
Mr. Wofford's Democratic leanings were already apparent when he was 10 years old. He tells the story that in the 1936 Presidential campaign, he walked to school for months so he would not have to ride in the family car, which displayed a bumper sticker supporting Alfred M. Landon, the Republican candidate.
After graduating from the University of Chicago in 1948, Mr. Wofford and his wife, Clare, traveled to India and wrote a 1951 book about Mohandas K. Gandhi, "India Afire." As an informal adviser to Dr. King, Mr. Wofford later arranged for the civil rights leader to travel to India to discuss tactics for non-violent civil disobedience.
Mr. Wofford earned law degrees from both Yale University and Howard University, where he was one of the first white students. He then worked at the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling, then for the United States Civil Rights Commission. He taught law at Howard and Notre Dame before before joining the Kennedy Administration as a special assistant on civil rights.
Mr. Wofford was a founding staff member at the Peace Corps and was its associate director until 1966, when he became President of the New York State College at Old Westbury. From 1970 to 1978, he was president of Bryn Mawr College.
 
Sons Worked in Campaign
 After practicing law at a Philadelphia firm for several years, Mr. Wofford was named chairman of the state Democratic Party in 1986 and a year later was appointed by Gov. Robert P. Casey, his mentor, as the State Secretary of Labor and Industry.
The Woffords' sons, Daniel and David, both worked on the campaign, and describe their father as having a passion for books and enjoying swimming and poking around the vegetable garden. The Woffords' eldest child, Susanne, teaches English at Yale University.
But his family members are also quick to note that beneath his academic exterior, Mr. Wofford has an easy sense of humor. That surfaced today, when the Senator recalled for reporters the initial press coverage of his appointment.
"I began with a headline saying, 'What is Harris Wofford? It sounds like a town in Great Britain,' " he said. "Which didn't help with my Irish friends."
