HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION: Pennsylvania;
Wofford Helped by Voter Mood Swing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6

 BODY:
As Senator Harris Wofford basked in victory and television lights during a morning of nonstop interviews in a hotel lobby here, his two top campaign strategists sat nearby, sipping coffee and marveling at their strategy's success.
"This is the rarest thing in politics, an upset landslide," said James Carville, a 47-year-old strategist from Louisiana, whose partner, 30-year-old Paul E. Begala of Houston was the Wofford campaign's manager. 
 "This is like one time in my life where all the lines just crossed," Mr. Carville added. "It was an off-year election, a statewide election with national implications; it was an election against a well-known candidate by an unknown and it was a tested candidate against an untested candidate. There won't be another one like this."
 
A Winning Message
 Mr. Wofford and his message clearly crossed the right lines with voters, who crossed party lines, changed voting habits and braved unseasonably cold weather to vote for a man most of them barely knew. Political analysts who followed the campaign closely say Mr. Wofford won because he was a credible, qualified Democratic candidate who tapped into the deep well of middle-class anger at incumbents.
His call for national health insurance resonated profoundly with people who had concerns about their jobs, family health, personal finances or the direction of the economy. And his opponent, Dick Thornburgh, ran a defensive and ineffective campaign.
This was a David versus Goliath race. Mr. Wofford, whose June polls showed him trailing Mr. Thornburgh, a former two-term Governor of Pennsylvania, by a 67-to-20 margin, transformed that into a shocking 55-to-45 victory margin. Mr. Wofford, a former college president and one-time aide to President John F. Kennedy, had never run for elected office before; Mr. Thornburgh is one of the state's best known politicians, who when he left the governor's office in 1986 had a 72 percent approval rating.
But one asset the Wofford campaign had, Mr. Begala said, was that Mr. Wofford himself knew the central issues he wanted to champion from May 9, the day Gov. Robert P. Casey appointed him interim Senator to replace John Heinz, a Republican who was killed in a plane crash in April.
 
'Going for Change'
 And people who voted for Mr. Wofford got his message, loud and clear. "I am going for change," said Ralph D. Salyards, a 73-year-old Republican who lives in Hollidaysburg, in central Pennsylvania. "I am very dissatisfied with President Bush."
Debbie W. Klotz, a 37-year-old homemaker from York said: "I liked national health care for the simple reason that being unemployed, we are paying our own health insurance, and we can't afford it, but we can't afford to do without it."
And Maryanne O'Brien Donohue, a Scranton homemaker, said, "I really feel this is a time when the Democratic party is representing the middle class."
Even though Mr. Wofford was an unknown entity to most voters, few questioned his qualifications, Mr. Carville said. "What really helped, in this short campaign with intense coverage, was Harris's credentials," he said. "The media took him seriously from Day One. You know, they said, 'All right, in the forest of Senatorial timber, this guy is a redwood.' "
Mr. Carville, a lawyer, has run political campaigns since 1982, with Mr. Begala assisting him since 1984. This Senate race was their 10th consecutive statewide victory since 1986. "Notice I said 'statewide,' " Mr. Carville said. "We actually lost a mayor's race in Houston, but we're like doctors, we bury our mistakes."
The team's statewide candidates included Governor Casey of Pennsylvania, Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson of Kentucky, Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia, and Senator Frank R. Lautenburg of New Jersey, all of whom are Democrats. The unlucky mayoral candidate was Fred Hofheinz. The Wofford campaign was Mr. Begala's first as manager, though he has worked with Mr. Carville since graduating from law school in 1984.
Cliff Zukin, a professor of political science at Rutgers University, said: "Carville is extraordinarily effective and ruthless. The race between Pete Dawkins and Frank Lautenberg is widely regarded as the nastiest Senate race in the history of New Jersey politics."
Voter turnout, at 63 percent of Pennsylvania's 5.3 million registered voters, was considered moderate to high for a non-Presidential-election year, and analysts believe many people went to the polls because of the Senate race, which had taken on the character of a referendum on President Bush's domestic policies. By all accounts, Mr. Wofford succeeded in tarring Mr. Thornburgh, who served as chairman of President Bush's Domestic Advisory Council, with just about everything that anyone did not like about President Bush's policies.
"From Day One, Harris said the two Federal issues he was concerned with were national health insurance and extending unemployment insurance," Mr. Begala said. "Harris said he had run up against those two issues almost every day in his job as secretary of labor and industry. He said that health insurance was the Gordian knot, to use a Woffordian phrase, of every labor-management dispute he'd been involved in for the past five years."
 
The Health Insurance Issue
 When people responded extremely positively to the candidate's speeches and the campaign's first advertisement, Mr. Begala said, the campaign team realized that national health insurance would be its central issue. In that advertisement, Mr. Wofford said that if people have a fundamental right to a lawyer when accused of a crime, that working people should have a right to a doctor when they get sick.
Even when Mr. Thornburgh belatedly criticized the national health insurance plan, late in the campaign, the Wofford team was not concerned. They had done a survey in July of about 600 registered voters across the state, and it had included a presentation of the three most powerful concerns people have about national health insurance: that it would lead to higher taxes, would create massive Government bureaucracies and would take away people's ability to choose their own doctors.
"We lumped the three horribles together and, by a 63 to 30 percent margin, people said they still wanted national health insurance," Mr. Begala said.
People responded positively to Mr. Wofford's campaign, saying in interviews today that they sensed he was not just a candidate up on a soapbox telling them what he thought they wanted to hear. Mr. Wofford's discursive, rambling speeches and his rumpled, professorial appearance seemed to reinforce his image as a man of the people; a guy who milked cows at 4:30 A.M. to make friends with a few farmers.
"I felt Wofford was talking directly about the issues," said Bill Patterson, a 26-year-old unemployed librarian who particularly like Mr. Wofford's ideas on national health insurance and extending unemployment benefits. Mr. Patterson said he had been a Democrat until 1988, when he registered as a Republican and voted for George Bush. He said he would not vote for President Bush next year.
But political analysts say that it was campaign strategy as much as the issues that won the election.
"Far too much attention is being given to health care, and too little attention is given to the way the Wofford campaign controlled the agenda," said Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia. "Other than the quality of the candidate, that is the secret of success in any campaign. And Carville is always very aggressive, forcing the other candidate to react to his agenda."
The Carville-Begala team is bold. On Labor Day, after a summer of "awful, awful, awful" fundraising, the campaign had dredged up only $250,000, Mr. Begala said. "We had to get our message out to get more money," he said. "So we put it all into ads the week of Sept. 9. We went for broke."
Or, in Mr. Carville's poker metaphor, "We moved the stack to the center of the table." After that week, the Democratic National Senators Committee kicked in $500,000, and the Wofford campaign ultimately received and spent $4 million in the final 70 days.

HEADLINE: West Moves Cautiously on Renewing Zambia Aid

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Western donors, who often had stormy relations with Kenneth D. Kaunda, the defeated President of Zambia, say they are taking a "wait-and-see" approach before offering new aid to the country's newly-installed Government.
The restoration of the Zambian economy, one of the weakest in Africa despite the nation's fertile farmland and wealth in minerals, would be a long process with even more hardships ahead, they said. 
 Some expressed concern that President Frederick Chiluba, a labor union leader who was sworn in Saturday, had still not named a Cabinet today. Mr. Chiluba has pledged to dismantle state-run corporations and introduce private enterprise and market economics.
"The new Government was very critical of many of the policies of the old Government," said Duncan Wai, a World Bank official in Washington. "But we want to see what they are going to put on the table. We don't know to what extent these disagreements will be translated into policies."
But Mr. Wai said his international lending agency had not given up on Zambia despite the country's lack of progress over the years. "We are committed to work with Zambia as long as they unite on a position that the bank thinks is on the right track," he said.
Mr. Kaunda, who had presided over Zambia's largely nationalized economy since its independence from Britain in 1964, once described the International Monetary Fund as "a mad doctor" who prescribed quinine for every patient regardless of its illness. In 1987, objecting to the fund's economic austerity recommendations, he broke relations with the fund and the World Bank.
He invited them back, but relations were again derailed in September when Zambia failed to make a debt payment and reneged on a promise to halt food subsidies for the urban poor. As a result, the bank refused to go ahead with a $200 million loan.
With a population of nearly eight million and a debt of about $7 billion, Zambia is reported to have the highest per capita debt ratio in Africa.
Several Western diplomats said Zambia would likely get some short-term aid from their countries as a reward for the smooth transition from an authoritarian government to a democratically elected president and Parliament. But the disillusionment with the economy was such that new aid would not be sustained unless Mr. Chiluba lived up to his promises quickly.
The United States, which ranks behind the Scandinavian countries and Britain in the amount of its assistance to this country, canceled $15 million in agricultural aid and $20 million in food aid in May, after Mr. Kaunda balked at halting corn price subsidies.
Senior members of the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, the new party that swept the elections against Mr. Kaunda, say they believe that the key to an economic rebirth in Zambia lies with the farmers.
 
Weak Export Figures
 "Agriculture is a big part of the answer," said Guy Scott, chairman of the party's agricltural committee and a likely Minister of Agriculture.
Zimbabwe and Malawi, two neighboring countries, earned well over $400 million in tobacco exports alone, Mr. Scott said. By comparison, he said, Zambia exported only about $20 million in agricultural products, even though the soil was better and the countryside less populated. He added that the poor export figures were due to farmers not being offered adequate prices and being paid up to two years late.
In the last year, farmers rebelled by not growing corn, the staple food here, or by smuggling their crops across the borders into Zaire or Malawi where higher prices were paid, Mr. Scott said.
In the last month, he added, Zambia was spending the last of its foreign exchange buying corn at market prices from South Africa.
Mr. Chiluba pledged during the last week of his campaign to halt the corn subsidies that Mr. Kaunda had insisted upon keeping in order to placate the nation's urban poor. The World Bank has said that among the first requirements for restoring Zambia's economy is the lifting of the subsidies. Mr. Scott said he did not know when this would happen.

HEADLINE: Men Say Worry About Harassment Leads Them to Tone Down Conduct

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
The nation's new sensitivity to sexual harassment is stirring men to rethink the protocols of working with women.
Out of respect for women or out of fear of recrimination, they say they are trying harder to keep lewd jokes, raunchy language and the voyeur in their blood to themselves. 
 Some rules now seem clear, said more than three dozen men interviewed here recently, including business owners, laborers, clerks, and students preparing to join the work force. Female co-workers are not to be propositioned, pinched or fondled. The men say that they would not proffer promotions or raises in return for sexual favors, and that they do not make remarks about legs or breasts -- although they do say they witness such things.
But other matters are not so clear: whether to ask female colleagues out, how to address them, whether to comment on their appearance. For the most part, the men said, they choose caution, not all of them happily.
"Now you've got to be defensive as hell," said Louis Regnier, the 63-year-old president of a downtown real estate firm with 20 employees, a third of them women. "You can say, 'You look great today,' and get some screwball saying that's a sexist remark."
Vincent Del Nero, 30, construction manager for an electrical contractor, said: "You have to be more reserved. I'm treating women in the office less like friends. It means the workplace is less fun now. You can't kid around as much."
 
Thomas Hearings a Factor
 Some of the restraint and tension among men here is a result of the Clarence Thomas hearings in October: Each man interviewed said he watched them. But the men say the new attitudes also emerge from the sea changes in society that have brought so many women into the work force.
Providence, a windswept city of 161,000 at the center of New England's economic renaissance and subsequent collapse, provides a barometer of men's changing attitudes. Women poured into the work force here, driving the growth of employment in the services, though that is abating now with 9 percent unemployment and the collapse of banking institutions. Women also drive trucks and have joined construction crews and the police force; a few have reached the pinnacles of business, the professions and government.
The city's residents come from clashing cultures that contribute to confusion about women. A shrinking minority of Yankee patricians controls the oldest institutions, banks at the Hospital Trust Company and plays golf at the Agawam Hunt club. Second- and third-generation Irish and Italians vie for control of state and local government, and newer arrivals -- blacks, Latin Americans, Cambodians and Laotians -- have been moving into blue-collar and menial jobs.
"The stereotype of Italian men is that they're warm-hearted," said Sheldon S. Sallosy, president of the Providence branch of Manpower Inc., the temporary services firm. "They think nothing of putting an arm around a woman. Should they do that? The answer might be they should only do it to Italian women."
Age is also an issue. "I say 'dear,' and 'honey,' " said Mr. Sollosy, who is 64. "Somebody else might do the same thing and it would be construed altogether differently."
 
Restroom Graffiti
 Rhode Island has its own stories dealing with sexual harassment, a few of them unusual. One court case concerns the complaint of a warehouse worker who was dismissed after a female co-worker accused him of displaying his buttocks.
At Brown University, a 15-minute walk up College Hill from downtown, some female students last year covered their restroom walls with names of male students they deemed guilty of date rape. The women said they acted out of dissatisfaction with the university's response to their complaints; they stopped when the administration called a campus forum on sexual assault and harassment and strengthened its policies protecting women.
Gene Booth, executive director of the Rhode Island Commission for Human Rights, said he has been handling an increasing number of sexual harassment complaints since 1989, when the commission started keeping track of them, and that all sex discrimination cases, including harassment, now outnumbered complaints of race discrimination before the commission. He said the Thomashearings inspired an increase in inquiries not just from potential complainants, but also from men who feared they may have done something wrong and sought advice.
In dealing with female co-workers, men seem most concerned about the protocols of dating. A minority simply abstain, in part, they say, because of fear that a woman could sabotage a boyfriend's job if things don't work out. "I try to direct that energy someplace else," said Wayne Miranda, 29, a data entry clerk at Fleet National Bank. "I meet people at the laundromat and the supermarket, standing in the check-out line."
Inevitably, though, some people do mix work and courtship. When they do, the men said, they are treading more cautiously than ever.
"You try to find out her name first and a little background," said Gilbert Hackney, 33, a stockroom worker at a Macy's clearance store. "Don't rush into it. Ask her out for lunch. If she says yes, you take her out. You go back to your job for a good week or two. Give her a little time. Then ask if she would like to go out for dinner."
Wayne Gomes, 18, who works at Applebee's Neighborhood Bar and Grill with a score of other young waiters and kitchen hands, said: "It's simple. You ask, 'Do you want to go out on a date with me?' If she says no, leave your number. If she's interested, she'll call."
The old convention of asking for the woman's number could be imprudent today. "You call her," Mr. Gomes said, "and you could be harassing her on the telephone."
Some others say they limit their overtures to a single rejection, but not because of sensitivity to harassment. "It's my male ego," said Bruce DiTraglia, 40, a clerk-dispatcher who is president of a state employee union.
By contrast, Allister Greenidge, 26, the single father of two children and a worker at a telemarketing company, said persistence could pay, within limits. "A man knows when a woman's not interested," Mr. Greenidge said. "But if I see someone who might come around, I'm not afraid of her saying no. I'll work through her friend, who will tell her I'm not that bad of a guy."
 
Looking Versus Leering
 Under the new rules, men are also trying to differentiate between looking at women and leering at them. John C. Drew, 52, an insurance agent, grabs the binoculars by his desk. He lets the focus fix on women from the Rhode Island School of Design passing his office building and erupts in a hoot inaudible to the women. But he said he was appalled when construction workers jeered and whistled within sight and earshot of women passing by. "Cro-Magnons," Mr. Drew said.
Matthew Simeone, 22, a recent graduate of the University of Rhode Island and an aide at a state sewage-control commission, said: "It's acceptable to look a woman in her eyes. But looking up and down her body, that's harassment."
The rules are changing, too, in how men react to women dressed in revealing attire. "Stay away from them," advised Mr. Miranda, the data entry clerk.
In the climate of today's workplace, men here say they are reluctant to comment on the apparel for fear of provoking a complaint. "It would be harassment to say, 'That sweater looks good on you,"' Mr. Simeone said. "But I could say, 'You look nice today.' "
Mr. Gomes said he would not even say that now. "Before I would have complimented her on how nice she looked," he said. "Now I don't think I'd comment at all."
 
Terms of Address
 The men here say they are also rethinking how they address women. "A word like 'hon' becomes a friendly nickname," Mr. Miranda said. "But that can be offensive, and I stopped using it a couple of weeks ago. I'm not sure I'd like to be called that at the workplace either."
To get around salutations like "gals" and "girls," men say they try harder to learn a woman's name and use that. "For women, there's no parallel term for 'guys,' said Stephen Cohen, 23, a 1990 graduate of Wesleyan University who works at the Macy's clearance store while he looks for a more promising job. He uses names or "women."
At the law firm of Hinckley, Allen, Snyder & Comen, the use of "Mr." for the lawyers and "Miss" for secretaries disappeared as the firm started hiring female attorneys, said John Pendergast, head of the firm's labor relations team. Now most people there use first names. In today's less formal offices, honorifics seem stilted.
Some men say women hold them to a double standard. "Liberation, equal rights, that's all well and good," said Robert Hunt, 61, a newly wed construction plan review officer in the state government. "They should have that, totally," he said. "But a lot I run into say they like a guy to open the door for them, to do the gentlemanly things. That's kind of a contradiction."
In view of the contradictions, some men say a woman should let her own limits be known, rather than leave men guessing. "Let women draw the line," said Ronald Freemen, 43, a laid-off construction worker. Mr. DiTraglia, the union president, said: "Women call me 'honey' all the time, and if I call somebody 'honey,' I'm not trying to score. If a woman doesn't like it, she should turn around and say, 'Call me so-and-so.' "
Because of the scrutiny the Brown community has given harassment since the graffiti episode, men there are probably more alert than most to such things. The prevailing wisdom there, said Warren Brown, a junior, was that in addressing a group people should use language the group finds most acceptable.
Chad Nelsen, a senior, noted that being sensitized to women's concerns could serve Brown men well as they enter the workplace. "A new dynamic of our generation is we're going to work for women," Mr. Nelsen said. "You're not going to want to upset the boss."

HEADLINE: Aiding Amazon Forest Gains Support in West

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Western countries, including the United States, are becoming more favorable to the idea of a major international program to protect Amazon forests and jungles, diplomats in Bonn and Washington say.
For the last several years, the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, has been the only leader of a wealthy industrial country who has pressed the cause of rain forest preservation at international summits. As recently as last July, he sought action at the London summit of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies, but without notable success. 
 There are signs, however, that the United States may soon join the effort. Last month, the State Department sent a cable to Bonn and other capitals signalling new American interest in an ambitious Amazon project supported by Germany that could cost donor countries $1.6 billion over five years.
The project would create large Amazon reserves in which business would be restricted or banned. The $1.6 billion would be used not only to buy land and protect it, but also to find new, environmentally sound work for ranchers, farmers, prospectors, loggers and others who exploit the Amazon.
"To our great surprise, we received this memo from the Americans suggesting that they may be interested in taking part in this," said an aide to Chancellor Kohl. "Up to now, they have been very reluctant."
An official in Washington familiar with the memorandum said copies were sent to the governments of major industrialized countries.
"The United States is saying that we are going to participate in this project in some way," said the official. "We need a lot of information, because the United States is very conservative when it invests this kind of money abroad.
"There is a constituency pushing us to be more active, but we are not yet prepared to commit ourselves to one-seventh of $1.6 billion. That's a huge amount of money. What we are doing now is asking questions to people in Brazil, in Germany and in other places."
 
World Bank 'Pledge Session'
 Officials in Bonn and Washington said a World Bank meeting scheduled for December could become a "pledge session" for countries interested in protecting the Amazon. They said that outlines of a new American policy, as well as new views from Britain and others, may emerge there.
Scientists say the Amazon and other large tropical forests play an important role in keeping the world climate stable. Many believe that destruction of forests has contributed to global warming, a trend that threatens to flood low-lying regions of the world.
Environmental consciousness has grown sharply in Germany since the 1970's, when the Green Party became a force in national politics.
Some of Chancellor Kohl's critics in Bonn are skeptical of the depth of his environmental commitment.
"The trip to Brazil had a lot to do with publicity," said Liesel Hartenstein, an opposition member of Parliament. "He is giving aid to Brazil without requiring that it be administered in cooperation with native peoples, and without asking for land reform in Brazil or an end to tax subsidies for development in the forest. And he is not confronting what German companies are doing to encourage deforestation of the Amazon."

HEADLINE: Albany Deeply Divided Over Budget Gap Plans

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 6

 BODY:
As Gov. Mario M. Cuomo tonight began considering his Budget Director's plan to close the state's nettlesome budget gap, key legislators were deeply divided over their own approaches to the problem.
The lawmakers and their aides said that the Republican-controlled Senate favors closing the budget gap primarily through steep cuts in Medicaid and other social services. Members of the Democratic-controlled Assembly have begun to push a plan to restructure the state's finances over the next 18 months -- an approach that could mean both more long-term change and more gradual cuts. 
 The Governor has said that he hopes to avoid tax increases, but little else about his own approach to closing the $689 million gap in the current $30 billion general fund budget. Mr. Cuomo received a proposal from his budget staff tonight that charted a course for closing the gap. He is expected to adopt a strategy for attacking the problem by the end of the week.
 
The Presidential Question
 Mr. Cuomo has said that New York's recurring fiscal problems, and his obligation to address them, pose a major impediment to his running for President in 1992. His aides have speculated that the Governor would feel far more comfortable making the race if he could forge a quick legislative consensus around a plan to close the budget gap.
In addition to closing the gap for this fiscal year, which ends on March 31, Mr. Cuomo also wants to get a clearer reading of the expected gap in next year's budget, his aides said. If Mr. Cuomo is going to be on the campaign trail, the aides believe, he would want to use this year's deficit reduction plan to get a head start on attacking next year's problem.
Next year's budget gap is already projected at more than $2 billion by Mr. Cuomo's budget division. That number could grow quickly if the recession continues to choke the flow of tax revenues while causing rapid growth in expenditures on Medicaid and other social services.
In the absence of tax rises, it is likely that the Governor's plan will include deep cuts in the budgets of state agencies that have already been cut severely in the last 11 months. Cuomo aides said the proposal submitted by Budget Director Patrick J. Bulgaro also may include a small cut in aid to schools and cuts in social services programs.
Even before receiving a proposal from Mr. Cuomo, key legislators and their aides were skeptical today that a consensus could be forged quickly around such a plan. And the Governor conceded on a statewide television call-in show tonight that closing the budget gap "will require a lot of fighting with the Legislature."
The Assembly Democrats have suggested solving the problems of this fiscal year by restructuring the state's entire budget-making process. Under the complex plan envisioned by Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, the start of the fiscal year would be moved to July 1, and the legislature would pass a new budget in the coming months that would control state spend9ing until June 30, 1993.
By stretching out the budget, Mr. Miller's plan theoretically would soften the impact of cuts that otherwise would be needed to avoid a deficit in the current budget.
The Senate Republicans meanwhile have called for closing most of the gap with cuts in Medicaid and other expenditures on social services. "I'd like to see about $500 million of the $700 million gap closed through cuts in social services," said Senator John B. Daly, Republican of Lewiston.
Mr. Cuomo has called for containing Medicaid costs, and Mr. Miller has said there should be "no sacred cows." But Assembly leaders and aides to Mr. Cuomo believe Mr. Daly's proposal is unrealistic.
"There isn't that kind of money available in social services," said Assemblyman Saul Weprin, Democrat of Queens, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
The chasm between Mr. Daly and Mr. Weprin illustrates the difficulty of the task facing the Governor. But Mr. Weprin acknowledged that Mr. Cuomo may have added incentive this year to forge an agreement, raising the possibility that some unusual deals may be cut.
"I think he's got a great incentive to do that," Mr. Weprin said. "If he decides to run for President, he'll be able to devote his time to it."

HEADLINE: YUGOSLAV FIGHTING BREAKS CEASE-FIRE

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Croatian and Serbian forces engaged in artillery duels across the breakaway republic of Croatia today, shattering the 12th and latest European-brokered cease-fire accord less than 24 hours after it was reached.
For the second consecutive day, shells, apparently from Croatian artillery, fell on Serbian territory, hitting the town of Apatin and a village near the town of Sid. Serbian officials also asserted that Croatian forces shelled areas in the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which the pro-Serbian Yugoslav Army is using for its thrust into Croatia's eastern panhandle. 
 Artillery batteries and a naval gunboat of the pro-Serbian army blasted a major Croatian defense position and other targets around the historic town of Dubrovnik for about four hours today in what Croatian authorities called the worst bombardment in the Serbs' five-week-long siege of the town.
 
Croatian Asks for 6th Fleet
 In Zagreb today, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia called for the United States to send its Sixth Fleet into the Adriatic Sea to help stop the fighting.
"Ideally some ships from the Sixth Fleet should be sent into the Adriatic and air traffic should be blockaded just as it was in the Persian Gulf war," Mr. Tudjman said in the Croatian capital.
"These planes are striking civilian targets," Mr. Tudjman said, referring to the Yugoslav air attacks in Croatia.
European Community ministers have threatened Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, with economic and political sanctions if it does not agree to accept a peace plan by Friday. Serbia says that it will not be bullied into accepting the breakup of the country.
All five of Yugoslavia's other republics have accepted the proposal, which calls for a loose confederation of sovereign states within their present borders. Serbs oppose such a formula, saying it would create international frontiers between Serbia and many Serbs living in the other republics.
At least 2,000 people have been killed and 350,000 people have fled their homes since fighting began in Yugoslavia soon after Croatia declared itself independent on June 25.
Yugoslav warplanes rocketed the town of Daruvar today, and heavy clashes were reported in Karlovac, Pakrac and Nova Gradiska in Croatia.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Tax-Freeze Plan Needs M.A.C. Nod

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's plan to freeze property taxes for two years depends on $1 billion that has not been raised yet and might not be unless the state Municipal Assistance Corporation loosens its purse strings.
To raise the funds, the corporation would put off repaying bonds that mature over the next four years. It would refinance the bonds, extending payments through the year 2008, much like a homeowner taking out a second mortgage and getting an immediate cash windfall. 
 But Mr. Rohatyn, who is a close adviser to Governor Mario M. Cuomo, has repeatedly said he would not refinance the bonds unless the Dinkins administration satisfied him that the money would not be used merely to fill an existing gap, like paying for a wage settlement.
 
'It's a Gap Filler'
 He has insisted on a fundamental overhaul of the government that would hold down taxes and cut costs for years to come. He has hinted he would support using the M.A.C. money for priorities he holds dear -- schools and rebuilding the city's infrastructure.
But yesterday Mayor Dinkins included the $1 billion in his financial plan as "transitional funding" that would help the government avoid $500 million in property tax increases in each of the next two years, a proposal that has drawn fire from business leaders and the City Council. The Mayor's plan calls for the property tax increases to kick in again after the M.A.C. money runs out in 1995 and 1996, to the tune of about $330 million each year.
"It's a gap filler," the Mayor said of the M.A.C. money. "We can't dedicate it."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Rohatyn was cool to the idea. "If you want to take the simplest approach to this, it is borrowing money to finance a two-year tax cut," he said. "In effect, the M.A.C. money bridges over into the new taxes. Is this an appropriate use of M.A.C. funds which we have consistently indicated we felt should be an investment in the restructuring of the city and not a gap-closer?"
The $1 billion, if it is provided, would not come without a cost. While stretching out bond payments would provide the city with $1 billion in the short run, it would eventually cost taxpayers an extra $500 million in interest payments.
Several fiscal watchdogs -- including bond rating agencies and the city and state comptrollers -- yesterday questioned the wisdom of using the M.A.C. money solely to delay tax increases without assurances the sprawling government will be pared down in the long run.
"It's stetching debt so that current New Yorkers don't have to pay it but future New Yorkers do," said Ray Horton, president of the Citizen's Budget Commission.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION: The Restive Voters;
Mixed Results at Polls Show Both Parties That Status Quo Won't Satisfy the Nation

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The White House hit the panic button. The Democrats rejoiced in some states and mourned in others, and around the country the voters served notice that they are in a sour mood and that incumbents should ignore them only at their peril.
Both parties tried today to put the best face on a mixed outcome, but there were omens and alarms aplenty as the nation heads into the 1992 Presidential campaign, with the economy ailing and public attitudes bubbling on health care, race relations and taxes. 
 President Bush, who only months ago seemed headed for a stately stroll toward re-election, discovered this week that there are minefields strewn across the political landscape. The stunning Democratic victory in the Pennsylvania Senate race, and the White House's fumbling reaction to it -- canceling a trip abroad on Election Day but denying it was connected to the results -- sent a clear signal to the Republicans that their political operation needs work and their message retooling.
 
Rejecting Status Quo
 Still, this election was hardly a roaring repudiation of the party in the White House; Republicans scored sweeping gains in the New Jersey and Virginia Legislatures and defeated Ray Mabus in the Mississippi governor's race. Many analysts said the nation's electorate simply wanted something other than the status quo.
"The only good thing that happened for incumbents is the defeat of the term limit referendum in Washington," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. [Articles on the term-limit and assisted dying referendums in Washington State appear on page B16.]
Linda DiVall, his Republican counterpart, said: "Anyone who defends the status quo or gives the appearance of not paying attention to the voters is going to suffer the consequences. And whether you're talking about Mabus or Thornburgh or the New Jersey legislators, it's not enough to say here's what I did for you eight years ago or four years ago or two years ago."
 
Trial Run for Democrats
 The Pennyslvania Senate race dominated the day, much to the Republicans' chagrin, and offered some intriguing hints of the Presidential campaign to come. Harris Wofford, a Democrat appointed last summer to fill the seat left vacant by the death of Senator John Heinz, delivered a thumping defeat to former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Fresh from the Bush Cabinet, Mr. Thornburgh was informally advised by Bob Teeter, the President's poll taker and principal strategist.
Mr. Wofford talked about national health care, about the ailing economy and the need to shake up the status quo in Washington -- the very themes that many Democrats hope to use against Mr. Bush next year. Mr. Wofford ran as very much the outsider, the agent of change, and that made all the difference, analysts in both parties said.
Democrats were ecstatic, contending that Pennsylvania was a laboratory for a new message of "middle-class populism" that can carry the beleaguered party back to power, a message already being sounded by Presidential contenders like Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Mr. Teeter, while cautioning that no "broad conclusions should be drawn from off-year elections," agreed that the election showed the power of the economy and health care issues.
Mr. Wofford and other Democrats argued that the country has reached a critical mass politically on health care, comparable to the moment when it lurched forward on Social Security. But some analysts cautioned that the broad consensus for the notion of universal health care breaks down quickly when it comes to the means and the costs of providing it -- issues that were not fully explored in the Pennsylvania Senate race but could loom large in a Presidential election.
Pennsylvania could have another effect on next year's campaign: Some Democrats say it could be one more prod to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York to enter the race, one more tantalizing hint of Republican vulnerability.
 
A Chastened Bush
 The significance of Pennsylvania was only underscored by the White House's reaction to it. Even as the returns came piling in, the White House announced that Mr. Bush was canceling a scheduled trip to the Far East later this month. Democrats, who have been campaigning gleefully against Mr. Bush's travel schedule, trying to make it a symbol of his neglect of the domestic agenda, could barely contain themselves. They have been handing out T-shirts all week declaring, "George Bush went to Rome and all I got was this lousy recession."
Some Republicans were dismayed at the way the White House reacted Tuesday, which seemed to feed the perception that Mr. Bush was flummoxed by the recent turn of domestic politics, from the worsening economy to the escalating Presidential campaign. "You would have thought we had lost 26 House seats," a Republican strategist said.
Mr. Bush held a defensive news conference before departing for the meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Rome, denying that his canceled trip to Asia had anything to do with the election. But he seemed chastened, saying he understood that people were worried about the economy. "As far as I'm concerned we'll go the extra mile and we'll try even harder," he said.
For Mr. Bush, the election had to point out how much his political team has weakened since the 1988 campaign, when he could rely on James A. Baker 3d, now the Secretary of State, and Lee Atwater, who died of a brain tumor earlier this year.
 
Tax at Their Own Peril
 But Republicans were taking heart from their gains elsewhere. A year ago, as states struggled with strained budgets and all the hard decisions that requires, voters punished many of their governors at the polls; this year, they seemed to be continuing the trend, turning out Mr. Mabus, a Democrat, in Mississippi, and ventilating their discontent with state government in Virginia and New Jersey, where Republicans scored big legislative gains.
As Mr. Bush put it, "Our man in Mississippi won big, New Jersey won tremendous, blew them away in Virginia." Democratic professionals were closely watching the New Jersey results as a sign of the anti-tax sentiment generated by Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat. Frank Greer, a media consultant to Mr. Clinton, asserted, "The old style liberalism, which is to raise taxes and give money only to the poor, doesn't work."
In Mississippi, however, some Democrats, including Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserted that the Republicans prospered in part by using racially based appeals, like opposition to quotas. Clayton K. Yeutter, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, countered that the Democrats persistently cry race when they lose elections. But the Republicans, who today escalated their criticism of David Duke, the former Klansman running for governor in Louisiana, are clearly uncomfortable with the charge.
The anti-incumbent mood had its limits, of course: Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, seemed delighted to have beaten back a term limitation measure in his home state of Washington that would have cost him his job. But some analysts noted that the Washington measure was unusually strong, applying retroactively to those presently in office; they also noted that it would not have been a small thing for a state to force a Speaker of the House out of office.
But generally, the voters seemed to be in a demanding mood, and that signals that next year's Presidential campaign will be very different from that in 1984, when Ronald Reagan glided triumphantly to re-election. The economy could sharply change in the months ahead, and Mr. Bush retains enormous advantages, by virtue of the Presidency and his personal popularity.
Still, as Ms. DiVall said: "It's not morning again in America. You can't be a defender of the status quo." As the White House regroups for the 1992 campaign, this is one of the strongest signals.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 ELECTION: Election Roundup;
Wave of Voter Discontent Sweeps Many From Office

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Tuesday's elections across the country were a sharp expression of voter anger, with mixed results for Democrats and Republicans.
The Democratic Governor of Mississippi, Ray Mabus, lost to a conservative Republican businessman, and in the day's most celebrated contest, Pennsylvania's Senate race, Harris Wofford scored a major triumph for the Democrats by defeating Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General. On a local level, new people will be moving into mayor's offices in several cities. 
 "It was clearly us versus them, and them lost," said William Schneider, a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. "Underlying it all was a kind of populist discontent that took different forms in different states because they have different underlying political cultures."
In Pennsylvania, for example, Mr. Wofford's winning campaign revolved around his call for national health insurance and emergency extension of unemployment benefits.
But in Mississippi, Kirk Fordice's winning campaign -- like the platform of David Duke, who faces Edwin W. Edwards in Louisiana's gubernatorial election next week -- stressed opposition to racial quotas and criticized welfare recipients. It marked the first time since Reconstruction that a Republican won the governor's office in Mississippi.
In the view of Mr. Schneider, "it was left-wing economic populism that won in Pennslyvania," while it was "right-wing social populism" that helped Mr. Fordice.
 
Voter Anger
 In Kentucky, voter discontent may have helped Lieut. Gov. Brereton C. Jones easily defeat a seven-term Republican Congressman, Larry J. Hopkins, for the governorship. Mr. Hopkins, who received campaign help from President Bush, was hurt when it was recently revealed that he was among the lawmakers who had insufficient funds when they wrote checks on the House of Representatives bank.
Voter anger also surfaced in New Jersey, where residents furious over Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8-billion program of tax increases gave Republicans control of both houses of the State Legislature for the first time in 20 years.
Several Mayors were also victims of the mood of disenchantment. The incumbent in Houston, Kathryn J. Whitmire, finished last in a three-way race. With voters in a near frenzy over Houston's growing crime problem and jail overcrowding, her record 10-year term was ended by a developer, Bob Lanier, and State Representative Sylvester Turner.
Mr. Lanier will face Mr. Turner, who is seeking to be the first black elected Mayor of Houston, in a runoff on Dec. 3.
 
Surprise in San Francisco
 In San Francisco, Mayor Art Agnos came in a surprise second to his former chief of police, Frank Jordan, in a five-way race. Because neither won a majority, the two men will face each other in a runoff on Dec. 10.
The strength of the vote for Mr. Jordan, who garnered 31.8 percent to 27.5 percent for Mr. Agnos, was seen as an expression of voters' displeasure with what they view as a deterioration of the city and its services. Mr. Jordan ran on a tough conservative platform that criticized Mr. Agnos for failing to solve the problems of homelessness and panhandling in San Francisco.
By contrast, in two cities where the incumbents faced little serious opposition, voters re-elected their mayors, Raymond L. Flynn in Boston and Kurt Schmoke in Baltimore.
Mr. Flynn, a Democrat whose politics blend old-fashioned liberal economics with social conservatism, won 75 percent of the vote, the biggest margin ever by a Mayor of Boston. In an interview today, Mr. Flynn said that his victory, combined with the results in Pennsylvania and elsewhere, "make this election a real wake-up call both for the Congress and the President."
Mr. Schmoke in Baltimore won a second term with 72 percent of the vote after largely ignoring his Republican adversary, Samuel Culotta, a lawyer, whom he had defeated before.
But Mr. Flynn and Mr. Schmoke were exceptions in Tuesday's results, and Mr. Flynn seemed in many ways to fit the profile of what voters may be looking for, said Ralph Whitehead, a professor of journalism at the Unversity of Massachusetts. Mr. Flynn embodies the mix of "economic populism and social conservatism that is selling this year," Mr. Whitehead said.
 
Split Results
 In the two United States House races decided on Tuesday, the Democrats and Republicans split the results. In Philadelphia, Lucien Blackwell, a Democrat and former city councilman, won the seat vacated by William H. Gray 3rd, a Democrat.
In Charlottesville, Va., George F. Allen, a Republican state lawmaker and the son of the former Washington Redskins football coach, beat Katherine E. (Kay) Slaughter, a Democrat, for the seat being vacated by her cousin, D. French Slaughter Jr., a Republican.
Some significant referendum issues were also decided Tuesday. Voters in the District of Columbia approved a measure aimed at holding the makers and sellers of some assault weapons liable for the injuries and damaged those weapons cause.
In Maine, voters approved a measure that will stop the planned expansion of the southern part of the Maine Turnpike and will require the state to come up with alternatives to car and truck transportation. The measure had been opposed by Maine's Governor and most of the state's leading businesses.
Voters in St. Paul and San Francisco rejected efforts to repeal ordinances protecting the rights of homosexuals.

HEADLINE: Florio Still Firm on Some Issues, But Vows to Work With G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Giving a hint of what the next two years will be like in New Jersey government, Gov. Jim Florio pledged today to cooperate with the new Republican-controlled Legislature but said there were some issues on which he would be unyielding.
A day after Democrats suffered a devastating defeat at the polls, Mr. Florio met with reporters for an hourlong news conference during which he bristled, joked and jousted with reporters over questions about how much his economic policies and his own unpopularity contributed to the outcome. 
 "The answer is I don't know," said the Governor. "I know that there is a constituency out there that used the election as a way of saying they wanted a leadership referendum. I'm not sure that I believe that everyone who voted Republican wants everything that was done to be undone."
 
Angry Voters
 Exploiting voter anger over a $2.8 billion tax package that Mr. Florio pushed through a Legislature dominated by Democrats 16 months ago, Republicans gained a 58-to-22 majority in the General Assembly and a 27-to-13 lead in the Senate on Tuesday.
The outcome made Mr. Florio the first New Jersey governor since Richard J. Hughes, another Democrat, in 1968 to face a veto-proof opposition in both legislative houses.
Mr. Florio spent the entire day at Drumthwacket, the whitewashed Colonial mansion that serves as his official residence, where he said he took a string of telephone calls from people offering him advice, including Mr. Hughes.
"Governor Hughes called and one of the things he said was be as accommodating as you possibly can, but never walk away from your principles," Mr. Florio said.
 
No Direct Answer
 Mr. Florio invited journalists to the mansion for a midafternoon news conference, where he was inundated with questions about how much his own political problems influenced Tuesday's election. He avoided giving a direct answer, saying that it might have "motivated" some voters to vote against Democrats.
"I heard some important messages in yesterday's results," he said. "There is a sense of fear and anxiety about the future. And there is anger and pain about the present.
"Something else I hear from this election is that there is a great deal of antagonism on the part of people toward the entire political system."
The closest Mr. Florio would come to the contriteness that some of his questioners tried to draw from him was an admission that "one could always do better."
Mr. Florio said that he intended to meet as soon as possible with the new Republican legislative leadership and that he felt he shared similar goals with them.
"The people have chosen divided power," he said. "But they don't want paralyzed government. Now is the time to put politics aside and govern well. I'm prepared to do that and I'm pledged to do that."
But the Governor said he would not compromise on his support for abortion rights, his opposition to assault-style weapons and any effort to raise property taxes.
He said he would be flexible on other taxes, like an unpopular increase that raised sales taxes to 7 percent last year, from 6 percent.

HEADLINE: Yonkers Winner Benefits From Republican Split

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YONKERS, Nov. 6

 BODY:
This troubled city made a decisive break with the defiance and dissension of recent years by electing a new Democratic mayor, Terence M. Zaleski, a state Assemblyman who wants Yonkers to obey a Federal housing desegregation order.
Mr. Zaleski, 38 years old, will be the first beneficiary of a new form of government, giving him executive powers previously vested in a city manager and a longer term of office. 
 "It could be a whole new era of leadership for Yonkers," Gail S. Shaffer, New York's Secretary of State, said in an interview today.
 
'Breath of Fresh Air'
 "Terry is a breath of fresh air," added Ms. Shaffer, who also heads a state control board overseeing Yonkers's finances. "His election shows a maturation among the voters that they want to face reality and get on with the important challenges facing the city."
The victory of Mr. Zaleski, the son of a factory worker and a onetime science teacher and lawyer, came as something of a surprise to this sprawling town of 188,000 in southern Westchester County, New York State's fourth biggest city.
Many thought that a former Mayor, Angelo R. Martinelli, would make a political comeback on the strength of his name recognition, union backing and charisma. Mr. Martinelli, a Republican, ran on the Independent line, preaching compliance with the housing order.
Others here bet that the moderate positions of Mr. Zaleski and Mr. Martinelli on the housing question would divide voters, giving the lead to Peter A. Chema, a Republican City Councilman and a strong foe of the subsidized housing. But instead, Republican voters seemed to split between Mr. Martinelli and Mr. Chema.
Another factor was Mr. Zaleski's campaign performance. The three-term Assemblyman asserted himself in the primary by purging the entrenched leadership of the city's Democratic Party, which he labeled a "meddlesome political machine."
 
Call for Professionalism
 Mr. Zaleski hammered away at a single theme throughout his campaign: professionalism in a city government beset by economic woes and a growing crime rate.
Implicit in that campaign theme was a commitment to comply with a Federal judge's order to build subsidized housing in white neighborhoods. That order followed a 1986 ruling by Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan that Yonkers was guilty of four decades of segregation in housing and education.
The court-ordered housing remedy, calling for 200 units of public housing on the mostly white east side and another 800 middle-income apartments, angered many residents. In the summer of 1988, as city officials defied Judge Sand and incurred huge fines for contempt of court, Yonkers was pushed to the edge of bankruptcy.
Since then, as the housing program inched forward, the city has filed lawsuit after lawsuit challenging the desegregation order.
Though Mr. Zaleski said he always opposed the housing order, he felt it should be obeyed after it was upheld by the United States Supreme Court. Perhaps most important in this election was the simple fact that the public housing -- the most dreaded part of the desegregation order -- is now mostly built.
"The bitter end is already here," Mr. Zaleski said before the election. "The experience over the last few years has shown the futility of banging our heads against the wall. People are tired of the issue and want it resolved."
 
An Unresolved Issue
 Still to be resolved is the affordable-housing component of the order. Judge Sand has agreed to consider alternatives to the 800 units since few developers have expressed interest in the undertaking. Mr. Zaleski has said he wants to bring all parties together to devise a mutually acceptable plan. In addition, he said, he will try to make the "low-income units succeed so they don't create enclaves."
For the last two years, Henry J. Spallone, who was more defiant of the housing order than any elected official here, occupied the Mayor's office. He failed to stop the public housing, and largely because of that failure, lost his bid for the nomination in the Republican primary.
Mr. Spallone's singular focus on fighting the desegregation order practically paralyzed Yonkers when it came to other issues such as the struggling public school system, stagnant economic development, rising crime and troubled city finances.
At a news conference today, Mr. Zaleski vowed to tackle those issues immediately. He said he had already been in touch with Ms. Shaffer to discuss a $110 million revenue shortfall in the four-year financial plan submitted by the previous administration to the state Emergency Financial Control Board.

HEADLINE: Empty Offices Offer Guide To the Region

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
There are enough empty offices across the New York metropolitan area to fill 15 World Trade Centers, according to some experts. Planners, real-estate executives and local officials say the shape and health of the region are likely to be defined largely by the way those offices fill up -- or fail to fill up -- when and if an economic recovery begins.
Company choices about whether to locate in New York City, in the downtowns of cities like Stamford or White Plains or in the suburban office parks that sprouted across the region in the 1980's are likely to influence not only the vitality of Manhattan but also the quality of life throughout the metropolitan area. 
 "The future of the region for the next decade will be determined to a significant extent by which office space rents first," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association.
The association, the dominant private planning group in the New York area and for decades the source of influential planning concepts, estimates that there are 60 million square feet of vacant office space in Manhattan, 50 million square feet in northern New Jersey and 15 million square feet in southwest Connecticut. Which of those vacancies might rent first in a recovery is especially difficult to predict because of the combination of a slow economy now and an office inventory that many experts say could take 10 years to fill.
 
The Goal: Simply Renting
 That office glut interrupted trends of the 1980's that included both a dispersal of office rentals throughout the region and a healthy office market in Manhattan. The stimulus for new office rentals would come from the types of businesses that would revive first and fastest; no one knows which businesses those are.
For local planners, any effort to channel office growth has become a luxury. In Westchester, for example, planners have long sought to encourage office rentals in White Plains' rehabilitated downtown, which competes with office parks along nearby Route 287. But Patricia Lynn Oliva, Westchester County's Acting Commissioner of Planning, said that because of the economy, officials are eager to bring business anywhere into the county.
Because so much is affected by where people work and how they commute, some experts say, housing, transportation, the environment and a host of other regional concerns are at stake. "The recovery will tell you where you are going in the region," said David Shulman, who analyzes the real-estate market for Salomon Brothers.
Office rental patterns could multiply some of the region's current problems -- traffic jams, for example, or air pollution -- by increasing the number of people who drive to work.
And some experts say office-leasing patterns could accelerate changes in the quasi-urban centers developing in the suburbs and stretch the borders of the metropolitan area, sending people farther afield for affordable housing. That could speed the evolution of what will probably amount to a single densely populated metropolis ranging from eastern Pennsylvania across New Jersey and much of eastern New York State into Connecticut.
The decisions made in the early stages of recovery promise to have such an impact on the region because the office vacancy rate rose to nearly 20 percent in much of the area after the office building frenzy of the 1980's collided with the recession. In all, nearly 150 million square feet of office space may be vacant across the metropolitan area, according to the Regional Plan Association.
More than a third of that, or 60 million square feet, is outside the area's old downtowns. Much of it is along overburdened thoroughfares like the Long Island Expressway, Route 1 in New Jersey and Route 287 in Westchester. In some cases, the vacant buildings are isolated in the middle of what were once cornfields.
Some planners are sounding a traditional alert, warning that it is crucial to foster centralization by keeping offices in the region's old downtown business districts instead of scattering them among comparatively remote office campuses and roadside sites. Concentration, they say, is the only way to revitalize urban centers and insure the efficiency of public transportation and such services as sewer, water and electric lines.
 
Revitalizing Urban Centers
 "If the dispersed office locations are filled initially, it will create more traffic congestion in an already overburdened system and lead to environmental and social consequences that the region is not prepared to deal with," said Mr. Anderson of the Regional Plan Association.
Some of those studying office vacancies as a key to the future say the planners have already lost their war to keep the region's business life centered in its old downtowns. Others note that New York City received more than a quarter of the jobs created in the region during the 1980's, though it had received only about a tenth of those created during the 1950's and 1960's.
No one now knows whether that pattern would continue in a recovery, filling offices faster in Manhattan, or whether the growth would take place in the region's other downtowns, in suburban office parks or in former cornfields. As the economy slowed, rental prices fell across the region and vacancy rates climbed, setting the stage for fierce competition as owners compete for tenants.
Asking prices for office rentals on Park Avenue in Manhattan, for example, fell to $44 a square foot in June 1991, from $52 a square foot in June 1990, according to the Edward S. Gordon Company, a corporate real-estate consultant.
 
How to Structure the Sprawl
 In the Morristown area of New Jersey, the suburban area that is home to more than a dozen Fortune 500 companies, 22.66 percent of about 3.31 million square feet of high-quality offices are "available," according to the Gordon Company. In the area of the New Jersey Meadowlands, 35.14 percent of about 5.48 million square feet is available, and in the Newark area the availability rate is 15.96 percent of about 2 million square feet of high-quality space.
Even many of those who say they believe the area's old downtowns will hold their own in a recovery say that a crucial issue is how to structure the office sprawl that now has many more people commuting between suburbs than from the suburbs into New York City.
After World War II, about half of Long Island's wage earners commuted to Manhattan, according to the Long Island Regional Planning Board. Now, the board says, 86 percent of them work on Long Island.
 
'Put the Genie Back?'
 Whatever the planners' hopes, some experts say, market forces created the office vacancies and market forces will dictate where and when offices fill up. That, some of them say, means that in the vast swath across New Jersey, New York City's northern suburbs and southern Connecticut, a new growth spurt propelled by the leasing of empty offices is inevitable. Even if downtown offices rent proportionately as well as those in outlying areas, some experts say, there are now so many offices dispersed across the region that a recovery will spur the region's sprawl.
Christopher J. Dunleavy, the executive director of the Orange County Chamber of Commerce in New York, said that trend had been established over generations. Now, he said, the issue is, "Do we try to put the genie back in the bottle or do we try to manage the problem?"
Some experts said that the broad outlines of the region's future were already clear and that new office rentals would simply continue to increase density across the region. In "Edge City," a new book that has become influential in planning circles, Joel Garreau, a Washington Post reporter, argues that new quasi-urban centers are forming on the edges of New York and other old big cities across the country. These edge cities, Mr. Garreau says, offer much of what people wanted in old downtowns, including jobs, transplanted to what was once known as suburbia.
The first criterion that Mr. Garreau uses in determining whether a new center is becoming an edge city is whether it has at least 5 million square feet of leasable office space, about half as much as the World Trade Center. In the New York region, he has identified 17 such places, from the Princeton corridor along Route 1 in New Jersey to the Westport area along Interstate 95 in Connecticut.
Planners in some of the edge cities say they are acutely aware that new office rentals will bring a host of new problems.
 
New Rentals, New Problems
 Marvin R. Reed, the Mayor of Princeton Borough in New Jersey, said he feared a vast expansion of the gridlock that now seizes Route 1 during rush hours. New office rentals along the highway, he said, would mean that "the time within which Princeton people would not be able to, in effect, get out of their town would dramatically expand."
"It is not in our interest to foster this in and around us," Mr. Reed said. "It would be much better if it was focused down toward New Brunswick and Trenton."
Some planners say they fear that filling empty offices will be destructive to communities. Traditionally, they say, suburban centers have encouraged office construction as a clean form of industry that draws new residents and spurs housing construction. But many communities have found that such housing is affordable only to top executives. Potential employees from central cities find the new jobs inaccessible, and the largest number of employees, those at the middle and lower levels, must travel long distances to find affordable homes.
In Morris County, N.J., for example, a revival of the office market is likely to drive more and more employees to eastern Pennsylvania in search of housing, said Carol J. Rufener, the executive director of Morris 2000, a planning agency. That, she said, will extend the sprawl of the metropolitan area.
 
Where to Live?
 And the long commuting trips that sprawl creates are likely to leave employees feeling dissatisfied, Ms. Rufener said, because they cannot participate in community activities like baseball leagues and political parties. "When they're commuting and hour and a half each way," she said, "it's harder for them to have a sense that they're from anywhere." That sort of alienation, Ms. Rufener warned, could spur more corporations to abandon the metropolitan area entirely.
The first sign of a dramatic change in the regional office market, the experts say, will be like the starting gun in a race. Much about that race cannot be foreseen, they say. But some things are certain, some of them say, despite efforts spurred by the Regional Plan Association and others in recent months to foster regional economic cooperation. The office rental race, some of those in the field say, is likely to reignite rivalries as old as the region.
"Are we going to compete with the City of New York? Absolutely," said Lee Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
The Manhattan developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman said: "You have to worry about Princeton, White Plains. You have to worry about all the suburban locations."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Woos Rohatyn's Aid On Budget Gap

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Striving to win support for his handling of New York City's fiscal problems, Mayor David N. Dinkins pledged yesterday to shrink government and to freeze property taxes for two years by using $1 billion in aid from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to tide him over to better times.
But the chairman of the Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, said he was not yet persuaded that the Mayor's plans were anything more than borrowing from the future to cover current costs. And a major Wall Street credit rating agency, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said that "at first glance, the proposals fall short of a structural change in city finances and operations." 
 Mr. Dinkins has been seeking the $1 billion from the Assistance Corporation for months, but yesterday was the first time he outlined how he would spend it. The announcement appeared aimed primarily at gaining the approval of Mr. Rohatyn, the Governor, state fiscal monitors and Wall Street.
Submitting a five-year fiscal blueprint to the State Financial Control Board, Mr. Dinkins said the Assistance Corporation money would give the city time to bring its spending and revenues into line without the need to increase property taxes until 1995, when he would raise them by $330 million. He would cut 16,400 full-time jobs from the quarter-million now on the city payroll through attrition.
He included no money for pay increases for municipal employees through June 1994 but said he would negotiate raises in exchange for concessions to make workers more productive -- agreements that have eluded him for months.
His plan to balance the budget also rests on highly uncertain new revenues, including gasoline taxes or auto use fees, that require approval by a State Legislature that has long resisted them. The Mayor also said he would press Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature to enact the partial takeover of the city's Medicaid costs that the Governor has proposed.
Mr. Dinkins was required to submit the plan to the State Control Board, which was set up to monitor the city's finances in the last fiscal crisis and could reimpose binding powers over its spending if the budget fell out of balance. In the coming weeks, the board, headed by Governor Cuomo, will review the plan, and Mr. Rohatyn has said he would want the board's assurances that the plan is balanced before making the Assistance Corporation money available.
Yesterday, the board's executive director, Allen J. Proctor, said he could not comment until he had reviewed the proposal in detail. If Mr. Rohatyn refused to give the $1 billion, the Control Board would undoubtedly say the Mayor's plan was unbalanced should he try to include it.
Even as he outlined his long-term plans, the Mayor said the city faced a gap of about $210 million in the current $28.5 billion budget, which runs through June 30. His aides said they would close it primarily by cutting the purchase of supplies. For next year, the city estimates, there will be a gap of $1.2 billion and annual gaps of about $2 billion in the following three years.
Mr. Dinkins said the work force reductions would mean more pain for New Yorkers used to round after round of budget cuts the last two years, but he said he could not quantify them. And his aides said it was too soon to project agency-by-agency breakdowns of where the trims would fall. Since the Mayor pledged to maintain his ambitious police hiring program, it appeared inevitable that programs from parks to libraries to health care that have aleady taken deep cuts would be hit again.
The City Council and business organizations, which have sought a tax freeze, generally praised the Mayor's plan, with the New York Chamber of Commerce calling it a "welcome outline."
 
Serious Reservations
 But if the main pitch was to Mr. Rohatyn, it fell short. He could provide the $1 billion by refinancing -- stretching out payments on some of the corporation's bonds -- freeing city sales tax revenues that would otherwise be needed to make payments on them. The Mayor would use that money in the 1993 and 1994 fiscal years -- just as he would be running in what is expected to be a tough re-election campaign -- to avoid the $500 million property tax increases that he had previously planned.
Yesterday, while approving the broad outlines of the the Mayor's plan, Mr. Rohatyn said he had serious reservations about its reliance on what would amount to money borrowed from future taxpayers to plug holes in the city's operating budget, without assurances that the city would improve efficiency.
"It certainly would appear that the city is essentially using the M.A.C. funds to close budget gaps in lieu of real-estate taxes," said Mr. Rohatyn, who has urged the city to freeze taxes. "I think that would be a real problem for us. I think it will be a problem for the rating agencies, too."
Wall Street credit rating agencies have threatened to reduce the city's bond rating, forcing it to pay millions more in interest, if it relies too much on "one shot" revenues. Yesterday, Standard & Poor's said it needed more information before judging the city's plan when the Mayor submits his preliminary budget in January for the fiscal year that starts on July 1.
Standard & Poor's repeated its warning that without other cost-saving or revenue proposals, using the M.A.C. money for a tax freeze "would be little more than deficit financing" of the sort that has been forbidden since the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
"They have a lot of homework between now and January," said Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's. "But the requirement for homework has been out there for a couple of years. I expected more progress."
Anticipating such criticism, the administration sought to accommodate others whose support will be vital to put political pressure on Mr. Rohatyn to cooperate. For example, it adopted the Council's calls to freeze taxes and dropped the idea of placing tolls on the East River bridges that are now free, and it pledged to explore a range of other pet ideas of the Council.
In return, the Mayor won a warm, and rare, tentative endorsement from the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who congratulated the Mayor "for making a fundamental shift in his approach to fiscal recovery and for taking many significant steps that the Council and others hav suggested as ways to improve this city's economic health."

HEADLINE: A Traveling Showroom Of Design

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
Hot dogs and ice cream -- this is the stuff usually sold from vans on the street. But next week, architects and designers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut can order wood cabinets handpainted to resemble chestnut, iridescent silks to cover sofas and rolls of wallpaper -- from a van.
The 27-foot van is painted hunter green with "David Parrett and Associates" in gold lettering. Mr. Parrett, who represents eight manufacturers of home furnishings, has modernized the idea of the traveling salesman. Outfitted with cabinets painted faux chestnut, silk curtains, a damask-covered loveseat, a television, a videocassette recorder, a phone and a refrigerator filled with cold drinks, the van is Mr. Parrett's answer to the recession: a showroom on wheels. 
Mr. Parrett used to take books of wallpaper and fabric samples and catalogues of cabinetry to clients' offices. "Business was tightening two years ago," he said, "and I wanted to make a more professional presentation in a controlled environment. If somebody pulls up to your office and you spend one hour with him instead of spending a whole day in Manhattan showrooms, you, as a designer, have made better use of your time."
Mr. Parrett ordered the van in March and it was delivered in June. He has filled it with wallpaper and fabric samples and furniture, at a total cost of $60,000.
Inside, it looks like a living room, decorated mainly in shades of cream accented with black. The wallpaper, from Osborne & Little, is printed with black laurel wreaths on a cream background. An easy chair is covered in a cotton fabric that features a black leaf on a pale gold ground.
Smallbone, an English cabinet manufacturer, built the cabinets, two painted faux chestnut and one in stippled bamboo. Smallbone's artisans will go to a client's house and paint the cabinetry to suit the owner.
"We even painted cabinets to match someone's china pattern," said Jacqueline Scott, vice president of sales and marketing of Smallbone, which has a showroom in Manhattan. She designed the interior of the van in collaboration with Linda Banks, an architect in Norwalk, Conn.
Before Mr. Parrett takes to the road, hoping eventually to reach 600 architects and designers, he will add a desk and a compact disk player.
What music will he be playing, as he drives through the three states?
"Classical," Mr. Parrett said. "I prefer Bach." For information, call (201) 635-5545.

HEADLINE: Fate Orphans The News

 BODY:
Robert Maxwell died in the Canary Islands early enough on Tuesday for his thunderstruck employees at New York's Daily News to honor his memory with exemplary coverage and comment. The timing was their only consolation.
Still recovering from a calamitous five-month strike, The News was only beginning to bounce back when it was struck twice by fate. Two weeks ago its new managing editor, John Cotter, died just before he was to begin work. And now its new British owner has perished in circumstances as improbable as his astonishing rise to riches. 
 It will take weeks for the mists to lift on the future of Mr. Maxwell's communications empire. But few doubted his commitment to The Daily News. Inevitably, there is the uncertainty of succession, compounded by billions of dollars in corporate debts.
"Ford to City: Drop Dead" snapped the celebrated News headline when Gerald Ford shrugged off New York's financial crisis in 1975. Now the paper contends with providential instead of Presidential disfavor. Yet anyone visiting The Daily News's offices yesterday encountered professional calm, not despair. "It's one more thing," remarked a composed Ellis Cose, the editorial page editor. "We'll fight the good fight."
Mr. Maxwell was, as The News said, "a titan in the old style." The offspring of Czech Jews who died at Auschwitz, he made a new life in Britain, won a Labor seat in Parliament and implausibly teased a fortune from scientific publications.
However demanding he may have been with his subordinates, and whatever the truth about controversies that engulfed him -- including the recent charge that he secretly worked with Israeli intelligence -- Mr. Maxwell's zest for life and combat was exhilarating. That spirit may be his most precious legacy to a much-beleaguered, suddenly orphaned Daily News staff.
