HEADLINE: Mr. Dinkins's Vague Virtue

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins of New York yesterday offered up a new financial plan. Plan is an overstatement. The proposal makes painfully clear how much work he and his advisers have ahead.
This is a well-intentioned effort that continues to cut the work force. Recognizing the need to send a sympathetic message to recession-weary taxpayers, it calls for a two-year freeze on property taxes. But so many details are sketchy, missing or left to the future that no precise judgment is possible. Fortunately, the Mayor has time to turn this preliminary effort into a detailed blueprint by January, when his next financial plan is due. 
The most heartening aspect of the proposal is that it reveals his willingness to change his mind and hold the line on property taxes rather than plug future deficits with repeated tax increases. New Yorkers have already taken two tax jolts in two years. In place of taxes, the city plans to close deficits by restructuring and by relying on $1 billion from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
Both sources of money are questionable. Spending the M.A.C. money in two years would allow the city to avoid tax increases. But then what? Without credible commitments for new revenues and savings, spending money amounts to relying on one-shot revenues. It comes perilously close to deficit financing.
What is the restructuring that's supposed to save money? The Mayor presents a menu of options of varying plausibility. Some, like increasing the gas tax 5 to 15 cents, require action from a resistant State Legislature. Others aren't even spelled out, like "other user fees directly related to the transportation network."
The proposal fudges even more on work force reductions. It claims to cut 26,000 jobs over five years, but that includes part-time workers who are not in the official head count, and jobs not even financed by the city. The actual proposed reduction in full-time workers totals only 16,400. And all those would come from attrition, a humane but dubious technique for targeting agency cuts. Missing are any details on how many jobs the Mayor would cut from each agency; that makes it impossible to judge the impact on services.
Missing, too, is a sense of what reforms the Mayor wants from city unions. He says the unions will not get raises without gains from efficiencies and concessions that he has so far failed to extract from them despite months of trying. Nor does he specify which efficiencies and concessions would satisfy him.
Mr. Dinkins has provided an outline of where he wants the city government to go in the next two years of his administration. But it's not yet a plan.

HEADLINE: The Voters Said: What About Us?

 BODY:
Remarkable results. The Democrats got pounded in New Jersey. A nationally known Republican got pounded in Pennsylvania. Different states, different circumstances, different losers. But there was the hint of a common thread: Americans, particularly all those who think of themselves as the middle class, feel they're stuck on dead center. They're dismayed by stagnant incomes, a drifting economy and unresponsive government.
In New Jersey, where Republicans seized control of both houses of the legislature for the first time in 20 years, voters rose up against a Governor who had raised their taxes but, in their view, delivered little in return. 
 In Pennsylvania they defeated Dick Thornburgh, who was President Bush's Attorney General. They voted instead for a Democrat, Harris Wofford, who spoke directly to their personal economic concerns, including unemployment and the cost of health care. In both states, the margins were big.
These outcomes appear to be less the result of specific anger directed at incumbents than of general dismay about policy. True, the New Jersey vote was a severe slap at Gov. Jim Florio, who rammed through a $2.8 billion tax increase last year. True, Pennsylvania voters may have been penalizing Mr. Thornburgh for his connections to the nation's most visible incumbent, the man in the White House.
Yet the larger message was frustration. The voters of New Jersey, for example, might have been more forgiving of Mr. Florio's tax policies had they sensed any improvement in their own lot. Like most Americans, their after-tax incomes have gone virtually nowhere since 1973, and real disposable income is actually lower than it was when Mr. Florio -- and Mr. Bush, for that matter -- took office. Housing and medical care costs have risen, and for many families, two incomes are essential just to keep up.
Mr. Wofford exploited this point, blaming Mr. Bush and Mr. Thornburgh for the country's economic woes and -- much like the Republicans in New Jersey -- portraying himself as the last true friend of the middle class. It was to them that he pitched his tantalizing but distressingly vague promises of jobs, tax cuts and health insurance.
The Wofford victory has alarmed Republican strategists, and on Tuesday the President canceled a two-week tour of the Far East later this month. Mr. Bush may finally be hearing what the polls have been suggesting for weeks: However admirable his achievements abroad, he appears singularly inattentive to problems at home. That's probably the most important message the voters sent Tuesday; he better be listening.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Cuomo and Wofford

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
If Mario Cuomo decides to run for President -- a question not yet settled in his mind -- he almost certainly will not resign as Governor of New York, even though he would feel it necessary to wage time-consuming campaigns in most state primaries.
Mr. Cuomo is "very close" to a decision that he will not quit as Governor even if he enters the Presidential race. After nine years in office, and facing "the hardest part" of his tenure -- the state's and New York City's deficit problems -- he cannot "imagine dropping it here and saying there's something more important." 
 The question is a crucial part of the Governor's larger decision, because he stayed out of the 1988 Presidential race largely on grounds that he could not both govern New York and wage a strong national campaign. Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, the 1988 Democratic nominee, is widely considered to have been handicapped, moreover, by his dual role and responsibilities in an election year.
Mr. Cuomo is not considering the possibility that he might retain the Governor's office and enter only a few selected state primaries -- such as those in New York and California. This strategy would be "offensive" to voters, in his opinion, since other candidates would be entered in most of the state contests; if he did not do so, he might be thought to be seeking "special rules" for himself.
Besides, a number of the state primaries take place early in 1992 -- "a whole bunch of them" in a brief period in March. It's at least possible that the outcome of the nomination race will be determined then -- well before the California and other primaries.
In explaining some of the pros and cons he is weighing, Mr. Cuomo did not mention the smashing victory of another Democratic liberal, Harris Wofford, in the Pennsylvania senatorial race -- though that event could hardly be absent from his deliberations. Pennsylvania has numerous blue-collar voters and Democrats who defected to Ronald Reagan and George Bush; so Mr. Wofford's aggressive campaign and his defeat of former Governor and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh encouraged the idea that President Bush also might be vulnerable in 1992.
The Pennsylvania upset seems to teach Democrats at least two lessons. One is that they need to "set the agenda" next year, as Mr. Wofford did in making national health insurance and economic recovery the dominant issues; the other, related lesson is that the Democratic Presidential nominee should press an attack on Mr. Bush on these and other popular questions, and not allow him or herself to be forced on the defensive.
Mr. Wofford's campaign could be seen to be catching fire in recent weeks; so his victory was not the most surprising result of the 1991 elections. That distinction goes to the defeat, in Washington State, of a radical measure to limit the terms of state and Federal legislators; the limitations, if approved, would have been retroactive, so that the state's entire Congressional delegation would have had to step down in 1994.
Pre-election polls had suggested that 60 percent of Washington's voters favored term limitation; but after a strong opposition campaign by Speaker Tom Foley and others, the proposition lost by about 54 to 46 percent. This decisive setback seems bound to restrain what had appeared to be a rising political tide that might have had term-limitation measures on the ballot in about 17 states next year. Some form of term limitation already has been approved in Oklahoma, California, Colorado and several municipalities.
Opponents of term limitation, in Washington and elsewhere, have argued that this drastic step would shift power to the executive branch (nationally and in the states), throw out good legislators with bad, restrict the freedom of voters to choose and retain officeholders they like. Some think the movement represents, at root, a Republican effort to break the Democrats' hold on Congress and state legislatures.
The Washington result also suggests something less frequently mentioned -- that term limitation would shift Congressional power from small states to large. A small state often wields outsize power because one of its House members serves at length and becomes chairman of a committee. That would not be likely under term limitation, throwing Congressional power to the sheer numbers of large state delegations.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Great Reshuffle

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The Great Reshuffle is under way in the lives of nations. The Era of Political Dissolution is overlapping the Age of Economic Reassembly.
Political imperialism is on the wane. Russia is spinning off its losing acquisitions; Yugoslavia is breaking up bloodily, Czechoslovakia amicably; the Quebecers may part from Canadians and Scots quit Brits. 
 At the same time, economic unionism is waxing. In Asia, the flying tigers of trade are sitting down with the old lions; in North America, the Canadians and Mexicans are coming to see themselves as eco-Americans; and in Europe, you can hardly hear the rumble of political disintegration for the screeching of economic amalgamation.
Here is a quick way to encapsulate the Great Reshuffle: Politics is zigging while economics is zagging.
The zigging is good: with the breakup of empires, the end of statist Communism and the breaking of forced contracts binding different cultures, we are getting more personal freedom and a greater sense of the control of national destiny. Smaller nations, each speaking one language and proud of its special character, are more responsive than centrally controlled monoliths, provided new majorities respect minority rights.
The zagging, provided it is limited to the extension of economic freedom, is good too. Free-trade zones with tariffs no longer hindering trade should expand business horizons, increasing jobs and raising the standard of living. The three great trading communities (America, Europe, the Far East) will -- if good sense prevails -- agree to compete fairly, with the world's capitalist socks held up by the happy garter of price elasticity.
Then why, in the midst of the greatest forward thrust in two centuries of world history, all the grim faces and sour looks? Because in the zigging away from empire, there is concern about healthy nationalism's flip side of ethnic repression and local war; and in the zagging toward regional confederation, there is worry about getting free trade confused with imperialism under a new banner.
Here in Britain, fatherland of individualism and fond ally of its American colony, the fear is that the rush to European commercial union may involve a transfer of political power to French statist bureaucrats, as well as a loss of the Atlantic connection that has helped preserve its liberty.
Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, on the eve of British embrace of greater economic union with Europe, has denounced the intrusion of the Continentals into the "nooks and crannies" of a proudly independent culture: Brits don't like Brussels bureaucrats dictating environmental standards to British road builders and soft-drink bottlers.
That's only the beginning of resistance to union; the pressure by the European Commission leader, Jacques Delors, to adopt a single currency with Bonn bankers deciding London interest rates is being called "Delorean" (a play on the name of the failed auto maker), and his notion of a United States of Europe is looking less appealing all the time.
Now we're at the spot where the zigging intersects the zagging. Economic interdependence is helpful only as long as it does not impinge on political independence; then free trade begins to bother free people.
Which force is greater -- the trend toward economic union or the march to political self-determination? Extreme Eurocrats say the train of amalgamation is leaving the station, and point to how the newly independent nations of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet union are eager to join, thereby creating a superstate of over 500 million.
I think the Brits will go part of the way, linking currencies, but not all the way, linking their national life to the French and Germans. Less is to be gained on the swings of prosperity than is to be lost on the roundabouts of restriction.
As economic bureaucrats overreach, political sovereignty will be reasserted; in the end, a common language and set of values forges a nation's identity and determines its decisions.
The tug-o'-peace between those two forces -- zigging to political freedom, zagging to economic interdependence -- will shape the politics of the runup to the millennium. Neither need totally win, but in the end, the yearning for political freedom will dominate the desire for economic security.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New Mayor in Bridgeport Faces the Same Old Problems

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Joseph P. Ganim presented himself to this troubled city's voters as a sort of anti-matter alternative to the incumbent Mayor, Mary C. Moran: what she was, he was not, and vice versa.
Where Ms. Moran was hot-tempered, impetuous and difficult to get along with -- traits that many residents in this tough-minded city still admire -- Mr. Ganim said he would be a cool, decisive coalition builder. Ms. Moran, he charged, had dragged the city down over her two-year term and made it a symbol of urban failure with a bankruptcy filing that drew national headlines. He promised that he would make Connecticut's largest city great again, first of all by making it safe. One hundred new police officers would be added to the force. 
 The strategy worked. Mr. Ganim, a 32-year-old Democrat in a heavily Democratic city, won 54 percent of the vote on Tuesday and took the 58-year-old Ms. Moran's job.
But as different as the two candidates seemed during the campaign, Mr. Ganim is now poised to begin traveling much the same road that led his predecessor to see bankruptcy as a desirable option. Bridgeport, the only municipality in Connecticut that has its finances supervised by a state panel, is under a state order to raise its property taxes by 18 percent to fill a $16 million gap in the budget for the year that began on July 1.
 
Taxes and Promises
 Ms. Moran simply said she would not do it. If resisting the order meant a public feud with Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and a prolonged bankruptcy court battle, well, then that was simply one of the costs.
Mr. Ganim, while arguing that bankruptcy is not the answer, also thinks the tax increase is unnecessary. And he has some expensive campaign promises to deliver on. The new police officers will cost an estimated $5 million a year, on top of the already existing budget gap.
He said today in an interview in his law office that he had spoken with Mr. Weicker on the telephone and that the two men had promised to try to get along. But the same stumbling block remains: The state review panel has not revoked its order to raise taxes here, and the chief executive-elect says he does not think he will have to raise them.
"I believe taxes will stay stable," Mr. Ganim said.
Residents are bracing for a continuing rocky road.
"The taxes will go up," said Grace Moran, co-owner of CAS News, a convenience store in the city's north end. "He's got to get the money from somewhere."
Ms. Moran, who is no relation to the departing Mayor, was robbed at gunpoint a few years ago and heartily endorses Mr. Ganim's law-and-order platform. The store next to hers has been vacant for more than two years, and she now sells self-defense "pepper gas" from a display next to the cash register. Higher taxes, as hard as they may be on struggling businesses, may be worth it, she said, if crime can be brought under control.
 
View From the Bottom
 Other residents say whatever Mr. Ganim does, things are so bad now that it could look like progress.
"How much worse can they get? We're already bankrupt," said Rich Deaguila, a truck driver who voted for Mr. Ganim.
But crime and unemployment also go only so far as issues in a mostly blue-collar city that has long enjoyed a reputation as a place where politics is no fun unless someone howls in pain. Mayor Moran, for whatever else she achieved or did not, certainly knew how to bruise people. In her concession speech on Tuesday night she called the vote "Bridgeport's loss." She did not return calls to her office today.
Some people said that Mr. Ganim, who has never before served in public office, will have to learn fast how to be mean or he won't last at all.
Mr. Ganim received 15,768 votes to 10,951 for Ms. Moran and 2,258 shared between two minor party candidates.
In Waterbury, voters also threw out the incumbent mayor, Joseph J. Santopietro, who came in last in a three-way race, behind even a third-party independent candidate who had never run for public office before. The voters there returned former Mayor Edward D. Bergin, a Democrat, to the office he held nine years from the mid-1970's to the mid-1980's.
Mr. Santopietro was indicted earlier this year by a Federal grand jury on corruption charges. He pleaded not guilty and told voters he could continue his duties as mayor while fighting to stay out of jail. He received only 6,635 votes out of 32,496 votes cast.
In Hartford, Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry, a Democrat, ran unopposed, while in New Haven, the state's third-largest city, Mayor John C. Daniels was re-elected to a second term. He is that city's first black chief executive.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph P. Ganim, center, who was elected mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., at his headquarters yesterday with some of his campaign workers. (David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Growth Amid Blight: Uneasy Worlds Coexist

SERIES: Life at the Bottom; Mott Haven, the Bronx -- Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
David Lee has a collection of bullet shells that he picks up on the way to his knitwear factory in the morning. Stephen Mayo occasionally has to step around crack vials that collect in front of his office-products factory during the weekend. Lenny Gamss notes with bemusement that the free coffee he provides customers at his hardware store is often enjoyed by prostitutes on their way to work around the corner.
These are just some of the ways that local business people -- pioneers, really -- have learned to accommodate themselves to the torn landscape. For myriad reasons -- the lure of $3-a-square-foot rents, historical happenstance or transportation needs -- they have staked their capitalist claims in and around Mott Haven, one of the poorest neighborhoods in one of the poorest places in New York, the South Bronx. 
 At first glance, Mott Haven is the stuff that movies are made of. Drug dealers hawk their wares openly, store windows display bullet holes from shootings, children mill about, surrounded by addicts and prostitutes who are often their parents.
But look deeper, and Mott Haven is actually the uneasy intersection of two worlds: a fractured social-welfare state, and an unlikely experiment in economic development. Between them lie several pressing questions: How well can businesses adapt and thrive in such a seemingly hostile environment? Can economic development translate into help for a community where half the residents are estimated to be unemployed and the median family income is just $7,600? And what role should government play in bringing the two worlds together?
Virtually the only commercial activity in Mott Haven takes place on a two-block stretch of 138th Street. There, one can buy inexpensive household goods at Woolworth's, shoes at Fayva or fast food from Blimpie's. Yet one short block away, at 139th and Brook Avenue, lies what the police have identified as one of the most active drug-dealing spots in the city.
The "above ground" business exists in part because of the government-financed safety net. After all, Mott Haven contains one of the three largest concentrations of public housing in the city; housing projects, as well as renovated apartments and shelters for hundreds of formerly homeless families. About half of the residents living in the area are estimated to receive some form of government assistance.
 
'A Social Welfare State'
 Such a dense population of residents with guaranteed incomes, albeit small ones, translates into business opportunity for some. When asked where the money comes from to support retail stores in the area, Mr. Gamss, the hardware store owner, shrugged and said, "We live in a social welfare state."
As a result, commercial establishments on 138th Street are bustling with customers seeking inexpensive clothes, furniture and baby products. Other stores, which sell $125 sneakers and offer new and repaired beepers, seem to be geared more toward the drug trade.
So promising is the local market to certain entrepreneurs that one investment group recently built a 16,000-square-foot retail mall on 138th Street, and another is putting in the foundation walls for a 38,000-square-foot store across the street.
Local residents may not have large incomes, said Albert Srour, who is building the large store, but, "They still have to eat, they still have to dress and they need to buy necessities."
But the economy of Mott Haven is not just discount retailers and those who cater to drug dealers. Some small manufacturers in a nearby neighborhood are also thriving and expanding, despite the recession. Their growth provides jobs to residents of Mott Haven, often because no other workers will venture into the area.
This economic activity, in turn, is helping to chip away at the area's high unemployment rate, or at least is keeping it from increasing. It provides one of the few legitimate forces shoring up the neighborhood.
Take K.D.dids, a manufacturer of high-quality knitwear for dancers that has been growing at 30 percent a year, exports 20 percent of its goods to Japan and now employs 14 people, many of them from the neighborhood. One of them is 30-year-old Maria Santiago, who was on welfare for 13 years, raising three children, before she joined the company last year. She earns $6 an hour, a typical wage for the area. She now makes $960 a month, compared with $722 from welfare and food stamps. But having a job means more to her than money. She no longer has to make constant journeys to get her checks or answer invasive questions about her personal life. And she likes having a life and friends outside the house.
"I was kind of shy when I came here," Ms. Santiago said. "I didn't know how I would feel, what they would think of me. But they were friendly, and taught me, and gave me time to do what I have to do."
 
Companies Provide More Than Jobs
 Many companies seem to have accepted the notion that they must serve as more than places of employment, perhaps even as quasi-social workers.
Faced with a work force that is primarily Spanish-speaking, woefully uneducated and often with little or no previous work experience, business people in the area expect to train their new employees intensively. Many managers have had to learn Spanish in the process. Considering all the trouble, why not hire from outside Mott Haven? Some companies say they are committed to working with the community, while others say they have no choice. Newspaper ads that give a South Bronx location get little response.
Some companies have gone so far as to recruit from the local homeless shelters and prison work-release programs. American International Medical Equipment Sales, which manufactures and distributes medical products, became so involved with its work-release program that it held a Fourth of July barbecue and invited all the prisoners' families, many of whom were having a hard time accepting their relatives back into the fold. The company hoped it would help for them to see the prisoners in a more normal setting. It also hired a part-time psychiatrist.
Virtually all the employers interviewed in and around Mott Haven had nothing but good things to say about their local workers. Few had encountered any problems with drug abuse or theft. Most said that once their training was complete, the workers were among the most dedicated they had ever known.
"You can't believe how smart they are and how much they want a job," said Tricia Kaye, a co-owner of K.D.dids. "But nobody would train them."
Still, there is only so much small companies can do to pull a community up by its bootstraps. What is unclear is what role local government can, or should, be playing.
On the face of it, Mott Haven enjoys more intensive economic development assistance than most city neighborhoods. To the northeast is Hunts Point, the location of a huge wholesale produce market, which generates 22,000 jobs, many of them unskilled. Directly north is the commercial hub on 149th Street, with 100 stores employing 4,000 shop assistants, clerks and other employees from the area. On the southern flank is the Port Morris Industrial Park, which the state designated as an economic development zone in 1987. There, 650 companies employ 20,000 people, 80 percent of whom live in the Bronx.
Companies in the Port Morris development zone get wage credits if they hire a certain proportion of local people. They also get up to a 30 percent discount on their electricity, 5 percent on their telephone bills, and rebates on sales tax for materials used to expand their operations.
"If you look at the opportunities for jobs within a proximity of Mott Haven, it's actually pretty good," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the city Economic Development Corporation.
But critics say that while the city has painted some impressive broad-brush strokes, problems often arise from the clash of the two Mott Havens: the business community and the welfare state. Economic Development Corporation officials speak proudly about how they have helped to revitalize 138th Street by rebuilding the sidewalks. But at the same time, the city put a shelter for 100 homeless families just down the street. Local merchants complain of a general deterioration in the area since then, thanks to an increase in petty theft, car break-ins and prostitution.
Similarly, in 1987, the city took the largest remaining parcel of city-owned property in the area and turned it into a tow pound. The decision was a direct affront to the Borough President's office, which had been lobbying for a satellite center for the garment industry or a development centered on artists' studios.
"They totally ignored us," said Cecil P. Joseph, who heads Borough President Fernando Ferrer's economic development efforts. "They came in overnight and paved it over."
 
Measuring the Value Of an Industrial Park
 In one of the most incongruous developments yet, the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, which has been an important lifeline to the business community in the area, is using city funds to help an elegant row of townhouses prosper as an antiques center.
Questions have even been raised by some in the community about the true value of the Port Morris Industrial Park. In designating the area as an opportunity zone, the state projected that companies there would invest $72 million and hire 1,329 full-time and 243 part-time employees. But state officials acknowledge that they have not confirmed how much of that investment actually occurred. Anecdotal evidence suggests that more companies are coming to Port Morris than are moving out or closing down, and that many are expanding.
S & S Industries, for instance, which makes wires for bra cups, has tripled its space and doubled its work force in the last year. Mr. Mayo's Artistic Office Products company has gone from 50 to 75 employees. Zaro's Bakery, which has its headquarters in Port Morris, has increased its work force there from 120 to 150.
But few companies are expanding because of government incentives. Of the 55 companies that have partaken of the state's menu of benefits, only 8 have availed themselves of wage benefits, which are among the most beneficial. Most of the rest have only enjoyed a reduced electricity bill.
What concerns business executives far more is the difficulty they have had obtaining low-interest loans from the city or the state that were supposed to be available to small companies and manufacturers.
Andrew Brown, chief executive of American International Medical, recalls that after he won a contract with the Defense Department to produce 10 million surgical gloves, he approached state and city agencies for a loan to help buy equipment. He was already convinced that banks had been shunning the area because in 1981 he had so much trouble getting a mortgage on his building.
With a guaranteed government contract, a 20-year manufacturing record and a reputation as a good corporate citizen, Mr. Brown figured the city and state would surely lend him the $1.1 million he needed. The state Urban Development Corporation approved its half without much delay, but the city Financial Services Corporation spent months pondering his application. It finally granted an approval with so many conditions that the bank that was being asked to make a bridge loan to the company did not feel it had the guarantee it needed from the city to insure that it would be repaid. By that point Mr. Brown's contract with the Defense Department had expired.
Mr. Brown's experience is not unusual. Since 1987, when Port Morris received its special state status, the Urban Development Corporation has made loans to just two companies, while the city's financing agency has made eight.
Still, even if the state and city were to develop every vacant piece of land in Port Morris, it would not be enough to absorb the unemployed of Mott Haven. By placing so many high-rise housing projects in one area, the government has created a density of population that requires similarly dense employment opportunities. But many of the buildings in Port Morris are one- or two-story warehouses and factories, and the average business there employs only 30 people.
The real issue is why Mott Haven residents have not been able to find work elsewhere. The answer, Mr. Weisbrod says, lies with with much broader issues like illiteracy, drug abuse, poverty and a lack of social support services.
"The real problem is the degree of social investment that has to take place, beyond just providing housing," he said. "What we're witnessing are the consequences of the withdrawal of the Federal Government from domestic programs."
Mr. Brown says he too worries about the long-term consequences of government policies. "It's unfair for young people in the Bronx not to have an opportunity to learn how to make a living," he said. He thought things were bad in the slums of his native Glasgow, but he has since learned they can be worse.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 12, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about the business community in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx misstated the timing of New York City's approval of a loan to American International Medical Equipment Sales. The city's Financial Services Corporation approved the loan in December 1989, before a similar approval was given by a state agency, the Urban Development Corporation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Are Down As Weak Economy Is Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver and platinum futures fell sharply yesterday amid perceptions that this week's cut in interest rates would spur neither an economic recovery nor a rise in inflation.
Silver for delivery next month fell 7 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $3.998 an ounce, the contract's first close below $4 since Sept. 11. 
 December gold dropped $1.10, to $354.70 an ounce on the Comex, while January platinum deliveries tumbled $6.20, to $358.80 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The selloff followed a weak performance by the precious metals on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve and large American banks lowered key lending rates in hopes of stimulating an economic recovery.
Some analysts said the failure of precious metals to rally strongly on Wednesday signaled a lack of confidence in the economy and set the stage for yesterday's selloff.
"It's like crying wolf," said William O'Neill, the senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures. "We've had so many interest-rate cuts, and it really hasn't done anything. The markets want to see some kind of results."
Analysts said the drop in silver and platinum indicated pessimism about future industrial activity and perceptions that the inflation rate would remain relatively low. Investors tend to buy precious metals as a hedge against inflation.
The decline in commodity prices that began on Wednesday and continued yesterday was yet another sign of future economic weakness, said Bernard Savaiko, the senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc.
He said general weakness in commodity markets "is the first indication that the economy is going to follow."
Mr. O'Neill said silver futures were also under pressure from selling related to today's expiration of silver options contracts.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain and soybean contracts fell for the fourth straight day amid ideas that the fall harvest would be bigger and a Soviet food-aid package would be smaller than had been thought.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil slipped as rumors that Iraq would resume large oil exports gave traders reason to take profits.
Light crude for delivery in December fell 20 cents a barrel, to $23.20; December home heating oil fell 0.70 cent, to 70.32 cents a gallon, and December unleaded gasoline tumbled 0.92 cent, to 65.36 cents a gallon. Natural gas for December rose 1.9 cents, to $2.082 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: New Claims By Jobless Up by 14,000

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose 14,000 in late October, the Government said today.
For the week ended Oct. 26, there were 420,000 Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment help, up from the previous week's revised 406,000, the Labor Department said. 
 The increase was not viewed as entirely discouraging, however. It erased only a portion of a 46,000 plunge from the previous week, when claims had fallen from 452,000. Because claims rose by just 14,000, that means the 46,000 improvement in the previous week was not a fluke caused by the Columbus Day holiday, said Irwin Kellner, economist with Manufacturers Hanover Trust.
Mr. Kellner said the data, considered together, could be a sign that the trend toward increased layoffs "may have run its course."
Still, the 420,000 people filing claims is above lows of 400,000 during the summer.
To have 420,000 new people heading to an unemployment office during any given week "is not a level of claims indicative of a smooth, functioning economy," said Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities.
And yet, he noted, the four-week average of claims is about 425,000. "There isn't any sense of things having gotten worse," Mr. Brusca said.
Because the claims number can be extremely volatile from week to week, analysts generally hesitate to read a lot into one week's movement.
Government figures on joblessness that were released last week showed that companies failed to add workers in October and that some layoffs continued. The nation's jobless rate rose to 6.8 percent from September's 6.7 percent, as 8.6 million Americans remained without jobs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Net Up 25% At Wal-Mart

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose by 25 percent in the third quarter, as the nation's largest retailer once again outperformed its competitors.
Wal-Mart said it earned $353.2 million, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter that ended on Oct. 31, compared with $282.8 million, or 25 cents a share, in the comparable 1990 period. 
 The retailer's sales rose by 34.1 percent, to $10.73 billion from $8 billion. The company's stock rose $2 yesterday, to $48.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Faring Better Than Others
 Wal-Mart, with its low prices and reputation for good customer service, has fared far better than other retailers while the economic recovery has stumbled. Many other store owners are expected to post earnings declines because of the continuing slump in consumer spending.
Sales at Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark, have surged as it opened 126 new stores this year. The retailer had 1,652 Wal-Mart stores, 194 Sam's Clubs and four Hypermart stores operating at the end of the quarter.
Joseph Ronning, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman Inc., said he was pleased with the report, which was about as expected.
"The customers are responding to Wal-Mart's low-price image," he said. "They have the right product at the right price at the right time."

HEADLINE: Skepticism On Effects Of Rate Cut

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve and other bank regulators are trying to stimulate more bank lending by reducing interest rates and rewriting guidelines for examining real estate loans. But many bankers say the weakness in the economy will overpower those efforts and bank lending will remain sluggish.
"So long as the public is convinced that we are not out of the recession, I don't think rate reductions are going to have much immediate impact" on demand for loans or bank lending, said Ezekiel S. Ketchum, president of Meridian Bank in Reading, Pa. "People do not go out and buy a car just because rates are down half a point," he said. And businesses that do not foresee a sustained increase in demand for their products are not likely to borrow to increase inventories or production.
 
Bankers Worry About Inflation
 While bank profits would benefit by an increase in loan demand, several bankers warned this week that the recent initiatives were worrisome because they could eventually help revive inflation. 
 "Politically, the Fed cannot afford to sit on its hands, even though economically that might be the best thing for them to do," said Phillip E. Peters, chief investment officer at Boatmen's Bancshares in St. Louis. He noted that the inability of the Fed to bring down yields on long-term bonds was a sign that the financial markets were worried that inflation might not remain in the recent 3 percent to 4 percent range.
When the Fed announced a cut in the discount rate Wednesday to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent, it noted that the action came "in an environment of abating inflatonary pressures." That view is widespread among economists now, but has not been persuasive to many investors. Bond yields fell to 8 percent in February, but have not dropped much below that level even though the Fed has steadily reduced overnight rates for bank loans to 4 3/4 percent from 6 1/4 percent in that period.
 
How to Fine-Tune Prices
 "In one respect, lenders would like some inflation" because it could help some borrowers repay their loans, said Robert Aspinwall, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. But the problem, he said, is that economic policy makers do not have any fine-tuning policy tools to make sure that "they can get prices to rise, but not too much."
The danger of an overreaction by the Fed led Wayne D. Angell, one Fed governor, to vote against the latest discount-rate cut. Mr. Angell said yesterday that he did not expect the economy would be helped much by a cut in short-term interest rates. The best monetary policy for now, he said, is one which helps the housing market by bringing down long-term interest rates. But reductions in long-term rates require confidence, which is currently lacking in the financial markets, that the Fed is still fighting inflation.
Mr. Aspinwall is not the only banker to realize that a revival of inflation could benefit banks burdened by delinquent real estate loans. Often those loans are backed by buildings that are not attracting tenants and cannot be sold except at discounts of 30 percent or 40 percent from the amount lent by the bank.
 
Good for Real Estate
 John S. Reed, chairman at Citicorp, said at a meeting with analysts last month that periods of inflation had traditionally been the best time to own real estate. While he did not predict or recommend that the Fed adopt an inflationary monetary policy, he noted that the end of tight money could help attract more buyers for the real estate Citicorp owns.
The clarified guidelines issued yesterday by banking regulators for evaluating real estate loans was another part of the recent effort to stimulate more bank lending. However, the guidelines stopped far short of changes that would let banks relabel troubled loans as problem free.
"There is really not much regulators can do to make any dramatic change," said Steven Roberts, national director for financial institution regulation at KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm. He noted that with earlier problems, like loans to third world countries issued by large banks or the loans to farmers at small banks in the Midwest, regulators gave banks several years to solve the problems without forcing them to immediatly recognize their losses.
But in the wake of the savings and loan industry's problems, which were aggravated by years of regulators' tolerance of weak capital and poor lending practices, "forebearance has become a dirty word," Mr. Roberts said.

HEADLINE: Easier Rules For Banks Are Issued

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
As part of a drive by the Administration to stimulate the economy, the four Federal bank regulatory agencies announced new guidelines yesterday to make bank examinations less tough and encourage banks to make more loans.
The measures would permit examiners greater latitude in reviewing commercial real estate loans to try to "insure that regulatory policies and actions do not inadvertently curtail the availability of credit to sound borrowers," the agencies said in a joint statement. 
 Their action was intended to draw attention to an effort begun by the Adminstration in March to relax tight credit by making it easier for banks to make loans so that business could expand and grow. But some bankers and analysts said the guidelines would do little to help an economy hobbled more by a lack of loan demand than by an unwillingess of banks to lend. And others feared that yesterday's action could cause banks to make the kind of poor loans they did in the 1980's, which are causing problems today.
 
More Scrutiny of Regulators
 This also comes as greater attention is being paid to the actions of regulators. On Wednesday, a Senate committee rejected Mr. Bush's attempt to reappoint Robert L. Clarke as Comptroller of the Currency, the regulator of some 4,000 nationally chartered banks, in part because Mr. Clarke was considered too lenient in the 1980's and was seen as having failed to head off a wave of bank failures. And it comes as Congress is considering a complex bill to overhaul the banking industry and mandate earlier regulatory intervention at troubled banks.
"All this stuff is pretty marginal as far as I'm concerned," said Robert E. Litan, a banking industry analyst at the Brookings Institution. "I don't think the new regulations will do much to change things and the key thing is what message gets to the troops. In reality, examiners are probably totally perplexed. They've just seen their leader whipsawed in Congress and they know the climate on the Hill is to be tough rather than lenient. I think examiners are going to be very nervous about getting too liberal all of a sudden."
The measure, however, was praised by representatives of the banking and real estate industry, but raised concerns among others who feared any relaxation in regulatory standards. The document, which will be distributed to bank presidents and examiners, was drafted by the Comptroller's office, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve Board and the Office of Thrift Supervision. Last March, these agencies issued general guidelines and the document released yesterday provides specifics to guide examiners.
"A lot of this is common sense stuff," said Wendy B. Samuel, general counsel of the National Coucnil of Community Bankers. "But I can't picture a lot of bankers immediately changing their lending practices. Bankers would love to make loans and are finding that the sort of loans they want to make are just not there."
 
'Constructive Approach'
 Steven A. Wechsler, president of the National Realty Committee, said the guidlines were a "constructive approach to restoring regulatory balance to the system," while Robert H. Dugger, chief economist at the American Bankers Association, said the new guidelines "will definitely help."
But Herbert M. Sandler, chief executive of World Savings and Loan Association, one of the nation's largest, said "I'm concerned that a message not be given to go back to the old practicies of the 1980's when people received credit for loans which should never have been made. Now we're saying, gee, we're wrong, let's go back and give these people credit."
Among the specifics of the guidelines are details about when real estate loans should be classifed as in danger of default and how much should be set aside as reserves against them. One important move welcomed by the American Bankers Association was a shift in emphasis from evaluating existing loans on a worst case scenario based on current market conditions to judging real estate loans based on future market conditions.
The agencies also said they will convene a national meeting of senior bank examiners in December to review this policy statement. They will also undertake a random audit program to check up on how examiners are following the guidelines and plan to allow bank holding companies to use a greater amount of preferred stock to meet regulatory capital guidelines.
The argument against greater use of preferred stock is that it is a security considered to be similar to debt. But the change is intended to help Citibank and several other large money center banks meet their regualatory capital standards.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Investors Lured to Long Bond

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The third and most speculative part of the Treasury's $38 billion quarterly refunding auctions got the best reception of the three from investors yesterday as the wide gap between long-term and short-term interest rates created demand at the sale of $12 billion worth of 30-year bonds.
The bond auction came on the heels of disappointing auctions of new 3-year and 10-year notes, and that had created concern among many market participants about who might be willing to venture a bid on the new 30-year securities. The longer out in time the securities go, the riskier they are to hold because their value could decline if inflation heated up, driving up interest rates, but yesterday the higher yield on the long-term bonds attracted buyers. 
 The demand for the bonds was especially strong from smaller investors who normally avoid the Treasury's most speculative debt instrument.
The new bonds were auctioned at an average yield of 8 percent, down from an average yield of 8.17 percent at the last 30-year bond auction in August.
 
Stocks React Favorably
 "When you consider the economy and inflation, I think it makes sense to own bonds at 8 percent," one Government bond trader said.
The favorable auction results lent strength to the stock market, traders said. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.65, to 3,054.11, and the broader Nasdaq and Russell 2,000 indexes reached new highs. [Page D6.]
Unlike the 3-year and 10-year auctions, traders said that bids for the new bonds were tightly bunched.
The best gauge of demand among smaller investors is the amount of noncompetitive tender offers submitted, and at $937 million they were the second highest on record for a bond auction, according to William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
By submitting a noncompetitive bid, investors agree to pay the average price produced at the auction.
"Small investors stayed away from the 3-year and 10-year auctions and waited for the highest possible yield," Mr. Sullivan said. "And with the spread between yields on 10-year securities and 30-year bonds at what could be its widest margin, there was obviously a strong incentive to buy longer-term paper."
Even after the results were announced, demand for the new bonds remained strong, and by late in the day the 8 percent securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.89 percent.
The better-than-expected auction results helped push up prices in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds.
"We are celebrating the fact that the auctions are over," another trader said. "Happy days are here again. That is the headline."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the current benchmark issue, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021, were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 11/32, up 30/ 32, to yield 7.91 percent, compared with 7.99 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 101, up 9/32, to yield 6.63 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/4, up 1/32, to yield 5.59 percent.
The rally also pushed up the prices of the securities that were auctioned earlier in the week.
The 6 percent three-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.94 percent. And the 7.50 percent 10-year notes sold on Wednesday were offered in late when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.41 percent.
 
Bills Little Changed
 Rates on short-term Treasury bills were little changed yesterday, despite the Federal Reserve's rate cuts. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.61 percent, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at an offered rate of 4.67 percent.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a two-part, $350.5 million offering of securities backed by home equity loans by the the Fleet Financial Corporation.
The bulk of the issue consisted of $319 million of 6.70 percent securities with an average life of 2.18 years. They were priced at $99.781, to yield 6.895 percent, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
These securities are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
American Brands offered $150 million worth of 30-year debentures through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 8 5/8 percent securities, which mature Nov. 15, 2021, were priced at $97.105, to yield 8.903 percent, 1 percentage point over the yield on the new 8 percent 30-year Treasury bond.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-3 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, a competitive bid from an investor group led by Kidder, Peabody & Company won an offering of $225 million worth of triple-A-rated securities issued by the Convention Center of Rhode Island.
The serial and term bonds are all insured by MBIA Inc. The securities were reoffered to investors at a maximum yield of 6.75 percent on term bonds maturing in 2020.
In another development, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended Oct. 28. M-1, the narrowest measure, rose by $1 billion.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of new 30-year Treasury bonds:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Maxwell Executive Knows U.S. Unit Well

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
David Shaffer, the new chief operating officer of the Maxwell Communication Corporation, brings to the job a thorough knowledge of the company's key operation: its United States division. As president of Macmillan Inc. since March 1990, he has supervised the book publishing company and a subsidiary that publishes the Official Airlines Guide.
Having just returned from London last night, Mr. Shaffer said in a telephone interview that everyone was "terribly saddened by Bob's death, but he had structured the company in such a way that the company will not feel it at all." He added, "The day-to-day operating decision was already under my control." 
 Mr. Shaffer, who is 49 years old, was said to have grown close to Kevin F. H. Maxwell, who has emerged as the leader of the publishing empire established by his father, Robert Maxwell.
The executive joined Maxwell Communication when it bought Official Airlines Guide in 1988. He recalled that Mr. Maxwell had soon after named him executive vice president of the Maxwell Macmillan Group, which included all the information businesses of Maxwell Communication, both in the United States and overseas. "For a year and two months, I did run most of the international businesses," he recalled.
Maxwell Communications gets roughly 80 percent of its revenues and 90 percent of its profits, from its American operations, "The piece I have inherited," he said, referring to the foreign business," is only a minor part."
Maxwell Communication does not separate Macmillan's performance from its annual reports. But Mr. Shaffer said the company's joint venture on elementary high school publishing, for which data are simpler to analyze, has done very very well.
Kenneth Noble, who heads his own consulting firm in the media industry, said Macmillan's book operations had not been doing badly despite the recession.
Mr. Shaffer maintained yesterday that the company would not be under pressure to sell additional assets since the company is close to meeting its next debt repayment in October 1992 for $750 million. "The next payment is exactly two years later for $1.2 billion," he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Voters Rewrite Domestic Agenda

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THERE were seeming ideological contradictions in this week's election results. For instance, Pennsylvania voters handed a decisive Senate victory to the liberal Democrat, Harris Wofford, who stressed the need for national health care, over former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who upheld the conservative Bush Administration program, with heavy support from the President. But New Jersey voters appeared to have shifted sharply to the right, handing Democratic state legislators a crushing defeat for supporting Gov. Jim Florio's tax increase last year.
However, the common denominator in the Pennsylvania and New Jersey elections was money -- and the voters' anxiety, whether the worry was over how to pay medical bills or how to pay taxes. 
 President Bush quickly demonstrated that he had got the electoral message: He promised health-care and tax-cut initiatives, presumably going beyond his long-proposed cut in the capital-gains tax, which Democrats have labeled a "a tax break for the rich."
Mr. Bush has been supporting the cautious don't-worsen-the-deficit faction within the Administration, led by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, against the radical "pro-growth" faction, headed by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, an ardent champion of tax cuts, regardless of the immediate effect on the deficit. Is Mr. Bush ready to switch sides?
He has been blocking Democratic legislation, such as the bill to extend unemployment benefits, saying it would bust last December's budget agreement, which was supposed to cut the deficit by $500 billion over the next five years. Meanwhile, the Congressional Budget Office projects the budgetdeficit for the current fiscal year will soar to a record $362 billion. How Mr. Bush means to get around the deficit issue while proposing tax cuts to stimulate the economy (and without causing an upsurge of interest rates) remains a mystery.
For the present, the job of insuring that economic stagnation does not cost the Republicans the White House next year is being handed to the Federal Reserve. Immediately after the election, the Fed cut the discount rate to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent and the Federal funds rate to 4 3/4 percent from 5 percent. The Fed said the move had nothing to do with the election. True, President Bush, Secretary Brady and other Administration figures have been loud in their urgings to the Fed to cut rates. And Democrats had joined in urging the Fed to ease further. Nevertheless, the Fed's move this week was filed at the central bank under the Funny Coincidence Department.
Worries about the economy have not squeezed all ideology out of the political contest. Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, is calling for higher tax rates on the rich and lower taxes on the middle class and lower-income groups.
The 1992 campaign could still become a contest between the politics of envy and the politics of greed. But events this week stirred hopes that fear of the political consequences of a sick economy could cause politicians to veer away from their partisan deadlock and start the process of resolving dangerous social and economic problems.
Health care, for instance, is not an issue of rich versus poor or business versus labor. A survey by Dun & Bradstreet this week reported that the top five worries of the nation's small-business proprietors had become health-insurance costs, cash-flow squeeze, cost control, recession and finding qualified employees.
"I've tried for three years to get health-insurance costs under control," said Kathie M. Leonard, co-owner of Auburn Manufacturing Inc., a textile manufacturer in Mechanics Falls, Me., whose premiums have risen 27 percent since 1990. Despite her efforts, Ms. Leonard said, "This little company is going to pay 80 grand in premiums this year."
Similarly, the issue of education and training, which business calls "finding qualified employees," is one on which employers and employees can make common cause.
Anger over hard times and fear over competition for jobs have doubtless aggravated racial tensions, not only in Louisiana and New York but even in Dubuque, Iowa, which both parties need to address.
This week's election seems certain to quickly break the logjam between Mr. Bush and Congressional Democrats over legislation to extend unemployment benefits.
Thus a new political agenda is emerging, as the overriding issue for all incumbents, especially President Bush, becomes how to solve the nation's economic and social problems. Much historical evidence shows that the incumbent in the White House is unlikely to be re-elected with the economy in the tank. The riddle is to how to get it out of the tank, when an orgy of public and private debt-creation, by undermining national savings, investment, productivity, trade and economic growth, has put it there.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up a Bit in New York After Declining in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was narrowly mixed against other currencies yesterday following a series of losses.
The dollar fell in European trading but recovered in New York dealings. Analysts said it drew some strength from a variety of factors. 
 Kevin Logan, chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said there was a feeling in the market that the dollar was reaching bottom after tumbling in recent weeks in response to declining interest rates.
With the Federal Reserve having lowered its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 4 1/2 percent, on Wednesday, traders also bought dollars in the belief that short-term rates were unlikely to fall much further, Mr. Logan said.
Stable interest rates are a positive sign for the dollar. Like all currencies, the dollar is supported by higher rates, which increase foreign demand for American investments.
 
A Lift From Bond Prices
 A surge in bond prices yesterday also spilled over to the dollar, Mr. Logan said. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up nearly a point, or $10 for every $1,000 in face value, by late afternoon.
The dollar was marginally lower against the Japanese yen in New York, falling to 129.87 yen from late Wednesday's 129.90. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.03 yen, to a closing 129.70 Japanese yen and in London it was quoted at 129.88 yen.
The British pound fell against the dollar, slipping to $1.7705 in New York, from $1.7750 late Wednesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.7800 from $1.7718.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6410 German marks, up from 1.6370; 1.4480 Swiss francs, up from 1.4475; 5.6055 French francs, up from 5.5970; 1,234.50 Italian lire, up from 1,227.25, and 1.12225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.12335.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.6305 German marks, down from 1.6395; 1.4390 Swiss francs, down from 1.4495; 5.5740 French francs, down from 5.6090; 1.8375 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8485; 1,224.50 Italian lire, down from 1,229.50, and 1.1210 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1238.

HEADLINE: Consumers Cut Borrowing For Fifth Straight Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit outstanding fell an additional 2.5 percent in September, the Government said today, as Americans continued paying off old bills faster than taking on new debt.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit fell by a seasonally adjusted $1.55 billion in September, the fifth straight decline and the eighth in nine months. All categories except revolving credit declined. 
 The trend "reflects the recession's impact on consumer spending," Michael P. Niemira, an economist, wrote in Mitsubishi Bank's Weekly Economic Indicator Report.
Consumer credit shrank a revised 1.4 percent in August, rather than the initial 2.1 percent estimate, and 1 percent in July. It has not risen since April.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. Overall consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Automobile credit continued to show the largest decline. It was down 9.9 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $2.3 billion, after dropping 8.6 percent a month earlier. Revolving credit, including credit cards, jumped 12.6 percent, or $2.4 billion, after a 6.6 percent advance in August.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up Slightly In October

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Thanks to cold weather that swept most of the nation in the last week of October and widespread, generous price promotions, the nation's retailers saw a slight uptick in sales.
But most analysts and merchants took little encouragement yesterday from the numbers, which showed winners like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Gap Inc. continuing to gain market share at the expense of those selling more expensive merchandise. 
 "Looking at the short-term, they did a little better than expected, but taking the long-term perspective, the numbers are really quite disappointing," said Daniel D. Barry, a retail analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company. "For the vast majority of retailers, sales were below plan for the third consecutive month."
 
More Apparel Sales
 Mr. Barry said colder weather across most of the country spurred sales of apparel, while big-ticket items like home furnishings languished on store floors and catalogue goods sat on warehouse shelves.
Those buying patterns contributed to a 2.9 percent decline in overall sales at the J. C. Penney Company, based in Dallas. Sales at Penney's same stores, those open at least a year, fell 2.4 percent, while catalogue sales dropped by 8.2 percent.
Analysts consider sales at same, or comparable, stores a more accurate indication of a retailer's performance.
Stores emphasizing low prices showed the strongest gains. The Pic 'N' Save Corporation in Dominguez, Calif., which sells merchandise obtained from manufacturers' close-out sales, as well as overruns and discontinued lines, reported a 10.3 percent increase in same-store sales last month.
Analysts said most of the store chains that reported strong gains achieved them with heavy promotions that would cut into profits. Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, the flamboyant chain of men's apparel stores based in Maryland, for example, reported a 30 percent rise in its sales and a 9 percent same-store gain, but analysts said much of the rise came from cutting prices.
"You're seeing that situation in case after case, so I think we need to be careful about putting any faith in the notion that the consumer" is ready to buy, said Robert F. Buchanan of Alex. Brown & Sons Inc.
The Merrill Lynch Retail Index of 23 leading retail chains showed a 2.3 percent increase in same-store sales for the month, compared with a 1 percent increase in September.
Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said even in comparison with the poor sales of October 1990, when the nation reacted to troops being sent to the Persian Gulf, last month's sales gains were disappointing. He said they reflected lingering consumer concerns about the economy, as well as "lackluster offerings from many retailers in the fashion area."
But Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, an industry publication, said the modest upswing in sales at merchants selling moderately priced goods indicated that shoppers were beginning to relinquish their grip on their wallets.
For example, the Best Buy Company, a consumer electronics and appliance retailer based in Bloomington, Minn., reported a 40 percent sales increase over all and a 17 percent rise among its comparable stores.
"Contrary to the nay-sayers and doctors of doom, I am very confident that consumers will continue to release pent-up demand," Mr. Barnard said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	By The Associated Press -- Following are the October sales and sales for the fiscal year to date reported yesterday by some of the nation's largest retailers, compared with the previous year's results.
Sales include those from stores open at least a year, or same stores. Retailers release only percentage changes for same-store sales, while providing dollar figures and percentages for overall sales.
Dayton Hudson: Same-store sales rose 6 percent in October and, over all, 12 percent, to $1.27 billion. In the first nine months, same- store sales rose 2.6 percent and, over all, 10 percent, to $10.68 billion.
The Gap: Same-store sales rose 17 percent in October and, over all, 36 percent, to $211 million. In the first nine months, same-store sales rose 13 percent and, over all, 31 percent, to $1.72 billion.
J. C. Penney: Same-store sales fell 2.4 percent in October and, over all, 2.9 percent, to $1.27 billion. In the first nine months, same- store sales fell 3.4 percent and, over all, 3.4 percent, to $9.97 billion.
K Mart Corp.: Same-store sales rose 1.7 percent in October and, over all, 6 percent, to $2.48 billion. In the first nine months, same- store sales rose 3.6 percent and, over all, 7.6 percent, to $24.02 billion.
The Limited Inc.: Same-store sales rose 4 percent in October and, over all, 16 percent, to $442.8 million. In the first nine months, same-store sales rose 3 percent and, over all, 17 percent, to $4.09 billion.
May Department Stores Co.: Same-store sales rose six-tenths of a percent in October and, over all, 8.7 percent, to $767.5 million. In the first nine months, same-store sales fell three-tenths of a percent, but overall sales rose 7.8 percent, to $7.25 billion.
Melville Corp.: Same-store sales rose 1.3 percent in October and, over all, 5 percent, to $723.3 million. In the first 10 months, same- store sales rose five-tenths of a percent and, over all, 16.9 percent, to $7.52 billion.
Merry-Go-Round Enterprises: Same-store sales rose 9 percent in October and, over all, 30 percent, to $56.4 million. In the first nine months, same-store sales rose 6 percent and, over all, 26 percent, to $511.3 million.
Sears, Roebuck & Co.: Same-store sales rose four-tenths of a percent in October and, over all, five-tenths of a percent, to $2.57 billion. In the first nine months, same-store sales fell 2.1 percent and, over all, 1.7 percent, to $23.98 billion.
TJX Cos.: Overall sales rose 11 percent in October, to $217 million. In the first nine months, overall sales rose 13 percent, to $1.98 billion.
Wal-Mart Stores: Same-store sales rose 9 percent in October and, over all, 35 percent, to $3.67 billion. In the first nine months, same-store sales rose 10 percent and, over all, 36 percent, to $30.25 billion.
Woolworth Corp.: Same-store domestic sales fell four-tenths of a percent in October, while overall domestic sales rose 4.2 percent, to $391 million. Total sales, including foreign, rose two-tenths of a percent in October, to $717 million. In the first nine months, same-store domestic sales fell 1.5 percent, while overall domestic sales rose 3.1 percent, to $3.97 billion. Total sales, including foreign, were up six-tenths of a percent, to $6.85 billion.

HEADLINE: Broad Gain Lifts Dow by 15.65, to 3,054.11

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Blue-chip issues posted moderate gains in active trading yesterday, drawing strength from I.B.M. and retailers, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.65, to 3,054.11. The broader market made solid advances, taking the Nasdaq and Russell 2,000 indexes to new highs.
A favorable outcome to yesterday's 30-year bond auction strengthened Treasury securities and lowered interest rates, helping stocks become that much more attractive to investors, some analysts said. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 206.9 million, up from 167.4 million on Wednesday. Gainers outpaced losers by a margin of 1,085 to 560.
 
All Indexes Are Up
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.75, to 393.72, while the Big Board composite rose 1.84, to 217.14, and the American Stock Exchange composite rose 1.61, to 388.26.
In active trading, the Nasdag composite rose 5.80, to 545.28, and the Russell 2,000 increased 1.44 to close at 185.80.
Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president and head of stock index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Brothers, said that after a battle between bulls and bears for weeks, it appeared the Dow was poised for a new high. "The question is," he said, "will the rest of the market be capable of doing the same?" The Dow's high is 3,077.15, reached on Oct. 18.
"One clue may be that in a recent four-day pullback by the market, the broad list of stocks did not come under selling pressure," he noted. "I see institutional portfolio managers continuing to pour money into secondary growth stocks, as evidenced by the Nasdaq and Russell indexes reaching new all-time highs. In fact the whole aggressive growth in the secondary markets has outperformed the blue chips by 50 percent this year and is still doing so."
I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, said yesterday that the earnings outlook was improving. I.B.M. rose 3 1/4 to close at 99 7/8.
 
Retailers Attract Investors
 Investors, encouraged by some better-than-expected October sales results at retailers, did a little shopping of their own. The Limited was up 2 3/4, to 44 3/8; Wal-Mart Stores 2, to 48 7/8; Dayton Hudson 3 3/4, to 62 1/2, and K Mart 2 3/8, to 44 3/8.
Bristol-Myers Squibb said it planned to begin introducing Pravachol, its recently approved drug to control elevated blood cholesterol levels. The company expects it will be available in the United States by prescription in the near future. The stock was as high as 85 1/2 yesterday and ended closing down 5/8, to 84 3/4.
Shaw Industries rose 1/2, to 30 5/8, after Josie Esquivel, an analyst with Shearson Lehman, upgraded the carpet maker's stock rating based on the weakness of the stock. She said that the fundamentals were there and that she expected the stock to appreciate about 25 percent in the next 12 months.
 
 
International Paper Off
 International Paper, trading near its high for the year, closed down 1/2, to 74 1/2, as John Chrysikopoulos, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, removed the company from the recommended list. International Paper said the analyst had left them with the impression that the adjustment was more a reflection of the industry.
After reporting better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, Cisco Systems stock rose 3 1/2, to 52 1/4. Traders said that Cecilia Brancato, an Oppenheimer analyst, raised her earnings estimate by about 20 cents for the year for the computer-networking systems company.
Amax Gold, in a bid to buy Fairbanks Gold, slipped 1/4 to close at 11 1/8.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ashland Oil Appoints Successor to President

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Ashland Oil Inc. said yesterday that it had selected Paul W. Chellgren, senior vice president and chief financial officer, to become president and chief operating officer at the end of January.
Mr. Chellgren, who is 48 years old, will succeed Charles J. Luellen, 62, who had previously announced his attention to retire in January. John R. Hall, 58, remains chairman and chief executive. 
 Mr. Chellgren was nominated to the board of Ashland Oil yesterday. He is currently chairman of Ashland Coal.
He joined Ashland in 1974. His father, W. E. Chellgren, retired as controller of Ashland Oil in 1980 after 33 years with the company. The younger Mr. Chellgren holds a bachelor's degree from the University of Kentucky, an M.B.A. from Harvard and a diploma in developmental economics from Oxford.
Mr. Chellgren becomes second in command at a difficult time for independent refiners like Ashland. Changing environmental rules have created a huge new demand for capital.
In a telephone interview yesterday, he said the Clean Air Act's requirements for reformulated gasoline and low-sulfur diesel fuel were "absorbing all our discretionary capital." This year, he said, Ashland would invest $504 million, of which $280 million would go into petroleum refining and marketing. "Four years ago, that business consumed $88 million," he said.
As a result, he said, some of the company's businesses "just don't have the capital to grow." Among these, he said, are the new Super America convenience stores and quick oil change outlets, as well as the chemical business.
In addition, the company has been hit by dozens of lawsuits from neighbors of its main refinery, and four plaintiffs won a $10.3 million decision in May 1990. Ashland appealed to the Kentucky Supreme Court, which may rule by the end of this year.
Frederick P. Leuffer Jr., an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc. who follows Ashland, said the suit "on the surface looks pretty frivolous."
"But after Texaco-Pennzoil, in this industry we don't call anything frivolous," he added, referring to the Pennzoil Company's successful multibillion-dollar lawsuit challenging Texaco Inc.'s acquisition of the Getty Oil Company in the 1980's.
Still, Mr. Leuffer said, Ashland's stock price reflects investors' belief that Ashland had "a reasonable chance of coming out the victor."
He said Mr. Chellgren "knows the operations and the finances inside and out."
"He's a very very bright, capable man," Mr. Leuffer added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Operating Officer For Cincinnati Milacron

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Cincinnati Milacron Inc., a leading producer of machine tools, has named Raymond E. Ross president and chief operating officer.
Mr. Ross, who is 55, was previously executive vice president of operations for the company. 
 Milacron said Mr. Ross would essentially perform the same duties, because it previously did not have a chief operating officer. Daniel J. Meyer, chairman and chief executive, had been serving as president, but he relinquished that post with this week's appointment of Mr. Ross.
The Cincinnati-based company, like others in the machine-tool industry, has been suffering in the last year because of a downturn in orders from the automobile industry. But Milicron said that orders were now rebounding and that new orders were coming from a wide range of industries.
Despite those gains, the company lost $104 million on sales of $552 million in the first nine months of this year. That loss included $94 million in one-time charges. In the comparable period last year, the company earned $7.1 million on sales of $587 million.
Mr. Ross came to Milacron in 1968 as a manager in the plastics-forming division and he has held a number of managerial positions, mainly in product development and marketing.
In 1985, he was named general manager of plastics machinery, an area in which the company has looked for future growth. Mr. Ross oversaw the development of injection molding machinery, an important product line for the company.
Milacron has undergone a broad restructuring in recent years, reducing its size as demand from machine tool buyers declined. The company has redesigned products, closed unprofitable operations and reduces its work force.
Still, Mr. Ross said, Milacron "is always looking for ways to cut costs further."
"Our plan is to make money in this economy," he said, "and if it gets better, that will be a real plus. We have to get our costs down."
He added that he hoped to continue to improve the company's exports, which he said had increased in recent quarters.
Before coming to Milacron, Mr. Ross worked at Recto Molded Products Inc. for eight years.
Mr. Ross is a graduate of the University of Cincinnati, where he earned a degree in industrial management. He and his wife, Mary Ann, have three daughters and one son.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
The Fed is trying to make sure that the two American banks secretly owned by B.C.C.I. do not fail, according to government officials and others familiar with the rescue program. The collapse of either Independence Bank or First American Bankshares would be "political dynamite," regulators said. [Page A1.]
Many bankers say weakness in the economy will overpower the Fed's efforts to cut rates and stimulate more bank lending. [D1.] 
 New guidelines to make bank examinations less tough and to encourage banks to make more loans have been announced. [D1.]
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims rose 14,000 in late October, the government said. [D3.]
The nation's retailers saw a slight up-tick in sales thanks to cold weather that swept most of the nation in the last week of October and widespread, generous price promotions. [D5.]
