HEADLINE: Democrats' Finance Choices on Jobless Bill

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Senate Democrats today proposed legislation extending unemployment benefits that would give President Bush three choices on how to pay for it: declaring a budget emergency and increasing the Federal deficit, curbing foreign aid or raising estimated income tax payments.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, scoffed at the plan as "government by multiple choice." And Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk and the leading House sponsor of the measure, called it a "Chinese menu" approach. 
 The Democratic proposal, introduced by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, would cost $5.4 billion and would provide as many as 20 weeks of benefits for workers out of a job more than half a year.
"We're trying very hard to be accommodating," Mr. Mitchell said. He insisted that the Democrats still preferred that Mr. Bush declare an emergency and pay for the benefits, to about 3 million jobless people, as he refused to do in bills he killed in August and September.

HEADLINE: Jobs and Poverty Increase for Hispanic Americans

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
More Hispanic people are working, more are earning at least $50,000 a year and more are completing high school than eight years ago, but more are also living in poverty, the Federal Census Bureau said today in a new report.
Overall Hispanic buying power, bolstered by a 52 percent increase in the number of Hispanic households, rose 67 percent since 1982, the report said. 
 The figures, adjusted to reflect the effects of inflation, do not reflect the changes in income for Hispanic individuals or families over the same period.
The number of Hispanic families below the poverty line increased to 28.1 percent, up from 26.2 percent a year ago, and more than double the national poverty rate of 13.5 percent.
 
'A Mixed Bag'
 Hispanic Americans, who may be of any race, generally are defined as those who share a Spanish-language heritage and trace their roots to Spanish-speaking countries.
"This is a mixed bag," said Jesus Garcia, a Census Bureau demographer who was a co-author of the report. "It shows some good news and some disturbing news." He said Hispanic women were entering the work force in far greater numbers. About 3.8 million, or 51 percent of Hispanic women over the age of 16, are employed or looking for work. That compares with 2.6 million, or 47 percent of the same group eight years ago.
Estimated unemployment rates for Hispanic women have also gone down in the same period, to 9.2 percent from 16.3 percent, the report said.
But Hispanic men saw less improvement in their work situations. the total percentage of Hispanic men over 16 in the work force decreased slightly, to 78.2 percent from 78.7 percent, which Mr. Garcia described as statistically insignificant. Total unemployement in that fell to 10 percent from 16.6 percent.
Both the 1982 figures and the new 1990 updates, taken from an annual survey of about 150,000 households, reflect periods when the nation's economy was in recession.
"They're in the labor force," said Sonia Perez, an analyst with the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic rights lobbying group in Washington. "They're working. But if you look at the type of jobs, you'll see they are concentrated in low-wage jobs."
The figures reported by Mr. Garcia and his co-author, Patricia Montgomery, bear this out. Nearly 30 percent of all Hispanic men were working in assembly-line jobs or as laborers in industries like construction, while just 19 percent of men in the non-Hispanic population were working in those job categories. Another 17 percent of Hispanic Americans were in the service industry, a category that covers jobs from telephone operators to hotel maids. For non-Hispanics people, the figure was 10 percent.
Other findings of the report included these:
*One-third of Hispanics Americans are single, compared with about one-quarter of non-Hispanics Americans.
*Only about 7 percent of Hispanic Americans are divorced, about 1 percent fewer than the non-Hispanic population.
*The proportion of Hispanic households with incomes of $50,000 or more is now 13 percent, compared with 11 percent eight years ago.
According to the new figures, the educational attainment of Hispanic Americans who are at least 25 years old has increased. About 51.3 percent of them are high school graduates, as against 45.8 percent eight years ago.
But another indicator, the percentage of families headed by single women, is a matter of increasing concern. Nearly one in 4 Hispanic families are headed by single women, as compared with 1 in 6 families in the population as a whole.

HEADLINE: Southern California Agency Eases Stance on Air Quality

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Faced with growing complaints from businesses and politicians that pollution control rules are creating too much of an economic burden, Southern California's air quality authorities say they plan to soften their hard-line approach to enforcing the regulations.
Officials of the South Coast Air Quality Management District, which sets air-quality rules for most of Southern California and is extremely influential in setting statewide and national policies, said they do not plan to roll back the strict emissions standards for businesses, automobiles and individuals they have set in recent years. 
 But they said on Wednesday that they would change their approach to putting the regulations in effect in a way that would reduce the costs of compliance for thousands of enterprises, from gasoline stations to oil refineries.
 
Being 'More Flexible'
 "There's been mounting criticism of the agency from the process viewpoint, and we felt that needed to be corrected," James M. Lents, the district's executive officer, said in an interview today. "There's added stress because of the recession. We feel its possible to meet all our cleanup goals but to do it in a more efficient and flexible way."
Environmental groups said they were concerned that the political pressure on the district to ease up on businesses might lead to a more substantive softening of the regulations and a slowing of the region's progress in cleaning up its air, the most polluted in the nation.
"Whether the new system lowers the amount of scrutiny on companies remains to be seen," said Joel Schwartz, a staff scientist with the Coalition for Clean Air, an environment group. "But if the A.Q.M.D. is going to back off, it could have grave consequences for pollution control in the basin."
The changes were developed after the air quality district came under growing pressure from the owners of large and small companies and from local and state politicians. Business owners have complained for the last several years that the air-quality regulators have been overly rigid in their enforcement of the rules but extremely slow in granting permits for businesses to expand their operations or open in new locations.
 
'District Feeling the Heat'
 Business owners and politicians said the result has been added impetus for many companies to join a wave of industry leaving California, taking jobs and economic growth along with them.
"The Air Quality Management District is feeling the heat from Sacramento and from individuals in the private and public sectors because we are being confronted with the adverse effects of the orders the district is issuing," said State Assemblyman Richard Polanco of Los Angeles.
Officials of the air quality district said their approach would be changed in several ways. First, they said, they would speed the process under which companies are granted permits to expand their operations or open new ones. For many small businesses that are minor polluters, the wait will be no more than seven days, the agency said, and for moderate polluters no more than 30 days. Waits for permits have been six months or longer for many small and medium-sized companies. Larger companies that emit more pollutants will still have to go through a lengthy process to get permits.
The officials said they would also shift their regulatory focus from the small and medium-sized businesses that use solvents, paints and other substances and processes that emit pollutants to the manufacturers and distributors of the pollution-causing substances. Rather than directly regulating an automobile body shop, for example, the agency will monitor the sale of auto paint by manufacturers and distributors to insure that the total amount of pollutants does not exceed the limits.

HEADLINE: Letelier Case at Critical Stage as Chile's Top Court Takes Over

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Three months after the Government of President Patricio Aylwin renewed charges that the head of Chile's secret police under Gen. Augusto Pinochet had masterminded the killing in 1976 of a former Chilean diplomat in Washington, the fate of the case rests with the Chilean Supreme Court.
Emotions here are divided and running high as a panel of five members of the court, all appointed by General Pinochet, will decide over the next two weeks whether the evidence against Gen. Juan Manuel Contreras Sepulveda and his deputy, Col. Pedro Espinoza Bravo, is sufficient to charge them with murder and to proceed to a criminal trial. 
 General Contreras, who headed General Pinochet's secret police, the DINA, in the mid-1970's, and Colonel Espinoza were placed under house arrest in September, becoming the most senior officials of the Pinochet Government to be charged with a crime involving human rights violations.
What many are debating here is whether 18 months after General Pinochet gave up power to a democratically elected Government the nation's Supreme Court can be considered independent. Of the 19 members on the court, only one, Adolfo Banados was appointed by President Aylwin. Justice Banados is investigating the case and will argue the Government's side before the five colleagues appointed to conduct the pretrial hearings.
"I think the public pressure and the thoroughness of Banados's investigation, plus his own integrity, will make it hard for them to throw out the case," said a senior aide to President Aylwin this week, reflecting the Government's positive mood.
 
'This Is the Test Case'
 But not everyone is convinced of the outcome.
"People have said that the transition to democracy in Chile is complete, but I am not so sure," said Sergio Baeza, an economist and representative for the International League for Human Rights. "I think this is the test case to see if there is real justice in Chile."
The current stage of the case is critical, many Government officials say, because if the Supreme Court accepts the evidence Justice Banados has accumulated as valid, it will be hard not to convict the two former police officials.
Since Mr. Letelier and a colleague, Ronni K. Moffitt, were killed by a remote-controlled bomb in the Thomas Circle area of Washington on Sept. 21, 1976, the case has played a critical role in relations between Chile and the United States.
A District of Columbia court quickly indicted eight people, including General Contreras and Colonel Espinoza. But attempts to extradite them were thwarted in 1978 by a Chilean military court that had jurisdiction in the case.
Mr. Letelier had been Foreign Minister, Defense Minister and Ambassador to the United States under the Socialist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens. After Mr. Allende's overthrow, which the United States had secretly encouraged, Mr. Letelier was imprisoned for a year, exiled and stripped of his citizenship.
Michael Townley, an American who confessed to building the bomb that killed Mr. Letelier, has testified that he was working for DINA and has named General Contreras and Colonel Espinoza as the authors of the assassination.
But the Chilean military court did not allow Mr. Townley's testimony as evidence and the case languished until President Aylwin pushed through a change in Chilean law that gives jurisdiction to the civilian courts whenever a case affects Chile's relations with another country.
The two men have denied any involvement and have argued that the case really belongs to the military courts and should be transferred back. The military courts are considered highly favorable to General Pinochet, who continues as Commander in Chief of the army.
Human rights activists say the case represents a symbolic form of retribution for hundreds of families with relatives who disappeared during General Pinochet's rule. The reason is that there is very little chance that they will ever be able to prosecute those responsible for the torture and killing of their relatives, even though they know whom they are. Under a law imposed by General Pinochet as a condition for agreeing to democratic elections, amnesty from prosecution was granted anyone accused of human rights abuses from 1973 through 1978. Those were days of internal war, General Pinochet maintains, and abuses were to be expected.
The one exception was the Letelier killing.
"This case has tremendous symbolism for the U.S. and Chile," said a senior Western diplomat here. "If justice is brought in this case, it represents a kind of justice for all who suffered during those years."
Last March, the Commission on Truth and National Reconciliation issued a report detailing 2,000 cases of deaths and disappearances during the Pinochet years.
Though General Contreras and Colonel Espinoza have been confined to the military hospital in the fashionable Providencia section of Santiago, they are under less than severe conditions, according to lawyers close to the case, living in suites and under constant protection by personal bodyguards. The lawyers say General Pinochet talks to General Contreras by telephone almost every day.
If convicted, the two former police officials could get 15 years to life imprisonment. Mr. Baeza argues that General Contreras should also be stripped of his wealth, which is said to be considerable.

HEADLINE: Wilder Called Factor in G.O.P. Gains in Virginia

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FAIRFAX CITY, Va., Nov. 7

 BODY:
When the Virginia General Assembly convenes next January, Republicans will be a major legislative force for the first time since Reconstruction, thanks to the anti-Democratic tide that swept across the state in Tuesday's elections.
But that tide did more than drown the political hopes of Democratic incumbents and challengers spread from suburbs here on the outskirts of Washington to rural mountain hollows in the state's western reaches. 
 As it swept Republicans close to even with Democrats in the Senate and to more modest but nevertheless significant gains in the House, it also inundated some of the hopes of Gov. L. Douglas Wilder and left him politically embarrassed. He was not a candidate for anything on Tuesday, but he is a candidate in next year's Presidential race.
 
Coattails in Question
 To a degree, Tuesday's results were a referendum on the Governor as a Democratic leader, raising questions about his political stature and the length of his political coattails. The results also left him with the prospect of dealing with a Legislature whose newly powerful Republican minority will go out of its way in a Presidential campaign year to make political mischief and strike troublesome deals with dissident Democrats.
Before Tuesday, the Virginia Senate was split 30 to 10 in favor of Democrats. Now it is split only 22 to 18 in favor of Democrats.
In the House, the split before Tuesday was 59 to 40 in favor of Democrats, with one independent. Now the Democrat edge has been reduced to 57 to 41, with one independent and one contest undecided. Further, Republicans contend their gains in the House were greater than the statstics indicate because their candidates had to run in a number of districts that had been stacked in favor of Democrats by recent redistricting.
Asked by reporters whether he had been a drag on the Democratic ticket, Mr. Wilder replied, "I haven't felt it, don't see it."
 
Some Acceptance of Blame
 He said some candidates had run poor campaigns and he accused President Bush of putting voters in an anti-incumbent mood. But in the end he did not totally duck culpability for the Republican gains.
"To the extent that I'm the party head and to the extent that the party suffered setbacks, I accept whatever fault that is in terms of blame," he said.
Mr. Wilder has been campaigning on his record as Virginia's Governor, asserting that, unlike at least half of the other governor's in the country, he balanced his state's budget this year by cutting programs, people and waste, not by imposing new taxes. He boasts that when Virginia, like the rest of the country, was challenged by hard economic times, he met the test with leadership, not deficits.
In the campaigning leading up to Tuesday's election, Republican candidates across the state questioned Mr. Wilder's boast of not raising taxes and concentrated on reminding voters how few services and dollars now flow down from Richmond.
"He was a real easy target," said Steve Haner, the director of the Republican caucus in the General Assembly. "Now we can't wait to have at him when we convene next year. This is going to be fun."
Some Democratic leaders and almost all Republican leaders and political pundits said Mr. Wilder was a definite factor, if only because he was the leading Virginia Democrat. They noted that his approval rating in public opinion polls has been hovering around 30 percent since he began spending roughly one of every three days out on the Presidential campaign trail, the lowest rating in modern times for any Virginia governor. They also pointed out that hardly any Democratic candidate asked his help in the campaign.
One of the bluntest commentaries on whether the Governor contributed to the Democratic defeats came from one of his closest political allies, State Senator Stanley C. Walker, a Norfolk Democrat who did not fall victim to the Republican onslaught.
"I think Wilder played some role in the defeats," he told the Richmond Times-Dispatch. "And it's been speculated that the party did not do as well as it could because he wasn't putting as much emphasis on state races as he should."

HEADLINE: Duke Expresses Shock at the Lineup Against Him

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 7

 BODY:
At a candidates' forum today, State Representative David Duke said he was shocked by the number and diversity of the endorsements received by his opponent in the Louisiana governor's race, former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards.
When Mr. Edwards took his turn at the podium, he replied, "David, I, too, have been shocked by some of the endorsements I've been given and I guarantee that if it wasn't for you I would never have gotten them." 
 On paper, Mr. Edwards appears to have amassed advantages that would make him the ready favorite in an ordinary campaign, but, as Mr. Edwards himself acknowledged today, the mere presence of Mr. Duke on the ballot assures that there is nothing ordinary about this race.
For example, a variety of business and political leaders who opposed Mr. Edwards in the past are now backing him. But they have openly expressed doubts about Mr. Edwards and have made it plain their prime motive was fear of what would happen to Louisiana with the election of Mr. Duke, a former grand wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and a one-time neo-Nazi.
 
Money Is One Advantage
 Mr. Edwards's most tangible advantage is monetary. Campaign finance reports made public today showed that from Sept. 30 to Oct. 27 Mr. Edwards raised more than $1.1 million while the Duke campaign gathered less than $550,000. At the end of the reporting period Mr. Edwards had $468,000 on hand while Mr. Duke had less than $262,000
As a result, Mr. Edwards has been broadcasting television advertisements for a week with no response from Mr. Duke, who has had to rely on two televised debates with Mr. Edwards and appearances on national talk shows to get his message across.
While Mr. Duke's money came mostly as small contributions from nearly 21,000 people, Mr. Edwards had about 1,500 contributors, including 302 who had given $5,000 each, the maximum permitted under Louisiana law.
With nine days remaining until the election, Mr. Edwards has developed a carefully structured campaign that is using many of the standard strategies and tools of contemporary American politics, like wide use of television and public opinion surveys. Mr.Duke, on the other hand, is exploiting the anti-incumbent fever and general hostility toward government that have produced surprises in many recent elections, including some of those earlier this week, but is vague on what programs he would promote and policies he would pursue.
Mr. Duke has made virtually no changes in his appeal to middle-class economic resentments and racial biases in this campaign. He focuses on national issues such as affirmative action programs and the tax burden on salaried workers rather than on matters of specific concern to voters in Louisiana.
 
Trying to Reach Out
 Mr. Edwards, however, has tried to reach out to new constituencies, a strategy that has required him to try to define his position on a variety of specific state policies.
Ever since he and Mr. Duke finished first and second in the Oct. 19 open primary, Mr. Edwards, a Democrat, has made a vigorous appeal to the supporters of the third-place finisher, Gov. Buddy Roemer, a Republican. He has offered to preserve Roemer programs in areas like government ethics, the environment and education and he has promised to rehire specific Roemer administration officials.
Rather than dwell on Mr. Duke's controversial past Mr. Edwards's television commercials attempt to portray a grim picture of what would happen to Louisiana if Mr. Duke should be elected. Against images of padlocks on factory gates and employees that vanish from their workplaces, one commercial states, "Unless Edwin Edwards is elected Governor, Louisiana's shaky economy could collapse."
Another ad proclaims, "This year's election is about unity." In another Mr. Edwards attempts to neutralize his image as a political insider by stating, "I may not be as good a friend to some people as I always was but I am going to be a better Governor than I ever was."
 
Appearance Before Power
 The contrast between the two candidates was clearly evident today when they appeared together before the annual meeting of the Louisiana Association of Business and Industry, an event that drew many of the most powerful men and women in the state.
Shedding much of the flamboyance and quick wit that used to mark his campaign appearances Mr. Edwards has tried to portray himself as an experienced and statesmanlike leader.
In his presentation to the business association, Mr. Edwards touched on subjects as diverse as vocational education and oil drilling permits as he offered a detailed review of his business and fiscal policies in his three terms in office, noting what things he would change.
On the critical issue of Louisiana's tax structure, which relies on the no-longer-abundant levies on the oil and gas industry, he said he would call a constitutional convention to review the entire subject.
 
Duke's Counterattack
 Mr. Duke, however, argued that that he would produce a better business climate as Governor by repeatedly hammering away at one generalization. "We need less government in Louisiana, not more government," he said. "That is what I am going to work for. That is the real issue."
And he repeatedly referred to Mr. Edwards's 12 years in the Governor's mansion between 1971 and 1987, painting his opponent as a virtual incumbent. "Edwin Edwards has already proved to us that he's against business," he said.
Returning to his favorite theme, he warned: "If we don't begin to solve the problems of the rising welfare underclass in our state, I can guarantee you that your taxes will go up. Your tort problems will increase, the insurance problems will increase and business will suffer."
Mr. Edwards has been endorsed by many top business executives in the tourism and convention industry, and today Mr. Duke's voice rose to an angry pitch as he lambasted those who would cancel meetings and sporting events should he be elected.
"Some liberals right now, people who are opposed to your interests, are trying to put pressure and intimidation on the people of Louisiana to vote against me," he said.
Earlier, Mr. Duke spoke out against what he perceived as another form of outside interference when he responded to harsh criticism from President Bush, who said Wednesday that Mr. Duke was unfit for public office because of past espousal of racist and Nazi beliefs.
"It is really improper and unfair for him to go in and support a very liberal Democrat who would devastate the Republican Party in Louisiana," said Mr. Duke, a registered Republican who has been disavowed by the state and national party organizations.
 
Wide Endorsement for Edwards
 Mr. Edwards has been endorsed by a wide array of business executives, leaders of professional groups, environmentalists and women's organizations that previously backed Mr. Roemer, but it is not an easy marriage. Many of these same people saw themselves as champions of reform against an unethical and outmoded regime when they helped Mr. Roemer unseat Mr. Edwards in 1987.
In his closing remarks Mr. Edwards spoke of "this unique opportunity to put together this coalition of people who heretofore never came together in a campaign."
Recognizing the doubts he has had to overcome he said, "I am here to tell you, I'm not going to blow it."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Away From It All, Bush Savors Rome

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 7

 BODY:
President Bush fairly bounded out of the double glass doors of the American Ambassador's palatial residence, Villa Taverna, today, extending his hand to Prime Minister John Major of Britain and crying, "Hello John!"
As the two posed for cameras, glancing upward and commenting on the clear blue Roman skies for lack of anything else to say in that peculiarly uncomfortable moment known as a photo op, Mr. Bush seemed visibly relieved. 
 After all, here he was in Rome, bonding with a fellow member of the club of world leaders, in which the President considers himself honorary chairman, and not back in Washington, where he had been hearing nothing but criticism of his domestic policies.
Instead of questions about unemployment lines, civil rights, abortion and the business dealings of former members of his staff, reporters here asked about subjects he likes: East-West relations and the future of Europe.
Of course, this is just the sort of jaunt overseas that has drawn Democratic political fire to the peripatetic Mr. Bush, as his opponents try to paint him as being focused on foreign affairs at the expense of American taxpayers.
Although Mr. Bush could hardly have canceled a meeting of the Atlantic alliance in response to domestic political pressure, as he did a visit to East Asia planned for this month, this is the first foreign trip during his Presidency in which the White House seems on the defensive.
It may even be the first time that a President, especially one so popular, has had such a political imbroglio over his constitutional duty to make and discharge foreign policy. Even President Richard M. Nixon managed to get a lift out of a visit to the Soviet Union on the eve of his resignation in 1974.
Mr. Bush's troubles wait for him at home. He is to return on Saturday to a series of fights with Congress and, undoubtedly, renewed criticism of his travels.
But for now at least, American officials said, the President is in good spirits. "He replied to the Democrats before he left, found something to be happy about in Tuesday's election results and now has a couple of days' break from the political hassles," one official said.
 
On the Defense at Dawn
 No wonder Mr. Bush was smiling all day. This trip has all the frills that he loves.
There were meetings to be held with presidents and prime ministers. There was a summit conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to attend. There were speeches on weighty matters to be delivered, and tonight there was a glittering affair of state at the Quirinale Palace at which President Francesco Cossiga was the host. Mr. Cossiga welcomed Mr. Bush with elaborate military honors, including mounted troops with brass helmets and breastplates.
This was a sharp contrast to Wednesday morning. The President had issued an extraordinary summons to reporters to go at dawn to the White House, and he stood in a chill autumn wind on the South Lawn and launched into an intensely defensive statement about his commitment to domestic issues.
His trip to Rome, he explained testily, is "a very important part of the responsibilities of the President working for peace around the world."
His talks with European leaders will "generate a lot of new business opportunities for American farmers particularly, but manufacturers and service industries as well."
The Asian trip that he canceled "does have some very important aspects, particularly the Japanese leg, because it affects jobs for America."
Suddenly, Mr. Bush sounded a lot less like a President with sky-high approval ratings who recently gave America its first big military victory in years and a lot more like a candidate trailing his opponent with only a few days before Election Day.
Indeed, at a meeting of his senior advisers before the news conference, John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, who an official said was the "architect" of Mr. Bush's decision not to go to Asia, wondered aloud how reporters would interpret that choice.
An official said Marlin Fitzwater, the press secretary, offered this analysis, "They'll spin it that we're running scared."
When Mr. Sununu expressed some surprise and asked how anyone could reach that conclusion, the official said Mr. Fitzwater replied, "Because the President of the United States called a news conference at 6:30 A.M., that's why."
 
Sununu in the Spotlight
 For Mr. Sununu, as well as Mr. Bush, this trip must have seemed a welcome break.
Just when he thought he was recovering from the political damage caused by his extensive use of military aircraft for personal travel, Mr. Sununu was rocked by the disclosure that his former personal aide, Edward M. Rogers Jr., had signed a $600,000 contract for the legal representation of Sheik Kamal Adham, a figure in the criminal investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International.
That left reporters scrutinizing Mr. Sununu again to see if he had any connection to the bank.
In Rome, the former New Hampshire Governor, who generally takes a back seat on foreign affairs, was right up front at the President's side. He was at every photo session with European leaders and took a prominent seat just behind the President's left elbow during the opening session of the NATO summit meeting.
Last year, when the alliance met in Rome in July, Mr. Sununu was nowhere to be seen. But that was before his political difficulties. "Ever since Sununu got in trouble, he's like Velcro at these meetings for photo ops," an American official said.
Still, Mr. Sununu seemed to have some difficulty getting into the diplomatic swing of things.
At one point while photographers recorded the opening session, Mr. Bush pulled a piece of paper out of a stack on the table before him, turned to his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and asked him a question.
Mr. Sununu, who was next to Mr. Scowcroft, tried to hitch his chair closer to join in the discussion. But Mr. Scowcroft by then had snared the document and began reviewing it without seeking Mr. Sununu's counsel.
 
Microphones That Bite
 Mr. Bush often professes his nonchalance about negative news coverage. But just as he avidly studies the public opinion polls that he says he never reads, the President pays close attention to what reporters write or broadcast about him.
Today, at a photo session with Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy before the NATO meeting began, Mr. Bush warned his colleague to beware the television microphones because they can pick up every word you say.
Gesturing at one, which was covered in a fuzzy material to filter stray noises, Mr. Bush told Mr. Andreotti: "These woolly animals give you a very hard time. They've bit me a time or two. I've been bitten by them once or twice."
He paused and added with a grin, "Not on purpose, I'm sure."
Mr. Andreotti looked baffled, leaving reporters watching this scene to wonder what sort of translation he was getting of Mr. Bush's comments.

HEADLINE: Weicker Drops State From Regional Clean-Air Effort

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Setting his state on a course independent of 11 other Northeastern states from Maine to Virginia, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said yesterday that Connecticut would not accept strict new standards on automobile emissions as part of a regional effort to control smog.
The other states have agreed among themselves to use a plan adopted by California that will eventually require cars that run on alternate fuels like natural gas, methanol and electricity. The plan phases in tighter controls on hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide, two chemical ingredients of smog, produced by cars powered by gasoline. 
 "Nobody knows what this technology is about," said Mr. Weicker when asked by reporters in Hartford yesterday morning. "Everybody is saying we want to do something, without knowing what it is they're going to go ahead and do. And it's very very expensive."
 
Support from Car Makers
 There is no legal requirement for the states to act jointly. The issue has been argued mostly among environmentalists and health advocates on one side, and auto and oil companies on the other, with little sign of interest from the general public.
With the rest of the Northeast moving rapidly to adopt the California program, some officials predicted yesterday that Connecticut would be swept along because auto makers would not bother to ship a different version of a car to an island with looser standards in the center of the Northeast market. Car dealers now swap unsold cars among themselves across state lines as they find customers for individual vehicles.
However, at General Motors, Alan R. Weverstad, the manager of emissions compliance, applauded Mr. Weicker's action and said his company would probably ship the cars demanded by the Connecticut market. "The residents of Connecticut will be afforded a better model mix and less cost," he said.
If Connecticut goes its own way, car buyers who want to register a vehicle in that state will have to buy it there. While states in the Northeast generally have not worked through the details, California forbids registration of a car that does not meet its emission standards if it has less than 7,500 miles on the odometer.
Most officials in neighboring states responded in measured terms to Mr. Weicker's decision, stressing that they hoped he would eventually change his mind. Still, they were not reticent about their disappointment, with some of the sharpest reaction coming from Thomas C. Jorling, New York's environment commissioner and a major force behind the multistate agreement.
 
Starting With 1996 Models
 He predicted that someday Connecticut would have to deal with its pollution problems by banning automobile use on some days, and putting controls on lawnmowers and barbecue grills, or making decisions on development that would curb economic growth.
In a telephone interview Mr. Jorling said, "they're willing to enjoy the benefits of increased reductions, but they're unwilling to participate in making reductions for their own citizens and the downwind states."
Even if Connecticut had decided to adopt the California standards for low-emission cars, it would not have made much difference in cutting pollution until well into the next century. The first cars with the equipment will not be available until the 1996 or 1997 model years, and it would take years after that before many of the cars on the road had the new equipment.
Mr. Weicker, who was a maverick Republican in the United States Senate before being elected Governor of Connecticut as an Independent, said he would keep an open mind and might reverse himself with new evidence, but said, "I am not convinced at this time as to the costs and the benefits."
In a statement explaining Connecticut's decision, Timothy R. E. Keeney, the commissioner of environmental protection, said the cost of the equipment would run $470 a car, and "economic models show that when you send that kind of money to Detroit, something has to give at home." The state's economy would contract if cars cost more, he said, and the result would be a loss of 1,300 to 8,000 jobs.
Car manufacturers have said the cost could run $1,000 a vehicle, while California experts say it would probably be under $200.
Connecticut has concluded that adopting California's program would remove pollutants at a cost that might be $15,000 per ton. The other states relied on a joint study that put the cost per ton of less than $3,400.
All pollutants drift across state lines with the wind, but smog -- or, more properly, ozone -- is a particular problem for downwind states. It takes hours for nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons, baked by the sun, to produce ozone, which is how rural areas can develop dangerous ozone levels.
In Massachusetts, which is usually downwind, Daniel S. Greenbaum, the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, said the Massachusetts Governor, William F. Weld, had become a supporter of the program in part because of the pleadings of the Governor of Maine, John R. McKernan Jr. "We shouldn't be polluting Acadia State Park in Maine any more than Connecticut should be polluting Cape Cod," Mr. Greenbaum said.
Yesterday, as Governor Weicker explained his decision to reporters, Rhode Island decided to join the multistate agreement. New York has been leading the call for adoption of the California standards, an option that the states were given by the Federal Clean Air Act. In Massachusetts, the Legislature has voted to adopt the standards. Last week the Governor of Vermont, Howard Dean, endorsed the plan and said he would submit it to that state's legislature. The other two New England states, New Hampshire and Maine, have also agreed, as have New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia.
Connecticut has said it will require cleaner gasoline, force gas stations to install equipment to recapture pollutant-laden fumes that are released in refueling, and make inspections stricter, among other steps. But Paul G. Billings, a lobbyist at the American Lung Association said, "they have not done anything more than announce what the law requires them to do."


GRAPHIC: Congress gave California the right to make its own rules to comply with Federal clean air standards. The other 49 states were told thaty they could folow the national program or adopt California's. New Jersey, New York, nine other states from Maine to Virginia and the District of Columbia have agreed to the plan. Connecticut will not go along, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said yesterday.
 
"More and more cars will have to comply" shows percentage of new cars that will have to meet new emissions standards.
 
"Emissions will be sharply reduced" shows output of the chemicals that make smog will be cut in stages. By 1999, most new cars will have to meet new standards for low emissions for the first 50,000 miles. Over the next four years more and more new cars will have to meet stricter standards for ultra-low emissions and for no emissions.

HEADLINE: Maxwell's Gift to Campus in Doubt

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Much as he did at The Daily News, Robert Maxwell swept like a gallant knight last summer into another New York City institution, Polytechnic University.
Mr. Maxwell, a trustee at the university since 1986, was elected chairman in July, then promptly announced that he would donate $10 million to begin a fund-raising campaign. Exuding what the university president called "an aura of a very successful businessman," he gave the sometimes beleaguered campus a sense of renewed confidence. 
 His abrupt death has shaken that confidence, plunging the university into grief and creating considerable uncertainty about its financial future. While Mr. Maxwell had pledged the largest donation in the university's history, he had not yet sent the check.
At the main campus on Jay Street in downtown Brooklyn, stunned students said that in a short time, the flamboyant 68-year-old publisher had endeared himself to students and that his interest had raised morale and built pride in a school that has a relatively small endowment and that nearly closed during a financial crisis in the 1970's.
"With Maxwell, we saw Poly heading in a lot of different directions," said Joseph Mirabile, a senior majoring in electrical engineering. "When we heard about his death, all of these expectations started to disappear."
The university president, Dr. George Bugliarello, said the trustees were to discuss the impact of Mr. Maxwell's death and begin a search for his replacement on the board at their regularly scheduled meeting on Tuesday, the same day Mr. Maxwell was to have turned over his $10 million donation to the school.
The gift would have nearly doubled the university's $13.3 million endowment, one of the smallest of any major technical institution in the country. A spokesman in London for Mr. Maxwell's media empire, which includes the Maxwell Communication Corporation and Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., said that the status of the pledge was uncertain and that his family had not made any decisions concerning his estate.
Mr. Maxwell's association with Polytechnic began in the mid-1970's when his publishing house, Pergamon Press, published Technology in Society, a scholarly journal edited by Dr. Bugliarello and a professor at the university, A. George Schillenger.
The university, founded in 1854 and known as Brooklyn Poly or just Poly, granted him an honorary degree in 1985, and a year later he joined the board of trustees. His involvement increased after his triumphant 11th-hour purchase of The Daily News in March.
"He told me he felt that after buying The Daily News, a great commercial enterprise of New York, he felt very strongly he should invest his time and money in making Polytechnic the great technological university for New York," said Joseph J. Jacobs, a university trustee and president of Jacobs Engineering Group in Pasadena, Calif.
Dr. Bugliarello said Mr. Maxwell, who never went to college, had a vision of international cooperation between the university and industry that he immediately put to practice. Though he presided over only the September board meeting, he reorganized the trustees, spearheaded a pay increase for professors and began to shape plans for a $200 million fund-raising drive.
 
'Spirit of Poly'
 After news of his disappearance, then death, spread through the university, a makeshift memorial to Mr. Maxwell -- an easel holding the front page of Wednesday's Daily News -- was set up in the lobby of Rogers Hall, the university's main building on Jay Street.
It was, students and professors said, a reflection of how deeply Mr. Maxwell's presence touched the university, which with 6,000 students lives in the shadow of larger, wealthier technical institutions like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Michael Papa, an electrical engineering student, said part of Mr. Maxwell's appeal was "a scrappy attitude" perfectly in sync with a student body of first- and second-generation immigrants, often the first in their families to go to college.
"He seemed to embody the spirit of Poly," he said.
Shortly after he took over as chairman, Mr. Maxwell held a reception in Rogers Hall, greeting some 300 students who filed through a receiving line -- a gesture described as at once imperial and utterly down to earth.
At the reception, the student president, Manuel Vara, surprised Mr. Maxwell by asking him to sign "a compact" vowing to commit himself, as much as the students, to the university's future.
With his big smile, Mr. Maxwell replied, "And are you Mephisto?"

HEADLINE: For Dinkins's South Africa Trip, A Donor List From Who's Who

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
More than a third of the money that Mayor David N. Dinkins has raised to finance his trip to South Africa next week came in a $50,000 check from the Speaker of the California Assembly, Willie L. Brown, according to a list of contributors released yesterday.
The list is also sprinkled with prominent New Yorkers like Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier and head of the Municipal Assistance Corporation; Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the developer, and Howard J. Rubenstein, the public relations executive. 
 "I think it is important for the Mayor to go to South Africa," said Mr. Rohatyn, explaining why he contributed. "I think emotionally for him, it's like the first time I went to Jerusalem."
Mr. Brown was in meetings yesterday and could not be reached for comment, but his spokesman, Michael Reese, said Mr. Brown often makes such private donations. Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Rubenstein could not be reached for comment.
City officials released the list as they outlined details of the trip for the first time. The Mayor is scheduled to meet with Nelson Mandela and other leaders of the African National Congress, the main black party in South Africa, but city officials said yesterday that it appears unlikely that the Mayor would meet, as hoped, with the South African President, F. W. de Klerk, or the leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, the major black party opposing the A.N.C.
 
Meeting Scuttled
 Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch said President de Klerk plans to be out of the country during the Mayor's visit. And African National Congress officials scuttled a meeting with Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the leader of Inkatha and Mr. Mandela's main rival among black leaders in the country, Mr. Lynch said.
"Most of the itinerary was negotiated by the A.N.C. and not by us," Mr. Lynch said.
A total of $145,434 was raised for the trip, city officials said, much of it coming from city officials, civic leaders and news organizations that are paying their own travel expenses to accompany the Mayor. The figure is incomplete because many going wrote checks directly to a commercial airline. The organization collecting money for the trip is the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit entity that the Mayor used to raise money for the parade for Persian Gulf veterans.
City officials said the final cost for the trip had yet to be determined. The only money coming from taxpayers will be the cost for more than a dozen bodyguards for the Mayor.
 
Defraying Expenses
 Since most of the 33 city commissioners, clergy members and private citizens in the delegation have been asked to pay their own way, the contributions from Speaker Brown and others not going will, in effect, defray the expenses for about 10 support staff members, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch and the Mayor's wife, Joyce. The Mayor initially said he would not pay for his expenses but later reversed himself and donated $5,000.
The fund-raising became a focus of attention in September when the Mayor was forced to cancel his first plan to charter a plane and take a larger delegation. That trip fell through because Mr. Lynch, overburdened with the racial crisis in Crown Heights, failed to raise the $500,000 the trip would have cost.
The collapse of the trip stung the Mayor personally and was seen by many in the government as a sign of disorganization at the upper levels of his administration. In October, the Mayor announced a scaled-down version of the trip, with the delegation paying its way. He also delivered a stinging speech countering the critics, saying that he hoped his commissioners could lend technical expertise to the African National Congress and forge economic ties between New York and those he believes will run a post-apartheid Government.
None of the contributors do business with the city, Mr. Lynch said. He said the trip organizers had also rejected donations from several companies and corporations doing business in South Africa.

HEADLINE: Tax Cut for Middle Class Urged by Rostenkowski

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the most influential tax writer in Congress, today introduced a tax cut for working-class and middle-income families that would be offset by taxes on the wealthy.
The proposal was immediately endorsed by the House leadership, underscoring the Democratic strategy of promoting the interests of the middle class as the Presidential election season nears. 
 Mr. Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which initiates all Federal tax legislation. As such, he is the Congressional leader on taxes.
The proposal that he offered today, one of several tax-cutting measures that have been advanced by lawmakers in recent weeks, would create an income-tax credit equal to 20 percent of the Social Security and Medicare taxes that a worker paid. The maximum credit would be $200 for a single taxpayer and $400 for a working couple.
 
Would Last Two Years
 About 16 million workers with little or no tax liability would be eligible for smaller credits, but Mr. Rostenkowski's plan focuses on individuals and families with incomes of between $20,000 and $75,000 a year.
The tax cuts would last for two years. They would be paid for over five years by two provisions that Mr. Rostenkowski's legislation would make permanent: a 10 percent surcharge on taxable incomes above $1 million and a new, higher tax bracket, 35 percent, on incomes above $85,000 for individuals and $145,000 for couples.
"This will help middle-income taxpayers who have been neglected over the last decade," Mr. Rostenkowski said at a news conference today."Although it is not a big-money bill, it still does something for the economy."
Like other lawmakers, Mr. Rostenkowski said there was no chance of winning passage of a tax cut before Congress adjourns for the year later this month. Proponents of the various proposals are all aiming for Congressional action early next year.
 
Republicans Cool to Idea
 House Democrats promoted Mr. Rostenkowski's plan as a way of improving the fairness of the Federal tax system while leaving two things untouched: last year's White House-Congressional agreement intended to restrict budget deficits, and the Social Security reserves that will be needed when the baby-boom generation starts retiring early in the next century.
But Republicans gave the proposal a cool reception. Indeed, one Republican supporter of a rival plan, Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the ranking minority member of the Senate Finance Subcommittee on Taxation, said the Rosentkowski bill had no chance of becoming law. "The President has said he would veto an increase in tax rates, and that veto would be sustained," he said.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, attended Mr. Rostenkowski's news conference and embraced the plan. "As the President grapples and gropes for a real response to a recession that has lasted over a year," Mr. Gephardt said, "Democrats led by the Ways and Means Committee chairman resume our historic role of hearing the problems of the middle class."
On Wednesday, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, proposed a $300 tax credit for each child up to 18 years old and full deductibility, for all wage earners, of up to $2,000 in contributions to individual retirement accounts.

NAME: Roger Lowenstein

SECTION: Section B; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk; Law Page

LENGTH: 794 words

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
From Hoboken to Hollywood: A 1960's Idealist Finds a Home in 1990's Television.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
A little more than a year ago, Roger Lowenstein was sitting in his law office in Hoboken, blearily looking out at the Clam Broth House next door. It was 10 o'clock at night. He still had not eaten dinner. Everyone else had long since gone home and he still had loads of work to do. His marriage had disintegrated, in part because of the demands of his work. As courts grew clogged and the practice more complicated, his law work had turned from trying cases to pushing paper. Moreover, his partners grew increasingly rebellious, his clients unappreciative, and, it seemed to him, the profession more cynical.
In short, Mr. Lowenstein was experiencing yet another existential crisis in his 47-year-old lawyerly life, one that came to an end only when a friend, a Hollywood type, called to entice him out with tales of the good life. 
 One day, the story goes, Sherwood Anderson grew so fed up with making paint in Elyria that he packed his bags and began walking to Chicago, where he wrote "Winesburg, Ohio."
Similarly, with that phone call Mr. Lowenstein decided to suspend his practice and follow his muse to Los Angeles, where, through a series of flukes, he became a writer for the television series "L.A. Law."
Alas, Mr. Lowenstein's tenure was brief; after a mere 15 weeks, he and two other newly recruited lawyer-writers were axed. Recession has reached McKenzie Brackman as much as it has real law firms. But Mr. Lowenstein remains so enthralled by the experience that what was supposed to be a sabbatical from the law has become permanent exile.
The course of a career like Mr. Lowenstein's is a blueprint for a whole generation of lawyers. They went to college (in his case, the University of Michigan) and law school (Harvard) during the New Frontier and the Great Society. Infused with idealism, they took low-paying but psychically rewarding jobs in the public sector. (Mr. Lowenstein was New Jersey's first Federal public defender). A few years, children and mortgages later, these lawyers entered more mainstream, remunerative forms of practice.
Cut to that fateful night in June 1990, with Mr. Lowenstein, by now a miserable $200,000-a-year lawyer, peering out his office window. By September, he was on his way to California, half titillated, half terrified. As things turned out, he took to Tinseltown like Gauguin to Tahiti.
His first gig was as a $300-a-week technical adviser to the A.B.C. program "Equal Justice." Soon he was writing scripts for two other shows, "Law and Order" and "The Human Factor." Then, in the spring of 1991, he was one of three real-life lawyers hired to help write episodes of "L.A. Law," a show lawyers either love or love picking apart.
Mr. Lowenstein soon found himself at 20th Century Fox, toiling in the very cubbyholes where Faulkner, Fitzgerald and Pearl S. Buck once worked. He spent his days brainstorming with other writers, hobnobbing with Richard Dysart and other stars of the show, and fielding phone calls from envious lawyers.
In fact, his lawyer friends were far more impressed, he ventured, than if he had he been named to the United States Supreme Court. Some called begging for guest appearances. Once, his father called to complain about the status of Leland McKenzie, the fictitious firm's erstwhile pillar of rectitude, who had taken up with Rosalind Shays, the dragon lady running the place.
"I told him, look, the guy's been a stiff for five years; give him a break, give him a little sex," Mr. Lowenstein recalled. He reports that his father is now a happy man; Shays subsequently fell down an elevator shaft and Mr. Dysart, who portrays MacKenzie, sent him an autographed glossy.
But in August, the bubble burst. With production falling perilously behind schedule, the show cashiered its three lawyer-writers and brought in a senior producer. "I was stunned," Mr. Lowenstein recalled. "I felt like Mike Tyson had just punched me in the stomach." Now, he is back to writing scripts as a free-lancer.
Mr. Lowenstein left behind a pile of plots. Never, now, will Arnie Becker, the show's waspish lawyer, appear before a rabbinical court, or Bennie, its retarded messenger, visit the Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library to learn more about Watergate. But far from feeling bitter, Mr. Lowenstein, who says he has earned $80,000 over the last 12 months, feels reborn, partly because he believes he is reaching more people now than he ever did in practice.
"Roger Lowenstein in 1968 would have poo-pooed writing for television because, unlike the law, it wasn't an adequate vehicle for making the world a better place," he said. "But given the growing cynicicm of lawyers and judges, I was simply wrong. Besides, this is fun -- and most lawyers don't have enough fun."

HEADLINE: School That Battles To Save Small Souls

SERIES: Life at the Bottom: Mott Haven, the Bronx -- Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
The main entrance to St. Luke's Elementary School is on East 139th Street. You can't get in that way, though. The doors are locked to guard against the open drug dealing on the block.
Instead, you enter the school from East 138th Street, walking past a litter-strewn lot and through a dim alley screened by razor wire. The passageway, speckled with graffiti, is a dreary exercise in urban blight. But just inside the back door, where a hall monitor in a St. Luke's tie is posted, all traces of the street wondrously disappear. 
 There are paper pumpkins and fish colored by childish hands. There are bake sales and curtains decorated with balloons and plays put on by kindergartners. There are, in short, all the trappings of a snug suburban school nestled in some of the meanest streets of Mott Haven, one of the meanest sections of the South Bronx.
In a neighborhood where most institutions are regarded with mistrust or worse, and where a sense of community is usually no match for the pervasive sense of powerlessness, St. Luke's is a rare place indeed, a small island of hopefulness amid the general despair.
But no school, no matter how fiercely it tries to keep the outside world at bay, can fully insulate its students from their surroundings. So at St. Luke's, education is regarded as a battle for small souls that must be waged anew each day.
Victory, says the Rev. Gerald Ryan of St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church, belongs to the vigilant. The school's mission, he said, "is sowing the seed and watching it, and taking care of it and not giving up on it."
So cheery is St. Luke's compared with the streets outside that on entering, one feels as if one had slipped, Alice in Wonderland-like, into some fictional space. But even the most casual conversation with a St. Luke's student demonstrates the fragility of the glue-and-construction-paper peace that exists inside the school walls.
Marcelina Maldonado is a chatty, outgoing fifth grader with fluffy bangs. Talking about herself, she begins innocently enough. She would like, she says, to be like Kelly, her favorite character in the television series "Beverly Hills 90210." "Kelly has a car," she explains gravely. But after a few minutes on this theme, she abruptly changes the topic.
"A teen-ager, he was my best friend, he passed away," she says. "He was stabbed."
"My mother," she continues, "is wanting to move to Florida, because she's sick and tired of it all. There be shootouts all the time, and so many drug dealers."
The violence and the drug dealing often press up right against St. Luke's gray exterior. Recently, drug dealers began doing business from the schoolyard, setting up lounge chairs underneath the basketball hoops. When St. Luke's principal, Sister Pat Howell, asked them to leave so the children could play outside during lunch, they agreed, then returned as soon as the lunch hour ended. Now there is a policeman stationed by the playground every day at noon.
By the standards of Mott Haven, a neighborhood whose history has been fragmented by successive waves of arson and abandonment, St. Luke's is an unusual example of stability. The school was founded in 1903 and has operated continuously since then.
As the resources of the community have contracted, St. Luke's has tried to make up some of the difference. Evenings, neighborhood teen-agers who do not attend St. Luke's use its gym for basketball. After they leave, the gym becomes an overnight shelter for a dozen homeless men.
But St. Luke's itself is hardly immune from the recessionary pressures that have shrunk funds for schools and social programs across New York City. Last year, the Archdiocese of New York, which oversees the school, cut St. Luke's subsidy in half. The school now has a shortfall of $106,000 out of a total operating budget of $550,000. To save money, it has begun to share some of its staff members, including its gym teacher, with other Catholic schools in the area. It has begun a fund-raising drive among alumni, and has raised its tuition by $10 a year.
Still, no one seems to be quite sure how the shortfall will be met. "To get that amount of money," said Anna Reese, whose daughter, Yaneira, is a fifth grader at St. Luke's, "you have to have a miracle."
Measured against the average family income in the neighborhood, roughly $7,600, St. Luke's tuition -- $900 a year for parishioners, $1,050 for nonparishioners -- is substantial. The fact that the school costs money to attend suggests that its students are more affluent than those who attend the nearby public schools, and their parents more highly motivated.
Yet St. Luke's students, kindergartners through eighth graders, are fairly representative of the neighborhood at large, and of its many troubles. Almost 60 percent of St. Luke's students come from households receiving some form of public assistance. Most come from families headed by single mothers.
Sister Pat, a lanky woman with the kindly unflappable air of someone who has seen, and learned to deal with, just about everything, has worked at the school since 1977. Over the years, she says, she has seen virtually all of the troubles that have afflicted Mott Haven show up in one form or another among students at St. Luke's.
"It's not that they're coming from single-parent homes," she said of the new breed of students, "it's that they're coming from their grandparents. And the younger kids are more violent; they have more learning disabilities."
The violence and drug dealing in the neighborhood have prompted many families to leave Mott Haven, Sister Pat continued, making the school population increasingly transient. "You used to have 95 percent of the kids go K through eight," she said. "Now 50 percent go all the way through."
 
Pent-Up Energy
 Because of the dangers of the neighborhood, many of the children are not allowed to leave their apartments except to come to school, and their pent-up energy is ferocious, Sister Pat said. "At lunchtime, you have to let them just run. For some of these kids, it's the only time they'll get out."
So pervasive is the violence in the neighborhood that students at St. Luke's seem almost to be inured to it; they discuss gruesome murders in the same tone they use to talk about their friends and the games they play.
"When I first moved here I was scared," said Michael Orta, a fifth grader. "I heard Uzi gunshots. They started going real fast, and the police found a magazine. But now I feel used to it. I know who's a drug dealer, and who's not."
Parents of St. Luke's students offer a variety of reasons for sending their children to parochial school, few directly related to the religious training the school provides. They point to the school's security, its discipline and its dress code -- blue plaid skirts for girls, dark pants and ties for boys -- which, they say, eliminates competition among the children for expensive clothes. Most frequently, they point to the generally poor condition of the local public schools.
"If you're poor, you have to get a decent education," Mrs. Reese said.
Based on their reading scores, the public schools in Mott Haven are among the worst in New York City. Public School 65, for example, which is three blocks north of St. Luke's on East 141st Street, ranked 616th out of the city's 633 elementary schools in reading scores. Only 48 percent of P.S. 65's students read above remedial level, while at St. Luke's the figure is 70 percent.
 
Most Finish High School
 Almost all of St. Luke's graduates finish high school, and many go on to college. The school, however, has had its share of tragedies. Three years ago, for example, one of its graduates was killed in a drug deal gone sour. Recently, St. Luke's teachers have spotted another graduate dealing drugs in the neighborhood.
Sonia Andujar is one of St. Luke's success stories, a graduate who went on to college and then returned to teach at the school herself, although she now lives in the safer precincts of the North Bronx, near Pelham Parkway. Ms. Andujar's classroom is a classic scene of kindergarten, with tiny chairs and fuzzy drawings and big block letters lining the walls.
But the stories she hears from her pupils are not the kind one expects to hear from 5-year-olds. "They say 'When I grow up, I don't want to be hanging out, I don't want to be drunk,' " she said. "They want to grow up to be somebody."
"Everybody," she said, "says ugh, the South Bronx. But I think that the people here are worth something. They're not all bad."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 8, 1991

SECTION: Section C; Page 23; Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1265 words

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
The lure of the bargain is the main attraction in the print market this fall. From the size of the crowds recently at both Sotheby's and Christie's in New York and the traffic at last weekend's Print Fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, it appeared that business was booming.
But while the market is showing definite signs of recovery from its spring slump, the enthusiasm may have been greater than the money spent. "People are still holding back," said Christopher Drake, who runs the print department of Agnew's in London. But David P. Tunick, a Manhattan dealer, reports renewed interest in prints. "Old clients are coming back to us saying, 'Tempt me,' " he said. "There's a pent-up yearning to buy." 
 But only if the price is right. As the recent New York auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's showed, sales depended largely on what bidders thought of the auction houses' estimates.
At Sotheby's two days of print auctions last Friday and Saturday, sales totaled $5,280,155. Seventy-one percent of the 788 lots found buyers. These figures are slightly better than May's sales but well below last November's $12.5 million total for a comparable two-day period. For the most part, prices last weekend hovered around the low estimates. "Last spring people just sat on their hands waiting to see if we've hit bottom," said Susan Pinsky, who heads Sotheby's print department. "It appears we have. Bidding was active because people have begun to realize this is a good time to buy."
Christie's auctions, held Monday and Tuesday, brought in less money than Sotheby's -- sales totaled $2,568,247 -- but Christie's offered fewer prints. Of the 356 lots on the block, 73 percent sold. A year ago, Christie's print sales totals were nearly three times as much, $6,833,640, for a comparable period. But these recent figures were slightly better than the $2,456,872 total in May, and the number of lots sold rose from May's 65.6 percent
Since the 15th century, when woodcuts of devotional images were sold, prints have always attracted a broad spectrum of collectors. Today rare prints can cost upward of $1 million, but they can also be found for as little as $50. In fact, for years prints have been to the art world what the Gap is to retailing -- accessible and stylish.
But when the art market went wild in the late 1980's, the Japanese began to buy prints with a fervor. Treating them as though they were works of fine art, Japanese buyers spent huge sums, especially on artists like Chagall, Miro and Dubuffet. Prices at auction set records. "The Japanese were the spark plug and we had the gas," recalled Brooke Alexander, whose SoHo gallery specializes in contemporary prints. "To stay in business we had to play the game."
The Japanese weren't the only force driving up the market. Mr. Tunick recalled that in the late 80's, when painting prices were going through the roof, many serious collectors began to buy prints and drawings instead of what they considered overpriced fine art. Mr. Tunick also saw museums buying prints then too, spending well into six figures.
But Richard Solomon, who heads the contemporary print department at Pace Prints, a Manhattan gallery, said the party ended in the spring. "Newton proved right. Gravity does exist. Both the Japanese and the auction houses had driven us to hysteria. When the whole art world felt the hot flash of demand, they stopped paying attention to reality. Now we're trying to get back on track to what was traditionally a smaller, sounder market." As business has slowed, prices have returned to what dealers say are 1986-87 levels, an exact mirror of the Impressionist, modern and contemporary markets.
Still, there appears to be a renewed enthusiasm. At the Print Fair's opening, a free invitation-only viewing, attendance was about 2,800, a record for an armory art opening. Moreover, this was the first Print Fair, which is sponsored by the International Fine Print Dealers Association. At the print auctions, both Sotheby's and Christie's had standing-room-only crowds. And last week alone, Mr. Tunick said, more than $2 million worth of prints were either bought or reserved at his Manhattan gallery.
Speaking of Sotheby's sale last week, Ms. Pinsky said, "When prints didn't sell, it was because the estimates were still too high." But at both the auctions and at the Print Fair, popular and rare prints commanded high prices.
For example, Agnew's sold a Matisse "Jazz" to a German museum for $350,000 at the Print Fair.
At Sotheby's, Edvard Munch's "Young Girls on the Bridge" was sold for $187,000 to Lionel Epstein, a Washington collector who was reportedly acting as an agent for another collector. The print had been estimated to sell for $100,000 to $150,000.
Also fetching top dollar at Sotheby's was David Hockney's "Image of Celia." The print was estimated to sell for $130,000 to $150,000 but the $110,000 it brought was considered a high price in the trade. So was the figure for Mary Cassatt's "Gathering Fruit," which fetched $104,500, just above Sotheby's estimate of $80,000 to $100,000.
Both auction houses were selling Manet's "Courses." Sotheby's version sold for $57,750, just below its low estimate of $60,000. That was a conservative figure compared with Christie's estimate of $180,000 to $220,000 for its print, which did not sell. "Ours was in considerably better condition," explained Elisabeth Hahn, who heads Christie's print department. "But I'm not sure even if we had put a lower estimate on it if it would have sold. Having the same print for sale at both auction houses is hard, even though it was a print that hadn't been on the market for 12 years."
Figuring out realistic estimates for prints can be tricky because the print market has several mini-markets, each with its own collectors and its own price levels. Old Masters, for example, have barely been affected by the market fluctuations. "That's because it takes courage to buy top Old Master prints," Mr. Tunick said. "They're not flashy enough to appeal to speculators."
Other print markets include American prints up to 1950, mid to late 19th- and 20th-century prints and contemporary prints. Right now American prints by such artists as Hopper, Whistler and Cassatt are all doing well. It is those artists who were purely driven by the Japanese bidders who have fared the worst.
Contemporary prints have also lost much of their value since prices soared three years ago. "When the market for paintings took a nose dive so did we," Mr. Alexander said. This was the part of the print market that saw the greatest inflation during the boom years. Now prints by artists like Jasper Johns are worth only about half what they were three years ago. For example: At Sotheby's last week, Mr. Johns's "Periscope I," estimated to bring $20,000 to $25,000, sold for $22,000. The same print sold for $53,000 exactly three years ago. "But our estimate then was only about $22,000, which shows we're back to a realistic, steady market again," Ms. Pinsky explained.
And back to an active contemporary-print market as well -- one that startled experts at both auction houses. The large number of dealers bidding in the recent print sales was a surprise, too. At Christie's, for example, 8 of the top 10 lots were bought by dealers.
Gem Hom, a Manhattan dealer who specializes in 19th- and 20th-century prints, said he and his colleagues were buying wherever they could find good material. "The time is right," he said. "It's really a buyers' market. And I'm sure next year prices won't be any cheaper."
