HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

Sondheim at Carnegie Hall
Although there's no official announcement yet, the show everyone will want to see next spring (April 22, to be exact) won't be on Broadway, but at Carnegie Hall. A tribute to Stephen Sondheim is in the very early planning stages, with Ken Marsolais producing the gala as a benefit for the hall. 
 Mr. Marsolais says it would be premature to comment, but another executive involved in the production says that Scott Ellis and Susan Stroman (the director and choreographer, respectively, of "And the World Goes 'Round," the John Kander and Fred Ebb revue Off Broadway) will do the same for this show, and Paul Gemignani will conduct. Patti LuPone and Dorothy Loudon have both signed on, the executive says; Angela Lansbury has been asked to be mistress of ceremonies, and Victor Garber, Bernadette Peters, Mandy Patinkin and Madonna (remember "Dick Tracy"?) have also been asked to participate.
 
Carry a Big Tote Bag
 It's the height of shopping season on Broadway, and producers are looking for that special something: a theater for the spring. Two shows now making the rounds are "A Small Family Business," the American premiere of the Alan Ayckbourn comedy to be directed by Lynne Meadow for Manhattan Theater Club, and Mike Nichols's production of "Death and the Maiden."
Ms. Meadow is in the enviable position of searching for space, since "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" continues to thrive at City Center. Because the Ayckbourn play, about an honest man who takes over his family business, requires a two-level set, Ms. Meadow has looked at a variety of Shubert theaters. Although no contracts have been signed, Brian Murray will probably play the lead, she says. Ms. Meadow also says an Off Broadway theater is possible, which would lower production costs.
"Death and the Maiden," by the Chilean playwright Ariel Dorfman, is about a woman who has been tortured and plots her revenge. With the stars Mr. Nichols wants for the three-character play, he'll need a lot of seats. One executive involved in the negotiation says that the lead will probably go to Juliet Stevenson, the English actress currently playing the role in Lindsay Posner's production at the Royal Court Theater in London; that Gene Hackman plans to fly to London next week to see the show, and that Richard Dreyfuss has been approached for the third role.
 
End of 'The Good Times'
 "The Good Times Are Killing Me," the play by Lynda Barry about a young girl growing up in a racially mixed neighborhood in the early 1960's, will close at the Minetta Lane Theater on Nov. 24, and no one involved is exactly sure why.
When it opened in April at the Second Stage, the show received mostly positive reviews and extended its run there through June. It moved to the Minetta Lane in Greenwich Village for an Aug. 8 opening, with David Mirvish and the Second Stage producing. Business was strong until the Jewish holy days, a customary lull for most shows, says Robyn Goodman, the co-artistic director of the Second Stage. But it never bounced back.
"I wonder if it was because the show is about two girls," Ms. Goodman says. "Programmers have found with television that girls will cross over as an audience for stories about boys, but boys won't cross over if the story is about girls."
Maybe. But one executive close to the show who spoke on condition of anonymity questions its marketing strategy. "The producers and the advertising agency tried to go after too many audiences instead of focusing on one," the executive says. "The show could be sold to kids, baby boomers, blacks, or a downtown audience, since Lynda Barry's cartoons in The Village Voice have such a big following. But instead of focusing on one group, they tried all of them and never got enough of any."
Ms. Goodman replies: "Marketing is such an easy thing to throw a potshot at. We definitely went after family audiences, but at some point you just have to let a show get its own legs."
Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which is an investor in "Good Times," says the real reason for its early demise is a combination of the recession and a change in theatergoing patterns. "It seems that unless a play has some twist to get people out of the house, like 'M. Butterfly,' they're not going anymore. We're losing the people who go to the theater as part of their regular routine. When money is tight, a ticket to a play is the first leisure item to go."
Ms. Goodman says a national tour of "Good Times" is planned.
 
Congratulating a Playwright
 So far, there hasn't been terribly much to celebrate in the theater this season, so the talk of the week is the lavish fete given Tuesday night for the playwright Harry Kondoleon on the publication of "Self Torture and Strenuous Exercise: The Selected Plays of Harry Kondoleon" by Theater Communications Group. Stephen Graham, chairman of the board of the New York Theater Workshop, gave the party with his wife, Cathy, in their town house, and it outshone many a Broadway opening night.
The guest list was a theatrical who's who: the playwrights Wendy Wasserstein, Paul Rudnick, David Henry Hwang, Jay Presson Allen and Charles Busch; the composer William Finn; Robyn Goodman and Carole Rothman, co-artistic directors of Second Stage; Lynne Meadow, artistic director of Manhattan Theater Club, and Andre Bishop, artistic director of Playwrights Horizons.
A reading of Mr. Kondoleon's new play, "Half Off," will be held for an invited audience on Nov. 18 at Playwrights Horizons. It is about a husband and wife who are killed in a car crash, and what happens when their respective sisters must decide the future of the couple's children. (Mr. Kondoleon calls the play a comedy.) Elizabeth Wilson, Jane Cronin and Mitchell Lichtenstein will be in the cast.
 
A Hirschfeld Book-Signing
 He's older than Methuselah and younger than springtime, and if your name is Nina, he's your kind of guy. Al Hirschfeld's new book, "Hirschfeld: Art and Recollections From Eight Decades," is just out from Charles Scribner's Sons, and the artist will sign copies at the Margo Feiden Galleries, 699 Madison Avenue, at 62d Street, Manhattan, today through Monday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. The theater drawings range from Mr. Hirschfeld's first, of the French playwright and actor Sacha Guitry, which appeared in The New York Herald Tribune in 1926, to "Miss Saigon," which ran in The New York Times last spring.

Mark Lamos will direct the drama about an expatriate English psychiatrist in Beverly Hills, trying to get away from his in-laws and his practice. Performances begin in March. HEADLINE: HEEDING ELECTIONS, LAWMAKERS OFFER HEALTH-CARE IDEAS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Congress reacted quickly today to Tuesday's election results, with Senate Republicans contending that the White House was moving too slowly to develop a health-care program and Democrats and Republicans alike objecting to a plan to divert $1 billion from the Pentagon budget to aid the Soviet Union.
Nineteen Republicans, including Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, offered comprehensive legislation to provide basic medical care to most of the 34 million Americans who lack health insurance. As for the Soviet aid plan, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle said that the $1 billion would be better spent helping poor people in the United States than providing food, medicine and other "humanitarian assistance" to the Soviet Union. 
 "Several months ago, I predicted that health care would be the No. 1 issue in the 1992 Presidential campaign," Mr. Dole said, "and judging by the intensifying focus on health care, it looks like my prediction is coming true."
 
Who Would Pay?
 Both Republicans and Democrats would try to create incentives for people to buy private insurance. But one Democratic idea would go so far as to virtually eliminate the private health insurance industry, supplanting it with public insurance.
The Republicans estimated the cost of their proposal at $150 billion over five years but did not say how they would pay for it -- a significant omission that was all the more striking because many of the sponsors consider themselves fiscal conservatives.
The Republicans emphasized that they had been working on their health-care proposal since July 1990, but they cited the stunning upset in the Senate election in Pennsylvania as evidence that voters wanted action. Senator Harris Wofford, the Democratic candidate who called for expanding health-care coverage, trounced former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who once was Governor of Pennsylvania, by a 55-to-45 ratio.
 
'Significant Action' Predicted
 "The Pennsylvania elections indicated clearly that the American people want the health-care issues addressed," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. He predicted that Congress would take "significant action" before adjourning next year.
Mr. Bush acknowledged the potency of such political concerns earlier this week, when he called off plans for a two-week tour of the Far East, under growing pressure to combat the recession and pay more attention to domestic problems. Mr. Bush said the White House was working on health-care proposals, but there was no sign of urgency about the issue among his aides before Mr. Bush departed Wednesday morning for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Rome.
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, chief sponsor of the Republican bill, said he and his Senate colleagues were not waiting for the White House. "I don't know who gives marching orders or who marches to the orders, because clearly we don't," he said.
Mr. Chafee said the Republican plan would help control health costs while offering some health insurance to "nearly everybody" who now lacks it.
 
Tax Credits Proposed
 The Republican bill would create new tax credits and tax deductions to help individuals, families and small businesses buy health insurance and pay medical expenses, especially for preventive care. It would more than double Federal spending for community health centers, to $1.3 billion a year in 1996. It would limit damages for "pain and suffering" in medical malpractice lawsuits, a step some say would lower overall medical costs, and it would establish a new public program to finance health care for low-income people ineligible for Medicaid.
Under the bill, the Federal Government would, for the first time, regulate private insurance premiums to make sure that coverage is affordable and available to small businesses, many of which are now priced out of the market. This proposal is anathema to many insurance companies but appears to have an excellent chance of becoming law because it is favored by two powerful Democrats, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman of the Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
The Republican bill would also encourage use of health-maintenance organizations and other "managed care," in which people get a discount for using certain doctors and hospitals.
More than 60 House Democrats support a bill calling for a Canadian-style system offering universal access to health care through a single publicly administered program. Many Senate Democrats would require employers either to provide health insurance for their workers or to pay a special tax to finance a new public health-care program for the uninsured.
 
Second Look at Aid
 A bipartisan storm of criticism erupted in Congress today over the proposal to shift $1 billion from the Pentagon budget to provide economic and humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union. The proposal had already been approved by House and Senate negotiators, but lawmakers said today that if the Pentagon could spare the money, it should be spent on domestic problems.
"At a time when our own country is feeling the worst economic times in decades, and where one out of 10 people is on food stamps, it's going to be extremely difficult to suggest to the American people that we have resources available to provide $1 billion to the Soviet Union," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
Conservative Republicans said they would rather spend the money on poor people in America than on poor people in the Soviet Union.
 
Alternative to Canada
 Senate Republicans portrayed their health-care package as an alternative to Democratic demands for a publicly financed program of national health insurance modeled after Canada's.
Republicans said their bill differed from the leading Democratic proposals in several ways: It seeks to create incentives for more people to buy private health insurance, but it would not impose new Federal mandates on employers, nor would it establish a nationwide publicly financed program of health insurance.
Senator Christopher S. Bond of Missouri, a co-sponsor of the Republican bill, said the liberal Democrats' proposals were "a health-care fantasyland run by a bigger and bigger Government."
Administration officials, especially John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, have indicated that President Bush would prefer to put off legislative action on health care till after the 1992 elections. But Senator Bond said Mr. Sununu "is not driving our bus."
Senator Chafee said that 34 of the 43 Republican Senators had been serving on a panel that investigated the costs of health care and the problems of the uninsured.
 
'This Is Serious Business'
 Asked if the Pennsylvania election results were a warning to politicians, Mr. Chafee said: "We didn't need any warning shot. We've been preaching this for a long time, that this is serious business. And Republicans better get with it."
In a response typical of Democrats today, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said, "Our Republican colleagues in the Senate have placed themselves miles ahead of the Bush White House, but they are still light-years behind the American people."
John M. Gibbons, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, welcomed the Republican senators' proposal without endorsing its details. "It's a serious effort, and we commend Senator Chafee," he said.
Mr. Gibbons said the Administration supports efforts to make health insurance more available to small businesses, to encourage health maintenance organizations and to curb excessive awards in malpractice suits.
Eddie Mahe, a political consultant who has advised dozens of Republican candidates, said the Pennsylvania results meant that "President Bush must now put forth some kind of health-care initiative next year."
"This Democratic Congress fully intends to move such legislation, assuming the Democrats can reach enough consensus in their own ranks to do so," Mr. Mahe said. "If the President is once again in a reactive position, that would not serve him well."
In the 1988 campaign, the Democratic candidate for President, Michael S. Dukakis, supported a proposal that would have required employers to provide health insurance for their employees or to finance such coverage through a surcharge on payroll taxes.
The co-sponsors of Senator Chafee's bill, besides Mr. Bond, Mr. Dole and Mr. McCain, were Senators William S. Cohen of Maine, Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, John C. Danforth of Missouri, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, Slade Gorton of Washington, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, Connie Mack of Florida, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, Ted Stevens of Alaska, Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming and John W. Warner of Virginia.
The proposal to aid the Soviet Union was devised by the chairmen of the Armed Services Committees, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, both Democrats. It is intended to increase American security by reducing the chance of turmoil in the Soviet Union.
Under the proposal, President Bush could use up to $1 billion of Pentagon money to transport and distribute surplus food, medicine and other "emergency humanitarian aid" to the Soviet Union.
Senate and House supporters of the proposal predicted last week that it would win quick approval. But today it encountered criticism on both political and procedural grounds. Some lawmakers said it violated the 1990 budget agreement and infringed on the prerogatives of the Congressional committees normally responsible for foreign aid.
Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, said the use of Pentagon money for Soviet aid would set "a dangerous precedent opening the door to using defense accounts" for nonmilitary purposes.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
The Land of the Fee? Not Yet, Fans

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
A plan to televise the Nov. 16 Notre Dame-Penn State game on a pay-per-view basis was scuttled yesterday when ABC Sports, the College Football Association and SET Pay-Per-View agreed that one week was inadequate time to market the contest to potential buyers.
"It's not going to get done," said Mark Mandel, a spokesman for ABC Sports. An executive of SET, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said: "It was a wise decision not to pursue it until we can do it right. We were getting real tight on the time frame." 
 SET has produced pay-per-view events on short notice before, but the Notre Dame-Penn State game would have set a standard for quick turnarounds. Most pay-per-view offerings require more than a month to create promotion geared to raise consumer awareness and provide marketing support to cable-system operators, who sell such events directly to their subscribers.
"It was a quick time frame that proved impossible to do," said Richard Rosenthal, the Notre Dame athletic director.
Said Mandel: "We were considering it an experiment. We were hoping that it would come through."
The prospect of Notre Dame-Penn State on pay-per-view was raised a week ago in talks between ABC and SET because it is one of three regional games on ABC that day, available to only half the country, including New York.
The remaining homes denied the game on their ABC stations would have been eligible to receive the pay-per-view feed for about $10, provided they have access to pay-per-view. Earlier that day, ABC's nationally broadcast game will be Miami at Florida State, which could determine the country's No. 1 team.
Before the breakdown of the proposal, Scott Kurnit, the president of SET, said he saw great potential in major college games on pay-per-view. "We're talking a terrific new programmer in ABC and the C.F.A.," he said.
The Fiesta Bowl's decision on Wednesday to raise its payout to teams to $3 million apiece if the top-ranked team goes to the game increases its allure to two potential No. 1 teams: Florida State and Miami. One or the other may be asked to settle the national championship in Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Ariz. Either team's likely opponent would be Notre Dame.
The Fiesta payout, enhanced by about $1 million, is likely to be raised with private funds, sponsorships and higher advertising rates for commercial spots that the Fiesta Bowl can sell on its own. "But it's not NBC money," said Kenneth Schanzer, executive vice president of NBC Sports.
The Fiesta will compete directly with ABC's Rose Bowl on New Year's Day. Although the Fiesta's 4:30 P.M. starting time on Jan. 1 is a high-viewing time on the holiday, the competition from Pasadena could blunt the ratings for the Fiesta confrontation.
Would NBC shift the game to prime time on another night, as it did with the 1987 Penn State-Miami game, which earned a whopping 25.1 rating? Not likely. "It'll get its audience on New Year's Day," said Schanzer.
NBC doesn't have many options. It airs the Orange Bowl at 8 P.M. on Jan. 1. And NBC would not want to preempt its strong Thursday prime-time programming the next night. Although the best prime-time slot might be that Friday, N.C.A.A. rules prohibit shifting a bowl game beyond Jan. 2.
Another round of musical bowl chairs could take place if the Blockbuster Bowl in Miami wins a long-shot bid by snaring Florida State or Miami. Could the Blockbuster, which paired Florida State and Penn State in 1990, lure the Seminoles back? Would Notre Dame follow? Would CBS shift it from Dec. 28 to a prime-time slot -- one as prime as Jan. 2 against NBC's powerful Thursday night lineup?
"We believe Florida State or Miami would come if the money was significant," said Ken Haines, executive vice president of Raycom Sports, which owns the Blockbuster Bowl, whose payout would be $3 million per team for a national championship game. Would Wayne Huizenga, the chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment, sugar daddy of the bowl and owner of the new Florida Marlins baseball team, sweeten the payout pot? Said Haines: "He could, but I don't know if he would."
After tomorrow's Tennessee-Notre Dame game on NBC comes "Jockspots" at 5 P.M., which explores the longtime lucrative bond between athletes and Madison Avenue. The show reprises old commercials, from Casey Stengel hawking Tabby Cat Food to Mean Joe Greene's classic Coca-Cola spot and examines how companies like Nike, Nuprin, Coca-Cola, Hanes and Upper Deck currently use athletes in their advertising.
If you experience any difficulty separating the program from the commercials, the effect is intentional. The advertisers include Hanes, Nuprin, Upper Deck and Coca-Cola, making "Jockspots" a perfect vehicle for the troubled network economy: cheap to produce and irresistible to sponsors.
The show was spearheaded by Jon Miller, NBC Sports' vice president of programming, and a former salesman for the division. Miller is in charge of NBC's efforts to create inexpensive sports programs that require no rights fees. No cash was paid to acquire the rights to the ads in the show or to the athletes on view.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
How to Succeed in Hipness by Really Trying

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
"Strictly Business" is an utterly joyless romantic comedy about young upwardly mobile blacks who make it big by adapting themselves to the worst values of the white establishment.
Specifically, it's about Waymon Tisdale 3d (Joseph C. Phillips), a Sidney Poitier look-alike and a hotshot member of a big midtown Manhattan real estate brokerage. Waymon wears Brooks Brothers suits and is engaged to the beautiful, equally ambitious Diedre (Anne Marie Johnson) who, though black, affects the speech of the lockjawed white upper-middle class. 
 Waymon's life and career threaten to go out the window when he falls in love with Natalie (Halle Berry), a pretty black promoter of fashionable downtown discos. She finds Waymon hilariously square until he enlists the aid of Bobby (Tommy Davidson), a young man in the mail room. Bobby offers to teach Waymon how to be black and hip if Waymon recommends him for the office trainee program.
"Strictly Business," directed by Kevin Hooks and written by Pam Gibson and Nelson George, is a junk bond of a movie that plays as if it had been made during the economic delirium of the Reagan era. Bobby's way of helping Waymon to find his black roots is to supervise his purchase of a flashy new wardrobe. Nothing else.
This is conciousness-raising of a sort that Armani and even Brooks Brothers might applaud. The film has the satiric edge of a damp croissant. Its characters simply want their share of a boom that no longer exists. Instead of being funny, the movie is seriously depressing.
"Strictly Business" is noteworthy only for what its cast members have done elsewhere. Ms. Berry will be remembered as the foul-mouthed junkie in Spike Lee's "Jungle Fever." Mr. Davidson is a recruit from television's "In Living Color" and Mr. Phillips comes to the big screen from "The Cosby Show."
Sam Jackson, who plays a small role as the head of the office mail room, won a special award at the Cannes International Film Festival this year for his brutally fine performance as Wesley Snipes's crack-addicted brother in "Jungle Fever."
"Strictly Business," which has been rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), has vulgar language and scenes of simulated sex.
 
Strictly Business
 
Directed by Kevin Hooks; written by Pam Gibson and Nelson George; director of photography, Zoltan David; edited by Richard Nord; music by Michel Colombier; production designer, Ruth Ammon; produced by Andre Harrell and Ms. Gibson; released by Warner Brothers. Running time: 83 minutes. This film is rated PG-13.

PUB-DATE: November 8, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 443 words

HEADLINE: Ringing: The Health Care Alarm

 BODY:
Harris Wofford's striking upset victory over Dick Thornburgh in Pennsylvania's Senate race makes health care reform Topic A on the domestic agenda. Mr. Wofford's rousing declaration that "working people should have the right to a doctor when they are sick" contributed mightily to his triumph.
That said, his call for national health insurance doesn't advance debate very far. Everyone in Congress agrees there should be universal, affordable coverage for medical catastrophe. The practical question is how. 
 Many in Congress advocate Canada's "single-payer" plan. Under this system, Americans would continue to pick their doctor, but the Government would set fees and pay the bills. The vaunted Canadian system, however, isn't working as well as proponents claim. Costs are off the charts compared with Western Europe and have risen only a fraction less than in the U.S.
Indeed, much of Canada's cost advantage over the U.S. is due to differences in demographics, not health care delivery. Critics of the Canadian system charge that it freeloads off U.S. technological innovation and that the rationing it imposes means that, for instance, women must wait months for a simple pap smear.
Another popular proposal in Congress is unfettered competition. Individuals would buy coverage from private insurers, with the help of tax credits. The idea is to control costs by forcing medical providers to compete. But most individuals buy medical care out of ignorance and under duress; operating on their own, patients put ineffective brakes on providers.
The best answer is managed competition. Individuals would be assigned to large groups, probably at work. Unemployed or otherwise uninsured individuals would be assigned to public groups.
Members of each group would be represented by a sponsor who would negotiate coverage with medical providers. The system would be competitive, inducing providers to offer quality care at attractive costs. Yet the system would also be managed, because sponsors would have the leverage, for example, to prevent insurers from discriminating against the chronically ill. That way workers would no longer be afraid to change jobs for fear of losing their insurance.
The chief objection to managed competition is that it denies members a free choice of doctors. That's true, but there is no imaginable way to have everything: free choice of doctor, unrationed access and affordable prices. Mr. Wofford is right to call for national health insurance; his election shows how much the public cares. But now, Congress must decide which kind. Managed care isn't perfect, but it's the best answer proposed so far.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Get Pentagon Out of Civilian Research

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a computer scientist, I find "Pentagon Wizards of Technology Eye Wider Civilian Role" (Science Times, Oct. 22) disturbing. You distort the content of a longstanding debate in the scientific community, discussed in a 1987 book of which I was co-editor, "Computers in Battle: Will They Work?" 
 Some 70 percent of all academic research in computer science is financed by Department of Defense agencies, one of the highest percentages in the sciences. But this research investment is of dubious commercial benefit. The bulk of military research financing goes toward narrowly defined topics, which result in limited production, despite some support of basic research.
Moreover, the military deliberately restricts the free flow of scientific information, through security classifications and publication restrictions. Billions of dollars of "black" weapons programs are completely concealed from the public.
Most misleading, you take the statements of former and present leaders of Defense Department-financed institutions at face value, when they claim significant benefits to the civilian economy as spinoffs of military directed research.
A strong argument can be made that civilian funded and directed efforts, such as those of the National Science Foundation, if evaluated in spinoffs per dollar invested, are a better investment. In fact, military technology has benefited much more from developments in the commercial sector than the reverse. This is particularly true in microelectronics.
Congress will shortly be debating proposals for a National Public Network facility, and is just starting to fund the National Research and Education Network. It is important to remove the Defense Department as sponsoring agency.
 
DAVID BELLIN
Professor of Computer Science
Pratt Institute
Brooklyn, Oct. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: Exports Would Help New York Area

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "New York City's First Hurdle: Defeatism" (editorial, Oct. 13), you are too pessimistic about the economic growth possibilities for the three-state New York, New Jersey, Connecticut region. 
 Two promising areas for stimulating regional economic growth are export expansion and foreign tourism. An unusual opportunity exists for strong leadership and regional cooperation because most foreign countries are not in recession, and the dollar is still "cheap" against other major currencies.
The United States has become a low cost manufacturer, and although our exports have been expanding, too few American companies are taking advantage of attractive export opportunities. According to the National Association of Manufacturers, two-thirds of its 13,500 members have neither exported nor manufactured abroad.
A principal reason for this export myopia as well as for the failure to develop the kind of export orientation that is second nature in virtually all other countries is that the huge United States domestic market has enabled companies to become successful without a need to export.
It is encouraging that officials from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York City have taken steps to cooperate in attracting new industries to the region. A similar cooperative and expanded effort to stimulate exports could be even more promising. The big advantage of export promotion is that the companies to be assisted are already in the region.
In 1990, exports through the New York Customs District totaled $51 billion. A modest 5 percent annual increase in exports would result in $2.5 billion in export revenue and create, it is estimated, 50,000 new jobs. The implications of even such a small increase for state and local finances, including tax revenues, decreased welfare and unemployment payments, are tremendous.
As for foreign tourism, it may be enough to suggest that bringing together government officials and representatives of companies that benefit from tourism could result in identifying promising action programs.
The region has opportunities for expanded exports and increased foreign tourism. The question is whether or not the government officials of the region can rise to the leadership challenge.
 
STEFAN H. ROBOCK
New York, Oct. 25, 1991
 
The writer retired as the R. D. Calkins Professor of International Business at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Murder, Rape, Mayhem: It Must Be Sweeps Time

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Last Sunday, made-for-television movies featured a doctor who finds on her operating table the man who had raped her weeks earlier (CBS's "Rape of Dr. Willis") and a woman being imprisoned for a crime she did not commit and then being raped by a gang of female inmates (ABC's "False Arrest"). This Sunday at 9 P.M. -- are you ready? -- you can have a mother who fails to stop one bullying son from driving her other son to murder (CBS's "My Son Johnny") or one whale of a woman whose credentials are ticked off in the title (ABC's "Wife, Mother, Murderer").
 Obviously, gentle reader, we are in another television sweeps period, during which ratings are crucial in the pricing of network commercials for an entire business quarter. Industry researchers, those indefatigable souls who are generally proved wrong some 90 percent of the time, have evidently determined that women like to watch other women get into trouble and then, even if putting a considerable strain on credulity, get out. And so another dumb formula is born, usually carrying the fuzzy label of "inspired by an actual event." 
Why is this Jeopardy Jamboree so prevalent in these particular times? Some analysts might trace the fascination with violence to recession anxieties. But escapism in the Great Depression took the form of sophisticated movies with glamorous stars like Carole Lombard and Irene Dunne, not to mention Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. The unsettling truth these days is that popular entertainment is barreling toward creative bankruptcy.
 Looking on as positive a side as possible, television movies, unlike their theatrical counterparts, do create badly needed employment opportunities for actresses over the age of 30. And students of cultural and social pathologies can have a field day cataloging just what types of aberrant behavior television executives think will sell best across the nation. The electronic landscape is littered with unsettling reflections of ourselves.
 The dysfunctional family in "My Son Johnny" consists of Marianne Cortino (Michele Lee), a Baltimore widow; her older son, Johnny (Rick Schroder), and her other son, Anthony (Corin Nemec). Johnny is a smooth-talking bum, dedicated to drugs and tormenting his brother. He is also mama's pet. She insists on seeing his constant harassment of Anthony as little more than "boys will be boys" horseplay. Murder finally forces her, very reluctantly, to face the truth. Strong performances all around do wonders for a tediously repetitive script.
 In "Wife, Mother, Murderer," Marie Hilley (Judith Light) is discovered in Alabama poisoning her husband and trying to kill her daughter. It seems the insurance money would help Marie realize some of her social-climbing fantasies, most of them puny. Fleeing to Florida under a false identity, she meets a gentle soul who marries her and gives her a home in New Hampshire. Rarely at a loss for a quick con game, Marie eventually ends up in prison but manages to sweet-talk her way into a three-day furlough, during which her story is finally resolved. For a tale so chock full of incident, "Wife, Mother, Murderer" is numbingly predictable. Even an accomplished actor like David Dukes ends up standing around looking helpless.
 And the lineup gets more crowded. This Monday, NBC's "Deadly Medicine" is about a pediatrician (Veronica Hamel) accused of killing children who were her patients. She didn't do it; her creepy nurse (Susan Ruttan) did. And then there's . . . but no need to burden you with too many dreary details. The networks will do that for you without even being asked.
 
'The Kathy and Mo Show' 'Parallel Lives'

 HBO Tomorrow at 10:30 P.M.
 Kathy Najimy and Mo Gaffney, taped onstage in San Francisco, bring their award-winning collection of offbeat characters to cable television in the form of an "HBO Comedy Hour." Together or separately, the women are hilarious and, not so incidentally, wicked gender benders as they flit in and out of male impersonations. Best bit: Two middle-aged girlfriends enrolled in women's studies at a community college going on a field trip to see a feminist performance called Sister Womyn Sister.
 
'Living With the

 Living Theater' Channel 13 Sunday at midnight
 The video artist Nam June Paik offers, with Betsy Connors and Paul Garrin, a fond and touching tribute to Julian Beck and Judith Malina and their Living Theater, which became an internationally renowned center of experimental theater in the 1960's. There are interviews with the married couple; clips from performances and from their 1984 trip to Switzerland to visit the grave of the Russian anarchist Mikhail Bakunin; scenes from Beck's funeral, and interviews with the four Beck children. Underlying everything is, in the words of Ms. Malina, "one's vision of revolutionary possibilities." Anyone gorged on network foolishness these days will find the shrewd Mr. Paik's alternative invigorating.

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
Last-Ditch Credit

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
For those with damaged credit or no credit history at all, a secured bank credit card may be a good idea. Consumers who may not qualify for an ordinary card -- those hurt by the recession, divorce, bankruptcy or layoffs -- can often get a secured Visa or Mastercard issued by a reputable bank. But the secured cards require a money deposit as collateral. The higher the deposit, the higher the credit limit. A secured credit card offers a chance to repair a credit history, or start one, since card behavior is reported to the major credit bureaus. For a list of issuers of secured credit cards, send $4 to Bankcard Holders of America, 560 Parkway, Herndon, Pa. 22070; telephone (703) 481-1110. Here are some pointers on secured cards.
 
Minimum deposit: From $250 to $500, usually earning 4 percent to 5.25 percent interest. The deposit cannot be withdrawn while the card is held, and the money is kept on deposit for at least 45 days after the account is closed to allow all charges to clear.

 Finance charge: Depending on the bank, the rate will range from 19 percent to 22 percent.

 Annual fee: $25 to $35

 Restrictions: Some banks require applicants to have a checking or savings account, with store and other accounts not seriously overdue, and bankruptcy disputes settled.
 
(Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Armco Outlay Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Armco Inc., the Parsippany, N.J., steelmaker, said it would cut capital spending by 42 percent this year to a total of $40 million. At the beginning of the year, it had budgeted $70 million for capital projects. According to a 10-Q filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company deferred the spending because of the recession. Last year, Armco reported $85 million in capital spending. Robert Kent, an Armco corporate vice president, said a plan to acquire Cyclops Industries might be partly responsible for the spending cut.

HEADLINE: Fighting to Get on the Perfume Shelf

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Even by French standards it was an affair to remember. The 17th-century Chateau de Vaux-le-Vicomte glowed with the light of candles and fireworks. There was Champagne and sumptuous food galore. Barefoot Tahitian dancers and Mexican musicians added exotica, and a handful of film and fashion celebrities provided glamour.
All this to introduce Dune, the 13th perfume created by the House of Dior since 1947, and the first Dior fragrance for women since the big success of Poison in 1985. The recent party made it clear that despite declining sales and the proliferation of new perfumes worldwide, Dior was not about to let three years of research and a $37 million investment go unnoticed. 
 Judging by early sales, the investment seems to be paying off. Figures have not yet been disclosed, but Maurice Roger, president of Christian Dior Perfumes, said sales of Dune in Europe had been exceptional.
Danielle Bizot, a spokeswoman for the French department store Printemps, said that so far Dune ranks fourth in sales among fragrances this season.
Mr. Roger said: "Two-thirds of the initial success of a perfume lies in its name, its design and promotion. Only one-third is its actual fragrance."
Dune, which sells for $180 an ounce, is clearly a gamble by its owner, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the world's leading luxury-goods company. The company also owns the fragrance licenses for Givenchy and Christian Lacroix perfumes. Earlier this year it introduced Givenchy's Amarige in Europe.
"It's an extremely bold move given that the market is so bad and that they only recently launched Christian Lacroix's C'est la Vie, whose losses last year were pretty high," said Michael Diehl, an analyst for Kleinwort Benson Securities.
In the last two years, the annual growth rate of the $11 billion world perfume industry has declined by 5 to 10 percentage points. Sales have been hard hit by the American recession; the decline in travel because of the Persian Gulf war, which led to a 35 percent decrease in purchases of duty-free perfume at airport shops, and the drop in value of the dollar and the Japanese yen.
"Our decision to launch at this time is simple," Mr. Roger said. "We are coming out of a crisis, and people need optimism. We have more flexibility and a better chance of success with a market that is so fragmented."
Sales of Dune started in Europe and the Middle East in mid-September. They will begin in Asia in the spring, and in the United States next fall.
Promoted as "the perfume of serenity," Dune is aimed at "the natural woman who is dynamic, generous and now also deeply modest," the ad copy reads. Bottled in winged transparent glass and boxed in tangerine peach, its floral scent is meant to evoke "the seaside on a beautiful sunny day, between dune and countryside."
Christian Dior needs a fresh fragrance to reassert itself in an increasingly saturated market, analysts said.
 
Fighting for Space
 In the United States alone, 25 to 30 new perfumes come out each year, all vying for counter space in department stores, where most sales are made.
"Maurice needs this one," said Allan Mottus, a cosmetic industry consultant based in New York. "He's had a dry spell since Poison. The designer house's percentage of the market has declined because they're not introducing as frequently as the other names in the business."
"I think that they have a chance with Dune," Mr. Mottus said. "They are selling a kindler and gentler female psyche, which women of the 90's, who are going to have a tougher time than ever, may just buy out of wish fulfillment."
Not only are more perfumes being introduced, they are being done so more expensively. White Diamonds by Elizabeth Taylor, Escape by Calvin Klein and Spellbound by Estee Lauder all went on sale this year with campaigns costing an average of $25 million each.
As a result, "we are seeing bigger and bigger companies in the business," said Deepak Raj, an analyst for Merrill Lynch Research. "Only companies like Unilever, which owns both the Elizabeth Taylor and Calvin Klein brands, can afford the investment needed for these mega-launches."
Many new perfumes that do not have the leverage of a big company behind them have resorted to gimmicks and incentives, like a gift with each purchase, to retain counter space and sustain sales.
"We are seeing perfume being treated more and more like a gadget," Mr. Roger said. "Americans are buying it as if it was a cheap T-shirt. They're getting a free umbrella, or a free gift in the bargain, and as a result they have more unused perfume sitting in their medicine cabinets than they do medicine."
Though Christian Dior has not announced the projected forecasts for sales of Dune, the company is hoping to equal, if not surpass, the success of Poison, which in its first three months sold $25 million.
"If we are not very active on a day-to-day basis, we'll lose our central location and find ourselves selling under the escalator," Mr. Roger said.
Still, not everyone is impressed.
"It's a little too green for me," said Margaret Aflalo, who was testing samples of perfume in the Galeries Lafayette store in Paris. "But it's very different from the rest of Dior's perfumes, much more natural."
It generally takes six to eight months before a perfume can be judged successful, after shoppers have had a chance to make repeat purchases.
 
A Crucial Market
 Even if Dune fares well in Europe, its success in the United States, which represents 35 percent of the worldwide market, is not guaranteed.
"Americans are much more oriented toward celebrity perfumes, whether it's Elizabeth Taylor or some tennis player," said Mr. Diehl, the Kleinwort Benson analyst. "If it's Liz Taylor, who has a certain timelessness, the fragance has a chance of lasting, but if it's a tennis player the fragrance is just as likely as him to come and go."
What makes a perfume a classic, putting it in the ranks of a Chanel No. 5 or Guerlain's Shalimar is, according to Mr. Roger, an avant-garde, innovative quality and a design and fragrance that have a global appeal.
"The perfume industry is a massive gamble," Mr. Diehl said. "But once you get a brand established, then you've got a license to print money."

HEADLINE: Your Money;
A Tax Wrinkle For the Year-End

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Investors face a new wrinkle in year-end tax planning. This year, for the first time, people who borrow to invest in the market can deduct the interest on those loans only to the extent they can match it with income from investments.
Either dividends and interest or capital gains on securities count as investment income and can offset what tax law calls investment interest expense. But margin traders who wind up losing money cannot deduct investment interest costs against wages, salaries and other ordinary income. 
 Eli J. Warach, a tax lawyer and author of the Maxwell Macmillan 1992 Federal Tax Handbook, says this rule can open opportunities before Dec. 31. "The trick is to arrange your transactions so that you use up otherwise nondeductible interest to wipe out taxable gains," he said.
For example, Mr. Warach said, an investor who has realized $10,000 of investment income and paid $13,000 of investment interest this year can deduct only $10,000 of the interest; the rest can be carried forward to a future year. But if he has $3,000 worth of long-term gains in his portfolio, he could take them now and deduct all the interest expense.
If he likes the holding, he can buy it back, establishing a higher cost basis, although he will incur transaction costs. The "wash sales" rules apply only to losses, not gains.
What's more, Mr. Warach said, if the investor is in the 31 percent Federal bracket, the deduction is worth 31 percent on Schedule A, whereas long-term capital gains are taxed at a maximum of 28 percent on Schedule D.
He gave another example. An investor who has realized $2,000 worth of long-term gains and has no paper losses owes $3,000 in interest on outstanding margin loans. If she pays $2,000 of the interest this year, he said, she will be able to deduct it because of the gain. If she pays all $3,000, she will have to carry $1,000 of it forward to a future year.
There is one caveat. Only interest payments on loans used to pay for investments are deductible under these rules. If an investor took out a margin loan to buy a car, the interest would not be deductible. But he could sell a holding, use the proceeds to buy the car and replace the security in the portfolio with a comparable issue purchased on margin.
Hal Cohen of Deloitte & Touche in Parsippany, N.J., noted that many investors were asking whether to delay taking capital gains in case President Bush wins a cut in the capital gains tax rate next year. He recommended basing the decision on economics first, but added, "It may not be a bad idea to defer the gain until next year."
If investors wind up in a net capital loss position this year, up to $3,000 can be taken against earned income. Anything over that would be carried forward to future years.
 
Adjusting Withholding

For taxpayers who wind up with sizable net gains, dividends, interest or other income not subject to withholding -- consulting or freelance work, for example -- the tax question is whether they are going to be liable for penalties and interest.
Taxpayers are required to pay as they earn, either an amount equal to 100 percent of the tax they owed the previous year or 90 percent of this year's tax liability, through either payroll withholding, payments of quarterly estimated taxes or a combination of the two.
The year-earlier test is easier to calculate; taxpayers merely need to add up their withholding and estimated tax payments for 1991, projecting through the end of the year, and compare the results with last year's tax. But for people who will owe less tax this year than last, meeting that test would amount to giving the I.R.S. a free loan until they file their returns and get refunds.
To use the 90 percent test, taxpayers need to project their income and deductions and calculate what the tax will be fairly accurately -- a task made far easier with one of the popular computer tax programs, like Taxcut, Turbotax, Macintax or J. K. Lasser's Your Income Tax.
Charles H. Gaylord, Jr., president and chief executive of Chipsoft, Inc., which makes Turbotax for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers, said last week that he had used his own product, which even a novice can install in 5 or 10 minutes, and discovered that because of a profitable stock sale in June, as things stood, he would be liable for the underpayment penalty.
So, he gave his company's payroll department a new Form W-4 to increase withholding, and will turn in a revised W-4 in January. The reason is that withholding is deemed to have occurred evenly through the year, even if a big chunk comes in November and December. Estimated payments are not; had he made an estimated payment now to cover the capital gains tax, he would still have been liable for some penalty and interest, although less than had he waited until April.
Conversely, people who discover they are headed for a big refund, could turn in a new W-4 to decrease their withholding. The programs can also help weigh the tax consequences of securities sales, charitable gifts and other year-end choices.

HEADLINE: Pension Agency's Accounting Systems Criticized

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Federal agency that insures most private employee pension plans, already running a multibillion-dollar deficit, is unable to audit its books, a Congressional study has found.
The disarray in accounting systems at the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation ranges from a two-year breakdown in a premium-processing computer system, corrected in 1990, to its inability now to identify unpaid, overpaid or underpaid insurance premiums, the oversight subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee said in a report issued Thursday. 
 Under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, the Government insures most private pension plans, through premiums paid by employers to the pension corporation, a unit of the Labor Department. Premium rates have risen steeply since 1974, with the increase especially sharp in the last several years. About 40 million people are covered by the Federal insurance program.
Last month James B. Lockhart 3d, the executive director of the agency, told Congress that the corporation's deficit was "well over $2 billion" for the year ended Sept. 30, an increase over last year's deficit of $1.8 billion.
Some of the subcommittee's findings were based on reports in January by the agency's inspector general and the General Accounting Office, an investigatory arm of Congress.
A spokesman for the pension agency read a statement saying that under Mr. Lockhart, who took office last year, the agency requested a G.A.O. audit more than a year ago and has "already taken steps to address G.A.O.'s concerns."
The statement also said that the automated computer system used to process premiums was restored last year with "no significant effect on the financial condition of the corporation."
The corporation has said it will be able to pay liabilities through the end of the decade because it has ample cash flow, and the private pension plans it backs are well funded with $800 billion in liabilities backed by $1 trillion in assets.
 
Danger in Some Industries

But financial problems in certain industries, including steel and airlines, could increase the agency's deficit to $11.4 billion by the year 2000. In addition, a recent Federal court ruling involving the LTV Corporation's unfunded pension liability of $1.6 billion went against the agency, which is appealing the decision.
The pension corporation is one of several Federal insurance programs in which the financial exposure and condition worry private and Government economists.
A Federal fund that insured deposits at savings and loan associations went bankrupt after owners of the savings units could not generate enough premium income, and the cleanup will now cost taxpayers more than $200 billion. In addition, the fund that insures deposits at commercial banks, despite recent increases in premiums paid by banks, faces insolvency and is seeking Congressional authority to borrow up to $70 billion from the Treasury.
Among the pension agency's financial and accounting problems cited in the subcommittee report were these: financial statements that could not be audited, inability to control premium payments forwarded to the Washington office effectively, lack of a compliance program to indentify fully and collect premium payments, and a two-year breakdown in the operation of the premium-processing's computer functions.
Judith Bekelman, a spokeswoman for the agency, said that the agency was "on track to have auditable financial statements in 1992," that its system to control premiums was up and running and that a more advanced computer system for the agency will be in place next year.

HEADLINE: S.& P. Cuts Ratings on G.M. and Revises Outlook on Ford

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Large and continuing losses at the nation's two largest auto makers prompted the Standard & Poor's Corporation today to lower the ratings on the preference and preferred shares of General Motors and revise its ratings outlook to "negative" from "stable" for the bonds and preference shares of Ford.
S.& P. said it had lowered the G.M. ratings by one notch. It also warned that it might reduce the ratings on $90 billion of the company's debt, the ratings of which were last lowered in February. The rating on $110 billion worth of Ford debt was affirmed. 
 The General Motors Corporation was singled out by the ratings agency for "unprecedented" losses in its North American operations. Analysts have estimated that G.M. is losing from $500 million to $600 million a month in North America, an amount that is partly offset by overseas profits and earnings from G.M.'s GM Hughes Electronics and Electronic Data Systems subsidiaries.
G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, has experienced "disappointing" progress in improving its operating efficiency, S.& P. said. One reason might be that G.M.'s market share in North America has been stuck at about 35 percent while the company's factory capacity is appropriate for a 40 percent share.
G.M.'s European operations, while profitable, may be vulnerable because consumer demand has softened in the German market.
Wall Street was not surprised by the action, which reflects the effects of a weak economy as well as soft prices and brutal competition with Japanese auto makers. G.M.'s common shares fell 75 cents today, to $34, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Cost-cutting will be more difficult for G.M. because of its future retiree medical costs, which S.& P. said were greater than those of its competitors. Separately, G.M. said its estimate of such expenses over the next 20 years, under new accounting guidelines that will soon take effect, was in a range of $16 billion to $24 billion.
Scott Sprinzen, a spokesman for S.& P., said the agency probably would not act on G.M.'s debt ratings until February, when it will have a chance to review the auto maker's fourth-quarter financial results.
A G.M. spokesman said, "We feel the action taken by Standard & Poor's is largely a reflection of the persistent recession that has gripped the nation and impacted the entire domestic auto industy." G.M. said the action should also send a signal to Washington that the industry "needs support" in light of Government regulation "that continues to impair U.S. competitiveness."
In the case of the Ford Motor Company, S.& P. noted that earnings had been poor but that Ford's operating efficiency in North America was much better than G.M.'s The ratings agency predicted that Ford, because of aggressive cost-cutting, could become profitable within two years even if the economic recovery was gradual.
S.& P. said Ford had demonstrated "a greater commitment" than G.M. to keeping its balance sheet strong, as evidenced by a $750 million issue of convertible preferred stock. A Ford spokesman said the company was pleased that its ratings were affirmed.
Ford's shares closed today at $26.125, down 25 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Chrysler Corporation, the No. 3 auto maker, has also been losing money, although it reported a smaller third-quarter loss than analysts had forecast. Chrysler's ratings were last downgraded in June.

HEADLINE: Whither Hemlines? In Short, Even Retailers Aren't Sure

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The European and American designers' spring previews have left retailers with no clear direction about where hemlines are supposed to fall.
Many store executives seem irritated by the confusion on the modeling runways -- and all the talk in fashion stories -- of short and long styles. But merchants also seem somewhat relieved that they can avoid the financial risk of trying to market a sudden shift in fashion. As a result, most are stocking short skirts, long dresses and a healthy inventory of pants, which have become the only sure-fire option when hemlines are in flux. 
 "Personally, I think that the length of a hemline is not relevant to women today," said Eugenia Ulasewicz, president of Galeries Lafayette U.S.A. "I think a woman nowadays has both long and short in her closet and a very independent sense of style."
 
Hemming and Hawing
 As the fashion shows wind down in New York, Louis Dell'Olio of Anne Klein has voted up, sticking with the prevailing trend. Calvin Klein voted down, in word if not entirely in fact. And Claude Montana, in perhaps the best imitation of Mario Cuomo, tried to have it both ways: he showed skirts that grazed the thighs in front and tickled the calves in back.
"There certainly are some long looks here, and that's what has grabbed the headlines," said LaVelle Olexa, senior vice president of Lord & Taylor. "But there are also some very, very good short skirts and dresses. Long is out here. However, it really is just another option."
She said that Lord & Taylor would feature some skirts and dresses with longer hemlines, but that garments hemmed above the knees would still have a strong presence in the company's 49 stores.
The idea of women buying both short and long dresses and skirts might seem like good news to the Sakses, Bloomingdale's and Macy's of the world. Not so. With no fresh reasons to come into department stores and boutiques, women may just wear their old clothes until the fashion mavens settle the debate. That does not help an industry hurting badly in the recession.
Designers, too, have a simple economic reason for changing hemlines: sales. New looks used to stimulate sales, as women rushed out to replace the stale styles hanging in their closets. But few retailers or manufacturers now say that a shift to longer hems would bring customers rushing in.
Some experts say the hemline's role as the demarcation that has separated the chic from the gauche since early in this century is falling victim to shoppers less willing to be dictated to, and to merchants far less willing to sacrifice dwindling profits for a fashionable reputation.
"For the majority of middle America, which is at least 50 percent of the buying public, the hemline is irrelevant," said Irwin Cohen of the Cohen Brothers Dress Company, makers of moderately priced women's apparel. "I don't think the American consumer is in any financial position to disregard her current wardrobe just to be in vogue."
Facing that reality, many Seventh Avenue manufacturers, who have usually taken most of their cues from the European shows, turned up their noses this time.
"Today's woman is not intimidated by what's on the runway in Paris," said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller.
To some in the industry, the hemline hoopla is a painful reminder of the miscalculations they made in 1987 when they filled store racks with short skirts, a radical departure from the accepted style. Even now, some women of a certain age, in some professions and in many parts of the country remain shy about baring their knees.
Most women rejected shorter skirts. Stores were left to mark down their shorter merchandise drastically, a task they do not wish to repeat.
Retailers "thought they had more influence, and that women wouldn't dare reject their suggestions on fashion," said Cynthia Cohen Turk, president of Marketplace 2000, a consulting firm.
So now, merchants and mainstream apparel manufacturers are practicing prudence and ignoring the range of edicts handed down from the runways in Paris and Milan.
 
The Knees Still Have It

 Laurence Cioaba, divisional merchandise manager for women's designer clothing for Barneys New York, said longer, lean looks like those shown by Karl Lagerfeld and Azzedine Alaia seemed fresh and modern. "A shorter skirt still retains a major commercial value," she said, referring to lengths just above the knee. "But the miniskirt definitely looks a little passe."
Alfred Schatzberg, president of After Five, a New York maker of party dresses and gowns, said about 10 percent of the company's spring collection would be longer. But he said the longer lengths were chiefly a result of fabrics his designer, Julie Duroche, chose, rather than any signals from Europe.
"Most American manufacturers are still going above the knee," Mr. Schatzberg said. "The few longer dresses you'll see are almost a test so no one gets hurt -- not the retailer and not the manufacturer."
The discussion about hemlines has also coaxed one of Seventh Avenue's little secrets out of the closet. As many people suspected, those who make the clothes that are staples in women's wardrobes never really hiked their hems across the board.
"Through all the hoopla about the short, short skirts, longer lengths have sold consistently well," said Larry Lefkowitz, president of Maggy London International, which sells $65 million worth of apparel aimed at career women.
Many fashion experts recall that in 1974, Yves St. Laurent introduced the "midi" to women who had worn the "mini" since the 1960's. Fashion writers deplored the longer look, but within a year shoppers were snapping up the new style.
Garment makers say the difference between now and then is that women have not yet tired of short skirts.
"There's an evolution going on right now," explained Mr. Konheim of Nicole Miller. "Evolutions are financial successes. Revolutions, like what we saw in 1987, only cause people to stop and stare at whoever's throwing the Molotov cocktail."

HEADLINE: Fed's Policy Makers Supported Lower Rates, if Necessary

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers voted early last month to authorize lower short-term interest rates if the economic recovery appeared to need further stimulus, according to minutes of their meeting released today.
But members of the Federal Open Market Committee generally felt at their meeting on Oct. 1 that policy was on the correct course and they said they would accept only a "slight bias" toward easing interest rates. But the Fed has cut interest rates on two separate occasions since, to encourage borrowing and thus stimulate economic activity. In a speech last week, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, suggested that the economic recovery might be faltering. 
 Today's release of the minutes came two days after the Fed lowered the discount rate to 4 1/2 percent, from 5 percent, and also allowed the Federal funds rate to fall one-quarter of a percentage point, to 4 3/4 percent. The discount rate is what the Fed charges banks for loans; the Federal funds rate is what banks charge one another for loans.
Some large banks responded to the lower rates by reducing their prime lending rate to 7 1/2 percent, from 8 percent.
Earlier, on Oct. 30, the Fed had let the funds rate fall to 5 percent, from 5 1/4 percent.
A Panel of 12
The target for the funds rate is set by the Open Market Committee, which consists of the 7 Federal Reserve board governors and the presidents of 5 of the Fed's 12 regional banks. The discount rate is controlled by the board itself.
The committee meets behind closed doors eight times a year, with the most recent meeting taking place on Tuesday. Minutes of the meetings are released about six weeks later.
The minutes of the Oct. 1 meeting expressed an optimism that was absent from Mr. Greenspan's speech on Oct. 28. In recent weeks, he said, the recovery has "turned demonstrably sluggish." But at the Oct. 1 meeting, the Fed officials "generally concluded that on balance the evidence was consistent with a continuing though still sluggish recovery in economic activity and that the prospects remained favorable for a sustained expansion at a moderate pace over the next several quarters."
Thus, the minutes continued, the committee favored maintaining current policy, but said it could accept a "slight bias" toward easing if needed. That language contrasted with the minutes of the Aug. 20 meeting, which said the committee policy "provided for giving special weight" to developments that might require easing.
The vote at the Oct. 1 meeting was 10 to 0. There are two vacancies on the Fed's board of governors.

HEADLINE: Title Insurers' Low Reserves Stir Worry

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
The nation's title insurance industry, which provides protection to millions of American property owners, may not have enough money in reserve to meet a recent surge in claims. As a result, some industry executives and experts predict that many title insurers will be weakened in coming years, and they fear what would happen if one of the big ones had serious problems or even failed.
In an industry so concentrated that six insurers handle three-fourths of the nation's properties, the fallout could be substantial. 
 If confidence in the title insurance business was shaken, home lenders could become more stingy about issuing mortgages. At a minimum, they would demand higher interest rates to compensate for possibly defective title insurance on properties securing the loans. Presumably premiums could increase to reflect what industry executives see as the new and higher risks.
If a title company failed, millions of homeowners and lenders would be in jeopardy until they got another title insurer, and if a claim were then to arise they would not be able to secure new coverage.
Although no giant title insurer has failed, smaller companies have. And the insolvency of a midsize title company, the Title USA Corporation, which collapsed in October 1989 after issuing nearly a million policies, provides a glimpse of the hardship that could follow were a giant insurer to fail.
A number of years back, the National Bank of Albuquerque issued a $500,000 mortgage to an Albuquerque, N.M., man seeking to build a home, only to find out that the land on which the home was to be built had been seized by the suburb of Las Ranchos. That village maintained that the land in question had always been public property. When the bank filed a claim with Title USA, it got back a letter instead from the Texas Insurance Department saying that Title USA was out of business. To this day, the bank is trying to recover its $500,000.
"Not being a big bank, we would consider that a very big loss," said Leonard DeLayo, the bank's general counsel. "And we don't expect to recover a penny of that from the title company."
Title insurance has always been a profitable backwater of the insurance market. It is little studied; it is virtually unregulated at the Federal and state levels; ratings agencies do not assess the financial strength of title insurers; the leading companies have no cachet, and consumers do not shop around.
Yet, title insurance is the lubricant of the real estate market, an essential element if properties are to change hands smoothly. Home buyers use it to protect against the risk that the seller does not actually own the house they are buying or has failed to pay taxes or other bills. Lenders rely on title insurance against the possibility that some other creditor will appear and demand title to a troubled property before the lender can repossess it.
 
Some Obviously Losing Money

Virtually everyone in title insurance agrees these days that the rate of claims has risen sharply, to about 12 to 15 cents of every dollar taken in through premiums, from about 3 cents in the mid-1970's. The great bulk of premiums -- up to 90 to 95 cents on the dollar -- goes to pay agents and researchers and to cover home office expenses. So, some insurers are obviously losing money.
And as claims rates have soared, most insurers have failed to place enough money in reserve to pay the higher claims, many industry experts say. While no one expects reserves to be at 15 percent of premiums, most title experts say that a figure of 10 percent is reasonable.
"Frankly, many title insurers just have not reflected the true cost of doing business," said Robert Scherer, the chief financial officer of the Chicago Trust and Title Company, the nation's largest title insurer.
Some states have laws that require title insurers to set aside funds. But experts say that these laws were adopted years ago, that the levels they require are too low and that in any case, the laws differ widely by state, creating a crazy quilt of regulations.
 
Reasons for Higher Claims

The current, higher rate of claims reflects several trends. One is the generally depressed market for real estate, in which many builders have left unfinished homes and office buildings, which are subject to claims by construction workers.
A second reason is that the title insurers now employ more freelance title researchers, who make mistakes. And a third reason is that the discovery of hazardous waste under homes and factories, which can make it difficult to transfer the title on a property, has led to a number of claims against insurers.
 
Reluctant to Increase Reserves

Yet, most title insurers have been reluctant to increase their reserves, largely, the experts say, because they do not want to report to stockholders the lower profits that would result.
"You have an important part of our economy that is not what it appears to be," said Aldo C. Zucaro, president of the Old Republic Title Insurance Group Inc. of Chicago, the sixth-largest title insurer in the country. "In a few years, when all of us are ready to sell our homes and retire to Arizona, we will all be up the creek if we find out that we do not have clear title to our homes and that the title insurance company is not there to bail us out."
And given the imbalance between reserves and claims in the industry, the chances of a big title insurer failing are no longer remote, he added.
Concerned policyholders always have the option of replacing one policy with another. But it can be expensive; typically, the one-time premium on a $150,000 home is at least $500. Insurance experts suggest that consumers considering this option discuss their concerns with the lender who provided the mortgage and request that the lender share in the cost.
Recently, Old Republic released a study that all but predicted that title insurers would be the next financial institutions to go broke if the companies were not forced to recognize their obligations. The study, "Title Insurance: a Time to Address Financial Stability Issues," was greeted with some skepticism. Some industry executives said the report was self-serving, because Old Republic is one of the few large title insurers to have increased reserves seriously in recent years.
 
Others Worried, Too

But Old Republic is not the only party to suspect that title insurers may be headed for rough waters. For the last four months, the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, has been studying the claims-paying ability of title insurers that cover its mortgage-backed securities. And Wall Street analysts who follow title-insurance stocks have also begun to raise questions about title insurers' financial strength.
"There are definitely one or two big title insurers that could suffer serious problems" as a result of their underreserving, said Charles Ronson, an analyst at Baird, Patrick & Company, a Wall Street firm.
For years, title insurance was a conservative, low-risk business. Title insurers would invest premium revenue, while their employees would review real estate transfer records to make sure a property was free of tax liens, unpaid contractor bills or other encumbrances. Claims were rare and usually resulted from a clerk making a mistake in reading a record.
"Title insurance was considered a wonderful vehicle for acquiring cheap funds for investment," Mr. Ronson said.
 
A Low-Profile Business

And it attracted little attention.
Joseph Belth, a consumer advocate who teaches insurance at Indiana University, said: "I don't even incorporate title insurance into my survey course. Maybe I should."
And Stephen Brobeck, the executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, a Washington lobbying group, said, "We've just always looked at the business as posing extremely low risk."
In recent years, title insurance has come to be dominated by a handful of large, national companies: Chicago Trust and Title, owned by Alleghany; First American Title Insurance in Santa Ana, Calif., owned by First American Financial; Commonwealth Title Insurance in San Francisco, owned by Reliance Group Holdings; Lawyers Title Insurance in Richmond; Stewart Title Guaranty in Houston, owned by Stewart Information Services, and the main title insurance subsidiary of Old Republic International, the Title Insurance Company of Minnesota.
As their control over the market grew, the companies increasingly relied on freelance researchers whose work often produced higher-than-normal error rates. As a result, claims have soared.
 
Effect of Real Estate Slump

Claims have also risen because of the real estate slump. As property values have softened nationwide, many developers have abandoned projects in midstream, halting wage payments to carpenters, electricians and other construction workers. Because many state laws give construction workers first rights to a bankrupt property -- even if it has been mortgaged -- many banks have found they do not hold the first lien they thought they had. Their position compromised, many banks have filed claims with their title insurers.
Banks have also increasingly been filing claims with title insurers in connection with discovery of hazardous wastes. Essentially, the banks contend that discovery of chemicals or other dangerous materials under a mortgaged property makes the title to the property invalid since the property in many cases can no longer be sold.
The insurers argue that while property near hazardous wastes may be unmarketable, the title is still technically good. But having to defend against these claims is costing the title insurers millions of dollars.
 
Some Problems Documented

Publicly available data from individual title insurers document some of the problems. As of Dec. 31, 1990, for instance, the First American Title Insurance Company was reporting a reserve ratio of about 3 percent. The ratio is based on year-end reserves and the sum of the last five years' premiums.
Lawyers Title Insurance had a reserve ratio of 7 percent; Stewart Title Guaranty had a ratio of 6.8 percent. Only Old Republic's title insurance group had a reserve ratio in double digits, at 11.1 percent. The current reality could force all but Old Republic to raise those figures.
