HEADLINE: Bush Returns the Democrats' Fire, Pointing to Success Against Iraqis

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 8

 BODY:
President Bush paused between a summit session of the Atlantic alliance and economic talks in the Netherlands to renew his increasingly defensive battle with Congress today. He charged that if it had been left up to the Democrats, America would be sitting "fat, dumb and happy with Saddam Hussein maybe in Saudi Arabia."
Mr. Bush began a news conference among the meticulously trimmed hedgerows of Villa Taverna, the American Ambassador's residence here, seeming determined to focus on his role as a head of state who holds a predominant position in Western military and political councils. 
 He tried to keep the focus on an optimistic assessment of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting that he had just concluded. But in a reflection of the political realities that face Mr. Bush when he returns from the Hague on Saturday evening, the questioning quickly turned to the domestic issues that have come to dominate the electoral debate in the United States, to Mr. Bush's clear frustration.
The President found himself answering queries about abortion counseling, taxes, AIDS, national health care, interest rates and other issues. Even when the subject was foreign affairs, Mr. Bush was trying to explain why Americans suffering from economic recession should care about whether the United States retains a leadership role in NATO or its continental allies develop their own "security identity."
At times, Mr. Bush seemed to have shaken off some of the hesitancy and defensiveness that has characterized his responses to Democratic assaults on domestic issues in recent weeks.
He crisply denied that the country was in a recession, while conceding that the economy was not as "robust" as he might have hoped. He accused the Democratic-controlled Congress of blocking legislation on taxes, transportation and other proposals that he has made in an avowed attempt to stimulate economic growth.
But at other times, Mr. Bush offered confused, rambling answers. "I'm not interested in higher tax cuts," he said at one point, prompting his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, who was sitting nearby, to shake his head and mutter, "He means higher taxes."
At another point, asked if he would curtail his travels next year because of Democratic criticism and polls showing that Americans think he spends too much time on foreign policy, Mr. Bush wanted to say that he would pay no attention to the "carping," as he called it. But he tripped over his words.
"No, you're not going to see me stay put," he said, adding: "I am not going to forsake my responsibilities. You may not see me put as much -- I mean, un-put as much."
When pressed hard about his contest with the Democrats, Mr. Bush turned to a theme he has used before and is certain to raise again when pressure builds on domestic issues: his success in the Persian Gulf war this year.
"If I had had to listen to advice from the United States Senate leadership, the Democrats -- or from the House, the leadership over there -- to do something about the Persian Gulf, we'd have still been sitting there in the United States, fat, dumb and happy, with Saddam Hussein maybe in Saudi Arabia," Mr. Bush said.
The President said he recognized that he must do more to convey a sense of concern about domestic issues to Americans. He said he wanted to come up with a national health-care proposal before the elections and acknowledged that he had not done as much as he might to promote awareness of AIDS.
But he said that any failure to improve the economy was not his fault, but that of Congress, which is controlled by the Democrats.
"I am going to do as better job as I possibly can on showing the concerns I feel, and hopefully, in spite of the opposition of Congress, try to find answers to some of the problems that are plaguing the American people," he said, adding: "People are hurting there and they need help. But they don't need the President to forswear his obligations for national security and foreign affairs."
Mr. Bush said he had still not made up his mind about various proposals for tax cuts that are floating on Capitol Hill, including one by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, that would give 80 percent of American taxpayers a credit of $200 to $400 and pay the $46 billion cost by creating a new 35 percent tax bracket and a 10 percent surcharge on millionaires.
Mr. Bush, who has strongly opposed fully legalized abortions, said he would veto newly approved legislation that lifts a Federal ban on abortion counseling in clinics receiving Federal money. The Senate vote was sufficient to override a veto, but the House fell 14 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed to overturn the veto.

HEADLINE: Blacks See Old Hate Behind Duke's New Strength

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAHNVILLE, La.

 BODY:
State Representative David Duke stared directly into the camera and asked the voters of Louisiana to give him a chance. Albert Joseph, one of those voters watching the smooth performance on a grainy television set here, shook his head no.
"Six thousand white people from around here voted for Duke," said Mr. Joseph, a 61-year-old black businessman who has lived most of his life in this small, semi-rural town about 25 miles from New Orleans. "I'm not just worried about David Duke. I know where he's coming from. 
 "I'm worried about the local Dukes, the smiling-in-your-face Dukes, the Dukes in the plant, the Dukes in the courthouse, the Dukes holding a dagger, waiting for you to turn your back.
"David Duke is only one man. He didn't get this far by himself."
 
Sign of Deeper Problems?
 For Mr. Joseph and his neighbors, Mr. Duke, the Republican candidate for governor who is a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, is a sign of deeper racial and economic problems that threaten black progress. They believe that Mr. Duke has pulled away the sheet hiding the feelings of too many of their white neighbors.
The suggestion that Mr. Duke simply symbolizes a protest vote against politics as usual is as hollow as a soap commercial to Mr. Joseph's neighbor, Kamau Odinga.
"It is easy for white people to forgive David Duke for being in the Ku Klux Klan," he said. "They were never the victims of the Klan; they were never hung from trees. We cannot forget or forgive that. But it's not just blacks who will suffer. Remember, he was a Nazi."
To experts on Louisiana history and race relations, Mr. Duke's campaign has driven a wedge between blacks and whites, even though Mr. Duke has made no direct appeals to race.
"Racial prejudices and fears have been inflamed," said Lawrence Powell, who teaches history at Tulane University in New Orleans. "I think that's what Duke wanted. Just beneath the surface, there is a racial hair trigger."
Wayne Parent, a Louisiana State University political scientist, said Mr. Duke is riding a wave of racial intolerance and antagonisms that began slowly emerging in the South 10 years ago.
"Pollsters found out it's one way to win elections," he said. "The emergence of David Duke really heightened the distrust many blacks are feeling toward whites."
But it is more than distrust. It is also a feeling of betrayal and disbelief that a man who is both a former Klansman and a former neo-Nazi, who celebrated Hitler's birthday well into the 1980's, could be so close to so much power.
In a recent voter survey commissioned by The Shreveport Times, Mr. Duke, who is from the New Orleans suburb of Metairie, and Edwin W. Edwards, a former three-term Governor who is his Democratic opponent in the Nov. 16 run-off, were separated by only a few percentage points, with Mr. Edwards slightly ahead.
Blacks make up 31 percent of the state's population and 28 percent of the registered voters. For Mr. Edwards to win, there must be a huge black turnout, experts say.
Mr. Odinga says that for the first time in a long time, it will be easy to get his black neighbors -- some old enough to remember when blacks couldn't vote -- to the polls. "Even if they have to walk for miles in the cold and rain, they will turn out in droves," said Mr. Odinga, a chemical engineer and political organizer.
"Duke has caused black people to organize like nothing else I've ever seen here. This is a moral issue."
 
The Tensions of Recession
 Even before Mr. Duke's campaign, tensions were high in a state struggling through a recession that began in the early 1980's with the drop in oil prices.
The picture has been especially bleak for black people. In an article last May in the Tulane University's alumnni magazine, two members of the sociology department wrote that half of the state's black families live beneath the Federal poverty line, as against 10 percent of its white families.
Louisiana has the third-highest rate of poverty among children, the professors wrote, and New Orleans, the state's glistening jewel, is the country's third-poorest city. More than 60 percent of the city is black.
The closeness of the race has shocked many blacks like Giselle Boutte, a 32-year-old social worker in New Orleans. "I'm scared to death he might win," she said. "I'm scared for the future of my daughter. If he's elected, I'm moving out of the state."
Some who say they are afraid also say they are not surprised at Mr. Duke's political success. They say there is a deep vein of racism waiting to be tapped.
Shirley Randall of Hahnville says Mr. Duke isn't fooling anyone: "A tiger can wallow in the mud and cover up his spots. He's still a tiger."
In the last few weeks, Mr. Duke has clearly become a lightning rod, drawing increasingly intense opposition, not just from blacks, but from a cross section of Louisiana life. Disgust at Mr. Duke's past and the impact his election would have on the ecomony, especially tourism, were the most common reasons given by non-blacks for opposing Mr. Duke.
 
Memories That Still Sear
 But for many blacks, especially older people, Mr. Duke is a symbol of painful, soul-numbing images and memories: "white" and "colored" drinking fountains, segregated housing and schools, masked riders in the night.
"He and his kind want to turn back the clock 100 years," said Ron Chisom, a neighborhood organizer in New Orleans who is 50.
Mr. Duke, 41, has tried to disown his past. Today, he calls himself a "conservative Republican" and on the stump he sounds like one, attacking busing, affirmative action, high taxes, soft-on-crime liberals.
Many blacks and others in Louisiana say that Mr. Duke's repeated attacks on welfare programs are thinly disguised attacks on blacks. Blacks, along with other minority groups, account for 74 percent of the state's welfare recipients. Nationwide, about 45 percent of welfare recipients are black.
To applause from his largely white audiences, Mr. Duke says that welfare is dragging the state to its knees. In fact, welfare accounts for about 2 percent of the state's budget, and grants under Louisiana's public aid program to families with children are the third lowest in the nation.
Some blacks say they agree with Mr. Duke's message but cannot bring themselves to vote for a former Klansman.
Shaking her head as she stood on a street in New Orleans, LeShawn Porter, 24, said she knows of at least five black people who plan to vote for Mr. Duke because they believe he has changed. "They're crazy," she said. "Absolutely crazy."
 
Not Courting Black Vote
 Mr. Duke came in second in the state's open primary last month, beating out Gov. Buddy Roemer. In The Shreveport Times survey, 58 percent of the white voters said they would support Mr. Duke, and 28 percent said they would back Mr. Edwards, who is seeking a comeback after surviving two trials on corruption charges. The survey of 817 voters was done Oct. 24-26 by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research of Columbia, Md. It had a margin of error of plus or minus three and a half percentage points.
Mr. Duke has spent little, if any, time campaigning in black neighborhoods. "I haven't been invited," he said recently in Baton Rouge. "I've always been willing to go into that community. Black liberals are concerned about me. Black conservatives aren't."
Mr. Duke's campaign has spurred blacks into action up and down Louisiana. In Ruston, in the northern part of the state, 1,200 students at the predominantly black Grambling State University registered to vote in two days following Mr. Duke's second-place showing in the primary.
"I had students who stood in line for three or four hours waiting to register," said Bill Richey, a political science instructor at the school.
And on a weathered block of North Robertson Street in the Treme section of New Orleans, 78-year-old Augustine Alexander, a retired domestic worker, vowed to crawl to the election booth if she has to. "If God hears my prayer, Duke won't get any closer to the governor's mansion than here," she said.
All told, 32,243 new black voters registered after the primary. And many blacks said last week that they were confident Mr. Duke would be defeated because of the new numbers and unified spirit.
But during that same two-day registration period, 35,054 new white voters also signed up. John Maginnis, publisher of The Louisiana Political Review, said new white voters were expected to support Mr. Duke by at least a 2-to-1 ratio.
Back in Hahnville, Mr. Joseph was sitting in his bar, the But Cut. He also operates a restaurant and a beauty shop.
Mr. Joseph said he loves this town. One of the few times he left was to go "fight for my country" in the hills of Korea. He received a Purple Heart.
"We'll be out in force to vote," he said. "I'm just afraid after we beat him that he'll come back again or somebody else like him will. It seems like we have to keep fighting all the time."

HEADLINE: Times Square Redevelopers Seek Delay in Project

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Bereft of tenants and facing a glutted market, the developers of the huge Times Square Center office complex have raised the possibility of postponing the already long-delayed project.
In response, New York State officials strongly suggested that the answer lies right under the nose of one developer -- the Prudential Insurance Company of America -- whose Manhattan-based Prudential Securities subsidiary is shopping around for a great deal of space. 
 The Times Square Center project, which has crawled along since 1981 (always accompanied by official assurances that it was just about to begin), may now be moving too quickly to suit Prudential and its development partner, George Klein of Park Tower Realty.
It would appear that the real-estate market will not have recovered in the next few years, when the first of the 42d Street buildings might be nearing completion under a timetable set by the developers' agreement with the state and city.
Although neither developer would say exactly what modifications they are seeking, people close to the negotiations said that the question of timing is high on their agenda. The possibility that the developers would seek a delay was first reported in The New York Observer.
The scope of the project, however, remains unchanged so far: four office buildings at the crossroads of 42d Street, Seventh Avenue and Broadway, ranging from 29 to 56 stories and containing a total of 4.2 million square feet of space.
And no one is saying that Prudential or Park Tower is about to walk away from the endeavor. Harold Holzer, executive vice president for public affairs for the New York State Urban Development Corporation, noted that the developers had already committed a huge sum to buy land.
"These folks have $186 million in the project," he said. "Their feet may not be hot but they can't be cold, because they have so much money in it."
"We are not conceding in the least that in a soft real-estate market the project has to be abridged or slowed," Mr. Holzer added.
 
'Reshaping of Some Things'
 But some kind of change would seem to be in the works.
Refusing to be more explicit, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the deputy mayor for finance and economic development, said, "It may require the reshaping of some things, but if that can be done around a tenant, it makes more sense for everybody."
The city is eager to receive $90 million from the developers that would be used to renovate the Times Square subway station, as well as the tax revenues from a successful office project.
Prudential and Park Tower would have to begin building the first tower within a year of the state's delivering two sites, on the northeast and southwest corners of Broadway and 42d Street, in "vacant possession," meaning that the last tenants had departed. The developers would also be required to post a letter of credit to secure the renovation of the subway station.
There are three tenants on those sites who are not yet subject to a vacate order or who have not yet settled with the Urban Development Corporation. Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, said she believed the sites might be vacant by January.
Were the developers to begin construction in early 1993, they would probably be building into a market that still had tens of millions of square feet of vacant space and little appetite for more. That is particularly true around Times Square, where there are already a number of largely empty office towers.
The partners have been unable to secure a single tenant, having lost earlier commitments from Chemical Bank and the law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood.
At the same time, however, Prudential Securities, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company, has been searching for new space as it nears the end of its leases in lower Manhattan.
"Prudential Securities is looking for a location," said Mr. Holzer. "And we have a project with large office buildings. It seems to us that this is a match made in heaven."
 
Hoping for 'Grand Slam'
 Ms. Hernandez-Pinero would not confirm that the city was pursuing a link between Prudential Securities and Times Square Center, but she observed generally, "It's pretty obvious that to the extent you have a major space user, if you could secure their commitment to stay in the city and have them as an anchor tenant at Times Square, that's a grand slam."
Prudential Securities, known until last year as Prudential Bache, has some 5,000 employees in Manhattan and three major offices: 199 Water Street at Fulton Street; 100 Gold Street at Frankfort Street, and 127 John Street at Water Street. Most of these leases expire at the end of 1994.
A spokeswoman for Park Tower referred inquiries to Richard W. Matthews, director of public relations for Prudential Insurance in Newark, who said the company would not comment on "any aspect of our discussions with the city and state."

HEADLINE: Dole Calls Democratic Ideas On Jobless Aid Demagoguery

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, today accused Senate Democrats of "partisan demagoguery" in proposing legislation to extend unemployment benefits that would give President Bush three choices on how to pay for it: declaring a budget emergency and increasing the Federal deficit, curbing foreign aid or raising estimated income tax payments.
Mr. Dole said all three choices were flawed. But he scoffed at the overall plan as "government by multiple choice."

HEADLINE: Gephardt Assails Bush's Foreign Policy as Weak

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to broaden the 1992 campaign debate, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said today that President Bush's foreign policy amounted to little more than defending the status quo and failed to protect American economic interests.
Mr. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, told reporters today that his party's Presidential hopefuls should not be fooled by Mr. Bush's reputation for foreign policy success and should attack him for failing to "do more than tidy up after the cold war." 
 "Democrats should not cede this area to the President," he said.
Mr. Gephardt's effort to refocus the dialogue in a campaign that he decided in July not to enter himself was made tonight in a speech at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., and in a meeting with reporters in his office here this morning. The Northwestern speech was one of the Leopold lectures in economics.
Mr. Gephardt said it would be a mistake for Democratic candidates to accept the "false Republican dichotomy between foreign and domestic affairs." Indeed, he focused heavily on the need to strengthen the domestic economy. But he argued that if the economy remained weak the American people would turn inward and provide diminishing support even for wise foreign policies.
"Without economic growth," he said, the American people "will rationally demand that we simply turn inward. Public support will evaporate for international commitments at precisely the time President Bush is trying to expand them."
Some of Mr. Gephardt's prescriptions for an improved economy were familiar. He called for extended unemployment insurance benefits, a tax cut to benefit the middle class, and a solution to the health insurance problem. He said last year's budget agreement should be revised, cutting military spending to pay for greater efforts in "areas critical to economic strength -- education, training, research and development."
Mr. Gephardt said that the Government had to show more energy in protecting American trading interests abroad and that President Bush had "canceled the wrong trip," attending a "perfunctory" meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and calling off a visit to Asia when he should have "made the blue-collar worker's case" directly to Japan.
 
'Rolodex Relationships'
 Mr. Gephardt said the President ought to be able to say to American workers, "My personal relationship with the Japanese Prime Minister permits me to fight for fair trade, and the success of that fight will mean higher wages and greater opportunity for you and your family." Instead, he said, Mr. Bush was content to maintain amiable "Rolodex relationships with foreign leaders who don't share our interests."
Democrats, he said, must tell America that national security was achieved not just through military means, when necessary, "but also in other theaters where the battles of the 21st century are going to take place: in the clean rooms of high-tech laboratories, in the trading pits of the Bourses and foreign exchanges, on the docks of Yokohama and New York harbor, and in the classrooms wherever our students yearn to reach for the stars."

HEADLINE: NATO Summit Meeting Ends With Warning to Soviet Republics Over Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Western alliance ended a two-day summit meeting here today with a warning to the Soviet Union and its restive republics to bring their nuclear arsenals under central control, observe international disarmament agreements and curb the spread of conventional forces.
The warning reflected what Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany described as a sense that the Soviet Union's disintegration created an "explosive situation" as conventional and nuclear weapons slipped outside of Moscow's control. 
 For the last two days, the 16 leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have been meeting in a hotel on Rome's outskirts to try to redefine the alliance's role in a rapidly changing Europe from which its onetime adversary, the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, has disappeared.
 
Divergences Illuminated
 The meeting has produced some of the commitments demanded on Thursday by President Bush to a continued American military presence in Europe. And it has yielded a new military doctrine, supported by all 16 leaders, envisioning leaner and more mobile NATO forces supported by smaller nuclear arsenals.
But it has also illuminated marked divergences both on attitudes to the Soviet Union and on European plans to create a European army.
President Francois Mitterrand of France, for instance, refused to subscribe to today's warning to the Soviet Union because, a member of his delegation said, he felt its tone resembled that of a "preaching friar."
Mr. Mitterrand himself, a close supporter of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, told reporters that NATO should not "try to enter the internal affairs of countries or dictate policies."
"For countries outside the alliance, we are not their rulers," he said. "We do not have an evangelical mission."
What prompted his annoyance was an official NATO document, issued today and titled "Developments in the Soviet Union," that sought to address concerns about independent-minded Soviet republics, notably the Ukraine, where many nuclear weapons are stationed and which plans to create its own army, raising the prospect of an unpredictable nuclear force on the borders of Eastern Europe's uncertain new democracies.
 
Respect for Accords
 "It is critical that the Soviet Union and the republics take all necessary actions to ensure that all international agreements signed by the U.S.S.R. are respected, ratified and implemented," the document said, referring specifically to treaties on nuclear, biological and conventional arms controls.
"We call upon all authorities to refrain from any steps that could lead to proliferation of nuclear weapons or other means of mass destruction," it said.
"We urge restraint in the development of conventional military forces that by their size and character could exacerbate political tensions," the statement declared, asking that the Soviet republics define their relationships with one another without "threats, intimidation, coercion or violence."
Prime Minister John Major of Britain said that with winter coming and food shortages looming, the Soviet Union should "stop wasting its resources with vast military programs." He hinted that European food aid could be jeopardized by military buildups in the Soviet republics. "It makes no sense economically and no sense politically for the republics to build up their own forces," he said.
 
Issue of European Army
 Mr. Bush told reporters in the gardens of the American Ambassador's residence here today that there had been differences over how a proposed European army should relate to NATO's American-led command.
He was referring to a debate that centers on a proposal by France and Germany to create a European army ultimately answerable to the European Community, rather than to NATO.
But Mr. Major, who has advanced a counterproposal in conjunction with Italy, said Britain did not see a European army as "being subordinate to the European Council and taking orders from the European Council, or having its policies agreed collectively within the European Council."
"Britain will not accept that," he said. "No one has argued for that over the past few days."
Rather, he said, Britain foresaw a European force as "strengthening the European pillar of the alliance" without duplicating NATO's command.
NATO officials said the European allies seemed to have postponed a decision on the nature of the proposed new force, still in an embryonic stage, until a European Community summit conference in Maastricht, the Netherlands, next month that is supposed to advance the process of European political and and monetary union.
 
Distinctions Glossed Over
 For their part, Mr. Mitterrand said there was "never a question" of a European army seeking to challenge NATO, while Mr. Kohl said there was broad support for the French and German ideas at the summit meeting.
In its final document, the summit conference glossed over those distinctions, saying the proposal for a new force under the aegis of a previously dormant organization called the Western European Union should be welcomed "both as the defense component of the process of European unification and as a means of strengthening the European pillar of the alliance."
From the American standpoint, though, the declaration seemed to satisfy Mr. Bush's demand on Thursday for a statement of European commitment to an American presence in Europe, speaking of "the essential trans-Atlantic link as demonstrated by the significant presence of North American forces in Europe."
As almost an aside that could nonetheless have far-reaching consequences for the spread of advanced military technology to third-world countries, the declaration urged the Soviet Union to insure that its chaos did not facilitate "the export of nuclear or other potentially destabilizing military technologies."

HEADLINE: South Korea to Keep Out All Atom Arms

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea declared for the first time today that his country would no longer possess or store American or any other nuclear weapons on its soil, and called on North Korea to abandon any plans it might have to build a nuclear bomb.
Mr. Roh's comment, in a speech in Seoul, came after the disclosure in Washington last month that the United States would withdraw all nuclear weapons from South Korea as part of President Bush's ban on tactical nuclear weapons throughout the world. 
 Until today, both American and Korean officials had not confirmed the new policy for Korea explicitly.
American and Korean officials did not disclose any timetable for withdrawal or any other details about what nuclear weapons are now on Korean soil. In renouncing the storage of nuclear weapons, Mr. Roh made no specific reference to the United States. This was in keeping with the longstanding American policy of refusing to confirm or deny their presence.
 
Estimates by Expert
 One expert, Robert Norris, an analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, has estimated that the United States has 40 nuclear-tipped artillery shells in Korea, which would have been eliminated by Mr. Bush's global proposal, and 60 nuclear bombs at an air base near Seoul.
The United States is also reducing its troops in South Korea from 43,000 last year to 36,000 next year. Despite such changes and despite the shift in doctrine represented by Mr. Roh's speech, few experts consider it likely that North Korea will be persuaded to abandon its nuclear weapons plans.
The North Korean Government of Kim Il Sung is widely seen as increasingly weakened by a poor economy and pursuing a nuclear program to shore up its legitimacy.
But Mr. Roh's speech was expected to strengthen the Seoul's demands in the arena of world opinion. There was no immediate word on reaction from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.
In the speech, Mr. Roh borrowed the phrasing of North Korea, endorsing its long-stated goal of a "non-nuclear Korean peninsula" and adding that South Korea "will use nuclear energy solely for peaceful purposes and will not manufacture, possess, store, deploy or use nuclear weapons."
But Korean officials also said South Korea would continue to be protected by the American nuclear umbrella, in the form of nuclear bombs not on Korean soil or nuclear-tipped submarine-launched missiles. Moreover, they said nuclear-armed submarines would be allowed in Korean waters.
Only a few weeks ago, North Korea added a series of new barriers to inspections of its nuclear weapons plants, demanding that South Korea renounce the protection of any nuclear weapons before it would agree to inspections of its own nuclear installations.
Earlier, North Korea had demanded simply that South Korea remove American nuclear weapons from its territory, and it did not add the new conditions until disclosures that this demand would be met.
Mr. Roh's speech was the latest step in a renewed effort by governments around the world to put pressure on North Korea to accept international inspections of its nuclear installations, particularly the site at Yongbyon, north of Pyongyang.
The South Korean President said North Korea "continues to evade its international duties on account of groundless charges and excuses."
Analysts differ over how close North Korea is to making a nuclear bomb, with some Americans and Japanese saying it could be five or six years and some South Koreans saying it could be a year or two.
The two Koreas remain technically at war nearly four decades after the end of the Korean War. They have nearly 1.7 million troops facing each other, making the peninsula one of the most heavily armed parts of the world.
Western concerns have focused in recent weeks on North Korea's nuclear bombs, but there are also concerns that the threat of a nuclear North Korea might persuade South Korea to abandon its pledge not to build a nuclear bomb. Mr. Roh's pledge was thus regarded as significant.

HEADLINE: No Smooth Road Ahead for Tax-Cut Bandwagon

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Despite the enormous pressure of a stalled economy and the message from voters this week that they want tax relief, Democratic and Republican lawmakers say the tax-cut bandwagon is going nowhere in Congress this year.
There has been something of a tax-cut frenzy in recent weeks, with dozens of lawmakers advancing an assortment of proposals that their authors vow would revive the economy. The latest entry comes from Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the most influential tax writer in Congress, who had been said to be resisting moves for a tax cut but who proposed one himself on Thursday. 
 Most lawmakers in both parties say there is only a remote possibility that any tax cut plan would be approved by Congress before it goes into recess before the end of the year.
 
'Get the Debate Started'
 Speaking of his own tax-cut plan, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, said: "It would be very difficult to get it passed this year. But I think it's important to get the debate started. Any time you get on a tax bill you've got yourself an extended debate that takes some time."
Even if a plan wends its way through Congress in early 1992, formidable obstacles remain.
President Bush restated his opposition to the idea again today, saying it would be impossible under the constraints of the budget agreement hammered out by the White House and Congress last year.
"I'd love to be in a position to pledge every American, whatever, a tax cut," Mr. Bush said at a news conference in Rome. "But I don't want to do that when I can't see how I can do that and keep it inside the budget agreement."
Some lawmakers, too, are warning their colleagues to resist the pressures for cutting taxes.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said in an interview: "The greatest risk here is turning these kind of limited tax proposals into a wholesale bidding war that then winds up including everything from I.R.A.'s to capital gains to extension of tax credits to investment tax credits and a host of other members' favorites. So the big question that confronts both the President and the Congress is: Can you control the process so that it doesn't turn into chaos?"
But proponents of tax cuts in both parties are undaunted. Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, told reporters of the White House's resistance, "Up until a week and a half ago we weren't even in a recession if you listen to them down at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, conceded that passage of a tax cut might not be imminent, but such proposals "send a very positive message to the American people."
"A lot of what's happening now is psychological," he said. "People need their confidence rebuilt."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat who came up with a tax cut proposal in May, today framed the debate as guided by practical politics, saying, "The politics of the moment is how do you help middle-income taxpayers?"
Democrats contend that tax policy has favored the rich for the last decade and see tax cuts for the middle class as an appealing political issue. Republicans, meanwhile, are struggling to add provisions to their capital gains tax cut proposals that would benefit the middle class.
"Two or three months ago I would have said we would do nothing on taxes before the next election," said Jane G. Gravelle, a senior specialist in economic policy for the Congressional Research Service. "Now it looks more likely that we will."
But there is significant disagreement between Republicans and Democrats and in the parties themselves over how the tax cuts should be accomplished and whom they should benefit.
 
Gramm Offers a Plan
 The leading Republicans in favor of cutting taxes are Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. Their proposal would cut the rate of the tax of capital gains, expand benefits for Individual Retirement Accounts and offer a tax credit to first-time home buyers.
Mr. Rostenkowski's bill has already drawn the support of the House leadership. Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington vowed that "we are going to move forward with it" and that "it has a very high degree of probability of being passed by the House."
Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal calls for a tax cut for working-class and middle-income families that would be offset by higher income taxes on the wealthy. It would create an income-tax credit equal to 20 percent of the Social Security and Medicare taxes that a worker paid.
 
Downey Opened the Drive
 Other leading proposals are more narrow than the Rostenkowski plan, geared more to such provisions as helping families with children.
The opening move in the latest drive to cut taxes came in May from Representative Downey and Senator Al Gore, a Tennessee Democrat, who proposed replacing the personal exemption for children with an $800 refundable credit. It would also raise the top tax rates.
"Our proposal would primarily benefit middle-income taxpayers with children," Mr. Downey said in an interview. "And the Rostenkowski proposal would benefit everyone who pays Social Security taxes. In terms of the base of who's covered, his is much larger. But our credit is far richer for middle-income taxpayers."
In another effort to help middle-class families, Senator Bentsen, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, proposed a $300 tax credit for each child up to the age of 18 and a liberalization of incentives for I.R.A.'s. But critics dismiss Mr. Bentsen's plan as not realistic because it would be financed through cuts in the military budget, which would violate the budget agreement that passed last year.
Under the agreement, lawmakers are forbidden from using cuts in discretionary programs, like the military, to offset a tax cut. Instead, the cuts must be paid for by some other tax increase or a cut in mandatory spending, like Medicare or food stamps.
Lost in the political discussion of tax cuts is whether they would give the economy the jolt that it needs, particularly if they do not take effect until well into next year.
"The curious proposals are the ones for I.R.A.'s and capital gains," Ms. Gravelle said. "If they did increase the savings rate, they would be unlikely to stimulate the economy."
Echoing such concerns, Mr. Panetta warned against "quick-fix" solutions. "Obviously the election results from last Tuesday added additional fuel to the fire in trying to do something to address the concerns of the American people," he said.
"But my view is that the President and the Congress should develop a comprehensive package that looks not only at tax relief but includes the unemployment compensation piece as well as some targeted investments," he said. "But from a political point of view, it may be that the best you can hope for is a very limited tax relief bill."

HEADLINE: David Novick, Analyst On Racing, Dies at 85

 BODY:
David Novick, an economist who was an outspoken analyst on the horse-racing industry, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 85 years old and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.
He died of complications after a stroke, said his nephew, Roger Levin of Bethlehem, with whom he had been staying. 
 Mr. Novick headed the cost-analysis department of the Rand Corporation, a research institution in Santa Monica, from 1950 to 1970.
His work in the horse racing field was independent from Rand. Besides breeding and raising thoroughbred horses, he carried out studies for industry and Government organizations involved in horse-racing and other sports, testified before racing commissions and wrote a book-length essay on his specialty, "Economic Study of Harness Horse Racing."
In the 1960's and 1970's he also wrote economic analyses that appeared in The Blood-Horse, a magazine about thoroughbred horse racing and breeding.
One occasion in which Mr. Novick contended that the sport was overgrown was a speech to leaders of the Thoroughbred Racing Association in 1976. "Instead of filling the tub to overflowing, it would be better to open the drain a little, and have less quantity and more quality," he declared.
Mr. Novick was born in Easton, Pa., and studied at Lafayette College and Brown and New York Universities. He is survived by his wife, Mary Bateman Novick, and a sister, Dora N. Levin of Houston.

HEADLINE: In Voters' Wake, Reading the Message

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
A few miles north of Representative Robert E. Andrews's district, jubilant New Jersey Republicans are still celebrating the landslide in which they captured both houses of the State Legislature for the first time in 20 years.
A few miles west, across the Delaware River, Democrats are toasting Harris Wofford, a one-time college administrator with an anti-Bush message, who trounced former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, a confidant of the President, to become the first Pennsylvania Democrat to win a Senate seat in 23 years. 
 Surveying the results from his camp between the two political storms, the freshman Democrat says that what seems to be anti-establishment fury is actually a mosaic of contradictory trends.
 
Combining Messages
 The Pennsylvania outcome shows the political power of the economic malaise and pent-up demand for services like health care, Mr. Andrews says. But the New Jersey vote, essentially a rejection of the $2.8 billion in tax increases won by Gov. Jim Florio, showed that anti-tax fervor remains a potent force.
"When you combine New Jersey and Pennsylvania, the message is loud and clear: people want our economic crisis addressed and addressed without raising taxes," said Mr. Edwards, who succeeded Mr. Florio when the veteran Congressman ran for Governor. "Pennsylvania voters told Republicans 'You're not giving us prosperity, but even worse, you don't care.' New Jersey said 'If you confuse more taxes with prosperity, you're going to have a very short career.' "
Just days after the 1991 elections, members of the New York metropolitan region's Congressional delegation are already looking warily toward 1992, keenly aware that the voters' apparently conflicting messages -- rising demands for expensive services and continued pressure for major tax relief -- confront them with a potentially explosive shock wave.
"You can't have more without somebody having to pay more," Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Hartford Democrat and the chief deputy majority whip, said in noting that Senator Wofford's rise from a 44-percentage-point deficit in the polls was fueled by calls for national health insurance.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican who must face re-election next year, noted that the simultaneous demands for services and tax relief "creates some problems."
"Wherever people are perceived as indifferent to the plight of middle-class working families, they're in trouble," he said.
After years in which Republicans seemed better placed to take advantage of voters' anti-tax fury, the legislators said the political playing field appears to have leveled. Both the Democratic and Republican Parties, the lawmakers noted, suffered startling setbacks and enjoyed unexpected successes. Both parties, the politicians added, now confront political opportunities and mine fields.
"It rings an alarm for us all," Mr. D'Amato said.
"While voters get angry and disenfranchised, they take a close look in specific races," added Representative Samuel Gejendson, a Democrat from Connecticut.
"Voters want better choices," said Representative Robert J. Mrazek, a Long Island Democrat who is seeking his party's nomination to challenge Mr. D'Amato. "People are fed up with going to the hospital and bleeding on the floor and before they get treatment being asked who is going to pay for this. They don't like spending $6 billion a year in Korea when we can't spend half that much to send their kids to college. More and more people are saying 'I want the choices made for our kids.' "
 
Matter of Incumbency
 Several legislators noted that Washington State voters rejected an initiative to set term limits. That was good news for incumbents. Still they fared poorly in many races across the region.
In Suffolk County, a little-known Republican Assemblyman, Robert J. Gaffney, upset the incumbent, Patrick G. Halpin, who surprised even many of his Democratic colleagues four years ago when he ended 16 years of Republican control. And in neighboring Nassau County, a Republican stronghold for decades, Democrats made significant and unexpected gains. They now have enough votes on the Board of Supervisors to block even routine measures.
But incumbency did not necessarily spell defeat, even in Connecticut, where adoption of the first state income tax in history has superheated anti-tax fervor.
Mr. Andrews noted that in local races around his district, Democrats ran on pledges to freeze spending and did well, beating all three Republican incumbents running for re-election to the Camden County Board of Freeholders. That gave Democrats a 4-to-3 majority.
The New Jersey races, combined with the results in Pennsylvania, "give you one very clear picture and two very clear messages," Mr. Andrews said. "It tells Republicans that 'You better start paying attention to the economy and job creation and you better not think that a victory parade for the Persian Gulf war makes us all happy.' And for Democrats, 'If you think some harebrained tax scheme is going to put us back to work, think again.' "

HEADLINE: It's Beginning to Look a Lot Like Dec. 26

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
It's never too early to go holiday shopping, and there is an especially good reason not to wait this year. Many department stores around the country have already posted Christmas sale prices on all kinds of merchandise, including clothing, housewares and home furnishings.
And for people who hope to find lower prices after Christmas on things that they need for themselves, rather than for gifts, the experts say the bargains may not be any better then. 
 Lingering consumer concern about the economy has led to extensive price promotions, especially in the Northeast and Southern California.
"Retailers are stimulating sales by putting things out at attractive prices," said James Posner, a New York retail consultant.
To be sure, shoppers are still buying products at regular prices, particularly new merchandise in desirable styles or colors. But a combination of early sales, clearances and special purchases from manufacturers has created a discount atmosphere in many department and specialty stores where Christmas bargains are rarely found before Dec. 26.
 
'No Reason to Wait'
 "There's no reason to wait until after Christmas to buy the kind of things you want to buy," said Philip Johnson, the president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a consumer research concern in Chicago. "Things are worse this year than last year in terms of willingness to spend."
"You'll see more promotional activity this year than last," said Lee Abraham, the chairman of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, the largest independent retail cooperative organization. "The consumer wants to be able to buy at the lowest possible price, and I don't think anything is sacred these days, with the exception of cosmetics and very few of the branded lines."
For several years, some retailers, particularly big department stores, have begun seasonal markdowns far ahead the actual holiday. This year, there is more of the same.
"Department store numbers have been pretty dismal," said Rosalind Wells, an economist for the NPD Group, a market research company in Port Washington, L.I. She was referring to sales figures for September and early October. "In general, discount stores are doing better than department stores."
A survey last month of 450 people by the Shapiro firm -- a sample representing the 93 million households in the United States -- showed that only 24 percent of the respondents planned to spend more on gifts this Christmas than last, compared with 28 percent at the same time in 1990. That is the lowest October percentage since the recession of 1981-'82. Forty-seven percent of those surveyed said they intended to spend less, as against 44 percent last year.
And in the last week of October, the Conference Board, a business research group, reported that consumer confidence had dropped sharply in October -- a negative sign for Christmas spending. And because the selling season between Thanksgiving and Christmas is six days shorter in 1991 than it was last year, merchants are under pressure to attract more customers before Thanksgiving.
"Ten years ago, the philosophy used to be to run a sale during a slow period to get more business," said John J. Schultz, the executive director of the National Retail Federation, a trade association. "Now retailers have to do it during a peak period."
That means that some of the best Christmas values will be available this month. Since as much as 50 percent of the year's profits come in November and December, many stores are pricing as competitively as possible to insure that their sales will exceed those of the same period in 1990.
"It's hard to be patient in this world we're in, because it's such a precious time in terms of the bottom line for all retailers," said Gerald Mathews, an executive vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue. "Consumers who want some sense of specialness will find that higher quality products are not going to be available late."
"The longer you wait, the less likely you are to find a range of things to choose from," said Richard Feinberg, director of the Purdue University Retail Institute. "We already see Christmas sales occurring now, particularly in the Midwest."
Apparently, shoppers already know about this. In a study last month by Bruskin/Goldring Research of Edison, N.J., 38 percent of about 1,000 Americans surveyed said they would do most of their Christmas shopping in November, when the broadest assortment of goods will be available. What's more, adults plan to spend an average of $755 for Christmas gifts in 1991, down 12 percent from last year.
"Retailers are in for a pretty bleak Christmas unless they do something unusual," said Jeffrey N. Harris, vice president of marketing for Bruskin/ Goldring. "Whatever they did last year is not going to help this year."
One thing that more and more merchants are doing is emphasizing items that they have bought especially to put on sale now at lower prices. "Retailers have made special purchases that they plan to promote pre-Christmas," said Mr. Schultz of the retail federation. "Retailers want to sell now."
Also new this year is the wide variety of spring merchandise in the stores before Christmas, said Robert E. Salerno, a partner in New York of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and consulting firm. "This is the only way they've got to really drive people into the stores," he said.
What it all boils down to is that shoppers looking for price-cutting in the weeks ahead are almost certain to find it in many general merchandise categories. As Mr. Posner, the New York retail consultant, said: "There have been sales continuously: summer sales, back-to-school sales, Columbus Day sales, Election Day sales and now Christmas sales. It's just a renaming of sales."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I don't think anything is sacred these days" in pre-Christmas retail sales, said Lee Abraham, who heads a merchandising cooperative. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Finns Haven't Decided To Join Europe Yet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Europeans in Accord to Create Vastly Expanded Trading Bloc' (front page, Oct. 23), describing formation of the European Economic Area, misinterprets Finland's policy on full membership in the European Community. Finland has not applied for community membership, nor has it decided to apply next spring. Rather, the Finnish Government has simply stated that next spring it will make a decision. A positive one is by no means inevitable. 
 While pro-European Community voices are heard in all the country's major political parties, no party has yet formally supported membership. Even if the governing coalition decided to join the community, it would need the President's approval, since the Finnish Constitution makes the President responsible for foreign policy. His official position, and thus Finland's, is to give the European Economic Area a trial run to see how it serves the country's interests and to watch the development of the E.C., especially its security policy.
There are other reasons that Finland might not join the E.C. next spring. Widespread public opposition to membership might increase as the economic area treaty is debated in Parliament and then implemented. The Prime Minister's Center Party represents agriculture, the sector of the Finnish economy that will suffer most from the agreement. Protected industries will be subject to freemarket competition.
A highly homogenous and xenophobic populace will encounter more people from other parts of Europe, a continent about which the Finns speak as if it were on the other side of the world.
 
JASON E. LAVERY
New Haven, Oct. 23, 1991
 
The writer is a doctoral candidate in history at Yale University.

HEADLINE: Can Machines Think? Humans Match Wits

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
A group of human judges chosen to represent the Boston man-in-the-street engaged in a three-hour battle of wits with a handful of computer programs today. The idea was to answer what many scientists and philosophers believe will become the central question of the information age: Can machines think?
It was hard to tell -- harder than one might have, pardon the expression, thought. 
 The judges typed questions into computer terminals and tried to decide from the responses whether they were communicating with a man or a machine. One program proved convincing enough to fool 5 of the 10 judges. Two other programs fooled some of the people for some of the time. But the humans had, uh, second thoughts and realized that what they had thought were human thoughts were actually coming from diskettes, hard drives, monitors and electricity.
 
Cutting Through a Debate
 The tournament was the first attempt to run a Turing Test, the experiment first proposed by the Britishmathematician Alan M. Turing 41 years ago as a simple way of cutting through the philosophical debate about whether a machine could ever be built to mimic the human mind. If a person communicating with such a machine could not tell whether it was a computer or human, Mr. Turing reasoned, the question would be resolved.
Throughout the afternoon, while the typed conversations between programs and judges flickered on large screens in an auditorium at the Boston Computer Museum, a group of scientists and philosophers grappled with the meaning of the event.
"If a computer were to pass an unrestricted Turing Test," said Daniel Dennett, a professor of cognitive studies at Tufts University, "it will raise a number of deep civil rights questions. For example, it would be a crime to unplug such a machine because it would be a person in a legal sense. Turing should be thought of as a pioneer in machine rights."
First prize went to a commercial software program called PC Therapist III, which was designed to engage its questioner in a whimsical conversation. The program was written by Joseph Weintraub, the president of Thinking Software Inc., a small artificial intelligence software company in Woodside, Queens.
At one point, another program suggested to a judge: "Perhaps you're not getting enough affection from your partner in the relationship."
"What are the key elements that are important in relationships in order toprevent conflict or problems?" the judge responded.
 
Thinks It Doesn't Think. . .
 "I think you don't think I think," answered the terminal.
"What kind of a response to a question is that?" asked the judge. "Nextquestion: Do you think romantic relationships are unrealistic, doomed from the start?"
"I do tend to walk around with my head in the clouds," the terminal said.
"Are you a romantic?" the judge queried.
"I take in whatever you ask," came the reply.
"Have you experienced problems in romantic relationships?"
"I try to be agreeable," responded the terminal.
Many of the watching experts, including scientists, philosophers and psychologists who assembled here, said they were surprised by the outcome. Computer experts said they could easily tell the human from the computer respondents. Unlike the untrained observers, the experts spotted the "common sense" mistakes that were an immediate giveaway, as when the computer would respond to a question other than the one asked.
There were several other confusing results. One of the human confederates, Cynthia Clay, who was judged "most human of all contestants," was nevertheless judged to be a computer by two judges.
But the deeper question of whether computers will ever be able to convincingly mimic human beings and what it will mean for the human spirit if they can, remained tantalizingly distant.
"These were real judges," said Oliver Strimpel, executive director of the Boston Computer Museum, one of the sponsors. "Maybe the Turing Test isn't as difficult as we first thought."
 
Hard to Tell Difference
 Mr. Turing believed that by the end of the century it would be possible to program computers to play an "imitation game" well enough so that an average human judge would not be able to determine if a conversation typed at a computer terminal was with a human "confederate" or a computer.
That assumption has become the subject of a bitter debate between scientists and philosophers who have taken sides on the question over whether the human mind will ever be reduced to a set of computer programs.
The first modern version of the Turing Test, made possible by the establishment of a $100,000 prize by the philanthropist Hugh Loebner and with the support of the National Science Foundation and the Alfred P. Sloane Foundation, was not the true test that Mr. Turing envisioned. Because of limitations in the programs' abilities, each was confined to discussing a narrow topic, such as women's clothing, romantic relationships or Burgundy wine. For winning the first contest, Mr. Weintraub was awarded $1,500.
"We're witnessing history today," said Keay Dewdney, a computer scientist at the University of Western Ontario and author of the Computer Recreations section in Scientific American.
 
At the Start: Oops!
 Still, like many of the mythical confrontations between human and computer in science fiction literature and cinema, the first interim Turing test involved a technical glitch.
The start of the contest was delayed almost 45 minutes while techniciansscrambled to sort out a problem that kept telephone lines connecting two of the human confederates to the contest busy. When it did start, the number of terminals and screens was reduced from the original 10 to eight.
Several members of the Loebner Prize committee said they thought that the glitch made judging harder.
Joseph Weizenbaum, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology computer scientist, said that he was struck by how similar PC Therapist was to a program that he had written several decades ago called Eliza. Eliza became widely popular for engaging questioners in a simple nonsensical conversation. He said that such programs were very difficult to trick because it was difficult for humans to assess the nonsensical replies from the program.
After the contest, Mr. Dewdney said that he had quickly decided that there were six programs and two humans behind the terminals. But he was surprised when he heard that people were changing their minds about several programs late in the contest.
 
A Shakespeare Curve
 In particular, at a terminal which was discussing Shakespeare's plays, a great deal of confusion was inspired because the terminal kept changing its answer to the question, "What is your favorite play?"
One of the human judges, Lou-Anne Kroutil, a student and part-time auto mechanic, said she had been fooled by PC Therapist when it responsed with a nonsense answer.
"It typed something that I thought was trite, and when I responded it interacted with me in a very convincing fashion," she said.
Mr. Weintraub's program held a number of the audience spellbound. One conversation went as follows:
Terminal: A whim is a sudden capricious and often peculiar behavior. A bit of sunlight in a grim grey world!
Judge: Something like a hunch?
Terminal: Everybody sets out to do something and everybody does something, but no one does what he sets out to do.
Judge: Well anyway I would imagine whimsical converation is like a series of knight's moves in chess -- sort of zig-zag rather than following any particularline.
Terminal: A whimsical person is subject to erratic behavior and unpredictable thoughts. . . .how nice to be unpredicttable!
Judge: Are you kidding? Sure total predictablicity would make the world a dull place, but unpredictability is hardly a virtue!
After the contest was over Dr. Loebner pronounced himself satisified with the results and said that he felt that the Turing Test would now have a life of its own. Dr. Loebner is president of Crowne Industries, an equipment supply firm in Orange, N.J.
He said that he had thought of sponsoring a Turing Test seven years ago to stir interest in designing artificially intelligent programs.
Calling himself a "dyed-in-the-wool," utopian, he said that in bothliterature and science there has been a noble tradition by those whohave tried to build machines with human qualities.
The New York City philanthropist also revealed another, possibly more personal motivation in sponsoring the contest: "I'm in favor of 100 percent unemployment. I've always wanted computers to do all the work."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Selects Panel to Review City's Hospitals

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named the members of a commission charged with conducting a "head to toe" review of the city hospitals. The panel includes prominent doctors and lawyers but no one from the front lines of the hospitals themselves.
Union leaders representing doctors and hospital workers questioned whether the 18-member commission could impartially scrutinize contracts between medical schools and the municipal hospitals, known as "affiliate agreements," which some critics say are at the heart of the hospitals' problems. Some of the new commissioners have ties to medical schools that have multimillion-dollar contracts with the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. 
 "This is an establishment board," said Dr. Donald C. Meyer, executive director of the Doctors Council, a physicians union. "It's stacked heavily with people I would consider pro-affiliation. We have no faith in what this commission can come up with."
 
Appointments Defended
 But the head of the panel, Dr. Jeremiah Barondess, president of the New York City Academy of Physicians, defended the appointment of doctors who are associated with the affiliated medical schools, saying they know the details of the arrangements between the hospitals and medical schools.
"It's hard for me to imagine how to approach the affiliation issue with all of its sensitivities and complexities in an intelligent way at arms length," he said. "I really do think we need to have people with current expertise."
Mayor Dinkins asked Dr. Barondess to form the commission last month after a series of deaths in the city hospital system stirred a firestorm of complaints about the quality of care at municipal hospitals, which have been hit hard by budget cuts. Dr. Barondess said the panel would interview workers, patients, doctors and administrators and hoped to issue a final report in six to eight months.
Among the commissioners are two physicians on the faculty at Columbia University's medical school, which is affiliated with Harlem Hospital, the site of two deaths investigated in recent months. They are Dr. Gerald E. Thomson, an associate medical school dean, and Dr. Sterling B. Williams Jr., a gynecology professor.
These are the other members:
Carol Bellamy, ex-City Council President.
Richard A. Berman, former New York University Medical School official who is now on the New York State Health Care Financing Commission.
June Christmas, former mental health commissioner, mayoral adviser and psychiatry professor at Columbia.
Robert A. Derzon, former deputy commissioner of New York City hospitals.
Eli Ginzberg, Columbia economics professor.
Dr. Paul P. Griner, director of medicine at the Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester.
Dr. Robert M. Heyssel, president of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
Peter Johnson, lawyer and adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Bogart R. Leashore, the dean at Hunter College School of Social Work.
Stanley H. Lowell, a former Deputy Mayor.
Dr. Eric Munoz, director of the University of Medicine and Dentistry at New Jersey's University Hospital.
Ildaura Murillo-Rohde, former professor of psychiatry at New York Medical College.
Diana T. Murray, former vice president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
Howard Newman, dean of Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University.
Dr. Samuel O. Thier, former chairman of the Yale University Department of Medicine.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS: German Official's Remarks Help Dollar to Move Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved upward yesterday, once again influenced by apparent interest rate trends.
 Gold prices were mixed. 
Analysts said the dollar drew support from comments by Helmut Schlesinger, the president of Germany's central bank, who said he was not sure another increase in German interest rates was necessary.
 Mr. Schlesinger's statement depressed the mark, which, like all currencies, gains strength from higher interest rates. The prospect that German rates would not be rising would make interest rates in the United States more competitive, and the remarks helped the dollar yesterday.
 The dollar rose to 1.6485 marks in New York, from 1.6410 late Thursday. In earlier European trading, the dollar advanced to 1.6415 German marks from 1.6305.
 The dollar was also helped by the belief that United States rates are unlikely to fall much further after the Federal Reserve's move this week to drop the discount rate. The Fed lowered the interest it charges commercial banks to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent.
 Mike Faust, a currency market analyst with MMS International, said the dollar had reached the high end of a broad trading range and could move higher if it was able to break through 1.6500 marks.
 He described the market as quiet, with traders waiting for inflation figures to be released by the Government next week.
 The British pound lost ground against the dollar, falling to $1.7630 in New York from $1.7705. Sterling also fell in London, closing at $1.7680, compared with $1.7800 late Thursday.
 The dollar gained against the Japanese yen, rising to 130.43 from 129.865 in New York. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 130.23 yen, from 129.93 Thursday, and in London it rose to 130.25 yen.
 Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.4550 Swiss francs, up from 1.4480; 5.6345 French francs, up from 5.6055; 1,240.00 Italian lire, up from 1,234.50, and 1.13125 Canadian dollars, up from 1.12225.
 Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4505 Swiss francs, up from 1.4390; 5.6110 French francs, up from 5.5740; 1.8500 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8375; 1,234.75 Italian lire, up from 1,224.50, and 1.1261 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1210.
 Gold prices were modestly higher in New York after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold rose 50 cents, to $354.20 an ounce, and the Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $353.80, up 40 cents. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $353.75, down from $354.30.

HEADLINE: SPORTS LEISURE;
Is Ski Business Healthy? Check the Snowfall

BYLINE: By JANET NELSON

 BODY:
By last spring, the ski industry looked like a recreational version of the savings and loan industry. The number of people skiing was down, there had been poor-to-terrible snowfalls on the East and West coasts and the recession had hit everywhere. Rumors spread that ski areas were closing and dismantling lifts.
All of the above is true, but over the summer, managers at many ski areas appeared to ignore these problems and plunged ahead with new projects. Whitetail, a new ski area in Pennsylvania, was completed and is scheduled to open in December. Seventeen areas across the country built 24 new lifts, major snowmaking projects were installed at 20 resorts. A number of areas, including Sunday River, Me., Okemo, Vt., and Keystone and Beaver Creek, Colo., expanded skiing terrain to adjacent mountains. 
 By this fall, as early snowfalls came to the Rockies and temperatures in the East dropped to snowmaking levels, the bad news seemed like a bad dream. Some ski areas in New England and Colorado opened earlier than they had in many years.
"There's a great deal of strength in the ski market in terms of the demand side," said Marvin Kottke, a research economist in Storrs, Conn. Kottke traces skier participation, an industry term for the number of people skiing at ski areas measured by the number of lift tickets sold. "The last two years are an exception in snowfalls and that was the major reason there was less participation. When there is good snow, skiers ski."
 
'You Become Addicted'
 Kottke speculates that if snowfall figures were charted alongside skier participation, the two indicators would probably be parallel. (Kottke said that no one, to his knowledge, has ever plotted skier participation figures and average snowfall in this way, but that it would be a valuable index for the ski industry.) Last season, skier participation across the country dropped by 6.6 percent; in the Northeast it was down 16 percent and in the Pacific West 13 percent. But in the Rocky Mountains it was up 4.1 percent because they had a good snow year.
The recession also had an impact on the industry, and it could be even worse this season, particularly in the East. But John Lay prefers to look on the positive side. As president of Colorado Ski Country, a ski area trade association, he maintains that skiers' loyalty makes the sport relatively recession-proof. "The cruise industry is down and Hawaiian travel is down and theme parks are down," he said. "The issue is what people do with their disposable income. Once you ski, you become addicted and you continue to ski."
That indicates there could be a return to the slopes by many temporary dropouts, according to Lay. He sees growth as families return with their children, as women show more interest in improving skills and as foreign tourists -- possibly the fastest growing segment of the industry -- come to ski in the United States.
Ted Farwell, an economist in Boulder, Colo., who studies the ski industry, projects a one to two percent annual growth in the number of skiers over the next decade. This is not great but, as Farwell points out, it's not stagnant either.
Vermont ski areas had a steady growth in the number of skiers until last season when participation dropped from 4.6 million in 1989-90 to 4.1 million visits. "When you consider the Persion Gulf War, a week of rain at Christmas, which is normally the busiest period, and a bad economy, those figures aren't so bad," said Candy Moot, associate director of Vermont Ski Areas Association.
But ski areas in Vermont have also experienced more than the normal number of failures in recent years, and Magic Mountain, Ascutney, Haystack and Burke are in trouble. This season, Haystack will be operated by Mt. Snow and Burke will reopen under new ownership. Both Moot and Lay say the failure of smaller areas like these that do not have specific market niches is inevitable.
"In the ski industry, the economies of scale indicate that you have to be bigger to compete and provide the facilities that skiers want and demand," said Moot.
In both the East and West, there is a trend toward consolidation as larger areas take over smaller areas. "Actually more ski areas are changing hands rather than failing," said Farwell. "The big ones don't fail, but with mergers, successful areas bring weak areas into their companies."
Farwell said that out of about 600 ski areas in the United States, 31 are in some sort of trouble.
Unlike the ski-area side of the industry, ski equipment and clothing have taken a bigger hit in terms of dollars spent. At the end of last season, there were larger-than-usual inventories left in shops and warehouses. And, this season the pre-season orders of ski shops were down 35 to 40 percent, according to Bill Lawless, who heads Sports Research, Inc., a market research firm in Princeton, N.J., that tracks ski-shop business.
"Buying new equipment and ski clothing is more discretionary than going skiing," said Lawless. "So the ski retailer gets yo-yoed more than ski areas. I think there's a lot of pent-up demand. If we get good snow, the shops could run out of ski equipment and merchandise."
