HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Atlanta

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME; PETER APPLEBOME is chief of the Atlanta bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
Braves fans have put away their tomahawks for the winter. The uproar over the sequel to "Gone With the Wind" has died down. The 1996 Summer Olympics are still five years away.
It seems as if Atlanta has been in the grip of one fever or another nonstop for the past year. If you're overcome by any lingering vapors and find yourself doing the Tomahawk Chop, no one is likely to mind. But now that things seem to be calming down a bit, it's worth remembering that what really makes Atlanta special is the amazingly lush forest, lovely neighborhoods, and inviting parks and open space that really define the city. Even though the leaf season is past its peak, the inviting early November weather make this a perfect, understated time to explore the city and its surroundings. 
 Downtown the focus is Underground Atlanta, the hugely successful reincarnation of the city's original business district. But to get a sense of what makes Atlanta special, the cool autumn temperatures make this an inviting time of year to get in a car and drive along West Paces Ferry Road in Buckhead or Lullwater Road in Druid Hills to gawk at the grand old homes and the autumnal atmosphere created by the giant oaks, dogwoods, poplars and magnolias.
The 185-acre Piedmont Park, the city's major in-town park, and the Atlanta Botanical Garden there are good places to wander around on foot. Also worth a visit is the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area along the river that snakes through Atlanta. Sixteen miles to the east is 3,200-acre Stone Mountain Memorial Park.
 
 
Attractions
 There is, alas, no Tara, although there is a proposal to build one as a tourist attraction in suburban Clayton County. But, for those caught up in the recent spate of "Gone With the Wind" fever, Atlanta offers visitors some intriguing reminders of its Civil War past.
For anyone interested in the Civil War, a must see is the Cyclorama museum, 800 Cherokee Ave S.E., (404) 658-7625. Its highlight is a Civil War film and a 42-foot high circular painting and diorama depicting the Battle of Atlanta. Hours are 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. daily. Admission is $3.50.
A nice mix of the scenic and the historic can be found at Stone Mountain Memorial State Park (404) 498-5600, 16 miles east of Atlanta on Highway 78. A 3,200-acre park that sprawls around the world's largest outcropping of exposed granite, the park offers Civil War exhibits, cable car rides and a cruise on a paddle-wheel riverboat. The centerpiece is the world's largest high-relief sculpture (Mount Rushmore, which is slightly larger, is bas-relief), a 90-by-190-foot carving in granite of Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson. Entrance fee is $5 a car. Major attractions are open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. every day in the fall and winter.
The most vibrant bit of Atlanta's past and the best place in town for browsing, strolling and grazing is Underground Atlanta. Revived in 1989, Underground, the site of downtown's original 19th-century hub that was later abandoned, has emerged as a bustling island of activity in a downtown that really needed one. Situated between Peachtree Street and Central Avenue at Alabama Street, Underground's refurbished and renovated complex of shops, restaurants and clubs and its combination of authentic architectural elements and contemporary design have made it a huge success.
Adjacent to Underground, and a big hit with kids, is The World of Coca-Cola, 55 Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, (404) 676-5151. A high-tech tribute to Atlanta's leading corporate icon, the museum includes Coke memorabilia, an electronic soda fountain, and a chance to sample Coke products. Hours are 10:00 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday and noon to 6 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $2.50.
One of the most arresting and atypical buildings in Atlanta is the gleaming, porcelain-enameled High Museum of Art, designed by Richard Meier, 1280 Peachtree Street N.E., (404) 892-4444. On view through Jan. 5 is "Southern Expressions: Tales Untold," an exhibition of painting, sculpture and photography by southeastern artists. The museum is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Thursday and Saturday, from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Friday, and noon to 5 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $4.
The civil rights struggle that changed the South and the country forever is captured at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, 449 Auburn Avenue N.E., (404) 524-1956. It's the home of civil rights archives and memorabilia, and the reflecting pool with Dr. King's crypt. Hours are 9 A.M. to 8 P.M., and admission is free. Dr. King's boyhood home is just down the street at 501 Auburn Avenue N.E. Hours are from 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.
 
Events
 A perfect match of the right show in the right building is "The Phantom of the Opera," performed by a national touring company at the restored Fox Theater, 660 Peachtree Street N.E., (404) 249-6400. The show runs through Nov. 16 at the historic theater, which opened in 1929, with its Byzantine architecture topped by onion domes and minarets. Tickets run from $22.50 to $47.50. On Nov. 26 at 8 P.M. the Fox will present "Stars of the Bolshoi." Tickets are from $25.50 to $35.50.
From Dec. 6 to 29, the Atlanta Ballet, 477 Peachtree Street N.E., (404) 892-3303, will perform "The Nutcracker." Tickets are $5 to $35.75.
The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra performs at the Woodruff Arts Center, 1280 Peachtree Street N.E., (404) 892-2414. Future programs include a Tchaikovsky Spectacular, Nov. 29 and 30. Tickets for most concerts are $16 to $34. For children there is SciTrek, 395 Piedmont Avenue N.E., (404) 522-5500, Atlanta's enterprising science museum. Through Dec. 31 it offers "Nature's Fury," an interactive exhibit that re-creates natural phenomona like the feeling of being in an earthquake. The museum is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday and 12 to 5 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $6.
For a more ambitious excursion, try the New Georgia Railroad's train trip to Savannah, the historic town near the Georgia coast. From Nov. 22 to 24, a train powered by a working steam engine will make the trip at the time of Savannah's "Christmas Made in the South," a popular arts and crafts show featuring over 200 artists and craftsmen. The train leaves Atlanta at 7 A.M. Nov. 22 with approximate arrival in Savannah at 7 P.M. The return trip departs Savannah at 7 A.M. on Sunday, Nov. 24. Roundtrip tickets are $80. Meals, which are extra, are available on the train. Passengers must provide for their own lodging in Savannah. Call (404) 656-0769.
 
Where to Eat
 The hottest restaurant in Atlanta's pasta wars is Pricci, 500 Pharr Road N.E. (404) 237-2941. It offers unique pizzas, homemade pastas, and other Tuscan, Ligurian and Milanese specialties. Entrees range from $10.50 to $19.50 and an average meal with wine is about $28. A recommendation is pappardelle bolognese, a handmade pasta with veal sauce for $12.50.
The most popular neighborhood restaurants in Atlanta may be Indigo Coastal Grill, 1397 N. Higland Avenue, (404) 876-0676, and Partners Morningside Cafe, 1399 N. Higland Avenue, (404) 876-8104, two side-by-side eateries that both offer excellent food, amiably cramped surroundings and often a half-hour wait for a table. Indigo offers coastal fare with entrees ranging from $10.95 to $17.95. A speciality is Cape Cod steamer, with lobster, mussels, clams, shrimp, scallops, potatoes and corn for $16.95 to $19, , depending on market price. Partners offers varied entrees ranging from ravioli stuffed with lobster and shiitake mushrooms or smoked duck sausage priced from $10.95 to $17.95.
At Underground Atlanta,the best sit-down meal can be found at Lombardi's Underground, 94 Upper Pryor Street, (404) 522-6568. Italian entrees range from $8 to $17, and specialties include trittico del giorno, a sampler of three fresh pastas for $11.95 or cioppino, a stew of fresh fish, mussels, clams, calamari and shrimp, cooked in a tomato broth, and served on a bed of linguini for $14.95.
Some of the best and most convenient pre-theater dining can be found at Chef's Grill, 1280 Peachtree Street N.E., at the Woodruff Arts Center (404) 881-0652. The eclectic American cuisine includes crab cakes, fresh seafood and pizzas, with entrees ranging from $8.95 to $17.95. A specialty is sauteed crab cakes with tomato-chive butter for $14.95.
For an informal lunch or light dinner in eccentric surroundings in Atlanta's Midtown area, try R. Thomas' Deluxe Grill, 1812 Peachtree Road N.W., (404) 872-2942. It has neo-hippie decor, a heated patio garden, and it almost never closes, staying open 24 hours a day on Friday and Saturday and from 10 A.M. to 6 A.M. Sunday to Thursday. It has good chicken, omlettes, pasta and burgers with the Cajun sauteed chicken going for $7.95.
At the other extreme is the dining room at the Ritz-Carlton Buckhead, 3434 Peachtree Road N.E., (404) 237-2700. Dinners without wine range from $44 to $56. Menus change daily, but fall menus make use of fresh and seasonal dishes such as wild partridge and venison.
 
Where to Stay
 Atlanta's best-known luxury hotels downtown and the affluent Buckhead area, about five miles from downtown, are the two Ritz-Carlton Hotels. At the downtown hotel, 181 Peachtree Street N.E. (404) 659-0400, furnished in plush traditional style and known for fine service, doubles range from $150 to $250. The Ritz-Carlton Buckhead, 3434 Peachtree Road N.E., (404) 237-2700, where the rates, double or single, range from $145 to $210, is a short walk from two top shopping malls, Lenox Square and Phipps Plaza.
Also popular downtown is the Hyatt Regency Atlanta, 265 Peachtree Street N.E., (404) 577-1234, with 1,278 rooms and the signature atrium lobby designed by John Portman, where a standard double is $185.
A new, conveniently situated hotel in Buckhead that fits in with Atlanta's mania for all things international is the year-old Swissotel Atlanta, 3391 Peachtree Road N.E., (404) 365-0065, next to Lenox Square, Atlanta's premier shopping mall. The 348-room hotel is a Bauhaus-style building with public areas decorated with contemporary art. Doubles are $145 on weekdays and $99 Friday through Sunday.
In Atlanta's booming Perimeter area 10 miles north of downtown, there is the Doubletree Hotel, 7 Concourse Parkway, (404) 395-3900. The restaurant, Acacia, is well regarded and for a small fee guests at the hotel can use the nearby Concourse Athletic Club. Doubles are $129 to $149 Sunday to Thursday and $65 Friday and Saturday.
Atlanta's best-known bed and breakfast is the Ansley Inn, 253 15th Street N.E., (404) 872-9000, a restored turn-of-the-century mansion in the fashionable Ansley Park neighborhood. Rates range from $90 to $225 for the 12 guestrooms. Bed and Breakfast Atlanta, has a listing of bed and breakfasts from $36 to $100. Call (404) 875-0525, (800) 967-3224, or write to 1801 Piedmont Avenue, Suite 208, Atlanta, Ga. 30324.
Budget choices: At Days Inn Downtown Atlanta, 300 Spring Street, (404) 523-1144, a double is $89. At the Holiday Inn Buckhead, 3340 Peachtree Road N.E., (404) 231-1234, an easy walk to good restaurants and movie theaters, doubles range from $82 to $88.

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Tales From the Dark Side, Spun by a Reluctant Outlaw

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
Machismo is Ice Cube's meal ticket. He has been talking tough since he first appeared with N.W.A., the Compton, Calif., group that put gangster rap on the charts with its foul-mouthed tales of gunslinging, sex, dope-dealing and hatred for the police. After he left N.W.A. in late 1989, the group turned into a pandering self-parody while Ice Cube took on a veneer of political consciousness for his first solo album, the million-selling "AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted." Produced by Chuck D. of Public Enemy, the album presented Ice Cube's tales of ghetto violence as front-line reports on the status of the young black male as an "endangered species."
With his role in the recent film "Boyz N the Hood" as a brooding, reluctant gang member, and an elegy for victims of violence called "Dead Homiez" released as a single between albums, Ice Cube (whose real name is O'Shea Jackson) seemed to be recanting the outlaw persona he had created for himself. The packaging of his new album, "Death Certificate" (Priority 57155; all three formats), urges young blacks to join the Nation of Islam and shows Ice Cube reading a newspaper with the headline "Unite or Perish." 
But on "Death Certificate" it's hard to tell which is more obtuse, Ice Cube's gangster raps or his political statements. Throughout the album, the music stays basic, vamping so slowly that every word, each one shouted, is audible; Ice Cube isn't showing off his virtuosity, but rather his gift for storytelling and rhetoric.
When Ice Cube performed in July at the Apollo Theater, he acted out his dilemma: "I want to kick some knowledge," he said, but his on-stage posse demanded more gangster raps. Ice Cube seems to think that if he's not "hard" -- bloodthirsty, angry, foul-mouthed and woman-hating -- he will lose credibility (and album sales) with rap's core audience. He may be right. So the first half of the album tries to turn hypocrisy into irony; Ice Cube spins new tales of gang warfare and wild sex but frames them as "the death side, a mirrored image of where we are today."
The side opens with a funeral and ends with "Alive on Arrival," in which a young black man is shot, taken to the emergency room and questioned by police about gang activity before he is treated. He dies. The rest of the "death side" includes one more raunchy sex boast ("Givin' Up the Nappy Dug Out," with the album's catchiest chorus), a paean to guns ("Man's Best Friend"), a visit to a venereal-disease clinic ("Look Who's Burnin' ") and "My Summer Vacation," in which a gang of drug dealers, driven out of Los Angeles, sets up in St. Louis and brings with it customs like drive-by shootings. In good N.W.A. style, there are also confrontations with racist police. While his gangster raps usually end with bad news, Ice Cube clearly relishes the details of the violence.
The "life side," which opens with the sounds of a mother giving birth -- to a boy, of course -- is where the limits of Ice Cube's knowledge become clear. The album reflects some of the same concerns Public Enemy takes up on "Apocalypse 91: The Enemy Strikes Black," but at the level of a street brawl instead of a discussion. Ice Cube sounds happiest when he has someone to bad-mouth; to promote black solidarity and achievement, he has decided to fight racism with racism.
In "Black Korea," his revenge against Asian shopkeepers who are suspicious of their ghetto customers is to suggest a nationwide boycott and, as a bonus, arson. "I Wanna Kill Sam" personalizes Uncle Sam as a white supremacist, from Army recruiter to slave owner; a corpse with a toe tag reading "Uncle Sam" is on the front cover. "Horny Lil' Devil," a rant against miscegenation, goes out of its way to derogate white women and threatens to kill white men who desire black women, although Ice Cube can't quite bring himself to praise black women as anything but black men's property.
In "True to the Game," Ice Cube denounces upwardly mobile blacks who turn their backs on the ghetto as they succeed, saying they're "tryin' to be white or a Jew -- but who are they to be equal to?" The worst insult Ice Cube can think of -- applied to whites in "I Wanna Kill Sam" and "Horny Lil' Devil" and to N.W.A. in "No Vaseline" -- is to call someone a homosexual.
There's real rage and frustration behind Ice Cube's insults, and he hints at a broader perspective in parts of "I Wanna Kill Sam" and in "Us," which itemizes self-destructive behavior by blacks. Ice Cube has a few misgivings about his role. After an autobiographical rap that talks about his early misdemeanors and sexual exploits, he talks with a young boy, urging him to finish school and get a job. The youngster insists that he would rather live the street life, which becomes the transition to "Us," where the street toughs have grown up to dead-end lives.
But although some other rappers talk about changing larger political and economic structures, Ice Cube has held on to a gang mentality: it's his gang, right-thinking black males, against every other gang -- whites, Koreans, women, N.W.A. -- and all that matters is revenge.
Ice Cube speaks for parts of a suffering community, but suffering doesn't necessarily build nobility. Sometimes it just leaves scars, and those scars are revealed on "Death Certificate."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: South Bronx Houses;
Higher Density Goal Spurs New Designs

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
EVERYBODY talks about density, but builders in the South Bronx are beginning to do something about it. The results on the ground will emerge next year.
One place to examine them will be in the Melrose section, where the Procida Construction Corporation plans to break ground in March for a development called Melrose Court. The site is near the Hub, the central business district at East 149th Street and Third Avenue. 
 Melrose Court will consist of 263 condominiums in attached, four-story town houses, with three units to each house. Preliminary marketing began last month and the first houses are scheduled to be ready for occupancy by the summer of 1993. Procida's community-based nonprofit partner, the Bronx Shepherds Restoration Corporation, is assisting in sales and community relations.
Density was one of the issues two years ago when the 4.5-acre Melrose Court land was still an urban-renewal parcel known as Site 404. It was the object of competing affections from housing production organizations. A coalition of clergymen organized as South Bronx Churches, Inc., led demonstrations against Mayor Edward I. Koch because he wanted the land to be developed through the New York Housing Partnership. The coalition claimed it had been promised the site.
The housing developer for South Bronx Churches is I.D. Robbins, who in East Brooklyn popularized a one-family house for moderate-income buyers developed under the Nehemiah Plan name, with the sponsorship and financial backing of East Brooklyn Churches, Inc. Those houses are mostly built to a density of 20 to the acre.
In the Bronx, Mr. Robbins had hoped to build a similar house or perhaps two-family houses. But even he, bowing to the views of city and borough officials now that David N. Dinkins has been elected Mayor, has agreed to reach a density of 60 to the acre on the handful of larger sites that South Bronx Churches has been awarded. That means three units for each house.
Procida's design for Melrose Court makes major use of interior courtyards for front entrances. The ground-level apartment is entered from the street, but the upstairs apartments are entered from stoops that face large landscaped interior courtyards. The second-floor apartment is a simplex and the upper-level apartment is a two-floor, or duplex, unit. All the apartments have separate entrances from outside stoops.
The development, for which Marvin H. Meltzer of Manhattan was the architect, will fill three full blocks. The two interior streets will have secured entrances from the main north-south streets bordering the land, Brook Avenue and St. Ann's Avenue.
Courtyard-oriented housing has its precedents in New York City. In recent years it has been done by the General Atlantic Realty Corporation at its Spring Creek development in Brooklyn. But it is an unusual form for the burgeoning new-homes production pipeline in the Bronx. The sales experience will be watched closely for evidence of buyers' preferences.
IT is also a test of future low-rise housing forms in an area that has become a veritable laboratory for them because so much land is available and so many new-home projects have been launched. Already there is a question of how much new for-sale housing can be absorbed without rising levels of subsidy to assure affordability.
The South Bronx Churches concept for larger sites calls for two duplexes and a ground-floor simplex in a three-story building, with the units sold as condominiums. The plan is to build 270 units on five sites. "I don't think this is good, but once we start I think it will take the country by storm," he said. He is also building 270 one-family houses on 19 scattered South Bronx sites.
The Melrose Court development plan, like those in the large-lot South Bronx Churches plan, are condominiums, although it has been shown that it is easier to sell two-family houses than condominiums. The buyers' preference was confirmed last year in a survey undertaken jointly by the Housing Partnership, the nonprofit organization that acts as developer and often as marketing agent in many affordable-housing developments on city-owned land, and the Bronx office of the Department of City Planning.
On the other hand, Melrose Court should produce attractive urban design. The street scape is preserved because curbs are uncut for parking pads. Street entrances for the lower-level units assure a certain liveliness on the street, and the courtyard entrances make for a lively and useful courtyard. The two new wide streets cutting through the development will provide for parking perpendicular to the curb on both sides. And there are secured gates as entrances to these interior streets, giving Melrose Court a level of privacy most new Bronx housing lacks.
The housing will be built with masonry bearing walls and precast concrete plank, with front and rear framing that gives the look of individual town houses.
"THE development is effectively planned as a multistory building that gets subdivided," said Mario Procida, the 34-year-old architect. He is a principal with his brother, William, 29, in the family-owned company, which is based in the Bronx. Procida Construction, which has been in business since 1928, has produced close to 1,000 units of for-sale and rental housing in the Bronx over the last three years.
The form used at Melrose Court could in theory also be used for three-family houses, in which the owner gets one apartment and rents out two others, rather than for condominiums. But banks are described as wary of financing the untested three-families for fear that owners might have trouble finding enough renters at suitable prices. For builders, condominiums have been easier to finance.
The Housing Partnership considers it nothing less than a breakthrough that it has obtained financing from the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, for 15 three-family houses (45 housing units) at Sherman Avenue and McClellan Street in the Bronx. They are selling for $205,000. With Fannie Mae financing available, the number of new three-families may increase, assuming successful projects.
THE units at Melrose Court have been more heavily subsidized than typical for-sale assisted housing in New York City -- a maximum of $41,920 a unit instead of $25,000. That effectively lowers the price to make units more easily salable in their Melrose location.
Of the total subsidy, the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation is putting in $15,000 a unit, or $3,945,000; New York City is paying $10,000, or $2,630,000, and Bronx County -- the Borough President's office -- $16,920 a unit, or $4,450,000. In addition, the city has provided the land, valued at $4,538 a unit, or $1.19 million, which becomes a no-interest second mortgage on the house, repayable from a portion of any profit after resale.
The maximum subsidy would make units affordable to households earning as little as $24,000. Most buyers are likely to earn under $35,000, the Procida Organization says. People earning more -- up to the maximum of $53,000 for eligibility -- get less subsidy. With no subsidy the prices would be $97,685 for a two-bedroom and $118,714 for a three-bedroom.
Most of the people who have come to Procida's offices at 456 East 173d Street to look at scale models and floor plans have had annual incomes between $25,000 and $30,000 and will qualify for the full subsidy if they buy, said Christine Procida, Mario's sister, the marketing director for the project. Ms. Procida said that 200 people have visited the office. Contract signing has not yet started.
MELROSE COURT is viewed by Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer and city planning officials as the first phase of a longterm redevelopment designated Melrose Commons, which covers a broad swath of underutilized land between Park Avenue and Third Avenue from East 156th Street to East 163d Street. Melrose Court's four acres lie at the southeast edge of Melrose Commons.
The grand planning scheme was laid out by the Bronx office of the Department of City Planning last January. It looks forward to 3,000 owner-occupied housing units in Melrose Commons, along with the establishment of new retail and residential activities on East 161st Street and Third Avenue and a new 3.8-acre park.

HEADLINE: At Tiny Airport, Even the Ground Is Friendly

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
TO catch a recent 9:05 A.M. flight to Boston, Maureen Fleming left her Westport home at 8:15 and arrived 15 minutes later at Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford. Encountering no traffic on Interstate 95 or at the airport, she parked in the ample lot in front of the small terminal and within moments could see her 19-seat Beechcraft plane waiting on the runway only a few hundred feet from where she had left her car.
"It's a perfect situation for me," said Ms. Fleming, a communications consultant, who was bound for Fort Worth via Boston. "It's great, because you avoid the hassle of going through all that southbound traffic on I-95 in the morning and paying all that money to park at the New York airports. I'm surprised more people don't know about this place." 
 Sikorsky Memorial Airport, which is owned by the City of Bridgeport, is in the Lordship section of neighboring Stratford. Bridgeport city officials and the commission that runs the airport have sought to take a low-key approach to the complex, which Bridgeport has owned since 1937. The airport's new manager, Albert McDill, said he would welcome more business.
"The market in the area is being underserved, and the airport itself is underutilized," Mr. McDill said in a recent interview in his second-floor office overlooking the airport's two runways and spacious field. "There are a lot of opportunities here."
In large measure because the airport seemed to have been at a standstill for some years, the new manager was hired by the Airport Commission, which includes the Mayor of Bridgeport, three other city officials and the Stratford Town Manager. Before replacing the longtime manager, Morgan Kaolian, in September, Mr. McDill had been manager of the Sarasota-Bradenton Airport in Florida for eight years.
"The question is, What shall we do with this facility?" Mr. McDill said. The steps being taken to answer the question, he said, include the development of a master plan and an economic-impact study that is being done at the University of Connecticut.
The airport -- which was named for Igor I. Sikorsky, an aviation pioneer from Connecticut -- may extend one or both of the 4,800-foot runways to about 5,000 feet. Because the runways are relatively short, airlines are permitted to use only twin-engine turboprop planes that carry between 19 and 46 passengers, but no jetliners. Tweed-New Haven Airport, although a relatively small field that does not offer service to Boston, was able to initiate jet service to Chicago in May, because one of its two runways is 5,600 feet long.
In recent years Mr. Kaolian, who still flies in and out of Sikorsky Airport in the early morning and late afternoon to do traffic reports for radio station WICC in Bridgeport, had advocated expansion of one of the two runways, as long as the Town of Stratford agreed. He had also said the airport needed service from additional carriers, expanded ground equipment and up-to-date navigation instruments. Mr. Kaolian had forecast that the airport would evolve into a major transportation center for the region and would serve hundreds of thousands of travelers annually.
 
140,000 Passengers a Year
 The Mayor of Bridgeport, Mary C. Moran, said she would like to see the airport expanded. She also said that a name change might be in order, because of the confusion between the Airport and the Sikorsky Aircraft helicopter landing area near the Merritt Parkway.
"I know of people who've actually gone to the Sikorsky plant thinking it was Bridgeport airport," Mrs. Moran said in an interview. "I think it may be time to consider changing the name."
The airport now accommodates 140,000 passengers a year, Mr. McDill said. The three commercial carriers that operate at the airport -- Business Express, Continental Express and USAir Express -- account for about 35 percent of the overall business. The rest is "general aviation" -- a catchall phrase encompassing all civilian flying except scheduled airlines.
"We have a lot of corporate activity, including quite a few Fortune 500 companies," Mr. McDill said.
What Sikorsky Memorial Airport does not have are throngs of passengers, traffic congestion or long corridors to airport gates. Sikorsky does not really have a gate, just a door that leads to the runway. The door is usually opened by the same airline employee who takes tickets. Arriving passengers receive their luggage within minutes after they leave the plane, since the distance from the aircraft to the cargo area in the terminal is only about 100 feet.
Dr. Fred Sachs, who is affiliated with Yale-New Haven Hospital, said his first visit to Sikorsky Memorial Airport recently was a revelation. Normally he uses Tweed-New Haven Airport to fly to Washington, he said. But flights to Washington from Tweed go to Dulles International Airport, and on this day Dr. Sachs wanted to fly into National Airport, which was closer to the conference he was attending.
 
Empty Terminal
 "This is a really nice airport, and I definitely would use it again," said Dr. Sachs, who lives in Woodbridge, a New Haven suburb.
Even during the morning rush hour, the Sikorsky terminal, clean and spacious, is virtually deserted until a half-hour before a flight. On a recent Wednesday morning, after four planes had left between 6:30 and 7 A.M., the terminal was empty of passengers for the next two hours, until people began arriving for a 9:05 Business Express flight to Washington. Only nine passengers boarded that flight, including Greig Metzger, an exployee of Citibank, who said he had driven to the airport from his home in Fairfield in 10 minutes.
If there is a major drawback to flying out of Sikorsky airport, it is the limited number of flights and destinations. On weekdays 26 flights leave the airport and 28 arrive. Apart from one flight each day to New London and another to Albany, the flights go to Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Newark and Boston, with one of the Boston flights continuing on to Burlington, Vt., and another to Manchester, N.H.
Virtually all of the flights, though, connect with others to cities throughout the nation. Most fares are comparable to those at other airports in the New York region.
The airport is only a few minutes' drive from Interstate 95 and convenient to the Merritt Parkway. Yet few people seem to know the airport even exists. Finding Sikorsky is not easy; there is only one sign for the airport on Route 95, about a mile before the Lordship Boulevard exit, and no signs at all on the Merritt or on any other nearby highways.
"If you miss the one sign on I-95, you're in trouble," said Mr. McDill, the airport manager. "I've missed it a few times myself and have had to get off at the next exit."
Mr. McDill concedes that Sikorsky Memorial Airport may have to be promoted more in the future. He also agreed that a new name of a regional nature, like Fairfield County Airport, might draw more attention. "We have to let people know that it's here," he said.

HEADLINE: Republicans Now Facing Daunting Challenge

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
SOON after he took office last year, Gov. Jim Florio emerged from Drumthwacket, the Governor's mansion in Princeton, to tell reporters he had just had a meeting with legislative leaders. When one reporter asked him which Republicans were at the meeting, Mr. Florio looked surprised.
"Oh, there were no Republicans," he said. 
 If Mr. Florio wants to meet with legislative leaders starting in January, there will be nothing but Republicans around the table. Democrats were suddenly thrust into the role of virtual spectators for the next two years by voters who rejected the Democratic response to the state's economic problems and gave Republicans a landslide victory in legislative races on Tuesday.
Republicans, who are accustomed to being in the minority, were given such large majorities in both the Senate and the Assembly that they can pass any bill they want without Democratic votes and can override any veto Mr. Florio may affix to one of their bills. The present Democratic majorities of 23 to 17 in the Senate and 43 to 37 in the Assembly will be replaced by Republican majorities of 27 to 13 in the Senate and 58 to 22 in the Assembly. In short, the Republican Party is in charge. For many lawmakers who have spent their entire careers in the minority, the change may be daunting. After years of opposing solutions offered by the majority, they must now propose solutions of their own.
Assemblyman Wayne R. Bryant, a Camden County Democrat who will continue to serve as majority leader until the 205th Legislature is sworn in early next year, pledged his cooperation with the coming Republican majority, but added, "Now they'll have to govern, and it can't be done with smoke and mirrors."
 
'A Lot to Say' About Property Tax
 Other Democratic leaders, including Joseph V. Doria, the Assembly Speaker, whose thumbnail synopsis of the election was that "perception has won out over reality," and John A. Lynch, the Senate President, have promised to work with the Republican majority. But Mr. Lynch said he would "have a lot to say" if the Republicans rolled back Democratic initiatives designed to hold down property taxes.
Mr. Lynch had better loosen his vocal cords. Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New Providence, the state Republican chairman, said that "substantial changes" in the Florio administration's programs would have to be made to satisfy the mandate the voters gave the Republicans on Tuesday.
And he pointed out that the public's anger over Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax program had quickly turned into a personal dislike for the Governor that led directly to the Democrats' loss of leadership in the Legislature. "People didn't like the message, and they really didn't like the messenger," Mr. Franks said.
The kind of wholesale legislative changes seen last week usually occur only in years when a candidate for governor scores a landslide victory and pulls in legislative candidates on his coattails. A midterm election normally breaks down into individual contests in the 40 legislative districts because of the absence of a statewide election at the top of the ballot to support a unifying theme.
Although he wasn't on the ballot, and won't be until 1993 if he decides to seek re-election, Mr. Florio was the unifying presence around which the Republicans were able to devise a simple strategy: tie the Democrats to the $2.8 billion in new taxes and to Mr. Florio, whose positive performance rating has not climbed above 25 percent in public opinion surveys over the last year.
Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and a Republican Party consultant, said, "The campaign was probably monotonous and not very exciting, but it was effective."
Republicans will have a few weeks to savor their victory and prepare to deal with the harsh realities they will face next year, some of them of their own making. Republicans have promised to roll back the state sales tax to 6 percent from the 7 percent it was set at in the Florio program. They also have said they will not raise taxes.
 
Continuation of Problem Seen
 The economy is still in a recession, and there have been predictions of a continuing budget problem next year even with all present taxes in place. A drop of a penny in the sales tax will cost the treasury about $500 million.
In addition, some revenue-raising moves by the Florio administration to close holes in the current budget, like selling a portion of the state highway system to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority for $400 million, were one-time measures. Whoever is in charge next year is already faced with finding some replacement for that money.
Norman J. Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers, said the problems facing the new Republican leadership were enormous.
"The recession is not going to end in the next few months and pull New Jersey out of its problems," he said. "If the Republicans roll back the sales tax, they must find other sources of revenue or make draconian cuts in the budget, and that will be extremely hard to do.
"Some people have said the one-cent drop in the sales tax could jump-start the economy, but that's a fantasy. The way things are shaping up, the Republicans are going to have to find more than $1 billion to balance next year's budget."
 
Planning to Make Changes
 In addition to the financial problems that will dominate the coming legislative session, as they have the last two years, the Republicans have said they want to make changes in other major initiatives of Mr. Florio's first two years in office -- automobile insurance revision, school financing and the ban on the sale of assault weapons.
The National Rifle Association and the New Jersey Education Association were vocal critics of the Governor's bills and contributed heavily to Republican candidates in the legislative campaign. The rifle association succeeded in getting amendments to the gun law through the Legislature a few months ago, but Mr. Florio vetoed the amending legislation. He won't be able to do that in the future.
For the Governor, who was a lawmaker for all his 22 years in public life in the New Jersey Legislature and in Congress before winning the governorship in 1989, the role of executive was a new one. Mr. Florio was not a consensus builder during his first two years in office. He dealt with a small cadre of advisers and kept his initiatives under wraps until he was ready to push them aggresively through the Legislature.
Assemblyman Chuck Haytaian, the Republican minority leader, who will move up to Assembly Speaker in January, said he had only two meetings with the Governor during the first 20 months of the administration.
 
'Sent Message to Orther States'
 Mr. Haytaian said the New Jersey election had national significance. "It sent the message to other states that people want less government and less taxes," he said.
The speed with which Mr. Florio passed his tax increase package through the Democratic Legislature after telling voters during his campaign that he saw no need for new taxes stunned many taxpayers and inspired the anti-Florio sentiment that translated into Republican votes on Tuesday.
The Governor and his aides were not good at selling their programs. It took a week for the Governor's office to produce charts that showed that only 17 percent of the state's taxpayers would pay higher income taxes under the new plan. By then, the middle-income wage earners whom the program was designed to help were furious and had stopped listening.
 
A Pledge opf Cooperation
 Just exactly how Mr. Florio will deal with his reduced power in the legislative process remains to be seen. He has said he intends to work cooperatively with the new leadership, but many Republicans, recalling the snubs of the last two years, are skeptical.
At his meeting with reporters at Drumthwacket on Wednesday, Mr. Florio said that he would have a legislative program to present to the Legislature in January and said that if the Republicans found a responsible way to reduce the sales tax, he would go along with it.
At one point Mr. Florio said that some of his policies had undoubtedly persuaded some voters to go out and vote Republican. He also said he had been told that his "bedside manner leaves something to be desired." He added, "I can accept that."
 
Choice of 'Divided Power'
 Emphasizing that the election is over, Mr. Florio said, "The people have chosen divided power, but they don't want paralyzed government."
The Governor could just sit back and watch the Republicans wrestle with the same set of problems he has faced and be prepared to make political capital out of any gaffes to help his re-election chances in 1993. But it is unlikely that he will remain silent, given his reputation for confronting problems head-on rather than seeking compromise solutions based on a broad consensus.
The Republicans strongly criticized Mr. Florio's stewardship in the Republican Party's platform, adopted earlier this year. In it the Republicans said, "After 20 months of Governor Florio and the Democrats, one thing is clear: this is the worst managed state government in the history of New Jersey."
Even though they do not hold the Governor's office, with the enormous power they were handed by the voters last week, the Republicans will now have to show that they can do a better job.

HEADLINE: Auto Insurance: Do the Fixes Need Fixing?

BYLINE: By Jay Romano

 BODY:
EVEN as many motorists watch their insurance premiums drop in the wake of Gov. Jim Florio's sweeping transformation of the state's automobile insurance laws, some insurance industry experts and legislators say the Governor's plan is already following in the footsteps of previous unsuccessful attempts to rescue the state's ailing automobile insurance system.
In the last year, for example, three independent studies have predicted that the Market Transition Facility, the successor to the debt-ridden Joint Underwriting Association, is inexorably sliding into its own multimillion-dollar deficit. 
 While Department of Insurance officials insist that they do not anticipate a shortfall, industry experts say that the studies are accurate and that consumers could end up footing the bill if companies are granted rate increases to offset losses resulting from paying off the deficit.
At the same time, some experts are calling the Governor's plan nothing more than a "Band-Aid" that will inevitably fail to mend the system. Others say that only radical, politically unpopular remedies can produce an insurance system that is fair to consumers and profitable for insurance companies.
Still others say that despite the fact that premiums are decreasing, regulations imposed by the State Insurance Commissioner unfairly penalize many drivers by allowing insurance companies to charge exorbitant surcharges against those who commit minor traffic offenses.
The renewed debate comes on the heels of last Tuesday's apparent repudiation of Governor Florio's controversial political strategies, and as the Allstate Insurance Company, which insures nearly half a million vehicles, proceeds with its plans to stop writing policies and pull its business out of the state for good.
"We have felt all along that legislatively killing the J.U.A. certainly didn't make the problems or the conditions that created them go away," said Ronald Krauss, vice president of communications for the American Insurance Association, a New York-based trade organization of insurance companies.
Mr. Krauss said that despite repeated attempts at insurance revamping by legislators and governors of both political parties, the insurance system in place in New Jersey today was only marginally better than it was 20 years ago.
"The well-meaning efforts of the politicians to hold down auto insurance rates just wind up not succeeding," Mr. Krauss said. "You can't legislate away economic reality."
The economic reality that the insurance industry is now facing, he said, is the deficit in the Market Transition Facility.
Under Governor Florio's Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act, the debt-ridden Joint Underwriting Association was dissolved and the estimated total of two million drivers who were insured by it were transferred to the Market Transition Facility.
 
Rates Set at Same Level
 Rates for drivers insured by the Market Transition Facility were set at about the same level as those that had been charged by the Joint Underwriting Association, notwithstanding the fact that the association had accrued a $3.4 billion deficit.
Unlike the association, however, the Market Transition Facility will essentially "self-destruct" as drivers are shifted into the voluntary market. Only 10 percent of the worst drivers will remain in the pool by the end of September 1993, and they will then be placed in an "assigned risk pool," an insurance pool of otherwise uninsurable drivers that would be similar to the "assigned risk plan" that preceded the Joint Underwriting Association.
When the law was passed, officials said the Market Transition Facility would be self-supporting. That expectation, however, appears to have been overly optimistic.
In November 1990, two independent studies of the Market Transition Facility were commissioned -- one by the Insurance Department and the other by the Market Transition Facility itself. Both studies showed the Transition Facility to be running at a significant loss.
Robert Aldorisio, consulting actuary for Milliman & Robertson of New York, the company hired by the Insurance Department, said his company had calculated that in order for the Market Transition Facility to break even, rates would have to be raised by 62.1 percent. With no increase, Mr. Aldorisio said recently, the Market Transition Facility could have been expected to run up a deficit of as much as $1 billion.
 
$1 Billion Deficit Predicted
 The Insurance Department disagreed with the company's projections and raised rates 18.6 percent.
The department also took exception to the study that had been requested by the actuarial committee of the Market Transition Facility itself. That study, prepared by William M. Mercer Inc., New York-based actuarial consultants, predicted a $1 billion deficit.
Frank J. Karlinski, a principal of the company, said that since that projection did not take into account the 18 percent rate increase that was granted after the study was done, the projected $1 billion deficit would be about 18 percent lower.
"Anyone looking at it logically has to come up with the same conclusions," Mr. Karlinski said.
In fact, one year after the Mercer and Milliman studies, Chubb & Son, a Warren-based insurance company, commissioned a study by a Connecticut actuarial company, Tillinghast, in support of a rate increase request. The Tillinghast study projected an $865 million deficit for the Market Transition Facility by 1993.
 
'Didn't Come as Any Surprise'
 "That didn't come as any surprise," said John J. Degnan, senior vice president of Chubb & Son. "We know from history that the J.U.A. ran up a $3 billion deficit. In my view, the Market Transition Facility is just a continuation of the J.U.A."
Despite such projections, however, Insurance Department officials maintain that there will not be a deficit by the time the Market Transition Facility is phased out by Sept. 30, 1993.
"All I can say is that we think that this is a highly speculative study," said James Berzok, a spokesman for the Insurance Department, referring to the Tillinghast study. "We don't think it reflects what will really happen with the M.T.F. We're trying to operate the M.T.F. so that there will not be a deficit. We're trying our best."
Mr. Berzok said none of the studies could accurately predict the effect of several major changes included in the Governor's insurance law. "The problem with those studies," Mr. Berzok said, "is that they were using old J.U.A. data." He also said the Market Transition Facility was required by law to stop writing policies by Sept. 30, 1992.
In addition, he said, beginning April 1, 1992, drivers with eight points or less can transfer out of the Market Transition Facility and into the voluntary market. He said that on Jan. 1, 1993, age, sex and marital status would no longer be taken into consideration in setting rates.
 
Increases Might Be Necessary
 Mr. Berzok acknowledged, however, that if the studies were accurate, rate increases might be necessary.
"If the Commissioner feels that rate increases are needed to keep the M.T.F. self-sustaining, he'll grant them," Mr. Berzok said.
But Eric Salfeety, president of the Professional Insurance Agents of New Jersey, a trade organization based in Trenton, said that it was not only the potential Market Transition Facility deficit that had cast new doubts on the Governor's insurance program. Several factors are converging, he said, that will make Mr. Florio's insurance law as unsuccessful as any the state has had in the past.
"First of all, there is an inherent problem in the way he has proceeded," Mr. Salfeety said. "The style of the way the Governor's office is jamming this down the throat of the industry is causing as much of a problem as the law itself."
Another problem, Mr. Salfeety said, is that a large portion of the money being paid out in claims never gets to consumers.
 
Changes Called Halfway Measures
 "There are a whole lot of people who are making money in the accident industry," he said. "What you have to do is look at where the claims dollars go. You find that they are not ending up in the pockets of the claimant."
Mr. Salfeety said the overriding problem with New Jersey's insurance system was that political pressures to keep rates artificially low resulted in halfway measures at real changes.
"We've used Band-Aid solutions as the problems arose," he said.
John Walsh, director of consumer issues for the Hanover Insurance Company in Piscataway, said one such Band-Aid solution was the Legislature's decision to add no-fault insurance to the already existing fault system.
Under no-fault, Mr. Walsh said, an accident victim's medical bills are paid by his own insurer regardless of who is at fault in the accident. A pure no-fault system does not allow for compensation for pain and suffering, thereby keeping claim payments and premiums relatively low.
 
Need to Choose One System
 In New Jersey, however, by adding a no-fault system to the existing system, "the two work off of each other and afford an extremely high level of coverage," Mr. Walsh said. But at the same time, he said, "you're paying for two systems instead of one."
He said the only way to lower premiums would be to make the difficult political decision to choose one system.
State Senator Lee B. Laskin, Republican of Cherry Hill, who was defeated in last Tuesday's election, agrees that radical changes are necessary to create a stable, fair insurance system in the state.
"A politician will stay as close to the middle as he can trying to make the least controversial decision," Mr. Laskin said. "But to fix this system, you can't play with it. You have to take extreme, courageous measures."
Mr. Laskin, who for years has been calling for an "open market system" in which insurance companies are minimally regulated and thereby forced to compete with one another, called Mr. Florio's attempt at change "an act of political hypocrisy."
"The principal reform was to eliminate the J.U.A. and the $222 surcharge," Mr. Laskin said. In its place, he said, the Governor created the Market Transition Facility and its now-burgeoning deficit.
 
'One Monstrosity for Another'
 "He's substituted one monstrosity for another," he said, "while the underlying system remains basically the same."
Another aspect of the Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act that has rankled some experts is a provision that allows insurers to impose surcharges on drivers who are involved in chargeable accidents or convicted of motor vehicle violations.
Assemblyman Michael F. Adubato, Democrat of Newark, said that under existing regulations, drivers insured by the Market Transition Facility could be forced to pay significantly higher surcharges for traffic violations than those insured by the voluntary market. Mr. Adubato, one of the Legislature's experts on automobile insurance, did not seek re-election last Tuesday.
"If people commit the same offense, they should pay the same penalty," he said. "They shouldn't have to pay over 1,000 percent more just because they have the misfortune of not being insured by the voluntary market."
By way of example, Mr. Adubato said that if a Newark resident driving a 1990 Oldsmobile were convicted of going 42 miles per hour in a 25 m.p.h. zone, he would be hit with a surcharge of $2,263 a year for the next three years. The amount of the surcharge, Mr. Adubato said, is calculated at 87.3 percent of the person's $2,592 insurance premium.
 
Voluntary Market Surcharge
 If that same person with the same car and the same coverage and in the same place were instead insured in the voluntary market, Mr. Adubato said, his surcharge for the same speeding violation would be $232 a year for three years.
"The difference is that the surcharge on the M.T.F. driver is based on a percentage of his premium whereas in the voluntary market, the surcharge is a flat rate, no matter what your premiums are," Mr. Adubato said.
That disparity is exacerbated by the fact that rates are higher for those insured by the Market Transition Facility. And similar inequities exist with respect to surcharges for chargeable automobile accidents, Mr. Adubato said.
"The Commissioner of Insurance has gone way beyond the intent of the Legislature in implementing these outrageous regulations," Mr. Adubato said. "There is no rational way to defend this system."
Mr. Berzok said that while the surcharges were calculated on a percentage of the premium, the example given by Mr. Adubato represented the "worst-case scenario."

HEADLINE: Rutgers Celebrates 225th Anniversary

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
EXACTLY 225 years ago today, the last colonial governor of New Jersey, William Franklin, granted a royal charter establishing Queen's College, which was later to become Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. From its roots as a training ground for a few young men interested in the Dutch Reformed ministry, it has blossomed into the star of New Jersey's public higher education system.
It graduates more than 9,000 students annually in nearly 100 different fields and is fast closing in on its quest to be recognized as a leading public research university. 
 To mark the anniversary, the university has planned a weeklong series of events on its campuses, starting today at 4 P.M. with a concert here at the State Theater with Marilyn Horne and the Rutgers University Orchestra. Tomorrow, visitors can ring the Rutgers bell atop Old Queen's, a landmark building, as part of a self-guided walking tour, visit classrooms at Cook College and on the Camden campus view crafts demonstrations that celebrate Rutgers's colonial heritage. Later in the week there will be festivities on the Newark campus and a dinner to honor alumni for their community service.
For years considered just another sleepy state university, Rutgers came fully into stride in the 1980's when it aggressively began to transform itself into a major research university with a leading faculty. The shift in direction has brought charges that university teaching is being neglected, and significant cuts in state aid over the last few years threaten the momentum of change, but Rutgers's reputation continues to improve both within the state and nationally.
"While we are a very old institution, we are in another sense a fairly new institution in terms of the dimensions of Rutgers," said Richard P. McCormick, professor emeritus of history.
Rutgers's enhanced stature can be seen in everything from its buildings, now more than 600, to the quality of its students. A $600 million capital construction program, begun in the 1980's, has added many new buildings and renovated scores of others.
While performance on the Scholastic Aptitude Test has been declining nationally, scores for entering students now average 1095, an increase of more than 100 points over the last 10 years and more than 150 points higher than the current national average. There is also the much publicized statistic that one in five New Jersey high school valedictorians chooses to attend Rutgers.
Quality is not the only thing that has risen for students. Tuition has jumped 300 percent over the last decade to $3,114 for full-time undergraduates, causing fear that Rutgers is becoming increasingly unaffordable for many students.
The university has a roster of noted alumni, including Paul Robeson, the singer and political activist; George Segal, the sculptor; Ozzie Nelson, the bandleader and television star; Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate in economics, and Dr. Selman A. Waksman, a Nobel laureate for his discovery of streptomycin to treat tuberculosis. Jim Florio, a 1967 graduate of the university's law school in Camden, is the seventh Rutgers alumnus to serve as Governor of New Jersey.
Then there are the nearly famous graduates and the nearly graduated famous. Garret A. Hobart, an 1863 alumnus, died in office as William McKinley's Vice President and was replaced by Theodore Roosevelt. To the regret of development officers, Albert B. Wells, the wealthy president of the American Optical Company and creator of Sturbridge Village in Massachusetts, did not remember Rutgers after he was expelled from the college in the 1890's for stealing the bell clapper. Quincy Magoo, the absentminded cartoon character, was a 1949 graduate, although no one is sure exactly why.
Information on the schedule of events is available from the department of university communications at (908) 932-7315 Monday to Friday from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.
 
<HD>UNIVERSITY'S MILESTONES
 
HERE are some important events in the history of Rutgers University, as adapted from Rutgers Magazine:
1766: William Franklin signs the charter establishing Queen's College, named after Charlotte of Mecklenburg, consort of King George III.
1771: The first classes are held at the Sign of the Red Lion, a tavern on the corner of Albany and Neilson Streets and the current site of Johnson & Johnson's international headquarters.
1793: Facing a severe fiscal crisis, the board, by one vote, rejects a proposal to merge with the College of New Jersey, which is to become Princeton University in 1896. The college will be closed for much of the next 32 years because of a lack of resources.
1825: The school is renamed Rutgers College after Col. Henry Rutgers, a former trustee and wealthy Revolutionary War hero. A year later, he gives the college $5,000 and a bell that still hangs in the cupola of Old Queen's, but much anticipated future contributions are not to come.
1864: Rutgers is selected over Princeton and what is to become Trenton State College as New Jersey's land grant college. The designation marks the first official tie between Rutgers and the state, and expands Rutgers as a scientific institution, particularly in the fields of engineering and agriculture.
1869: In the first intercollegiate football game in the country, Rutgers beats Princeton, an outcome that will not be repeated for 70 years. Also, scarlet becomes the unofficial school color when no ribbons can be found in orange, the students' first choice. Trustees will make scarlet the official color in 1900.
1892: "I'd die for dear old Rutgers" becomes the slogan of the college after Frank (Pop) Grant, a football player, breaks his leg in a game against Princeton and supposedly utters the famous phrase.
1918: The New Jersey College for Women, now Douglass College, opens. Three years later, the College of Agriculture opens.
1945: The New Jersey Legislature designates Rutgers as the state university and increases its support. This infusion of aid, coupled with a huge influx of World War II veterans in the next few years, sparks a period of growth that accelerates in the 1950's.
1956: A major reorganization by the State Legislature shifts control of Rutgers's affairs from an autonomous board of trustees to a board of governors, the majority of whom are appointed by the Governor and the New Jersey State Senate. The change paves the way for a building boom, financed by more than $100 million in bond issues, at Rutgers in the 1960's.
1961: The Rutgers Medical School, now the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey/Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, is founded.
1972: Rutgers College becomes coeducational.
1981: The board approves a blueprint for becoming a major public research university.
1989: Rutgers is invited to join the prestigious Association of American Universities, an indication of the university's increased national stature.
1990: The university bestows its 250,000th degree.

HEADLINE: Zaleski's First Task: Settling Housing Issue

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
MAYOR-ELECT Terence M. Zaleski, fresh from a victory few had predicted with any confidence nine months ago, pledged a new professional approach to Yonkers' problems last week. He indicated he would begin with the housing controversy that has been the city's single most divisive issue.
The choice is probably a good one, according to housing experts and others familiar with the decade-old landmark court case, because a solution is at hand. The city may not be required by the Federal court or the plaintiffs to build the final 800 housing units ordered as part of the remedy for 40 years of segregation in the city's schools and housing. 
 Worsening economic conditions have scattered the contractors and developers who were originally offered cash, zoning bonuses and other incentives to mix 800 units of low- and moderate-income housing among 4,000 units in market-rate developments.
The judge in the case, Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan, has said that the 800 units of moderate-income housing, designated for the long-term phase of the plan, could be purchased instead of built. The city has expressed a desire to do that if the units do not represent more than 2 to 4 percent of any individual condominium or cooperative.
 
142 Units Are Almost Finished
 The court has recognized that in today's weak housing market it would be cheaper to buy existing apartments than to build them, and that it could be done expeditiously.
The first 142 units in the court decree -- public housing for low-income tenants -- are already in place, some of them ready for occupancy. They are two-story town-house structures on five sites in the city's mostly white neighborhoods.
Those on the so-called Raceway site, a former parking lot on the southbound service road of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway facing Yonkers Raceway, are the most advanced, with brick facades and landscaped front yards. They were described in enthusiastic terms by neighbors interviewed recently by National Public Radio.
Neil J. DeLuca, the City Manager whose job is being eliminated under the new strong-mayor form of government that Yonkers voters approved for inauguration Jan. 1, suggested several years ago that empty condominiums or cooperative apartments be purchased to fulfill the requirements of the long-term plan.
 
A Reluctance to Accept Proposal
 But when he announced the proposal, he was unable to identify any apartment complex willing to take one unit of such housing. City officials realized that it would have to be done in a coordinated fashion, with each condominium or cooperative taking a share.
This is a challenge that those familiar with the situation believe Mr. Zaleski, a Democrat, might take on -- to put the housing-remedy order behind him and be able to proceed with the other issues he has outlined since his election.
Some activity in this aspect of the housing case is already under way. Karen Hill, who has been seeking developers on behalf of the city to fulfill the long-term requirements of the housing plan, is understood to be negotiating to buy cooperative units in an apartment complex that is in financial difficulty in northwest Yonkers.
Mr. Zaleski said last week that his victory over two Republicans, Councilman Peter A. Chema and former Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, who ran as an independent, was part of a reform process that included "pushing the political machine past us."
 
Republican Vote Was Split
 He said he was referring to the successful campaign by reformers in the party to replace Ralph Arred, the Yonkers Democratic Party chairman. "With Arred in place I'm not sure I would have won," said Mr. Zaleski, who won a primary against James J. Mannion, a restaurant owner who had the backing of the city's Democratic leadership.
It is generally assumed that the two Republicans split a vote that otherwise would have been enough to overwhelm Mr. Zaleski, who took 36 percent of the mayoral vote. Mr. Chema had 33 percent and Mr. Martinelli 28 percent. The six-member City Council will be led by a Democrat, Vincenza A. Restiano, holding the new post of Council President. That post includes a vote.
Four incumbent Republicans, John Spencer, Salvator J. Sialiano, Thomas Dickerson and Edward Fagan Jr., won re-election. Symra Brandon, a Democrat, won the seat representing a mainly minority district in southwest Yonkers, given up by Joe L. Farmer, also a Democrat, to seek the Council presidency.
A close struggle for the seat given up by Mr. Chema pitted former Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a Democrat, against Edward Magilton, a Republican. It was likely to be resolved only after a recount of the votes.

HEADLINE: Baedeker

 BODY:
To the Editor: I worked for our State Department in Germany from the beginning of the Allied High Commission (1949-1954) and so lived on the Rhine, Bad Godesberg, for four years, after a year in Frankfurt.
In a Chicago bookstore in 1958 I found "The Rhine From Rotterdam to Constance," published in 1892. 
 In June I was on an Elderhostel program in Germany with a week in Goslar and visited Bad Harzburg again, and thereby got a glimpse of the Brocken. Our group was driven over to Halberstadt and Quedlinburg in the former East Germany. Halberstadt had been devastated by the Communists, after being bombed by the Allies because of an aircraft factory nearby. Quedlinburg was in better shape: That's the town from which the Texas G.I. took medieval artifacts at the end of the war and his heirs wouldn't give them up until the Germans paid them. They were not yet on display.
During our program in Goslar, we had a professor of economics from the University of Leipzig who described the uprising in that city, which then stirred the rest of the country. Since all teachers in the East had to submit their resignations by Sept. 1 this year, he didn't know if he would have a job after that. A nice man.
 
JEAN HOLKE
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Antitrust Actions on the Rise Again

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
A decade after the Justice Department dropped its long-running lawsuit against the International Business Machines Corporation, the computer industry is seeing a resurgence of Government antitrust investigations and private antitrust lawsuits.
The new antitrust actions are aimed not at I.B.M., whose power has waned, but at a group of younger companies and coalitions that have risen in prominence through their control of industry standards. 
 Lawyers say the renewed attention to antitrust matters is partly in reaction to two important recent trends in the computer industry.
One is the aggressive tendency of some technology companies to use their patents and copyrights to stymie competitors.
The other is the growth of joint ventures or consortiums, either to set standards or to allow companies to share research. Coalitions have recently been accepted by the Government partly because of a belief that standards help customers and improve American competitiveness with foreign rivals.
In light of the goal of increasing competitiveness, the greater antitrust activity might have a perverse effect, some observers say. Antitrust actions could have "a chilling effect on those kinds of ventures which U.S. economic policy seemingly wants to encourage," said Lee T. Gesmer, a Boston lawyer who represents several industry coalitions that have formed to promote standards.
But many other lawyers and industry executives said that the antitrust investigations, while making some companies nervous, have not yet affected corporate behavior much.
In recent months, Microsoft, the leading software company; Intel, the dominant chip maker, and the Open Software Foundation, a company backed by several computer makers, have acknowledged that they are under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission. The F.T.C. does not comment on its investigations unless it decides to take action against a company.
The Open Software Foundation, the founders of which include I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and Digital Equipment, develops standard operating system software for computers. Intel dominates the market for microprocessors used in personal computers, and Microsoft is the leader in the market for the operating system software used to control personal computers.
The F.T.C. also recently settled a price-fixing case against Nintendo, the video game giant, but some rivals think the Government is still looking at Nintendo's business practices. Nintendo said it did not believe such an investigation was under way.
The Justice Department, which shares responsibility for antitrust matters, does not seem to be as active as the F.T.C., but computer industry lawyers say it is also stirring. Recently, they said, the department fought a bitter turf battle with the F.T.C. and won the right to conduct the antitrust review of the acquisition of the Ashton-Tate Company by a software rival, Borland International Inc.
Last month the Justice Department and Borland signed a consent decree permitting the merger to proceed but requiring Borland to allow other companies to make products compatible with Ashton-Tate's popular dBase program.
Private lawsuits are also more noticeable. In a recent action filed in United States District Court in San Jose, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a large maker of semiconductors, charged Intel with trying to bar it from the microprocessor business.
A similar suit against Intel has been filed in Texas by the Cyrix Corporation, a maker of math processing chips based in Richardson, Tex. The Addamax Corporation, a small software company in Champaign, Ill., has filed suit against the Open Software Foundation in United States District Court in Boston, and several video game companies are locked in legal battles with Nintendo.
Industry was torn by Government and private antitrust lawsuits throughout the 1960's and 1970's. Virtually all of the cases were directed against giants -- notably I.B.M., which was dominant in computers, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which had a monopoly in telephone service and equipment. But that era ended in January 1982, when the Justice Department dropped its I.B.M. case and reached a settlement with A.T.& T. that broke up the Bell System.
Experts say one reason for the resurgence of antitrust investigations is simply that Federal regulators are becoming more aggressive in general after eight years of little enforcement during the Reagan Administration.
"I don't know of any particular bent toward going after computer issues," said Ron Rowe, director of litigation for the F.T.C. Bureau of Competition. But industry lawyers say that several factors have made the industry more subject to antitrust scrutiny and lawsuits.
One is that technology companies in the last few years have become a lot more aggressive in using patents and copyrights to block competitors. "Intellectual property and antitrust are two sides of the same coin," said Gary Reback, a lawyer in Palo Alto, Calif. "Any time there's an assertion of intellectual property rights, generally speaking there's a counterclaim on monopolization."
Indeed, Advanced Micro Devices and Cyrix have been sued by Intel for copyright and patent infringement, respectively. Similarly, Hewlett-Packard, which is being sued by Apple Computer Inc. for copyright infringement, has claimed that Apple is trying to monopolize the market for computer screen display software.
Another factor is the growing number of mergers, joint ventures and consortiums that mark the consolidation of the industry. Some such collaborations like the Sematech semiconductor consortium are meant to share basic research. The National Cooperative Research Act of 1984 encourages such cooperation on basic research by providing limited protection against antitrust suits. The electronics industry has been pushing for legislation to extend that protection to joint manufacturing ventures.
Many coalitions have been formed recently to set standards because customers want to be assured that they can buy computers from more than one vendor and still have them work together. That has fostered numerous such joint efforts as Unix International, X/Open, Sparc International, the Object Management Group and the Advanced Computing Environment -- formed by companies to convince customers that they are adhering to a standard.
Lawyers say standards enhance competition and are therefore desirable. "It's a matter of public knowledge that I.B.M.-compatible standards are probably pro-competitive," said Mr. Rowe of the F.T.C.
"Look at all the competition it engendered," he added, referring to the dozens of companies making personal computer "clones" and hundreds of software companies making programs for such machines.
But the ability to control the standard is critical. In I.B.M.-compatible PC's, Intel controls the development of microprocessors and Microsoft, the operating system software.
Detractors say microprocessors and operating systems would have advanced faster and been less expensive if there had been more competition. Intel, for instance, recently slashed prices of microprocessors and math processors, a move that some analysts said came only because its monopoly ended with the introduction of competitive products by Advanced Micro Devices, Cyrix and others.
Moreover, competitors have complained that Intel and Microsoft have used their sway to help each compete in other areas. Both Intel and Microsoft say they have bent over backward to be fair and have rapidly advanced the technology.
The case against the Open Software Foundation also raises questions about how to set standards. The foundation, based in Cambridge, Mass., evaluates software submitted by various companies, chooses winners and incorporates their software into the standard Unix operating system. It then licenses the standard Unix to its members and other companies.
Addamax, which makes software to enhance the security of Unix, claimed in its antitrust suit that Open Software is a cartel whose members control 70 percent of the Unix market. It said that Open Software offered to pay Addamax a ridiculously low price to include its software in the standard Unix and that Addamax had no choice but to go along.
"Addamax had a simple choice: to be the selected supplier and get a little money out of the market or not to be selected and get no money out of the market," the company said in its complaint, filed in United States District Court in Boston in April. Eventually, a competitor's software was chosen, forcing Addamax to reduce its staff from 80 to 15 people.
Lawyers contended, however, that Open Software was somewhat exceptional in that it actually sells software. Most other standards groups merely choose standards and allow any company to make a product that adheres to their standards. Still, some coalitions are being careful in light of the lawsuit and F.T.C. investigation of Open Software.
Sematech has also been the subject of complaints that it "plays God," in that its endorsement of certain equipment gives the manufacturers of that equipment a big marketing edge. But the consortium says it has not been been sued over the issue.
Nintendo, meanwhile, has attracted lawsuits because its game machines prevent unauthorized cartridges from being played. Nintendo says this is to prevent the market from being glutted with poor games. Others, again, see a simple pattern of control.
