LENGTH: 1137 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Plenty of Bells and Whistles on the Latest Portables

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Battery-powered color displays and data entry from pens or styluses appear to be the next frontiers in portable computing, judging from the new models on display at the Comdex trade show in Las Vegas, Nev., last month. While pen computing does not appear likely to capture a significant share of the portable market soon, primarily because of the lack of pen-based software, color displays are attractive for some specialized applications. And they use existing software.
Epson America, AST Research, Dell Computer, Sharp Electronics and several other computers makers showed off new battery-powered, color laptops at Comdex, with prices ranging from $5,000 to more than $10,000. The Sharp PC 6881 appears to be especially good, but it, like many other models, will not be ready until late spring because companies have had difficulty in getting reliable color screens. 
 The Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston, which did not mount a major display at Comdex, recently offered an alternative to the color portable -- a 17-pound color "luggable" that has to be plugged in to an electric outlet. Priced at $9,999, it offers the best color screen and system performance of any portable, if you are willing to regard it as a portable.
"This is the beginning of a migration process," said Bruce A. Stephen, director of PC hardware research at the International Data Corporation of Framingham, Mass. "Color is starting to appear at the high end, but it will eventually become a common, economical feature on most products." He predicted it would be a couple of years before color was the norm for battery-powered computers.
Portable computers capable of displaying color images have been around for a few years, but the high cost and weight of the systems made them impractical for all but the most desperate users. Color screens have added about $2,000 to the cost of otherwise conventional laptop computers. The least expensive of the color systems announced at Comdex was AST Research's Premium Exec 386SX/25C, with a suggested list price of $4,995. Without color, an otherwise comparable system sells for less than $3,000.
For many users it has been far easier and less expensive to buy or rent a conventional color monitor and attach it to the portable PC, using a "video out" jack that most of the newer laptops and notebooks have. A worker who moves among several offices on a regular basis, for example, could buy a color VGA monitor for each site for less than the price of the color option on a laptop machine.
For most people, color is a convenience, not a necessity. Apple Macintosh and Next computer users did without color for years, and the new Apple Powerbook notebook Macs are all monochrome machines. (A striking sign of the importance Apple attaches to color is that the Powerbooks have no standard way to attach to a color desktop monitor, except through a Radius Inc. adapter sold separately for $600.) How essential can color be for most business applications, after all, when few businesses invest in the color printers or copiers needed to transfer the images to paper?
But color can be important for special applications, like presentations, software development and graphic design. Color adds emphasis to information: a deficit on a spreadsheet pops out when it is highlighted in red ink; a colorful chart makes it easier to distinguish among different facets of the data presented.
Does a traveling sales representative need a color portable computer? On the one hand, as a visual aid for a sales presentation, it helps hold the customer's interest. On the other, the small size of the screens on most portables limits presentations to small, intimate groups. And some new portables use a color technology that becomes hard to read except by those directly in front of the screen, awkward for more than three people, huddled together, to watch.
Two technologies are popular for color portables. One, called active matrix, yields the best performance, at a higher price than passive matrix. Both technologies can produce VGA-level resolution, but only active-matrix screens can theoretically show 256 shades and colors at once, with the passive-matrix screens limited to 16. (VGA, for variable graphics array, refers to a system capable of displaying 640 picture elements, or pixels, horizontally and 480 pixels vertically.)
The active matrix screens offered by Sharp, Epson and Compaq, use a thin-film transistor technology that controls each pixel on the screen individually. With one or more transistors behind each pixel, the computer can supply more information to each point on the screen, yielding a greater palette of colors. And the colors are much brighter and the contrast sharper than on a passive screen. People standing to the side of the computer can see the image clearly. Passive matrix screens are essentially the same as monochrome liquid crystal displays, with a color filtering system added.
Part of the high cost of active-matrix screens is the result of United States Government trade regulations. In an effort to protect American makers of active-matrix screens against unfair competition from the Japanese, the Government slapped a 66 percent tariff on imported screens. The trouble is that there are no significant American makers of active-matrix screens to protect.
There is no tariff on active-matrix screens if they are imported as part of a complete computer system, rather than as components. As a result of the Government sanctions, then, American computer makers have shifted production of the new color portables to foreign plants.
The microprocessor driving many new color laptops is the Intel 386SL, a chip that has special power-management features that can be exploited by computer makers. Although it takes more power to operate a color screen than it does to run a monochrome screen, each computer maker says it can promise two to three hours of battery life for the color computers. As they say in car ads, your mileage may vary.
Dell, which was showing its seven-pound 325NC color notebook at the show, uses a nickel-hydride battery system instead of the conventional nickel-cadmium battery. So does Toshiba America Inc., one of the first companies to switch to nickel-hydride batteries. These batteries are supposedly more "environmentally correct" because they use a hydrogen derivative instead of toxic cadmium. And Toshiba officials say they are not subject to the infamous "memory effect" of nickel-cadmium batteries. The memory effect occurs when a user recharges the battery before it is completely exhausted. The battery then tends to lose power at the point it was recharged, shortening its effective life. Makers of ni-cad batteries dispute the existence of a memory effect, but users say it happens all the time.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Humming Along With Hyundai's Sonata

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
AS one afflicted with an oft-misspelled and usually mispronounced name, I am sympathetic to Hyundai. The South Korean company has been sending cars to the United States for five years now, and you still hear some very strange renditions of its moniker.
To set the record straight (and this is a good day for it), the name is Hunday as in Sunday. And the names of its products are Excel and Elantra, Scoupe and Sonata. 
 By whatever name, though, the company has made its presence known in fairly short order. It followed the introduction of its subcompact Excel in 1986 by moving from its beachhead in Garden Grove, Calif., to an 18-acre headquarters just off the San Diego Freeway, and then set about building large complexes for parts and distribution in Ontario, Calif.; Aurora, Ill.; Portland, Ore., and St. Louis.
For 1992, there is a new corporate logo in the shape of a stylized "H," and the company's American arm -- Hyundai Motor America -- has become the largest subsidiary of the Hyundai conglomerate, which sells cars and trucks in 65 countries and which accounts for 10 percent of South Korea's gross national product.
A lot of that is the result of the Excel, which quickly became a bestseller. But the Sonata has done well, too, and its new design merits a look.
The car in question was a black four-door Sonata GLS, the top of the line, and when I slid behind the wheel it was a case of love at first sit.
I had been driving a BMW 325i, and while it seems an embarrassment to say it, the Hyundai was more to my liking, or at least it seemed to make more sense than all the dollars that one would tie up in the sporty Bimmer. The Sonata was so . . . well, so liveable.
The styling is not spectacular and the Sonata turns no heads, despite its smoother lines and more aggressive look. But the car's appearance, with a new grille, a lower hoodline and different lights and accents, is average-nice. There is chrome trim, and the molded wheels carry big Michelin tires for what Hyundai says is a "more competitive" stance.
For a compact, there is surprising legroom in the back seat, and the interior is generally open and pleasing. The trunk, too, is relatively commodious, and the rear seatback folds down to form a pass-through and provide a cargo platform.
The tester had a dark gray interior of cloth and vinyl, but leather is available if you want to put some icing inside the cake. The front buckets have manual adjustments, but they include up-and-down functions in addition to sliding to and fro.
There is also an automatic "down" function for the driver's window. And, while many makers seem fixated on losing the power window switches somewhere on the center console, the Sonata's are where they ought to be, easy to manipulate on the armrest of the door. Even more amazing, the back windows go all the way down. Take note, Detroit.
The wheel is typical sport-sedan, padded but hard. And the wheel represents one flaw in an otherwise neat package: There is no airbag in its hub, and that means passive belts that motor up and over the door frames. They are annoying and dangerous, and they serve little purpose, since the lapbelts still must be buckled manually. Unfortunate, too, are the lack of standard antilock brakes and a standard sunroof, although both features are available as options, with ABS being new for '92.
Otherwise, the interior is well and sensibly put together. There is a flat and usable shelf in the top of the dash, and storage extends to a somewhat small glovebox and a series of bins, cubbies and toll-change holders.
The instrument panel carries full gauges, including a 130-m.p.h. speedometer and an 8,000-r.p.m. tach. Controls are easy to use, and the heating system is a good example. There are three simple knobs, one for temperature, one for the fan and one, with illustrations, to direct the flow of air.
The ashtray is large and easy to find at night, which is important for the relative safety of smokers, and the Sonata also offers a slide-out tray with two cupholders. Be warned, though, that it is directly above the ashtray, meaning you can't feed both vices at the same time.
As the top of Hyundai's line, the test car was equipped with a V6 engine, which can be had only with an automatic transmission. Attention has been paid to thriftiness, however, through an overdrive button on the shift handle. Fuel economy with the V6 is estimated at 18 miles per gallon, city, and 24, highway.
Lesser Sonata's carry four-cylinder engines and are available with five-speed sticks. Economy with the 2-liter four and the manual transmission is rated at 20, city, and 27, highway.
The 3-liter V6 puts out 142 horsepower, which is plenty in a car that weighs only 2,932 pounds, and both acceleration and highway performance are good. But, while there is sufficient potential for a speeding ticket, the car wants to go 60 m.p.h. just as you do, which means you need not keep an overly cautious eye on the speedometer.
On the road, the Sonata tracks as well as it hums, and there is a steady feel that lends a sense of security. The ride is comfortable if a bit stiff, and the car is happiest away from potholes, which does not necessarily make it a bad person.
It is price, of course, that makes the Sonata the truly solid citizen that it is. This plain-vanilla car starts at $11,150, and moves up to $13,995 for the basic GLS and $15,535 for the GLS V6.
At that rate, you could have two Hyundais for the price of the Bimmer. Keep one for Sunday, one for Monday.

HEADLINE: Welcome To 1992;
A Survival Guide For Elected Officials (Results May Vary)

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Yes, Mr. or Ms. Elected Official, the voters really are angry out there.
This is not the time to run on your savvy, your years of influence or your ability to work the "corridors of power," as Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General, put it in his hapless campaign for Senate in Pennsylvania. The voters are frustrated with the corridors of power, tired of the status quo. 
 They made that clear in Pennsylvania last week and they made it clear in turning the New Jersey Legislature on its head. The economy is ailing -- you've heard, right? -- and the majority of voters now tell pollsters that they believe the country is headed down the wrong track. The sweeping changes abroad only seem to underscore the feeling of drift and stall at home. The message to incumbents is clear: "Fight for change or die," in the words of Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee.
Incumbent governors seem to be an endangered species. Buddy Roemer, a Republican, lost in Louisiana and a Democrat, Ray Mabus, was ousted in Mississippi. The stunning Republican gains in the Virginia and the New Jersey legislatures were widely seen as slaps at the Democratic Governors, L. Douglas Wilder and Jim Florio -- who, fortunately for them, were not on the ballot.
This does not mean that incumbents are necessarily doomed. But many are in need of serious repositioning before the 1992 elections. "This election was not so much an anti-incumbent message as an anti-business-as-usual message," said Representative Vic Fazio, who as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is charged with protecting a few hundred nervous Democratic incumbents next year. There are clear lessons from this election for all incumbents, including the No. 1 incumbent, President Bush.
 
First, Get Real
 In a troubled economy, voters get down to basics. "This is about money in my pocket, prices for the essentials of life, the level of fear on the block," said Mr. Tully. Don Sipple, a Republican consultant, said, "Understand that the American people have an agenda, whether their leaders do or not."
Unemployment and health care were on the agenda in Pennsylvania, taxes in New Jersey, crime in the Houston mayor's race. The health care issue took off after Senator Harris Wofford rode it to victory in Pennsylvania: Democrats said their proposals would gain new momentum, Senate Republicans produced a plan of their own, and Mr. Bush announced that he would produce a measure before the 1992 election.
Over-arching it all was the economy: "Every issue that popped up is related to a stagnant economy," said a top Republican strategist, who spoke on condition of anonymity. This helps explain why a traditional conflict seems all the more acute among the voters: the demand for services and the aching sensitivity to taxes. Tax cuts for the middle class, also urged by Mr. Wofford, are now the rage.
 
Don't Be 'One of Them'
 Given the public's current distaste for Washington, its institutions and its policy gridlock, the smart incumbent will try to set himself apart. Witness George Bush in his first official campaign foray for 1992: "You work your heart out for new ideas in trying to bring new systems to this country, and you face the same old tired liberal cliches in Washington, D.C."
Harrison Hickman, a Democratic pollster, tells incumbents: "You have to separate yourself out. You have to say, 'Yeah, throw the bums out, but I'm not a bum.' " Mr. Hickman added, "I don't think you'll see a lot of people sitting behind their desks in their offices in their ads -- they'll be out, amongst the folk."
In fact, political professionals advise more town meetings, more talk radio interviews. "If I were doing an incumbent race, I'd show I wasn't the typical politician," said James Carville, a strategist for Mr. Wofford. "I'd have a lot of testimonial ads from people saying I cared about people and helped them. I'd document a lot of trips back to the state."
Incumbents in the House and Senate have often campaigned on their seniority, their accumulated clout. Next year, "fighting for change" might be the more appropriate theme. "I'm going to be working for Bob Packwood," said Mr. Sipple, "and the worst thing he could do is, 'I've been there for 24 years, I have seniority and I can get things done for Oregon.' "
Washington State showed this trend has its limits: Confounding experts, its voters defeated a stringent, retroactive term limitation measure after opponents warned it would cost the state influence in Congress.
Still, there is a restive air in politics, and last week's elections showed that outsiders can run at incumbents from the left or the right. Mr. Mabus, a Harvard-educated Democrat, was elected Governor of Mississippi in 1987 as a New South reformer. He was defeated on Tuesday by a conservative Republican businessman, Kirk Fordice, who ran an outsider's campaign that included attacks on liberal elitists, welfare abuse and racial quotas. "What we have tonight is a mandate for change," Mr. Fordice said.
 
Stay Clean, Stay Home
 Voters are in an unforgiving mood. This is not a good time to be associated with big political action committee money. This is not a good time to be taking Congressional trips to exotic climes. This is certainly not a good time to have bounced checks. Representative Larry Hopkins, Republican candidate for Governor in Kentucky, was already behind Lieut. Gov. Brereton Jones, his Democratic opponent, when the Congressional check-bouncing scandal broke. But the Democrat's lead exploded after Mr. Hopkins acknowledged writing 32 overdrafts at the House bank, according to Mr. Jones's polltaker -- growing from 12 to 23 points in two nights.
Any of the perks that make an incumbent look insulated from the ways of everyman and generally out of touch should be avoided, political professionals agree.
Mr. Bush is not immune. He revels in his role as Commander in Chief and a world leader. But last week he announced, with a trace of annoyance, that he was canceling a trip to the Far East later this month -- to keep an eye on Congress, he said, and tend to pressing domestic affairs. Democrats have been campaigning hard against Mr. Bush's travel, trying to make it a symbol of neglect of the domestic agenda. Mr. Bush seemed stung and defensive last week as he headed off to Rome for a NATO meeting, taking pains to describe how foreign trade agreements affect hometown U.S.A.
In the end, it is worth remembering that 96 percent of the House incumbents were re-elected last year, and that Mr. Bush remains at a comfortable level in the polls. Still, something is stirring among the voters, and a body can't be too careful out there.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
There's a New World Order in Asia; The U.S. Will Have to Catch Up

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

 BODY:
A handful of Asia-based diplomats are willing to give President Bush the benefit of the doubt. They are willing to believe that he canceled his trip to Asia this month for reasons that go beyond opinion polls suggesting that the President's globetrotting habits have cut into his approval rating among voters.
In fact, some diplomats say, President Bush may have been well advised to stay home until he knows with certainty how Washington should respond to the political and economic changes that are sweeping across the Far East, and that appear destined to alter the American role. "Everything is fluid in the region right now," said a senior European diplomat in Bangkok. "Perhaps now is not the moment for the President to visit Asia. The United States needs time to absorb it all." 
 Since World War II, American policy in Asia has centered on -- indeed, tens of thousands of Americans have sacrificed their lives over -- the two great land masses on the Pacific rim of China: Indochina and the Korean peninsula. But consider the news from the region in just the last few weeks: Cambodians announced the end of their 12-year civil war; Vietnam restored full diplomatic relations with its chief adversary, China, in hopes of concentrating on economic development; North and South Korea reported the first substantive progress on a framework to resolve more than four decades of brotherly hate.
Any one of those developments would have been startling a few years ago. Taken together at a time when the cold war is all but over, they could be important evidence of a new era of peace and prosperity, even amid reminders of lingering suffering like that of the Vietnamese boat people now resisting forced repatriation from Hong Kong..
Last week Mr. Bush and the other NATO heads of state met in Rome to chart a new role in a Europe without the Soviet threat that had defined the alliance's reason for existence. It was a get-together that Mr. Bush, who considers himself a sort of honorary chairman of the club of world leaders, might well have relished not only for its reassuring pomp but also for its comparative lack of ambiguity.
The Bush Administration has made its own Asia headlines in recent weeks by announcing its willingness to open talks with Hanoi to normalize diplomatic and trade ties 16 years after the war's end, its plan to remove tactical nuclear weapons from the region, and its intention to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Beijing this month. Mr. Baker would be the highest-ranking American official to visit China since pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananman Square were put down in a bloody confrontation by Chinese soldiers two years ago.
The American Century in Asia is not over yet, but already the United States is facing what could be the starkest policy choices since 1898, when President William McKinley invaded and colonized the Philippines even though he knew it as little more than a group of islands "somewhere away around on the other side of the world."
The question for the United States is whether it should continue in the role of policeman and mediator in a region that is increasingly able to resolve its own conflicts and that, far from being the home of "little brown brothers" of old, is now America's fiercest economic competitor. The Bush Administration insists that the choice has already been made, and that the United States military will remain in Asia indefinitely, although the Pacific force, which last year numbered about 140,000 men and women, will be cut by more than 10 percent as part of worldwide Pentagon reductions.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says a complete military withdrawal would almost surely result in a "series of destabilizing regional arms races, an increase in regional tensions and possibly conflict."
Yet that has not silenced forces on Capitol Hill and private defense analysts in the United States who argue that, at a time of domestic austerity, there is no need to continue defending nations that are able to do it themselves. They say, too, that American military forces in Asia are seen increasingly as a paper tiger, since it seems unlikely that the United States, still traumatized over the war in Vietnam, would ever allow itself to be drawn into another large regional conflict in Asia.
"This isn't Kuwait -- there's no oil here for the United States to rush in to protect, and the threat of Communism is dying here as it is everywhere in the world," said a Thai official. Selig S. Harrison, a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment, argues that the American military umbrella in Asia has subsidized the economies of booming East Asian nations, particularly Japan, by freeing them from large military expenditures. "We are helping to make Asia safe for Japanese investment," said Mr. Harrison, who estimates that the United States spends $42 billion a year in direct and indirect costs for its Far East military forces. "It's a ridiculous expenditure."
There is one important area of agreement between analysts like Mr. Harrison and the Bush Administration, and that is over the need for a continued American military presence in South Korea, which faces an isolated and unpredictable enemy to the north. Pyongyang is believed to have an active program to develop nuclear weapons and in the near future could have the bomb. Even in the Koreas, however, there is hope of finally making peace. Late last month, the two nations agreed on the broad outlines of a peace plan reported to include a non-aggression pact, a pledge of respect for each other's political systems and provisions for reuniting families across the border.
 
China and Vietnam
 In Indochina, the optimism about peace is greater still. Despite apprehension among their neighbors that China and Vietnam might be contemplating a destabilizing military alliance, diplomats say the recent warming between Beijing and Hanoi is instead a marriage of convenience between two still-bitter rivals wishing to put aside their differences for now to focus on economic progress.
Closer ties between China and Vietnam may also be the factor that prevents Cambodia from collapsing into civil war again. Beijing has broad control over the genocidal, Chinese-armed Khmer Rouge, responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians in the 1970's, while Vietnam retains influence with the government it helped install in Phnom Penh under Prime Minister Hun Sen. Under a United Nations peace treaty, the Khmer Rouge, Mr. Hun Sen and his political allies, and two other Cambodian factions will share power in what amounts to a coalition government.
In the expectation that the United States military will gradually reduce its presence in Asia, countries now living under the American defense umbrella have begun putting forward proposals for stepped-up regional military cooperation.
Several of the more ambitious proposals have come from Japan, which last summer recommended to the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations that they begin regular consultations on military issues. Last week, the new Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, expressed his hope that Japan would soon rewrite its defense laws to permit the use of its troops outside Japanese borders, as part of United Nations peacekeeping forces.
But with only a month to go before ceremonies to mark the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor and with memories of Japanese occupation and atrocities during World War II still vivid across Asia and the Pacific, Mr. Miyazawa's suggestion met with a decidedly unenthusiastic response outside Japan.
Said an American diplomat: "Given a choice between an Asian defense umbrella provided by the United States and one offered by Tokyo, you'd better believe that we're going to remain the more popular option."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Highlights of last week's elections

 BODY:

Some Surprises Beat Big Odds In National Races
 
 
Pennsylvania Senator
 
Harris Wofford, a little-known Democrat with an anti-Bush message, trounces former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, winning 56 percent of the vote to Mr. Thornburgh's 44 percent. Mr. Wofford was 40 percentage points behind Mr. Thornburgh, a popular former Governor, as the race began, but had hammered away at related themes: that President Bush's policies had damaged the economy and particularly the middle class, and that the United States badly needs national health insurance. Pennsylvania voters told pollsters that national health insurance was the No. 1 issue on their minds. On Thursday, Republicans in Congress introduced a new bill to create an insurance plan; it includes tax credits to help people buy insurance, millions for new clinics and regulations on insurance premiums. More Congressional Democrats spoke up for their own bill, which is modeled on Canada's system.
 
 
Mississippi Governor
 
Kirk Fordice becomes the state's first Republican governor since 1876, ousting the incumbent, Gov. Ray Mabus. In a bitter campaign, Mr. Fordice, a wealthy construction contractor, painted Mr. Mabus as a liberal in the Kennedy tradition and charged that he had bloated the state's payroll as its economy slid downhill. And, although he rejected comparisons with David Duke next door in Louisiana, he introduced racial themes late in the race, stressing his opposition to quotas and attacking welfare recipients.
 
 
Kentucky Governor
 
Lieut. Gov. Brereton C. Jones, a Democrat, gets 65 percent of the vote for governor, easily defeating a seven-term Congressman, Larry J. Hopkins. Mr. Hopkins had received campaign help from President Bush but was hurt when it was revealed that he was one of the lawmakers who wrote bad checks on the House of Representatives bank.
 
 
 
Power Shifts in State and Local Ruling Bodies

 
 
New Jersey Legislature
 
Republicans riding a tide of anger over tax increases by Gov. Jim Florio sweep Democrats out of their majorities in both houses for the first time in 20 years. The next day, as they introduce the members of their new veto-proof voting blocs, G.O.P. leaders say they will roll back about $550 million in taxes.
 
 
Virginia General Assembly
 
Although the Democrats maintain their majorities in both houses, Republicans become a major force in the legislature for the first time since Reconstruction. The Senate is now split 22 to 18 in favor of Democrats; before it was split 30 to 10. The results are seen as an embarrassment for Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination and describing how effective his government has been, but whom voters apparently felt was ignoring the state.
 
 
Suffolk County, New York
 
G.O.P. regains control of the government of this suburban Long Island county as a little-known Assemblyman, Robert J. Gaffney, defeats the incumbent, Patrick G. Halpin, in the race for county executive. Mr. Halpin's popularity suffered from the effects of the recession and the county's high taxes. In adjacent Nassau County, however, traditional Republican dominance of the legislature is sharply reduced as Democrats gather enough votes to block Republican ordinances.
 
 
New York City Council
 
A new 51-member council is elected with few surprises because most of the races were settled in the Democratic primaries. Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker from Queens who has led the newly powerful council in several challenges to Mayor David N. Dinkins, seems in no danger of losing his grip on the body.
 
 
 
Closely Watched Ballot Measures Are Defeated

 
 
Term limits for officeholders
 
In Washington State, a proposal to limit the state's governors and members of Congress to two or three terms is defeated. It is the first time such a measure has lost since term limits got the public's attention last year, when voters in California, Colorado and Oklahoma approved them -- although not for holders of national office. Opponents argued that term limits would mean populous states like California would overwhelm smaller ones like Washington that are protected by having senior representatives in important Congressional posts. One such opponent was House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, a Representative from Washington who would have lost his job if the measure had passed and whose last-minute campaigning against it was thought to have been crucial to its defeat.
 
 
Suicide help by doctors
 
Another Washington ballot initiative, one that would let doctors kill or assist in the suicide of terminally ill patients who ask to die, is also defeated. Opponents said the bill would mean elderly people with little money would feel family pressure to commit suicide, that Washington would become a "fly and die" destination for people from other states and that some people might be labeled terminally ill prematurely. The turnout in Washington is a record for an off-year election.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Chileans Pay Dearly For Economic Growth

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
The only people in America who may not be ready for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to decide whether he will run for President are the political cartoonists and satirists.
In a world overstocked with Dan Quayle jokes, Mr. Cuomo's should-I-or-shouldn't-I routine has provided fresh material for the monologues of Johnny Carson, Jay Leno and Mark Russell. Political cartoonists from coast to coast have searched for the best visual vehicle to depict the baggy-eyed Governor in the throes of his indecision. 
 Examples abound: Mr. Cuomo paralyzed by irresolution on the starting line of the New York marathon. Mr. Cuomo forlorn as The Boy Who Cried "Maybe." Mike Luckovich of The Atlanta Constitution drew three frames to show the Governor agonizing over a choice before revealing his decision in the fourth frame: "I'll have the lasagna."
Mr. Cuomo's monthlong bout of Presidential pondering is funny, said Stuart Carlson, a cartoonist with The Milwaukee Sentinel, because people can relate to the torment of making big decisions. But they are unaccustomed to seeing it in their public officials and their amusement can quickly turn into irritation if the process lasts too long, he warned.
"If you get past that point, people start to ridicule you," said the cartoonist, who drew a Super Mario video game that accepts quarters only after the player undergoes self-analysis as to whether it's the best way to spend the 25 cents. "If you take too long that tolerance begins to fade real fast," Mr. Carlson said.
Last week, Johnny Carson joked about a new car model, the '92 Cuomo, which "you drive down the center of the road with both directional signals on." Mark Russell, the political satirist, joined a number of comedians in poking fun at Mr. Cuomo's description of the conflict between his heart and his head.
"Cuomo says, 'My heart tells me to go for it but my head says stay home,' " Mr. Russell said in a recent television appearance. "I gather his spleen has the deciding vote."
Not all comedians interpreted this anatomical conflict in a completely negative light. "If he's got a heart and a mind," Jay Leno said last week, "he's already overqualified."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Forecasting the Hungriest Soviet Winter in Years

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan drew a laugh at a recent Congressional hearing when he told of seeing potatoes and onions in the Soviet Union being stored together in the same sealed boxes, so that they would not only spoil quickly but also smell bad.
The disorganization and waste of Soviet agriculture have long appalled visiting foreigners. Worsening the problems this year are regional droughts, the fragmentation of the Soviet Union and half-hearted efforts to establish a market economy. The result, some American officials increasingly fear, is that this winter's food problems may be the worst in decades. 
 At the same time, the Soviet Union's sheer size and the West's weak economic growth and budget troubles have made a heroic international effort to feed the Soviet people unlikely. And the disorganization is likely to limit the immediate effect of programs now being drafted to teach the Soviet authorities to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps.
These programs are likely to include the creation of two model distribution centers, a crop forecasting system to make information on harvest sizes available earlier, and agricultural extension services to teach better farm production and distribution techniques.
Some experts are skeptical about how much these measures will help. "The prospect of these little technical assistance programs having much impact on the crisis that looms this winter in the Soviet Union is not high," said Richard T. McCormack, who until last spring was the Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs.
Food riots by hungry Russians this winter could end the Soviet Union's new flirtation with democratic rule, he said, and result in a crackdown by an authoritarian regime denouncing hoarders and speculators.
Bush Administration officials have been less pessimistic, warning of hardships for the Soviet people but no starvation and playing down the risk of social unrest. Large quantities of food have been hoarded, they say, though it is unclear how much, or how well the food is being preserved. Mr. Madigan told the Senate Agriculture Committee on Oct. 30 that the Soviet Union should restrict access to low-price state stores to the genuinely needy. The rest of the population, he said, should be paying market prices at privately run stores that still obtain adequate supplies by doing their own purchasing and trucking. Moscow's mayor appeared to take a step in this direction last Tuesday when he ordered the rationing of basic foodstuffs and allowed higher prices for sales exceeding the quotas.
Three United States delegations led by top Agriculture Department officials have concluded that less grain than usual was produced this year and that cities and remote republics are not receiving what little there is. Distribution problems have worsened because of the new political and economic freedoms in the Soviet Union, American officials have concluded.
Unable to persuade Soviet citizens to buy bonds and Soviet republics to hand over tax receipts, the nearly bankrupt central authorities are offering state farms the equivalent of as little as $8 a ton for wheat and have stopped compelling state farms to deliver the goods. With the Soviet Union using subsidized Western loans to pay $120 a ton for imported wheat, including shipping costs, and with the value of the ruble rapidly falling, farmers have sold only half the usual amount of grain to the authorities this year.
Much of the grain left on the farms may now rot for lack of adequate protection from the elements. As part of a campaign to break the political independence of the Soviet countryside in the 1930's, Stalin eliminated most of the country's grain storage bins on farms and replaced them with grain elevators in cities.
 
Rival Republics
 Independence movements in the Soviet republics and a shortage of wholesale markets and private transportation are limiting the ability of entrepreneurs to take the government's place. The Soviet republics, for instance, are increasingly blocking the movement of grain and other commodities across their borders.
Azerbaijan has closed Armenia's oil pipeline, which provides fuel for Armenian industries, including food processing plants, and it was reported that troops were used Thursday to disperse shoppers who sacked a bakery still in operation. Russia and the Ukraine are now restricting exports of grain to other republics, requiring private traders to pay for licenses, tolls or bribes to move their stores across borders.
Danielle S. Downing, the owner of a small Moscow grain trading company, said that last month she was quoted a price of 2,500 rubles a ton for delivery of wheat within Russia. But the price was 4,000 rubles a ton for delivery in neighboring Uzbekistan, a fertile region that under Soviet central planning has specialized in cotton at the expense of food production.
The United States, Japan and Europe have made highly publicized pledges of food to the Soviet Union. But the only country making large deliveries in recent months has been the United States, which by the end of the month will have sent $2.5 billion worth of grain. France and Germany have sent smaller quantities.
But because of difficulties with the transportation and distribution of food and the eventual repayment of credits, the European Community has delivered only a ninth of the $1 billion in food assistance it pledged nearly a year ago. And Japan has not yet delivered on any of its food pledges for this fall because it is still haggling about repayment.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Must Democrats Shift Signals on Blacks to Win the Presidency?

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In 1964, President Lyndon Johnson confided to a young aide, Bill Moyers, that by signing the Civil Rights Bill into law he had "delivered the South to the Republican Party for a long time to come." In a sense Johnson got it wrong; there are still more registered Democrats in the South than there are Republicans. But some political analysts now think that if L.B.J. had substituted the words "the white vote" for "the South," he would have been right on target.
The bill, the most far-reaching civil rights measure ever passed by Congress, has been credited with greatly reducing discrimination and helping to create a viable black middle class. But juxtaposed with this progress are the fortunes of the Democratic Party, which, except for the election of Jimmy Carter in 1976, has been shut out of the White House since 1968. 
 These days there is a provocative line of reasoning that attempts to explain the slide: The Democratic Party is bleeding white working- and middle-class voters in Presidential elections in part because it is seen as being too concerned with the plight of the poor and of racial minorities -- mainly blacks.
 
'The Burden of Race'
 "I'm inclined to believe that the Democratic Party is permanently handicapped by its civil rights role," said Milton Morris, a vice president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research group specializing in black issues. "That image is not going to be easy to erase. What is now happening is long-term Republican ascendancy based on the burden of race that the Democrats bear."
Analysts say that these whites who have crossed over to vote Republican, in the main, are not racists loath to see blacks move up the economic ladder. Instead, they see Democrats as asking them to pay -- either through taxes or by giving up a job or a promotion -- for programs to compensate for a history of discrimination that they had nothing to do with. Whether this is a valid perception is almost irrelevant where the party's election performances are concerned.
"It's simply a question of mathematics," said Peter Brown, author of "Minority Party," and a proponent of this political theory. "About 80 percent of the people who vote in Presidential elections are white, and since Lyndon Johnson, no Democratic Presidential candidate has gotten more than 46 percent of that vote."
Mark Mellman, a pollster who has worked with a number of Democratic candidates, agrees. "There is no question that the Democratic Party has a problem on race," he said. "Many of the philosophical principles we have espoused put us fundamentally at odds with the majority of the American people. And when your principles are at odds with the majority, you have a political problem."
Cognizant of the party's racial Achilles heel, some Democratic officials and civil rights leaders gave a palpable sigh of relief over two recent events -- the decision of the Rev. Jesse Jackson not to seek the party's Presidential nomination next year and the passage of a new civil rights bill with the blessing of the Bush Administration. With Mr. Jackson deciding not to run, the most visible symbol of the Democrats' links with blacks is on the sidelines. "It is fair to say that some Democrats have expressed anxiety about both the Jackson candidacy and what it symbolized to traditional Democrats -- white Democrats, Southerners, blue collar, working-class Democrats," said an official with a major civil rights organization who asked that neither he nor his group be identified.
 
Fear and Civil Rights
 The agreement between Congress and the White House on the civil rights bill removes at least for the near term a difficult racially tinged issue -- race-based preference programs -- from the political debate. Indicative of the concern the so-called "quota" issue was causing Democrats was a list distributed at a Congressional Black Caucus forum in September, which called 16 Senators "shaky" in their support of the civil rights bill. Thirteen were Democrats, including Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Southerners like Richard Shelby of Alabama, John Breaux of Louisiana and Wyche Fowler of Georgia. Kerry Scanlon, an attorney with the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Education Fund, told the forum that a number of Southern Democrats were "scared to death" of being forced to take a stand on the civil rights bill in an election year.
But racial politics are being stoked by others. David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader, has achieved remarkable success running as a Republican in Louisiana by raising three hot-button issues with racial connotations -- crime, welfare and affirmative action. And in Mississippi, Republican Kirk Fordice scored an upset victory over the incumbent Governor Ray Mabus, using a commercial calling for "workfare, not welfare," which featured a stark photograph of a young black woman holding a baby.
 
A Two-Sided Dilemma
 Some Democratic analysts have noted with hope that the middle class is directing its anger not only against the poor, but also toward the other end of the class spectrum: the rich. The success that Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania had in last week's election in portraying Dick Thornburgh, his Republican opponent, as the defender of the status quo and the powerful, holds promise for Democrats in 1992; the success of Mr. Duke and Mr. Fordice does not.
Elaine Ciulla Kamarck, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute, a centrist Democratic research organization, defined the anger in a recent article: "What do the C.E.O.'s of major American corporations and members of Congress have in common with 15-year-old welfare mothers? Plenty. The vast American middle class is sick to death of all of them."
Racial politics places Democrats in an ethical and political dilemma: If the party moves to recapture those whites who have moved away, won't it alienate blacks who have been the Democrats' most loyal supporters in recent years? And Dr. Morris says that the situation presents difficulties for blacks as well. "Blacks could change the dynamic, but the only way they could do that is to leave the Democrats and go into a Republican Party which doesn't really care about them and is doing just fine without them," he said.
Some Democratic analysts think that the best bet for leading the party out of its racial thicket may be black politicians who can appeal to whites. L. Douglas Wilder, the black Governor of Virginia who is a fiscal conservative, seemed to aspire to that role. But, in searching for a solid base for a run for the party's Presidential nomination, he is more and more making a traditional appeal to black voters.
A few Democrats see the way out of the racial conundrum by fashioning programs to help people lift themselves out of poverty through work, home ownership and investments, rather than transfers of Government money.
But some Democrats are beginning to say that it is black politicians and civil rights leaders who will have to change if the party is to gain back the middle class.
"I think there are some people in the black leadership who need to wake up and realize that you can have all the litmus tests you want for candidates," said Bob Beckel, who was Walter Mondale's campaign manager in 1984, "but if they don't get you the Presidency, you're not helping your people."

Douglas Wilder, who is seeking the Democratic nomination, has begun to steer his message more toward blacks. (Evan Richman/Photoreporters)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1977 words

HEADLINE: ROHATYN PUSHES DINKINS TO DROP FISCAL PROPOSAL

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In an unusually blunt appraisal, Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has urged Mayor David N. Dinkins to abandon the long-term fiscal plan that the Mayor unveiled last week.
Describing the Mayor's proposal to use $1 billion in assistance corporation funds to freeze property taxes as a financial "sacrilege," Mr. Rohatyn called on Mr. Dinkins instead to enlist financial monitors and business and union leaders in a more fundamental effort to make New York City government more efficient. 
 "There comes a time when you have to say the emperor has no clothes," Mr. Rohatyn said in an interview on Friday, referring to the fiscal plan.
Mr. Rohatyn's remarks raise the stakes in the city's effort to fashion a satisfactory plan to meet the series of budget gaps looming over the next few years. The assistance corporation money could substitute at least in part for unpopular tax increases or service cuts.
By threatening to withhold that money, Mr. Rohatyn appears to be trying to prod Mr. Dinkins and the municipal unions into serious bargaining for labor concessions and restructuring of city government.
 
To Cut 16,000 Jobs
 Through his spokesman, Leland T. Jones, the Mayor said yesterday, "The plan meets a number of the objectives we had thought were shared by Mr. Rohatyn."
In the plan, submitted to the State Financial Control Board, Mr. Dinkins proposed to balance budgets in the four fiscal years beginning next July through a program of attrition that would eliminate 16,000 jobs and that would pay for wage increases over the next two years only through productivity agreements. The funds from the assistance corporation, an independent agency that borrows money on the city's behalf, would be used to avoid a $500 million property-tax increase that the Mayor had previously discussed.
But Mr. Rohatyn said the money should not be used as a substitute for new taxes or cuts. If the Mayor thinks the city cannot absorb more of either, he said, then he should ask the Legislature for the power to close budget gaps by borrowing -- a power that would trigger the return of state overseers that Mr. Dinkins has pledged to avoid at all costs.
"That's not something I support, nor does the Governor," Mr. Rohatyn said. "It's a theoretical alternative, not necessary at this point, but which has to be considered if the city can't make the cuts or raise the taxes."
But Mr. Rohatyn described himself as deeply frustrated at what he views as the Dinkins administration's indifference to fiscal realities.
"My mood is not anger, not despair," Mr. Rohatyn said. "It is sheer and total frustration. It is the frustration at watching a city degrade itself when it doesn't have to. People have given up hope partly because the administration doesn't give them any hope. The failure of this administration is its failure to give the city a sense of direction. The administration views itself as a victim instead of as leader of the city, and if there're any victims they are the people of the city."
 
'Everything for Nothing'
 The investment banker said he was speaking out reluctantly -- aware that he could be cast as the villain who refused to bail the city out -- in the hope of elevating the debate from a personal confrontation between himself and the Mayor and to enlist other partners, such as the State Financial Control Board, which he implied has been too reticent.
"The city administration has to recognize that this is not a personal thing, that institutionally we cannot do what the city wants, which is everything for nothing," Mr. Rohatyn said. "I couldn't do it if I wanted to. My board wouldn't do it. The rating agencies wouldn't let us do it. How does M.A.C. put its credit and legal liability on the line by selling a billion dollars in bonds to the public if we have to include in our offering a city plan in which we have no faith?"
Mr. Rohatyn's remarks were striking, even beyond their vehemence, because when the Mayor released the financial plan last Wednesday his administration left the impression that Mr. Rohatyn would acquiesce in, if not actually embrace, the proposals.
 
A Matter of Givens
 "While the city needs to accommodate M.A.C.'s fiduciary responsibilities as best it can, at the end of the day this is still the city's money, and M.A.C. needs to accommodate the fiscal needs of the city," First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said. "I thought in terms of programmatic and policy thrusts we had moved a long way toward the kinds of things Felix was talking about."
Mr. Rohatyn agreed that the direction was right but said that the Mayor had not gone far enough. He recalled that as recently as last week he had delivered a speech about what the corporation could and could not do without jeopardizing its own credibilty: "That the city can't raise taxes, that it has to cut the work force. Those weren't conditions; they were givens."
"It's a bad plan regardless of M.A.C.," Mr. Rohatyn said. "But the city has lobbied all sorts of organizations as part of a political effort to create the impression that the only thing standing between the city and prosperity is M.A.C. With a $120 billion budget over the next four years, the billion dollars from M.A.C. is a very small tail wagging a very big dog."
One measure of the strained relationship between the administration and the corporation was City Hall's suggestion that the timing of Mr. Rohatyn's remarks may represent a calculated strategy to create the crisis atmosphere that he had said all along was necessary to resolve the long-term budget impasse. Why, Mr. Steisel asked Mr. Rohatyn in a telephone conversation on Friday, had he not warned the Mayor of his reservations in advance and told Mr. Dinkins that "your guys are about to let you walk off a cliff?"
 
Replacing Mayoral Appointees
 To which Mr. Rohatyn replied that he had not been briefed until Tuesday, when the plan was already being printed. Also, he said, Mr. Dinkins had consulted him personally only once while the plan was being drafted -- to inform Mr. Rohatyn that Mr. Dinkins intends to replace the four mayoral appointees on the nine-member M.A.C. board who had been named by his predecessor.
"It was a message," Mr. Rohatyn concluded.
When Mr. Dinkins telephoned Mr. Rohatyn on Thursday to express disappointment over his initial response to the plan, Mr. Rohatyn recalled: "I said to the Mayor that I was astounded that there was any surprise. I couldn't conceive anyone not knowing this would be our reaction. If they didn't know, they shouldn't be there. He suggested breakfast. I said this was more than a two-hour breakfast discussion."
Instead, Mr. Rohatyn plans to confer with Mr. Steisel, Budget Director Philip R. Michael and, perhaps, officials of the Financial Control Board next week to present his objections in detail.
The Municipal Assistance Corporation was created during the city's 1975 fiscal crisis to borrow on behalf of New York City while it was shut out of the credit market and dug itself from under a mountain of debt that had been accumulating for years. Its bonds are backed by city sales-tax revenues. Mr. Rohatyn, senior partner in Lazard Freres & Company, was the architect of the corporation, and its only chairman.
Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board, concurred in some of Mr. Rohatyn's criticisms, saying the plan was so unspecific that it seemed more like a first draft. "This plan, in many ways, was far more impressionistic than any other plan has been," Mr. Proctor said.
 
Looking for Latitude
 Last week, Mr. Michael, the Budget Director, hailed the plan as "revolutionary," even though, he acknowledged, some of its components represented only first steps toward reform and others, such as inviting private contractors to maintain the city's fleet of vehicles or to collect recyclable garbage, were significant but "not sexy."
Mr. Steisel also said that while a billion dollars over two years might not seem like much nowadays, it would widen Mr. Dinkins's latitude to affect spending at the margins of a nearly $30 billion budget.
Mr. Rohatyn, who said he was sensitive to the perception that any outside intrusion could be viewed as undermining the city's first black mayor, volunteered no specific budget buts, except to cite proposals to replace more deskbound police officers with civilians and to demand a full day's work from trash collectors who are idle when they finish their routes.
Mr. Rohatyn recalled that he had voted for Mr. Dinkins for mayor in the Democratic primary and general election in 1989 but said it was too soon to say whether he would do so in 1993.
"It is both unnecessary and unfair for me to answer that question," he said. "He has two more years and the jury is still out. I would like to be able to vote for him again."
 
 
THE MAJOR PLAYERS

 
Who controls the city's finances
 
MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS
 
He ran with a liberal agenda, but as the Mayor during a recession he has been reduced to allocating losses among his friends. In yet another effort to demonstrate his fiscal conservatism, Mr. Dinkins proposed this week to freeze property taxes for two years, but the business community and budget watchdogs were still wary about a plan that they maintained lacked specifics.
 
 
GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO
 
Struggling with his own deficit of nearly $700 million, the Governor persuaded Mr. Dinkins not to press for quicker relief from Medicaid costs than the pace Mr. Cuomo proposed last month. But City Hall has been less responsive to gentle prodding from Albany to follow the state's example of bold budget-cutting -- a recalcitrance that may figure in the Governor's Presidential plans as he mulls whether the unresolved state and city budget crises require him to remain in New York.
 
 
FELIX G. ROHATYN
 
The chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created in 1975 to borrow on the city's behalf, has been placed in a bind: How long can he hold the city's feet to the fire by withholding the $1 billion he could deliver by refinancing the M.A.C.'s debt without getting burned politically himself?
 
 
PETER F. VALLONE
 
The Mayor's plan was the product of unusual cooperation with the City Council Speaker -- a tribute to Mr. Vallone's emerging influence and to Mr. Dinkins's recognition, even before Tuesday's election, that voters are fed up with more taxes for fewer services and that the business community is desparate for some predictability. The plan tentatively embraces some other Council recommendations and eschews a proposal anathema to Mr. Vallone and his colleagues from Brooklyn and Queens: tolls on the free East River bridges.
 
 
THE UNIONS
 
If Mr. Dinkins's metaphor for the city applies to its budget, the four-year financial mosaic is still missing a giant piece that may well not take shape until after Mr. Rohatyn's refinancing deadline. The plan doesn't rule out raises, but requires that they be paid for by productivity. The city and its police union are in arbitration, but talks with other unions have stalled as looming deficits and the proposed property tax freeze place more pressure on labor.
 
 
WHAT HAPPENS NEXT
 
In the coming weeks, the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, must review the Mayor's plan. Mr. Rohatyn has made the board's approval of the plan one requirement for making the $1 billion available. In January, Mr. Dinkins will submit his preliminary budget for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. That plan will then be reviewed by the Wall Street credit rating agencies. In April, the Mayor will present his final budget plan. After negotiations, a budget must be approved by the City Council. -- SAM ROBERTS

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ACTIVITY BY NORTH KOREANS WORRIES THE U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The rapid expansion of a mysterious nuclear complex in North Korea is heightening concern in Washington, Seoul and Tokyo that the unpredictable regime of President Kim Il Sung may be closer to producing a crude nuclear weapon than anyone thought just a year ago.
The concerns are being driven by North Korea's continued refusal to allow international inspection of the site at Yongbyon, a nuclear complex 60 miles north of Pyongyang that dates back at least two decades. 
 But a steady trickle of new intelligence information emerging from North Korea, one of the world's most closed Communist countries, suggests that a host of new installations at the site are nearly complete, including a suspected reprocessing plant that could produce hundreds of pounds of weapons-grade plutonium. And there are hints that other nuclear complexes are being built elsewhere in the country, perhaps underground.
 
Fear of U.S. Misjudgment
 While there are conflicting interpretations of the evidence, some of which has recently been made public, each new morsel seems to deepen the enigma of Yongbyon, and to stir nervousness among America's allies in Asia that Washington may again be misjudging critical warning signals, much as it did with President Saddam Hussein's bomb project in Iraq.
"The Iraqi experience scared us all, and we know much less about North Korea," said a senior Japanese official who has directed Tokyo's efforts to gather intelligence about North Korea's nuclear capabilities. "And it is far more serious to Japan than to the U.S. You have nuclear weapons; we don't."
Interviews with nuclear experts and government officials in Seoul, Tokyo and Washington in recent weeks -- along with new commercially available satellite photographs and sketchy information from recent defectors -- indicate that North Korea has already acquired an impressive degree of nuclear expertise.
 
British Reactor Replicated
 Though largely cut off from the Western technology and training that brought wealth to many of its neighbors, Mr. Kim's Government has successfully replicated a British reactor used to produce fuel for weapons, obtained some materials from Germany and received tutoring in nuclear physics from the Soviets that continued at least through this summer.
Very quickly, oratory surrounding the plant is growing more belligerent. A white paper issued by the South Korean Defense Ministry 10 days ago said that the project "must be stopped at any cost."
On Friday, South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, pledged for the first time that his nation would not "manufacture, possess, store, deploy or use nuclear weapons," a statement that seemed to confirm that all American nuclear weapons now stored there would be removed. But Mr. Roh also said, "Nuclear weapons in North Korean hands would be so dangerous and destablilizing that they would not only threaten the very survival of our nation, but could in an instant shatter the peace in Northeast Asia and the world."
American officials say it is premature to consider military options, and calming Seoul's powerful military establishment is expected to be one of the main tasks facing Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d when he visits Seoul next week, to be followed by the Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney.
For more than a year, the official line from American and South Korean officials has been that North Korea will have the materials needed to produce several bombs -- but not necessarily the technology to trigger them -- within three to five years. That estimate, however, appears to be based largely on the evidence provided by satellite photographs, combined with assumptions about the depth of North Korea's technical skills and its access to key components. In the case of Iraq, which has a much larger corps of trained nuclear experts, many of the same assumptions turned out to be wrong.
"I think that the detection methods we have really have their limitations," said James R. Lilley, who served as Ambassador to South Korea in the late 1980's and continued to monitor the project as Ambassador to China, a post he left this year. "As far as I know, you don't have the wealth of defectors in Korea that there were in Iraq to lay it all open."
"No one can afford to assume a country like North Korea is bluffing," said Mr. Lilley, who is expected to take up the post of assistant secretary of defense for international security affairs. "You end up with a lot of people dead in the sea that way."
Nevertheless, while many of the critical details needed to assess the North Korean nuclear program are still muddled, American experts doubt that the country has the financial resources or the depth of engineering talent that Baghdad has dedicated to its nuclear effort. Iraq has been a far more open society than North Korea, with connections throughout the Western world.
But there are few doubts that North Korea will be able to produce a simple nuclear weapon, and perhaps mount it atop a Scud missile. North Korea reportedly has already exported 90 to 100 Scuds to Iran and 20 improved versions to Syria.
Worrisome as North Korea's nuclear potential is, Japanese, South Korean and American analysts say they are even more worried by the Kim Government's unpredictability. It mounted an assassination attempt against the South Korean Cabinet in Rangoon in 1983 that killed 17 people, including 4 Cabinet members. And it was believed to be behind the explosion of a Korean Airlines jet in 1987 that killed 115.
 
Old Allies Provide Aid No Longer
 The Government's erratic behavior, many fear, may worsen now that the country is now being abandoned by its traditional allies.
On the other hand, the recent flood of disclosures, especially those from South Korea, raise the possibility that the North's capabilites are being exaggerated. Seoul has been nervous about negotiations between North Korea and Japan over the normalization of relations, and recognizes the propaganda value of portraying Mr. Kim's Government as the next Iraq.
No one knows how the North would use the bomb politically. But presumably the country's military leadership views the weapons -- and any agreement to allow international inspection -- as one of its few viable bargaining chips. It could trade inspections for economic aid from Japan or, over the long term, use it to bolster its position in future talks with the South over unifying the Korean Peninsula.
The coming visits of Mr. Baker and Mr. Cheney have been preceded by political maneuvering on both sides of the border. North Korea hinted over the summer that it would finally accept inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency -- a requirement under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which North Korea signed in 1985. But in September it backed away from the inspections, saying the United States first had to remove its nuclear weapons from the Korean peninsula.
Now that demand appears about to be fulfilled. In September President Bush said he would order the removal of all American tactical ground and ship-based nuclear weapons from Europe and Asia. And although there has been no formal announcement, officials say a private agreement has been reached with South Korea to remove air-launched weapons as well.
Playing for more time, Mr. Kim's Government recently added a new condition, announcing that the United States must also remove South Korea from the American nuclear umbrella. Then on Friday President Roh made his non-nuclear pledge.
 
Nuclear Ambitions Go Back to 1950's
 It is unlikely that the announcements from Seoul or Washington will dissuade Mr. Kim. North Korea's nuclear ambitions stretch back to the Korean War, when there was open discussion of using American nuclear weapons to end the conflict. The North's anxieties were heightened in the mid-1970's, when it was an open secret that the United States was basing at least 600 nuclear weapons on South Korean soil.
In the late 1960's, having already acquired a miniature reactor from the Soviet Union, the North decided on a a design for a 1950's-era British reactor called "Calder Hall," still operated by the British Nuclear Fuels Company, according to published accounts in the nuclear trade press and one intelligence official.
There are disagreements about whether enough details of the reactor's design were available in public documents to give North Korean scientists the outlines of what they needed, or whether classified details leaked. But the reactor uses graphite to modify, or control, the nuclear reaction -- and graphite is something the Koreans could produce at home. That would eliminate the need to import heavy water, or deuterium oxide, a highly controlled substance.
Construction began in 1980, and it took about seven years to complete the 20- to 30-megawatt reactor, about a mile downriver from the Soviet research installation. North Korean officials insist the reactor for peaceful research. Others have their doubts.
"When you look at the pictures, you see the reactor, but no electric lines, no transformers," said Toshibumi Sakata, a professor at Tokai University here whose laboratory has used computers to enhance French and American commercial photographs of the area, providing the clearest unclassified images of the sprawling facility.
There is even what appears to be a huge guest house, presumably for Mr. Kim or other dignitaries.
According to some South Korean estimates, by next year the reactor will have produced up to 20 kilograms of plutonium -- plenty for several bombs, if processed and incorporated into a weapon.
Two years ago American intelligence satellites picked up images of an even larger nuclear plant, estimated at 50 to 200 megawatts, which is expected to begin operation in early 1992.
Alarming Signs
Of Reprocessing Plant
More alarming are indications of another nearby building that is widely believed to be a reprocessing installation, which experts say should be operational by 1993 or early 1994. That would permit North Korea to extract weapons-grade plutonium from the spent nuclear fuels generated by the reactors. From all indications, the new installations at Yongbyon are being constructed with no direct help from China or the Soviet Union, both of which have joined the effort to convince North Korea to open itself to inspection. In fact, the Soviets appear to have cut off the supply of new nuclear equipment.
Nonetheless, the Soviet Union's longtime training of North Korean scientists appears to continue. A Japanese television crew that visited a Soviet nuclear research installation this year at Dubna, north of Moscow, took pictures of Korean children playing outside the residences and Korean-language signs in the institute. "They have been here for the last 35 years," a Soviet official says of the North Koreans in the television report.
There is also some evidence that North Korea, like Iraq, has cast a wide net in the West for needed materials. Last year the United States fined Degussa A.G. of Frankfurt, Germany, $80,000 for re-exporting to Pyongyang a shipment of American zirconium, which can be used to make uranium fuel rods.
Another German company, Leis Engineering G.m.b.H., was named in the German press a week ago as under investigation for shipping a specialized steel alloy to North Korea that could be used as a container for radioactive materials. The company denied the report.
The North has also nurtured relations with other non-nuclear countries interested in developing their own weaons. For instance, it is reported to have sold advanced Scud missiles to some Arab countries, perhaps in exchange for some nuclear expertise. "There are suspicions that Iran, Romania, and possibly the former East Germany contributed," Joseph S. Bermudez Jr. said last month in Jane's Intelligence Review.
Another likely source of technology is Japan, which has a large population of ethnic Koreans sympathetic to Mr. Kim's Government.
The biggest unknown is whether Yongbyon serves as the country's only nuclear complex, or whether it is the only one built within easy view of reconaissance satellites as a diversion.
A North Korean diplomat who recently defected to Seoul, Ko Yong Hwan, insists that there is at least one other major nuclear site, almost entirely underground, not far from Yongbyon. Intelligence officials say they harbor similar suspicions, but they are not sure that Mr. Ko, who spent the last several years in Africa, was in a position to know many details of the North's capabilities.

HEADLINE: U.S. Goes Along With Sanctions On Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Hoping to pressure Yugoslavia's republics to stop their civil war, President Bush said today that the United States would join in the European Community's economic sanctions against that strife-torn nation and in the call for the United Nations to impose an oil embargo.
"We will apply sanctions on Yugoslavia comparable to those of the European Community," Mr. Bush said at a news conference after four hours of talks here with the community's top two officials. "The E.C. can also depend on the United States to co-sponsor a new United Nations Security Council resolution on Yugoslavia looking toward a possible oil embargo and cooperate fully in efforts to strengthen an embargo on arms exports to Yugoslavia." 
 At a meeting in Rome on Friday, the community decided to withdraw trade preferences, end a trade agreement and economic aid, and urge the United Nations to impose an oil embargo.
Before ending a three-day European trip that was criticized at home as an attempt to escape domestic political problems, Mr. Bush said that he and the top community officials had narrowed their differences in a long-standing dispute over reducing subsidies in agricultural trade, but had achieved no breakthrough that could lead to a resumption of global trade talks under the General Agreemant on Tariffs and Trade.
Washington has called for slashing the industrial world's subsidies for farmers, but the community, not wanting to hurt its heavily subsidized farmers, has resisted such cuts. With pressures growing at home about the stalled domestic economy, President Bush took pains today to emphasize that a trade accord could help American farmers by increasing markets for their exports.
He and the European leaders vowed today to push forward with the aim of ending the 108-nation trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, in a few months.
"For the first time, I am reasonably optimistic about the possibility of reaching an agreement," said Jacques Delors, president of the community's Executive Commission, adding that a trade accord would be "a very important signal" to spur trade and the world economy. But neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Delors nor Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands, which holds the community's rotating presidency, described the progress that had been made.
The United States has for several months held back on applying heavy pressure to end the Yugoslav fighting, but at the urging of the European Community, it has stepped up its efforts. The community places most of the blame for the fighting on Serbia and the Serb-dominated Yugoslav army, which have fought to capture parts of Croatia since that republic declared independence.
 
Makeup of Yugoslav Trade
 Sixty percent of Yugoslavia's trade is with the community, while only about 5 percent is with the United States. American officials here said the Administration would probably move to deny Yugoslavia the preferential tariffs that come with most-favored-nation status, and would withhold a $5 million grant that was being made to assist Yugoslavia's transition to democracy and a market economy.
United States exports to Yugoslavia have been stagnant in recent years, totaling only $566 million last year. But Yugoslavia's exports to the United States have been growing steadily, to $773 million last year from $478 million in 1984.
Most of Yugoslavia's oil is obtained from the Soviet Union and Libya, and Moscow is said to be ready to support an embargo. Libya's position is unclear.
 
Effect of Sanctions
 A day after berating many Democrats for wanting to rely on sanctions rather than fight to oust Iraq from Kuwait, Mr. Bush said he could not say whether sanctions would succeed in ending the Yugoslav war. "I don't think anybody can predict with any accuracy that sanctions alone will solve the problems -- in Yugoslavia, in Haiti, or in Iraq, or in other places," he said. But he added that the community and the United States thought sanctions would make their position clearer to those parties in Yugoslavia refusing a cease-fire.
Asked by a journalist whether he would support a United Nations peacekeeping force to intervene in Yugoslavia, the President said, "You're too far ahead of the power curve. We're not talking about force, we're talking about economic sanctions."
In a luncheon speech in the resplendent Hall of Knights in the Dutch Parliament building, Mr. Bush made his strongest statement ever about the corrosive effect that ethnic tensions in Eastern Europe have had since the Berlin Wall came down.
"We see in Yugoslavia how the proud name of nationalism can splinter a country into bloody civil war," he said.
He said there was nothing to fear in healthy national pride, but added, "We must guard against nationalism of a more sinister sort: one that feeds on old, stale prejudcies, teaches people intolerance and suspicion, and even racism and anti-Semitism."
He said Western Europe is a model for how national frictions can be buried. "Western Europe stands as proof that in the space of little more than one generation, the spirit of democracy can transcend centuries of rivalry, war, nationalistic strife."
As part of the efforts to break the deadlock on farm trade, the President's trade representative, Carla Hills, and Secretary of Agriculture Edward R. Madigan, met with community officials here on Friday. The talks collapsed last December primarily over an American-community clash over how deeply to cut farm subsidies.
The United States has called for reducing subsidies for farm goods by 75 percent over 10 years and a 90 percent cut for export subsidies. But the community backs a 30 percent cut over 10 years starting with 1986, when the community made some cuts in subsidies.
In recent days, several European officials suggested that there was a broad outline for an agreement in which farm subsidies would be cut by 30 percent over five years.
