HEADLINE: Duke: The Ex-Nazi Who Would Be Governor

SERIES: Louisiana Showdown: Duke vs. Edwards/First of two articles

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The chant builds like a freight train and bounces off the walls in auditoriums and American Legion halls from Monroe to Metairie: "Duke, Duke, Duke, Duke."
It has become a familiar scene in Louisiana. David Duke -- an open white supremacist and anti-Semite for most of his adult life, who sold Nazi literature from his legislative office in 1989 -- stands a chance of being elected governor next Saturday. 
 Racing from Larry King to Phil Donahue, from Shreveport to Baton Rouge, Mr. Duke, now running as a mainstream conservative Republican, is basking in this moment, and the last thing he wants to do is ruin it by dwelling on the past.
"It's the same old stuff," he says with irritation as he wolfs down his chicken chow mein at the Ming Palace restaurant near his campaign headquarters. "People are sick of all that. They've heard it for two years."
 
Conceding the Link
 But in a campaign that has aroused searing racial and cultural emotions, Mr. Duke concedes a fundamental unity between his campaign now and his life spent at the dark fringes of the religious and racial right.
To hear Mr. Duke, the unity is cultural and benign, a love for Western Christian civilization that took him on a dark detour to Ku Klux Klan and Nazi activities he now disavows. "The common strain is my love for Western civilization," he said. "That's what I've always been about."
But watching a thickening stew of economic, political and racial unease, many see something far more ominous in his rise to mainstream politics.
David Duke was a voracious reader of white supremacist literature from the age of 14. An avowed Nazi in college, he is as steeped as any academic in the intricacies of eugenics and theories of racial differences.
Critics say his campaign is about developing a new vocabulary for old obsessions, a language in which images of Christian unity and "the rising welfare underclass" convey old messages in new code. Some say the fact that he is in a neck-and-neck race for Louisiana Governor means he has already won the race that matters to him.
"By the time this race is over, regardless of who wins, Duke will become the uncontested leader of the racial right in America," said Lance Hill, executive director of the Louisian Coalition Against Racism and Nazism. "Not only that, but there will be a racial right in America. He is both ascending to that position while creating it. Prior to that, there was Reagan and Bush. There was nothing to the right of that. There will be now."
"People ask who's the campaign manager," said Mr. Duke's top aide, Jim McPherson, a New Orleans lawyer. "There is no campaign manager. David Duke is the campaign manger."
Mr. Duke is in a runoff with former Gov. Edwin Edwards because of an unerring instinct for the pressure points in the American psyche that he has shown since his election to the State House of Representatives two years ago.
His first two issues were welfare abuse and the anti-tax mood of the 1980's. He made opposition to affirmative action a centerpiece of his 1990 race for the United States Senate.
Now, his message is a blend of dark and light, stories of welfare mothers and their unwanted babies contrasted with allusions to a morality based on his newly professed, born-again Christianity. His bottom-line image -- that of a nation decaying from within -- strikes a resonant chord, particularly in a state that has been reeling economically for almost a decade.
Tall, trim and blond at 41, his features enhanced by cosmetic surgery and an air of softspoken humility, Mr. Duke finished a televised debate Wednesday with a message aimed straight at middle-class fears.
"I appreciate the honorable people who have not been intimidated, who know that the time has come in this country to stand up for us, to stand up for our heritage and our way of life," he said. "Our Christian values are under attack. In some places in this country, we can't even sing Christmas carols anymore. We're losing the values the nation was built upon."
The message, combined with his incessant racially tinged attacks on welfare recipients, has made Mr. Duke the clear favorite of white Louisianans. Most political analysts believe that Mr. Edwards needs to get only about a third of white voters to win.
A recent poll showed Mr. Edwards with a lead over Mr. Duke of 55 percent to 33 percent, with 11 percent undecided. The poll, by the Marketing Research Institute of Jackson, Miss., for the magazine Louisiana Business 2000, had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Poll takers caution that surveys in past elections underestimated actual support for Mr. Duke.
 
The Man Is the Issue
 Admirers say Mr. Duke generates strong feelings less for his past than for his courage in speaking honestly about taboo topics. "I think there's a self-generated, vitriolic attack on him to engage in character assassination and dwell upon his past as a basis for rejecting what he is today," said Minos Simon, a lawyer in Lafayette and Duke supporter. "I think he's just saying something that the majority of the American people, let alone the people of Louisiana, feel."
Others see a very different David Duke.
Beth Rickey, a New Orleans Republican, talked with him for 40 to 50 hours on the phone and in person during 1989 as he tried to win her over to his views. She said his conversation was a diatribe on the primacy of race in culture, what he called "the Jewish question," and race mixing. In one conversation, she said he rattled on for so long that she dozed off -- only to awake to hear him still talking.
"He's a racial ideologue of a type that I have yet to encounter in my entire lifetime," she said. "He is not a George Wallace. He is beyond that. He is truly a type that one would find in the 1930's in Germany. He sees himself at this Messiah, that he's going to save the white race."
Mr. Duke said he was misinterpreted. "She came with preconceived ideas," he said. "She's a very strong liberal, and I'm not."
 
Words of Contrition Do Not Quiet Fears
 Whatever, the case, there is a palpable sense of fear in Louisiana as the campaign nears its finale. This week, a black television reporter, Norman Robinson, enunciated that mood during a televised debate.
"I am scared, sir," he said to Mr. Duke. "I've heard you say that Jews deserve to be in the ash bin of history. I've heard you say that horses contributed more to the building of America than blacks did. . . .Convince me, sir, and other minorities like me, why they should entrust their lives and the lives of their children to you."
Mr. Duke replied, as he usually does when challenged about past statements, with a combination of contrition and accusation: "Mr. Robinson, I don't think there's a human being on this earth or in this state who hasn't been at some time intolerant in their life. And I think that's true of white people. I think that's true of black people."
He admitted his own past intolerance, asked whether Mr. Robinson had ever been intolerant himself and went on: "I don't think you'd ask that question to him, but Jesse Jackson admitted spitting in white people's food when he worked in a restaurant as a young man." Mr. Jackson said in a 1987 interview with The Los Angeles Times that he had bragged -- falsely -- in 1969 about doing that.
The newspaper ad on the wall of David Duke's campaign headquarters in suburban Metairie quotes from Proverbs. "When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice," it says. "But when the wicked beareth rule, the people mourn."
"Rejoice with David Duke," it continues. "Mourn with Edwin Edwards."
The overt Christianity is new. But from his early teens, Mr. Duke has seen the world as a Manichaean struggle between good and evil, pure and impure.
 
An Unsettled Childhood, Then His Life Changes
 David Ernest Duke was born July 1, 1950, in Tulsa, Okla., the second of two children. The family later moved to New Orleans.
According to his biographer, Michael Zatarain, and interviews with neighbors, Mr. Duke's mother, Maxine Crick Duke, was an alchoholic who spent much of her time fearful and disoriented. His father, David Hedger Duke, a petroleum engineer, traveled extensively, including trips to Southeast Asia, where he was an engineer for the United States Agency for International Development.
According to Mr. Zatarain's biography, "David Duke: Evolution of a Klansman" (Pelican, 1990), Mr. Duke's life changed at 14, when he was asked to give an argument against integration in a term paper.
His research took him to the office of the New Orleans Citizens Council, one of dozens of such groups that sprang up throughout the South to oppose integration. He first read a book called "Race and Reason -- A Yankee View," by Carlton Putnam, which argued that history, psychology, culture and biology insured that integration would fail. After reading other books, he developed a passion for the idea that race and genetics is the dominant feature in human society.
Soon, the Citizens Council ofice became his home away from home. By high school, his interests had spread to Nazism and the Ku Klux Klan. A neighbor recalls a Nazi flag on the wall of his room. Before long, he came under the wing of Jim Lindsay, a Klan leader and rabid anti-Semite, who became Mr. Duke's mentor while his father was away.
In 1968, when he moved on to Louisiana State University, he became a fixture at L.S.U.'s Free Speech Alley castigating Jews and blacks. He called himself a Nazi and became a devotee of the Nazi leader George Lincoln Rockwell. Dressed in a Nazi uniform, he carried a sign reading "Kunstler is a Communist Jew" when William Kunstler, a lawyer often identified with liberal causes, spoke at Tulane University.
"He would talk about 'Mein Kampf,' " said William Connelly, then state chairman of Young Americans for Freedom. "He would describe how he was going to become mainstream and get elected to the Legislature. He thought Adolf Hitler's ideas were right."
After college, he switched his focus from the Nazis to James Lindsay's Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, becoming its leader or Grand Wizard in 1975 and building a reputation as a shrewd marketer for racist ideology.
Danny Welch, director of the Klanwatch project of the Southern Poverty Law Center, says Mr. Duke's performance at that time presaged his later career.
"If I had to choose anyone from the white supremacy movement to get in a position of power, it would be David Duke," he said. "He used tactics that had never been used before -- throw away the robe, put on a three-piece suit, cut your hair, and get yourself on TV."
He did something else new. He ran for office, getting 33 percent of the vote in his race for the state Senate in 1975, the first of his seven political campaigns.
 
Trying for a New Start After the Klan Days
 Mr. Duke left the Klan in 1979. Depending on who tells it, he left either because of a rift in which he was accused of trying to sell the Klan mailing list for $35,000 or because of a belief that the Klan's image carried too much negative baggage.
He spent virtually all of the 1980's consorting with those at racist fringes of society and trying to jump-start his career.
Mr. Duke had often been involved in odd ventures. In the 1970's, he wrote two books under pseduonyms. Under the pseudonym "Mohammed X," he wrote, "African Atto" a martial arts manual for black militants. He later said it was a way to develop a mailing list to keep track of potential black agitators. Under the pseudonym "Dorothy Vanderbilt," he wrote "Finderskeepers," a dating-and-sex manual for women.
In the 1980's, he was implicated in, but never indicted for, an abortive plot to set up a white supremacist regime on the island of Dominica. He went through Est, the confrontational personal development group, and used what he learned in marathon "white leadership" training sessions. He got a divorce and cosmetic surgery, and attended a conference of organizations devoted to debunking the Holocaust.
He twice ran for President, first as a Democrat with a former Nazi as a campaign manager, then as the candidate of the Populist Party, an amalgam of extremists including Neo-Nazis and Klansmen.
In 1980, he founded the National Association for the Advancement of White People, which advertises Nazi and racist books.
In 1989, his electoral efforts finally bore fruit. By a 227-vote margin, his virtually all-white district in Metairie sent him to the Louisiana Legislature as a Representative.
 
Riding a High Tide Of Voters' Resentment
 Now, he is within reach of his biggest breakthrough yet.
Virtually all of those rallying to Mr. Duke's campaign say they are attracted by rock-solid conservative issues.
"I'm not a racist; it's plain stupid to hate a whole race," said Bill Lee, a 64-year-old inventor outside Mr. Duke's headquarters. "If Duke's able to cut taxes, he'll do more for business than Edwin Edwards ever could."
Some, even some on the radical right like the white supremacist Tom Metzger, agree. They say Mr. Duke has moved toward the mainstream.
"That's what sort of amuses me, the people who are attacking him who don't think he's changed," Mr. Metzger said. "I think David Duke will make a great politician, because politicians make themselves acceptable to a majority of people."
Mr. Duke's campaign spokesman, Howie Farrell, goes further, saying Mr. Duke's born-again Christianity makes his personal history irrelevant. "I don't think once you become a professed, born-again Christian that anything prior to that matters," he said.
But those who have followed Mr. Duke say it is hard to see, aside from his vague apologies on the campaign trail and on national talk shows, where the old Mr. Duke ended and the new one started.
In taped 1985 interviews with a doctoral candidate named Evelyn Rich, he advocatd an American apartheid, denied the existence of the Holocaust, and said: "People always say it's the same old Klan package. Well, it's true from the standoint of myself. My ideology has not fundamentally changed."
In 1989, he was still selling Nazi books from his legislative office. In his long conversations with Ms. Rickey, he voiced his traditional anti-Semitic and white supremacist agenda. In a 1989 taped interview with Abby Kaplan, a student, he said: "There's only one country anymore that's all white, and that's Iceland. And Iceland is not enough.
One who has watched Mr. Duke carefully is Sam Jones, the mayor of the small town of Franklin, one of several minor candidates without enough contributions to become a serious threat in the gubernatorial primary.
After eight months of appearing at the same campaign functions as Mr. Duke, Mr. Jones says the mainstream image is a hoax. "His greatest fear is for people to find out what he really is thinking and to have a full debate on his Nazi beliefs," he said. "The mistake the press makes around here is to call him a neo-Nazi. He's not neo-anything."
He saw no signs of a tendency toward violence in Mr. Duke, but he cannot say the same for some of his followers or the movement he is building.
"I had one of them after one of the forums come up to me and say, 'How would you feel about a constitutional amendment to exterminate Jews?' " he said.
 
A Message Is Heard Far Beyond the Bayous
 Played out on the often outlandish tapestry of Louisiana politics, the story of Mr. Duke is sometimes viewed largely as a product of the state's distinctive bayou fevers.
But Mr. Jones said Louisiana's sour economy more than anything else has created an environment in which Mr. Duke has won acceptance, and that the message should not be lost on the rest of the country.
"We've been in a 10-year depression here, and now it's going to get worse," he said. "Everyone is on the edge, and they're just angry. If he didn't have the baggage he had, he could have blown this race wide open, and even with the baggage, he could conceivably be elected Governor."
Win or lose, Mr. Duke has a national visibility he could not have imagined as a fringe figure just two years ago. When asked what the race has been for him, he answers with cool reserve: "One small step."

On Whites
 "There's only one country anymore that's all white, and that's Iceland. And Iceland is not enough." -- Interview with Abby Kaplan, a Tulane University student, Nov. 29, 1989
 
On Jews
 "Well, the Jews have developed a disease and given it to us already. It's called race mixing, and they're being quite successful." -- Interview with Evelyn Rich, doctoral student, Feb. 17, 1986.
 
On Blacks
 "We don't have a program to send them back to Africa. I think that's impractical. We do feel an ideal, perhaps an impossible ideal, would be geographic separation of the races, either within this country or on an extra-continental basis." -- Interview with The Baton Rouge State-Times, 1985
 
 "I tend to believe now that it (the Holocaust), didn't happen, O.K.?" -- Interview with Evelyn Rich, March 1985.

HEADLINE: Suburban Belfast: Is It a World Apart?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland

 BODY:
The road to Bangor curls northeast from the city's center, skirting the shipyards and the bleak neighborhoods beyond the River Lagan before it opens onto the green, suburban landscape of outer Belfast.
Here are the well-tended towns of Knocknagoney and Holywood and rural County Down, where "the troubles," the euphemism used to describe three decades of sectarian strife, are more often cursed because the odd bombing has tied up traffic along the Bangor road. 
 In the poor Catholic districts along the Falls Roads or the working class Protestant quarters of the Shankhill, people refer to the city's more affluent fringe as "cloud cuckoo-land," places less than a half hour's commute from the impoverished and barbed-wire parts of Belfast, but seemingly as foreign and inaccessible as the far side of the moon.
These green quarters and suburban enclaves are the other face of Belfast, and a measure of some of the forces subtly altering the landscape of Northern Ireland, where income increasingly has become as much a factor as religion in defining the great divide.
 
Ignoring the 'Troubles'
 "The troubles are as far away for some people who live in Northern Ireland as they are for people living in the U.S., and that includes a lot of middle-class Catholics," said the Rev. Eamon O'Brien, a Catholic priest whose parish of 800 poor and mostly unemployed is in the middle of a Protestant neighborhood in East Belfast.
Some of them, he said, have become calloused by a kind of cynical determination: since they can't do anything about the troubles, they might as well move away and ignore them. "There is an indifference among such people that is as deadly as opposition," said Father O'Brien.
In this era of European union, and talk of dissolving borders and the end of national emnities, the British image makers and main-line representatives of the Northern Ireland government like to argue that change is afoot in Northern Ireland too. They say you can measure it, in part, by the numbers of fine cars and nice homes and uninvolved people whose lives area far removed from the embattled zones of Belfast and Armagh and Londonderry.
It is a proposition that seems, on first glance, difficult to believe, given the fact that the Unionists, who are mostly Protestant, and the Nationalists, who are mostly Catholic, could not even settle on a way to begin negotiating their differences, when they sat down at the abortive peace talks last summer.
 
50 Murders in 4 Months
 Moreover, the province is now enduring one of its most violent years in nearly a decade. In the last 4 months alone, nearly 50 people have been murdered, many of them apparently innocent victims chosen at random simply because of their religion.
But while unemployment in the worst ghettos still runs as high as 80 percent, and fear prevents vasts numbers of young Catholic males from searching for work outside their own neighborhoods, it is also true that the proportion of Catholics working in Government jobs here has grown over the last two decades.
After years of overt discrmination in the civil service, which accounts for nearly half of all jobs in Northern Ireland, the percentage of Catholics now employed in Government jobs, outside the security sector, is more than 39 percent, nearly equal to their percentage in the overall population, which is about 42 percent.
Since Government salaries in Belfast are comparable to London, but housing costs and other essentials are about a third less, many middle-class Catholics, like the much larger pool of middle-class Protestants, have found themselves largely insulated from the effects of the current recession.
 
Many Contrasts
 The relative prosperity and, arguably, the growing diversity of those at the upper tiers of Northern Ireland society has served to accentuate the contrasts within Northern Ireland society, between the Catholic and Protestant haves, and the Catholic and Protestant have-nots.
Here is a place where overall unemployment rates continue to hover around 14 percent, as a result of declining job opportunities in the city's shipyards and industrial sector, but where a luxury car dealership in downtown Belfast reports that sales of new cars were up by 11 percent over a year ago, and used cars by 33 percent, in spite of the recession.
Measured against the rest of Britain, Northern Ireland also has the highest percentage of students who graduate with grades at the top of their class. On the other hand, a higher percentage of Northern Ireland students, mostly from the lower economic orders, drop out of school early, with no qualifications whatsoever.
And along Great Victoria Street, in the center of city, a struggling entertainment strip has emerged over the last five years, a stretch of pubs, clubs, restaurants and fast food outlets. Here, along streets patrolled by soldiers, is the site of Belfast's first McDonalds, as well as Roscoff's, the first restaurant in Northern Ireland to receive a one-star rating from the Michelin Guide, the much coveted measure of culinary distinction.
 
View of the Door
 If anything, all of these changes only serve to make Belfast seem more surreal than ever, a place where the well-furnished reception areas of downtown offices look just as they might in London, except many doors have handles that allow them to be opened only from the inside, and local politicians literally choose their lunch tables so they have a clear view of the front door.
In one sense, the specter of terror never leaves the mind, like the police guards encased in heavy flak vests who still greet drivers outside Government parking lots each morning with a cheery hello, followed by the question: "Did you check your vehicle for bombs this morning?"
But life does go on, in some parts of the province much more comfortably than others, and there are those here say it could be a lot worse. Not long ago, the Government published a group of statistics to demonstrate that rates of burglary, assault and routine crime are lower in Northern Ireland than almost any place in the Western world, once the impact of terrorism and sectarian crime is removed.
Locals soon gave the index their own name. When it comes to "O.D.C," or "ordinary decent crime," they say, Belfast is a lot safer than London, Chicago or New York.

HEADLINE: Doubts Voiced on Yugoslav Sanctions

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSANSKA DUBICA, Yugoslavia, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The European Community's limited economic sanctions against Yugoslavia have little chance of forcing the Serbs and the Croats to end their deadly feud and find a way of sharing in peace the lands they jointly inhabit, or once did, Yugoslav economists and Western diplomats say.
"The boycott will not achieve the results expected by those who imposed it," said Ljubomir Madzar, a Belgrade University economics lecturer. 
 The European Community has banned Yugoslav textile imports, ended trade concessions to this country and dropped it from an aid program for East European countries.
The United States and Canada announced today they would follow the European Community's lead, with President Bush declaring at a news conference in The Hague today that Washington would co-sponsor a United Nations resolution calling for an oil embargo against Yugoslavia.
The Yugoslavs -- burdened with a collapsing economy -- are certain to suffer further hardship as a result of the sanctions.
"But in a state of war there are always strict priorities," Mr. Mazdar said, "and for military priorities, there will always be enough resources. The fact is that the civilian population will carry the burden of these measures."
The 12 European Community countries accounted for about half Yugoslavia's $23.3 billion in foreign trade in the first eight months of 1991. Half of that is with Germany, the country pushing hardest for sanctions.
The Europeans hope to coax the six Yugoslav republics into accepting a plan they have proposed to transform this country into a loose association of sovereign states within the republics' present borders.
 
Steps Aimed at Serbs
 The European Community has imposed the sanctions on Yugoslavia as a whole because its trade agreements with Yugoslavia are with the country's national Government and not with the governments of its republics. There is no doubt, however, that the punitive economic measures are primarily aimed at Serbia and the army.
"It is pointless to think you can direct sanctions selectively against one Yugoslav republic and leave the others untouched," said another Western envoy, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Evidence of that could be seen here in Bosanska-Dubica, a small place on the border between Croatia and the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Gas lines were long, and fuel supplies seemed to be declining day by day.

HEADLINE: NICARAGUA SEEKS TO CALM CONTRAS

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Seeking to calm the fears and angers of former contra rebels who have returned to arms, the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is reducing the army presence in the northwest of the country and has promised to incorporate former contras into the police in the area.
But one rearmed contra leader, known as Indomable, has rejected the Government 's efforts as inadequate, and officials acknowledge that the ranks of his followers grow in spurts when something occurs to upset or frighten them. 
 Concurrently, demobilized members of the Sandinista Army militia have appeared with arms again, sometimes confronting Indomable and his men in numbers as large as 100.
Minister of Government Carlos Hurtado, who has responsibility for internal security, said the police and army measures were being taken progressively as the Government continues a series of negotiations with the main group of rearmed former contra field commanders.
 
Persecution Asserted
 "If we get an agreement with those people it will solve a good part of the problem," Mr. Hurtado said in an interview Thursday. "Groups will remain, but they will be minimal."
The former contras, who fought the former Sandinista regime for a decade with backing and training from the United States, began rearming in small numbers in April. They are still thought to number considerably fewer than 1,000.
They say they made the decision because in their disarmed state, they were being killed, persecuted and threatened by the army and the police, which are still controlled by the Sandinista Front under the transition accord that followed Mrs. Chamorro's election last year.
Officials and mediators say that what sets Indomable -- whose name is Jose Angel Moran Flores -- apart from the other rearmed contras is that he is much more confrontational and has little interest in negotiating unless it is for the total dissolution of the army and the police.
 
Confrontation With Patrol
 Other than actions by Indomable, there have been relatively few actual military operations by the rearmed contras, nor have the army and the police undertaken significant operations against them.
For example, in one recent encounter between about 60 rearmed contras and an army patrol of about 30 men, what first threatened to be a battle turned into a verbal argument, then ended with the contras disarming the soldiers and ripping off the officer's epaulets.
The Government's policy has been to negotiate, and most of the rearmed contra chiefs have sought to use their arms as a means of forcing the Government to recognize their security concerns.
"In any other country, these people would be hunted down with arms," said Mr. Hurtado, referring to the rearmed contras and the Sandinista militias. "We have opted to solve this as a socio-economic problem."
Roberto Menendez, deputy chief of the observer mission of the Organization of American States, which has played a mediating role between the Government and the former contras, said one army base has already been closed -- at Pantasma in the department of Jinotega -- and that two others would follow shortly.

HEADLINE: Action Now or Next Year? Bush's Advisers Are Split Over Campaign Strategy

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The results of last week's elections exposed weaknesses in President Bush's still emerging campaign and highlighted divisions among his advisers over how to handle Mr. Bush's unofficial candidacy.
On the broadest level, White House strategists say they still envision a plan that blames Congress for the country's ills and portrays President Bush as concerned about domestic issues. But the specifics are another matter. After the Republicans' embarrassing defeat in the Pennsylvania Senate race, Administration officials and party leaders said privately that the immediate reaction was little more than a frenzy of finger-pointing. 
 "We have no quarterback," said one Administration official. "We're a football team trying to keep our heads down."
In a political operation that has not taken formal shape and has lost key leaders since Mr. Bush's victory in 1988, two main factions have emerged. One group, which includes John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and key members of the Cabinet, advise Mr. Bush to remain above the fray until he officially announces his candidacy early next year. The other, more activist group, which includes Vice President Dan Quayle and Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, argue that Mr. Bush should take the offensive now.
 
Contrast to 1988
 Mr. Bush's advisers acknowledge that the campaign at this point lacks a coordinated top management team like the aggressive duo of Lee Atwater and James A. Baker 3d that carried Mr. Bush to victory in 1988.
The White House, for its part, is abiding by its original campaign timetable, which calls for Mr. Bush to delay formal announcement of his candidacy until after he has delivered the State of the Union address in January.
"His biggest strength is being President, the governmental things he's done," said Charles Black, one of Mr. Bush's top political strategists. "He will still spend the majority of his time being President."
Even though the speculation over who will run his campaign is common in political circles, the President is resisting assembling anything that looks like a formal organization.
So far, the campaign planners include the longtime Bush advisers Mr. Black, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, the poll-taker Robert Teeter and Clayton K. Yeutter, chairman of the Republican National Committee.
None of the top advisers has titles yet, though several have begun meeting weekly to start assembling what one described as the "short-term strategy" that will be the groundwork for the campaign. But most are so conscious of Mr. Bush's desire to play down talk of a real campaign that they will either not speak for the record or not talk at all.
Others expected to play major roles in the campaign are Craig Fuller, an aide to Mr. Bush when he was Vice President and who is expected to plan the convention; Frederic V. Malek, the businessman who briefly ran the 1988 convention; Roger Ailes, a media consultant; James H. Lake, a veteran Reagan-Bush strategist; Rich Bond, the political director for Bush in 1988; Mary Matalin, the Republican National Committee's chief of staff; Richard G. Darman, the budget director; Nicholas F. Brady, the Secretary of the Treasury; Ron Kaufman, a political director, and Mr. Sununu, as well as other members of the White House inner circle.
 
Awkward and Abrupt
 Mr. Bush has been testing campaign themes that emphasize domestic issues for several weeks now, but his statements have often been awkward, as they were in Rome on Friday when he came out against "higher tax cuts."
The abrupt, panicky appearance of the decision on Election Day to cancel Mr Bush's planned trip to Asia pointed up the organizational work that remains to be done.
So far, the two main factions within the White House have not agreed on a coherent and quick-witted response to the issues that are taking center stage -- especially health-care policy and the economy.
"The Bush Administration is either focused inside Washington or outside the United States," one Administration official said. "The problem is we need to focus on the United States."
 
Missing: Two Strategists
 Both sides admit that this year's campaign lacks the sort of top management team that ran the campaign in 1988, when Lee Atwater and Mr. Baker had Mr. Bush's ear and had aggressive political instincts.
But Mr. Atwater died this spring, and Mr. Baker is not expected to play a key organizational role because of his duties as Secretary of State. Most analysts agree that, together, they supplied most of the political muscle for the 1988 campaign. Mr. Sununu was a valuable asset in the New Hampshire Primary in 1988, but some Bush insiders doubt his grasp of national politics.
"Ask me how many times today I thought of Lee," said one Republican strategist on a particularly bad day last week.
Mr. Teeter, a veteran poll-taker and longtime friend of Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush, is counted on in some quarters to emerge as a central figure who could help fill the vacuum left by Mr. Atwater and Mr. Baker. But he and Mr. Sununu have clashed in the past, and it is unclear if the uneasy peace between them can last through a tough campaign.
 
'A Year is a Very Long Time'
 For the moment, Mr. Teeter is trying to do his part for the President by playing down the long-term impact of the vote in Pennsylvania, in which Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General, was a surprise loser to Harris Wofford, the interim Senator who is a Democrat. "Off-year elections are very bad predictors," he said. "There is a lot of historical evidence of that. They certainly have some implications on issues and the sense of the country, but a year is a very long time away."
By and large, however, many of the Republicans who are spending the most time denouncing Congress, keeping an eye on announced and unannounced Democratic candidates and thinking of 1992, say Mr. Bush still has time to smooth out the rough spots.
"Let me tell you about these early wake-up calls," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who heads the National Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee. "They're almost always wrong numbers.
"Ultimately when an election is lost, people are always trying to find someone to blame," he said. "If we had won, you would have had six or seven different groups and people claiming credit."

HEADLINE: Insurers' Drive to Sell 'Bare Bones' Health Policy Falters for Lack of Interest

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
A major push by health insurers to provide affordable coverage for millions of uninsured workers is running into unexpected trouble: Employers are not buying.
And that is creating a big problem for insurers, who have furiously lobbied state legislatures and insurance commissioners to be allowed to sell these so-called bare-bones policies. 
 The insurers have argued that these policies, with more limited benefits than the standard policies, were the best way to make coverage affordable for the many small businesses and individuals who cannot pay the steep premiums for more complete coverage.
The insurers had expected to sell millions of these policies and head off Federal programs, possibly even a Government takeover of health insurance. A variety of proposals before Congress offer solutions from a universal health system to tax credits for buying insurance.
 
Dearth of Employer Interest
 The bare-bones plans, the insurers calculated, would have a strong appeal to small businesses, allowing them to appeal to more qualified workers with benefits that could be offered at little additional cost. In addition to the lower cost of the limited-benefit policies, existing Federal tax incentives and new tax incentives in some states would reduce the cost still further.
But the dearth of employer interest in these basic policies, at a time when health benefits are of paramount concern to workers, is bolstering the arguments of those who contend that the best way to provide health insurance to the 34 million Americans who lack it is by mandating it.
Most of the limited-benefit policies, some of which can cost as little as about $50 for a single person, include the benefits required in standard policies with the exception of treatment for mental illness and alcohol and drug abuse. But they require the insured to pay more on doctor bills and for hospital stays and have lower maximum benefits.
 
23 States Encourage Policies
 Already, 23 states, from New Jersey to Washington, have altered their laws to encourage the bare-bones insurance plans. Changes are under consideration in New York and a dozen other states to make the insurance available. The approach involves no new taxes and, theoretically, could save millions of tax dollars spent on caring for the uninsured.
"It's a legislator's dream," said Richard E. Merritt, director of the Intergovernmental Health Policy Proj ect, a nonprofit research organization at George Washington University. But the plan has not been popular in the marketplace.
In the half-dozen states where insurers have marketed the limited-benefit policies, relatively few employers have signed on. The main reason, they say, is that the policies are still too expensive. They generally require that employers pay at least half the premium.
But Mr. Merritt, who said he was baffled by the poor reception of the policies, asserted, "It is too early to sound the death knell on these products."
Consumer advocates, who oppose most of the limited policies as inadequate, are pleased that the plans are not selling well. "Thankfully, the marketing has been disastrous," said Arnold Bennett, a spokesman for Families USA, a nonprofit advocacy group for health care changes in Washington. "The bare-bones plan is just a decoy, a way of delaying action on more fundamental reforms that threaten the insurance industry."
Insurers have successfully sold the bare-bones idea to legislators with the argument that some coverage is better than none. But Chris Petersen, senior counsel for the Health Insurance Association of America, a commercial insurers' trade group that promotes the new concept, said, "The solution has to be greater than this little piece of the puzzle."
Groups in Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the nonprofit insurance concern, have been the first to offer the limited-benefit policies. But industry spokesmen say nonprofit health maintenance organizations and commercial insurance companies will be playing an increasingly larger role by next year.
Introduction of the bare-bones policies has also cast some light on the decades-old debate about whether state rules mandating the breadth of coverage have greatly inflated costs, as insurers have long asserted. The states' consumer protection regulations specify the minimum benefits and services that must be contained in any policy sold.
Over the years the number of mandates have swollen, going beyond setting minimal coverage for such things as hospital stays, mental health and substance abuse treatment to more controversial items such as in vitro fertilization in Maryland, hair transplants in Minnesota and herbal therapy in Connecticut.
 
Limited to Small Businesses
 The limited-benefit policies are often 25 to 35 percent less expensive than standard health insurance policies, but state insurance officials say that about two-thirds of the savings come from higher deductibles and in the amounts paid by the insured, steps that the insurers could have taken without obtaining changes in law. The policies are usually limited to businesse with 50 or fewer employees as well as to self-employed individuals.
"What we've seen indicates that if you remove all mandated coverages, it reduces rates by only 3 to 10 percent," said James T. Odiorne, health care services administrator for the Washington State Department of Insurance.
So far, the bare-bones policies have been marketed in six states, including Rhode Island, where 242 policies have been sold since September. In Illinois, Kentucky and Virginia, where insurers have been selling the policies for up to 15 months, insurers have signed up businesses with only a few hundred employees total.
"The insurers overblew the market," said Steven T. Foster, Virginia's Commissioner of Insurance. "They thought there would be 80,000 or so people who would want this product, but as it turned out only about 35 employers have opted for it."
One of those employers is the Chase Concrete Construction Company, a four-year old concern in Chesapeake with five employees. "Most of our employees are young, and you wouldn't think they would give a hoot about health insurance, but they were ecstatic about it," said Jim Johnston, the former president of the family business who now serves as its bookkeeper. He said the company and its employees split the premiums, which are $76 a month for a single person and $180 for a family.
The program, offered by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Virginia, provides maternity care, outpatient surgery, two doctor visits, a dental check-up and children's medical check-ups. It pays for up to 30 days of hospital care a year with a $250 deductible and with the insured paying 20 percent of the bill. The maximum benefit for the overall plan is $50,000 a year.
In introducing the plan in July 1990, the company estimated the market at 350,000 uninsured employees, but it has sold the plan to only 25 businesses with a total 100 employees. "We're planning to restructure the product," said Ronald H. Bargatze, an executive vice president of the insurance company.
In Washington State, insurers have enrolled only 2,300 employees since last year. And half of the enrolled employees were in businesses that were downgrading their insurance plans from more standard insurance policies, a switch that is not permitted in most of the other states experimenting with the policies.
"We're not actively promoting it anymore," said James D. Conant, a vice president of the insurance concern of Seabury and Smith in Seattle, said of the limited policies. "We don't hear of any resounding success with the product anywhere."
Mr. Conant said most small employers would not buy the policies unless forced to by law. Part of the problem is that employers do not want to cut into their profits, he said. But the recession and problems related to specific businesses play a role as well.
To some of those advocating the policies, the most disappointing sales statistics come from Oregon, which has been a leader in efforts to reform its insurance programs and laws. The Legislature, not the insurers as in most other states, defined the benefits of a bare-bones policy, making it one of the most comprehensive in the nation. The state set a base price of only $53.33 a month for a single employee; two insurers offer this low-price policy, but three others provide higher-priced bare-bones policies with more benefits.

HEADLINE: Tuskegee Announces Effort to Raise $150 Million

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Tuskegee University, one of the nation's most prominent historically black colleges, is seeking $150 million in donations by the year 2000 in the largest fund-raising effort any black college has ever attempted.
Officials of Tuskegee, founded in Alabama a century ago by Booker T. Washington,, announced the campaign at a luncheon on Wednesday in New York. 
 "We know it's not going to be easy," said Benjamin F. Payton, the university's president. "It's a monumental challenge for us, but we can't wait for the recession to end to attack the needs we have."
Dr. Payton and Andrew F. Brimmer, who is chairman of the board of trustees, said Tuskegee had already received $54 million in gifts and pledges as part of the campaign, begun in 1989. Colleges and universities typically begin raising money two or three years before they announce a campaign.
Tuskegee's effort comes as the United Negro College Fund, the consortium of 41 historically black private colleges and universities, is itself in the middle of its largest-ever capital campaign, a $250 million drive. That effort's kickoff, last year, drew widespread attention when Walter Annenberg, the financier and former Ambassador to Britain, pledged $50 million.
But officials of Tuskegee and of the College Fund, to which Tuskegee belongs, said they saw no conflict in the two campaigns. Dr. Payton said Tuskegee would continue to receive money from the College Fund throughout its own campaign.
"They're raising $250 million for 41 schools, and we support them wholeheartedly," he said. "We're raising money for ourselves and they support us. We believe, as they do, that the more each individual institution does, the easier it will be for all to benefit."
Dr. Payton said the money Tuskegee is seeking would be used for campus buildings and equipment, endowments for faculty chairs and research, student scholarships and general operating expenses.
Tuskegee's curriculum emphasizes business, scientific and technical courses, a legacy of Mr. Washington and of George Washington Carver, the Tuskegee professor and scientist who became famous for, among other things, his discoveries of the many uses of the peanut and sweet potato.
 
Trading on Value
 Education and fund raising experts agreed with Dr. Payton's assessment, saying there was no reason to believe that the College Fund and Tuskegee would be competing for the same philanthropic dollars. Charles V. Willie, a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, said Tuskegee "is pioneering in what other black colleges have to do: take the issue of their value to the larger society through fund-raising campaigns."
Dr. Willie added: "Tuskegee's courage in launching this big a campaign at the same time as the U.N.C.F. demonstrates how chronically under-funded black colleges have been. It's a challege to Tuskegee, sure. But it's also a challenge to the nation, because these colleges have to be supported for the good they do America."
Tuskegee's goal puts it in rarified company, according to George A. Brakeley 3d, a fund raising consultant. He noted that roughly 30 colleges and universities have begun efforts to raise more than $250 million each and that at least 50 are aiming for between $100 million and $250 million. Eight have set goals of $1 billion or more.
Mr. Brakeley, president of Brakeley John Price Jones of Stamford, Conn., added that, despite the recession, Tuskegee's "landmark campaign makes perfect sense" for three reasons.
 
'An Emotional Decision'
 "First," he said, "their needs aren't going to go away because of the recession. Indeed, they'll get more pressing if they leave them to fester. Secondly, the kind of big givers a campaign like this needs aren't affected by these economic downturns. They can draw from deep wells." And, he said: "Giving to a college or university is as much an emotional decision as a financial one. If the institution says it has a need, and says it in the right ways, alumni and non-alumni donors are going to give."

HEADLINE: An Institution Under Duress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
It has been a tough few weeks for Congressional committees.
First, the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearings on Judge Clarence Thomas provided material for late-night comedians. Then, two major, complicated bills -- energy in the Senate and banking in the House -- suffered embarrassing defeats on the floor. 
 And for the last two weeks, the House Ways and Means Committee has been struggling to steer to the floor a bill on extended unemployment benefits that can pass. Members' technical wrangling has failed so far, even though there is something very close to a bipartisan consensus that the time has come to stop arguing and scoring political points and find a way to send checks to the jobless.
The first three problems produced complaints that the committees were failing the Congress. Republicans complained bitterly about the banking bill that the Rules Committee put before the House, and then they helped to kill it. Environmentalists assailed the Arctic drilling provisions in the energy bill that they successfully filibustered. Almost everybody complained at one point or another about the Thomas hearings.
And while Ways and Means has escaped much public criticism over the delays on the unemployment measure, that is probably because the differences among party leaders, the two Houses of Congress and the Bush Administration are at least as much at fault and more prominent.
 
Defense of the System
 Democratic leaders insist that these difficulties do not represent a pattern. Asked about the problems with the energy bill and the Thomas hearings, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said they were just a pair of exceptions. "It's as if a pitcher gave up two home runs and struck out the other 27 batters and you said he pitched a bad game," he said.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, argued that Congress was simply "not a place where it is simple to get clear, crisp, clean solutions."
It seems less simple than it used to be. Committees and their bills are treated with less deference on the floor than in the past. Junior members now act as if their votes and opinions count for as much as those of elderly chairmen. Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that was nothing for the Congress to apologize for; "people want their members to be more independent," he said.
But sometimes the independence suggests fragmentation, or "a series of independent baronies," in the view of Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. He also complained that as committee members stay with an issue for years and become expert on it they lose touch with their colleagues and even the country and "start talking about some arcane thing as if it was real."
 
Rising Use of Filibuster
 The Senate has to contend with another institutional change that makes a committee's task of forging a coalition much harder than it once was. The increased use of the filibuster means it takes 60 votes -- the number required to shut off debate -- even to take up a controversial issue. Once reserved for matters of fundamental principle, the filibuster is now a routine tool of legislative harassment.
Divided government is another hurdle for committees. They must either shape policies so President Bush will agree with them, or find the two-thirds majorities needed to override a Presidential veto. Since he became President in 1989, all of Mr. Bush's vetoes have been upheld.
 
Bypassing Committees
 Committees were given no chance to fail when it came to the two biggest legislative issues of the year. They had little to do with the vote to go to war over Kuwait and the compromise civil rights bill. The first was played out on the floor; the second was negotiated in Capitol offices.
To Thomas E. Mann, a Congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution, a research organization, decisions like that are not a reflection of committees but a realistic understanding of their limitations. "There are times when they simply can't manage enormous political conflicts," he said.
But, Mr. Mann added, he has less sympathy when different kinds of sensitivities, approaching political panic, led the Senate to rewrite its procedures for protecting its employees from discrimination and allow them to go to court.
The Senate should have sent the issue to its Rules Committee to examine the scope of the problem and consider how to solve it, he said. But as Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, complained, "the frightened may prevail," and the political imperatives created by the Thomas hearings would not allow anything but a quick vote on the floor.
The war, the civil rights bill and the treatment of Senate staff remain an exception, though. There are more checks on committee influence than there used to be, of course, but as Woodrow Wilson wrote in 1885, "It is not far from the truth to say that Congress in session is Congress on public exhibition, whilst Congress in its committee rooms is Congress at work."

HEADLINE: Planning Company's Failure Leaves Class Reunions in Lurch

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Class reunion organizers across the nation are scrambling to put together their own celebrations after the nation's largest reunion planning company closed its doors.
"The D.J. is out -- we'll bring in a stereo if we have to," said Gayle Shearer Smith, who is helping organize a reunion in Latrobe, Pa. "We're cutting corners, but there will be a reunion." 
 The company, Reunions, A Class Organization Inc., based in the Chicago suburb Hoffman Estates, closed last week. A letter to the company's creditors said that the recession had caused its revenue to plummet and that refunds to customers were extremely unlikely.
Reunions was the nation's largest organizer of class reunions, said officials at the National Association of Reunion Planners in Washington.
 
1199 Reunions in Limbo
 The company's collapse left in limbo about 119 celebrations scheduled this month, said John Kallergis, an accountant representing the company's largest investor. The investor's identity was not disclosed, but the liquidation firm said it was owed $350,000.
Officials were unable to estimate the amount of money Reunions had collected for events that have not yet occurred, but it was more than $10,000 for some get-togethers. Lawyers for the company did not return phone calls.
The collapse left class members in Pennsylvania, Michigan, Illinois, Massachusetts and Washington, D.C., trying to put together celebrations they had paid Reunions to organize.
Organizers sought help from local businesses, negotiated with hotels and other suppliers already scheduled to provide food and entertainment for their reunions and solicited alumni for more money.
In Latrobe, the Elks lodge has agreed to accept payment over time for the use of its center. The Chicago White Sox are helping pay for a reunion planned by the company at Comiskey Park's Stadium Club, a spokeswoman, Barb Kozuh said.
Organizers said they had lost thousands of dollars the company collected by selling tickets for the coming event.
 
'What Are We Going to Do?'
 "I was in shock," said Beth Bakunowicz, chairwoman of the reunion committee of the East High School class of 1981 in Rockford, Ill. "I just kept asking myself, 'What are we going to do?' At the point I got the letter, I wasn't even sure we had a place to have the reunion."
Ms. Bakunowicz estimated her classmates had purchased at least $4,500 in tickets, and she said she did not expect to get any of the money back.

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C. Takes Over Troubled Staten Island Bank

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Community National Bank and Trust Company, one of Staten Island's largest banks, was declared insolvent Friday and most of its deposits were sold to Chemical Bank.
Although Community National's deposits were insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, that government backing will not apply to accounts that exceeded the $100,000 insurance limit. The loss on accounts of more than $100,000 will depend on how much the Government collects on the loans and other assets of the failed bank. 
 At the bank's main branch at 3511 Amboy Road in Richmond yesterday, Michael Miano, who said he was a depositor for 24 years, read the signs announcing the bank's closing and said, "There's not much we can do about it. There was never any warning or anything."
He questioned David Barr, an F.D.I.C representive, and after he was reassured that his money was safe, he said, "You know, I don't have that much, but whatever I have is mine."
 
Echoes of Freedom National
 Mr. Barr said on Friday that a week ago, there were 174 accounts at the bank holding a total of $12.6 million of uninsured deposits. He said Federal examiners did not yet know how many of those account holders -- mostly local businesses and individuals whose accounts would exceed $100,000 when interest was paid -- withdrew funds in the past week. The fully insured deposits at the bank totaled $321.8 million and were spread among 47,400 accounts.
The F.D.I.C.'s decision to cover only insured depositors was similar to its handling of the Freedom National Bank, a black-owned Harlem bank that failed last year. Freedom National's failure resulted in losses for several churches and other nonprofit organizations that held some of the $11 million in uninsured deposits at the bank. At Freedom, insured depositors were paid by the Government because there was no other bank willing to bid for the deposits.
Community National depositors with accounts of up to $100,000 will have access to their money on Tuesday, the F.D.I.C. said. In the meantime, checks drawn on Community National, up to the insurance limit of $100,000, will continue to be honored.
"My stuff is insured," said Steve Demizio, who stopped by the bank yesterday. "But if this one is at fault, what about the next one, and the next one? What are you going to do, put your money under your mattress at night?"
Community National was a victim of the ailing New York economy, particularly declining real-estate values. The bank was a heavy lender for construction of new projects and other commercial real-estate loans, which accounted for more than 40 percent of its assets.
In 1990 the bank lost $17 million. Earlier this year regulators forced the bank to sign agreements to improve its lending practices, change management, and strengthen its finances. By late October, the bank's growing financial problems caused it to miss an interest payment on bonds it had issued.
For larger banks that have failed, like the Bank of New England in Boston, uninsured depositors have avoided losses because government regulators have made payments to other banks that agreed to accept all the deposits of the failed bank. Those large banks have been handled differently because government officials say the losses could be too disruptive to the financial markets and the local economy.
After Federal bank examiners decided a week ago that Community National was insolvent, Chemical Bank on Monday submitted the best of two bids received for the bank's deposits. As recently as Oct. 23, Community National was expecting to stay in business, and announced the hiring of Keith L. Dalrymple, a bank executive from Addison, N.Y., as its new chief executive.
The six branches of Community National -- five on Staten Island and one in Brooklyn -- will open for business on Tuesday, following the Veterans Day bank holiday tomorrow. Chemical, which already operates four branches on Staten Island, agreed to pay $972,000 for the deposits.

HEADLINE: FIRE INVESTIGATION ANGERS L.I. POLICE

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
When fire destroyed the Long Island mansion of Reginald Lewis last week, the chairman of a big New York food processing company, Mr. Lewis telephoned his friend Mayor David N. Dinkins for help.
The Mayor phoned Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown, spokesmen for City Hall and the Police Department said, and two police arson specialists were dispatched to study the ruins of the mansion in Amagansett. 
 Suzanne Trazoff, the spokeswoman for the Police Department, said yesterday that she did not see anything wrong with sending two officers working for the city to provide personal assistance to a leading businessman with a problem in an outlying community. Leland T. Jones, the spokesman for City Hall, said he was not sure.
But both said it had been wrong for the city police not to notify the police on Long Island that two specialists were coming out. And they said that it had definitely been out of line for Lieut. Phil Pulaski, the head of the arson squad, and one of his sergeants to identify themselves at the scene of the fire as a lawyer and an arson consultant. The incident was first reported in Newsday.
 
Displeasure in East Hampton
 In East Hampton Township, which includes Amagansett, the police were not pleased that they were not notified of the city's helping hand. They refused to let the strangers cross their police lines around the mansion and only learned that they were from the New York police department through a computer check of the license plate of their unmarked detective's car.
"They were told to be unobtrusive," Ms. Trazoff said. "They were not told not to identify themselves, but that was their interpretation."
No one in East Hampton complained formally until Thursday, the day after the fire, when Thomas L. Scott, the Chief of Police in East Hampton Township, returned a call from David W. Scott, the highest-ranking uniformed officer in the city. They are not related.
"I pointed out that we were aware that two of their people were out here and that we were upset that they didn't identify themselves," the Long Island chief said. "He apologized profusely. The guy apologized and that was enough."
A short time later, Commissioner Brown telephoned. "He told me it was a matter of miscommunication," the Long Island chief said. "He just wanted me to know it should not have happened and that he was sorry about it."
There were, said the Mayor's spokesman, "obviously some protocol problems," but he added he was not sure that anything was improper.
 
'Problem of Celebritidom'A Matter of Courtesy
 It was all really a matter of courtesy, Mr. Jones said, and what he described as "the problem of celebritidom in New York." It was not, he said, just that Mr. Lewis and the mayor were friends.
"That was one of the reasons," Mr. Jones said. "But the other reason is that he's the head of a major business in the city and this is just the kind of courtesy you extend to the heads of institutions in the city -- the publisher of a newspaper, the head of a church, a major businessman or a sports celebrity. You take their calls and if they need help you generally provide them with help."
The East Hampton police chief said the mansion, which he valued "in the millions," had "completely burned." He said his investigators had not yet been able to figure out what started the fire. He said he could not rule out arson, but added that nothing so far suggested criminal activity.
Mr. Jones said Mr. Lewis, the chairman of Beatrice Foods, is a friend of the Mayor and an acquaintance of the Police Commissioner who serves on the Mayor's appointed Council of Economic Advisers.
Ms. Trazoff said she checked with city lawyers and had been assured that nothing illegal had taken place. "It's really very simple," she said. "Mr. Lewis called the Mayor. The Mayor called the Police Commissioner and asked if he could help Mr. Lewis. The Commissioner called Mr. Lewis and offered his assistance. Mr. Lewis said he just needed some advice. So the Commissioner asked the chief of the deparment who asked the chief of detectives if they could make some one available to advise Mr. Lewis. And two detectives were sent out, not to do an investigation but to give Mr. Lewis some advice. No one is being disciplined because of this."
Henry J. Stern, head of the Citizen's Union, a civic group, faulted the Dinkins administration for its handling of the matter.
"What was done here was done so poorly," he said. "It's obvious that the local cops blew the whistle. The local force was rightly insulted. That made it into a farce."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Virgin Islander Has Shot at 5 Olympics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
With health and even a hint of ability, Seba Johnson of the United States Virgin Islands has a chance to do something not even Sonja Henie, the legendary figure skater of Norway, could achieve.
The youngest skier in the 1988 Calgary Olympics, at 14 years of age, Johnson is well positioned to compete in five Winter Olympics, one more than Henie and two other women who share the record for the winter games. 
 Johnson is an Alpine specialist who finished 28th in the giant slalom in Calgary. More important to the Virgin Islands, she served as a pioneer of sorts, becoming the first skier to represent the United States territory in the Winter Olympics, along with athletes who competed in the bobsled and luge events.
For Albertville, the Virgin Islands Olympic committee plans to enter Johnson and a second skier, John Campbell, as well as teams in bobsled, luge and curling.
"I wish the Virgin Islanders youth would get more interested in skiing," Johnson said from her dormitory room at the University of Maine, where she is a freshman, enrolled in the ski-industry management program.
"I'm going down there in December for a few days to talk to kids at some of the schools. I'm going to try to get them interested in racing or, at least, in skiing."
If it has taken some doing to get young athletes involved in winter sports, the Caribbean weather might be one reason. There isn't much snow in the Virgin Islands, and athletes like Johnson, who was born in Frederiksted on St. Croix, generally move elsewhere to live and train. Johnson was 7 when she and her mother moved to Kittery, Me. Her parents had divorced four years before, and her father returned to his country of birth, Burundi.
 With the new four-year cycle for the Winter Olympics starting in 1994, Johnson has a reasonable chance to compete that year in Lillehammer, Norway, when she would be 20, four years later in Nagano, Japan, and in 2002, when she would be just 28, a prime age for Alpine skiers.
Improved as a skier since Calgary, she was less concerned over a better finish in Albertville than in setting a good example for the young people of the islands.
"They all write me fan letters," she said. "They love me down there."
 
Bruised, and Now Blond
 It has been quite an autumn season for Christopher Bowman, the former United States national champion figure skater who has never quite fulfilled the greatness expected of him. Several weeks after winning Skate America in Oakland two months ago, he was punched in the face in downtown Toronto, suffering a broken bone around his right eye.
Bowman said he was leaving the home of his coach, Toller Cranston, when he was approached by a woman asking for money. After refusing, two males appeared. He said one tried to choke him; the other hit him with his fist.
For two weeks, Bowman thought subsequent medical attention was unnecessary despite bruising, swelling, blurred vision and occasional discomfort. Finally, after consulting a doctor, he underwent surgery to repair his cheek, which had fallen several centimeters as a result of the blow.
"But I'm fine now," he said the other day. "I'm feeling great and looking great."
He might have added, looking different. In a recent moment of whimsy, he had his jet-black hair dyed blond. He left his eyebrows black, along with his recently produced goatee. "It's pretty scary," he said. "Halloween just came a few days late for me."
But then he swore the reason for the hair-color change was not altogether frivolous.
"It's the pre-Olympic pressure," he said. "Now, people look at me and they don't want to talk about the Olympics. They want to talk about my hair. It's a way of turning the tables on them."
 
The Luge and Its Legions
 Luge is one of those arcane sports that elude the public eye in most places, including the United States, until the next Winter Olympics. Even at that, people in few countries are likely to notice. At the 1988 Olympics in Calgary, just 23 countries sent athletes to slide down the track on those tiny sleds, less than half the nations represented by skiers.
In an attempt to expand the sport's popularity, the international federation for luge began conducting an outreach program after Calgary to introduce the sport to countries without a track or without a luge program. By Albertville, as many as 30 countries are expected to compete.
"We feel the program has been very successful," Jan Steler, the secretary general of the federation, said from his office in Marseilles, France. "We now have more athletes from more small countries than we ever had before."
The program is funded by the federation, using coaches and former world-class athletes as instructors, and by the International Olympic Committee. Among the countries or territories participating have been Spain, New Zealand, Sri Lanka, Bermuda, the Virgin Islands of the United States and Puerto Rico. After Albertville, Steler said, the program will be expanded to reach luge-less countries in Oceania.
 
Unity Campaign Planned
 Administrators at the European Community headquarters in Brussels have planned a unity campaign for Albertville to celebrate the elimination of economic borders on the continent next year -- and to assuage any fears. They intend to flood competition venues with European Community banners, flags and posters and disseminate information through an exhibition inside a Euromobile and over a community-sponsored channel that will be transmitted to high-definition televisions placed in public places throughout the Olympic venues. . . . The mayors of the various villages in which Olympic events will be held complained at a news conference in Paris last week that occupancy rates for the season, normally at capacity, will be no more than 70 percent through the Games. Higher prices than usual might have something to do with it, but they didn't mention that. The mayors also announced that no cars would be allowed into the various areas within three hours of a competition. Spectators will be taken in and out by bus. . . . The sluggish economy has not left the United States Olympic Committee budget untouched. Officials said recently that they would reduce expenditures by up to 3 percent for 1992 although they promised that athlete-assistance programs would not be affected.

HEADLINE: All Those Tax Cuts: Fool's Gold

 BODY:
Last Tuesday, the 1992 campaign began for real. The parade of personalities was finally coupled to the engine of real issues.
Pennsylvanian voters, for instance, showed how much they care about jobs and health care by electing unheralded Harris Wofford to the Senate. Within hours, Republican senators were talking about health care reform and tax cuts, and Dan Rostenkowski, the Democratic chairman of the House tax-writing committee, proposed cutting taxes on middle-class families. 
 Health care reform is essential. The various tax-cut proposals are reckless. They risk selling out the future.
Election-year tax cuts for the middle class: that sounds like the purest political honey. Sponsors rationalize the idea by claiming such tax cuts will propel the economy out of recession and lift an unfair burden. It's a false promise.
Tax cuts are an ineffective way to fight recession; by the time a proposal could wind its way into law and affect the economy, the recession will almost certainly be over. Besides, under current law, Congress is required to offset tax cuts with spending cuts or tax hikes. The net impact on the economy would be zero.
Of the many tax-cut plans before Congress, Mr. Rostenkowski's is the best. It would provide modest tax relief to 80 percent of all taxpayers. He proposes giving a two-year tax credit of at most $400 to a working couple. Families too poor to owe tax would get the credit as cash.
Mr. Rostenkowski would pay for the credit by permanently raising the tax on couples earning more than $145,000 to 35 percent and placing a 10 percent surcharge on taxable income above $1 million.
The plan does a lot that's right. It would not bust last year's budget law, thereby maintaining Congress's pledge to control the deficit. And it would not burn up the peace dividend to pay for tax cuts, but would preserve it for desperately underfunded public programs.
But good as Mr. Rostenkowski's plan is, even it is perilous. By raising the tax on the richest families to 38.5 percent, it invites -- begs -- Congress to undo the Tax Reform Act of 1986. For one thing, Congress would be sure to cave in to President Bush's obsessive campaign to cut the tax on capital gains. And that in turn would start a rush to restore other wasteful tax shelters that were swept away in 1986. All told, much more harm than good.
The middle class is suffering, but not because taxes are unusually onerous. The problem is that for 20 years now, earnings have stagnated. The only solution is to raise workplace productivity. And that requires massive new public and private investment in job training, education, equipment and infrastructure.
Finding the money won't be easy. Starting in 1994, Congress will be forced to make huge cuts in domestic programs to meet its deficit targets. The only way out of the bind is to cut defense significantly beyond the huge reductions already scheduled. Either that or raise taxes.
Congress cannot afford to use the peace dividend to pay for tax cuts when it will need every dollar it can find to pay for the investments needed for prosperity.
It will take intelligent, honest candidates to carry that message to the public. Middle-class tax cuts are fool's gold.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
How to Beat the Democrats

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
President Bush's new campaign strategy of bashing Congress will defeat some Congressional Democrats, but it won't get him re-elected. It leads only to blind alleys. And if Mr. Bush pushes it to extremes, as he did last week by canceling his trip to Asia, he will undermine his own great strength in foreign policy.
Mr. Bush's outside political advisers plus his chief aide, John Sununu, advocate bashing. "All he's got to do is to create an enemy, and the enemy is Congress," Charles Black, a Republican political consultant told me by way of explaining the strategy launched by Mr. Bush two weeks ago in Texas. "Even if the public doesn't like the President, they don't like Congress more," Mr. Black said. "He's got to become more confrontational." 
 Many inside Bush advisers such as White House aides Richard Darman and Brent Scowcroft along with Secretary of State James Baker and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady counsel less confrontation with Congress and more "Presidential" action. They're on the right track, given the many cynical legislative games now being played by Democrats. If only Bush aides could come up with some Presidential-quality ideas on domestic problems and the economy, they might be able to sell their case.
But they don't have any good ideas. So all they can do is punch holes in the bashing strategy that at best is shortsighted and at worst is dumb politics. Here's what they can say:
* Mr. Bush will not find it easy to blame Congress for a weak economy when history shows the public eventually holds the President more accountable than Congress for financial ills. That's what is popping up in the polls as hard times set in. A recent Gallup poll shows that for the first time in years people put Democrats ahead of Republicans as the party better able to manage the economy.
* He cannot beat up on Congress about the economy and, at the same time, insist that the economy is not all that bad. The Bush line remains that there is no recession, only a "lack of consumer confidence." And if he does start acknowledging bleak prospects, he's got to have a program for rebuilding confidence -- and he doesn't have one.
* Mr. Bush will be hard put to portray Congress as irresponsible one day and make deals with it the next. If he signs the civil rights bill as expected, he cannot go around condemning Congress for legislating quotas. If he and the Republicans want to share political credit for extending unemployment benefits or health care, they will have to work closely with Democrats.
* In any war over taxes, Democrats can outbid the President. Mr. Bush is stuck to suspect schemes like reducing the capital gains tax for wealthy investors. Democrats can always counter with tax-the-rich proposals. They can also advocate tax cuts for the middle class, while Mr. Bush has to worry about the effect of such cuts on his efforts to reduce interest rates.
* Mr. Bush will have trouble deflecting Democratic attacks about not paying attention to the home front, and still do what he should abroad. Yet he must -- for the national interest and his own.
He had to go to the NATO summit meeting in Rome last week or forfeit America's vital leadership role in Europe. He has to be involved from time to time in Mideast talks or there will be no progress toward peace. He has to reschedule his trip to Asia, particularly to Japan and South Korea, because trade with Pacific Rim countries is critical to American well-being. His deft handling of such issues, including the war against Iraq, is what made him a popular President in the first place.
Mr. Bush may think his declaration of war against Congress will serve him as well as Harry Truman's fight against a Republican Congress in the 1948 Presidential campaign. If so, he's got things backward. That feisty Democratic President had a visionary domestic program and challenged Congress to approve it or pay the political consequences. Mr. Bush has no such program for what ails the country. If he fails to present plausible and compelling domestic legislation, voters will read his attacks for what they now are -- a cover for an empty shelf of ideas.
Of course, Mr. Bush's final campaign strategy will have to await the choice of his Democratic rival. But whoever the opponent, Mr. Bush's best strategy will be not to brawl with Congress, but to govern.
