SECTION: Section 4; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 743 words

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Bush's Strong Suit

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
President Bush seems rattled by sudden pressures to turn his attention to domestic problems. But even as he tried at his Rome news conference to change the subject, he sounded a warning that next year's Democratic nominee would do well to heed.
First, Mr. Bush beat his breast with words voters are likely to hear in 1992 as often as they heard "Willie Horton" in 1988: 
 "If I had had to listen to advice from the United States Senate leadership, the Democrats -- or from the House, the leadership over there -- to do something about the Persian Gulf, we'd have still been sitting there in the United States, fat, dumb and happy, with Saddam Hussein maybe in Saudi Arabia."
That may not be the political sledgehammer it appeared to be last winter. For one thing, it's not true -- Democrats supported the original dispatch of U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia, as well as economic sanctions on Iraq; and no one but Mr. Bush suggests that Saddam Hussein would have invaded Saudi Arabia after these actions.
More to the point, however, are the indications of polls and focus groups that euphoria over the desert war has largely faded, owing to disappointment at an inconclusive outcome that left Saddam Hussein in power, and to concern for the domestic economy.
But in a more potent vein, Mr. Bush added that though Americans are hurting economically and need help, "They don't need the President to forswear his obligations for national security and foreign affairs."
They certainly don't, and any President who did so, or even appeared to, would court defeat. One reason, of many, why Jimmy Carter was not re-elected in 1980 was widespread public doubt about his willingness and capacity to represent the nation forcefully in its foreign and security policies.
Americans like to think their nation is No. 1 in the world, which is why the quick desert victory was so cheering -- if only briefly -- to a people hungry for a demonstrable victory. Whatever else they may think of their President, they expect him, as their representative, to be a formidable figure on the world stage. Winning a war, as Mr. Bush did, tends to make any President just such an international champion.
Thus, any candidate the Democrats nominate to run against Mr. Bush next year is not likely to win merely by denouncing the President on the economy (unless the country is in a Depression on a scale approaching 1932) and other domestic issues. Those issues make Mr. Bush vulnerable; but voters also will have to be convinced that if a Democratic challenger is elected, the nation's foreign interests and its military security will be in strong, reliable hands.
This is more nearly a problem of personality than of experience. Ronald Reagan, for instance, was elected in 1980 with no foreign or security policy experience; but the public saw him as more trustworthy in these fields than Mr. Carter, whose standing as a tough guy had been hurt by his inability to win or force release of the hostages then held in Iran.
Similarly, in 1992, the problem for a Democratic nominee will not be the debatable question of his or her party's role in the desert war; rather, it will be that Mr. Bush himself organized an international coalition, led it and the nation, and won a war, however messy its diplomatic results. In doing so, he became "Presidential"; he showed himself capable of the primary duty the people demand of their leader -- strong assertion and defense of American interests in the world.
That may be a commentary on Americans -- that war is more convincing to them than, say, the peace that Jimmy Carter maintained. But for the politics of 1992, the real question is whether any Democrat can match George Bush's claim to be a proven Presidential figure, validated by war and victory.
It won't be easy and it probably can't be done by pointing the finger at Mr. Bush on domestic issues alone, vulnerable though he may be. Many voters hold the Democratic Congress, not to mention governors and legislatures, equally or more culpable. The President and his advisers will not hesitate to blame Democrats for domestic failures, as Mr. Bush did at Rome.
A renewed security crisis -- in the Middle East, for example, or in the former Soviet Union -- would quickly direct attention abroad again. Even the economy is strongly influenced by international affairs. That's George Bush's strength, and the Democratic nominee will have to deal with it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); SAUDI ARABIA (93%); IRAQ (79%); GULF STATES (72%);

HEADLINE: Conflicted on Europe

BYLINE: By Zbigniew Brzezinski; Zbigniew Brzezinski was national security adviser in the Carter Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Within a month, two cities in Europe are likely to symbolize a basic challenge to U.S. policy toward Europe. In Maastricht, in the Netherlands, the European Community's heads of government will seek to reach a breakthrough agreement on political union. And in Kiev, the Ukraine's legislators are likely to formalize their state's independence of any Soviet and thus Russian control.
Whatever the outcomes -- and these efforts will face many complications -- both represent historical milestones. Both will change Europe's political map. Both will contribute to the further redistribution of global power. And both will soon require a strategically sound and timely United States response to complex, even potentially dangerous, new dilemmas. 
 The painful fact is that U.S. policy and rhetoric concerning these basic choices have been strangely in conflict. We have proclaimed a thousand times that we would like to see a unified Europe -- a true U.S. partner in promoting economic progress, European security and global peace. We have said we want America and Europe to assume equal responsibilities, especially in the costly defense area. But when confronting the choice of whether to facilitate or obstruct genuine European political -- hence, also military -- unity, the U.S. at best waffles and at worst impedes.
We want European unity but feel uneasy about the European Community's growing economic power. We want Europe to stand on its feet politically and militarily, but we object to efforts to create a European defense structure by obstructing French and German efforts to link the Western European Union -- a purely European military coordinating structure -- with the community.
In practice, though not in rhetoric, we tend to be closer to the prevailing views of the British Tories, who would prefer not to see the emergence of a federal Europe endowed with political and military decision-making organs. Is such a stance wise and in keeping with the needs of the times?
Europe is groping for a new sense of self-definition, and it perceives a new destiny, especially with the collapse of Communism. A larger Europe up to the Bug River, Poland's eastern frontier, is becoming possible, perhaps less than 15 years from now. A larger Europe could offer hope to the millions liberated from Communism but fearful that post-Communism will increasingly mean poverty. And a larger Europe could be a stabilizing world power.
But before a wider Europe comes into being, it must first become deeper, and soon. Unless an integrated, increasingly federal Europe takes visble shape, there is danger that unity will not only become so diluted that it becomes meaningless but that Europe will be submerged by a wave of xenophobia and ethnic antagonisms. Every Western European country is susceptible to this danger, and the danger is rising.
In the absence of a genuine federal development, Europe is likely to remain powerless and increasingly vulnerable to a renewal of old national conflicts. Its failure to cope with the Serbian-Croatian war dramatically illustrates the urgent need for a Europe capable of acting as one politically. The inevitable rise in German economic power reminds us why it is essential to create joint and truly binding political institutions. An integrated Germany can be a locomotive of economic growth; a dominant Germany in a politically disjointed Europe can be a source of conflict.
All of this argues for a significant adjustment in U.S. policy. The Maastricht meeting will surely not overcome all the obstacles on the way to a federal Europe, but one of them should not be an America that is shortsighted in its European perspectives. Of the two competing visions of Europe's future -- the French-German and the British -- the first deserves American support.
American policy toward the crisis in the Soviet Union is also out of focus. Our rhetoric has traditionally favored democracy, pluralism and self-determination. But that theme has been overshadowed by one that is closer to real U.S. policy: that it is somehow in the interest of "stability" that a "Soviet center," preferably with Mikhail Gorbachev at the helm, be preserved.
The unintentional consequence of such a position might be a showdown between Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin. Claiming that he has the support of Western leaders and that "the main issue for them is the preservation of the union," Mr. Gorbachev is positioning himself as the defender of "the union" and "the benefits of socialism," both allegedly threatened by Mr. Yeltsin's reforms. This is bound to appeal to the Army, the last institution of central power.
But "the center" of the former Soviet Union can be restored only by coercion. The nations of the former Russian empire have awakened politically. Most will not accept a political center in the Kremlin. It is doubtful that even coercion would obtain compliance, but there is danger that misguided Western statements could encourage the Army to try coercion. (Early Western statements urging the preservation of Yugoslavia may have encouraged the Serbians' recourse to arms.)
The Soviet economy can be rebuilt only from the bottom up, on a highly decentralized basis. That renders useless, even counterproductive, notions of reform conducted by "the center." Western aid can be productive only if related directly to republican, even regional, governments, which are more capable of dealing with very diverse local problems.
In any case, on Dec. 1 the Ukraine will certainly vote for independence and then assert it. That, in turn, will force the Russians to redefine their political identity, which will not be easy. The gifted but troubled Russian people will face the question of whether they wish to remain an imperial nation destined to rule their neighbors, no matter what and no matter at what cost even to themselves, or to become a normal, increasingly modern and democratic European nation.
A moment of truth is thus approaching, but not only for the Russians. If the U.S. and the rest of the West refrain from recognizing the legitimate right of the Ukrainians to a sovereign state, they will encourage a crisis in Russian-Ukrainian relations. And rather than helping Russia define itself as a modern and post-imperial state, the West will reinforce its declining but still strong imperial impulses.
American strategy toward the former Soviet Union thus needs historical updating. We can help the Russians and non-Russians make the difficult transition to the post-Communist era only if we recognize and try constructively to channel the new political realities.
And since the Ukrainians' rejection of continued subordination cannot be avoided and the international significance of this stand cannot be ignored, a revision of America's position is needed. It is wrongheaded to ignore Ukrainian aspirations and even worse to twist Canada's arm to get Canada to renege on its plans to recognize the Ukraine's independence.
Instead, the West should seek to insure that the consequences of Ukrainian independence are benign. The Ukrainians are almost certain to favor a long-term economic agreement with Moscow and the other former Soviet republics. The Ukraine intends to be a non-nuclear state, while loose talk of an eventual army of 450,000 men (fewer than the current Soviet deployment of more than one million on the republic's soil) was largely the result of an effort to figure out what to do with the 600,000 Ukrainians in the Soviet Army.
The separation of the Ukraine, the second largest republic, will mean that the Soviet Government will in effect cease to exist. Its international responsibilities and nuclear weapons will be inherited by the Russian state. The dangerous division of power between Mr. Yeltsin (and the Russian state) and Mr. Gorbachev (and the Army) might thus be ended.
A formula I recently discussed in Kiev with the Ukrainian leaders would provide for a League of Sovereign States to replace the fading Soviet center. Much like the British Commonwealth, the league would not be a state (nor a U.N. member) but a coordinating and consultative organ, headed by a respected but not a policy-making figure.
The league could have mechanisms for arbitrating disputes and even for some coordination of policy. But, most important, over and above an open economic association, it would be based on the principles of pluralism and self-determination instead of imperial subordination.
Certainly, this would be in keeping with the best interests of all concerned. And this is why the time is ripe for a readjustment of U.S. policy. Maastricht and Kiev challenge us to define worthy and relevant goals for American policy in Europe. These can be stated directly: a federated European Community, and a League of Sovereign States in place of the former Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Rid American Sports of Racial Stereotypes;
Diversity's Pitfalls

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 28 front-page article about the debate at New York City's Hunter College on what to teach about diversity understates the opposition at faculty hearings to the proposed curriculum changes. 
 Two of the three proposed requirements -- courses on women and American minorities -- lack clear intellectual rationale. Political agendas and emotional sentiments, rather than reasoned thinking on the requirements of a liberal education, better explain why some groups -- blacks and Hispanic Americans, for example -- are included in Hunter's definition of minorities while Scottish-Americans, the disabled and the working class are excluded.
Moreover, contrary to the assertions of group advocates, the college curriculum already reflects considerable diversity, both in the range of courses and through the steady incorporation of sound scholarship on ethnicity, race, class and other group characteristics into the mainstream of academic disciplines.
The third proposed requirement, for a course on non-Western culture, would be more defensible if Hunter first required students to study Western civilization. There are many good reasons to study foreign countries and cultures, especially at a time of revolutionary changes in international politics and growing global economic competition. But it makes no sense to explore other cultures and civilizations without standards of historical and comparative perspective.
Increasingly, it seems only the best students are acquainted with the ideals of the European Enlightenment. An alarming number cannot even identify the differences between democracy and totalitarianism. More than 15 percent of the students in one of my classes recently equated the policies of Nazi Germany and the Bush Administration, stating that both: "systematically oppressed lots of people, including the homeless"; "were imperialists who started wars," and sought a "new world order to take over the world."
Hunter may benefit from revision of its curriculum, but the proposed diversity requirements are intellectually unsound and likely to be counterproductive.
 
CYNTHIA ROBERTS
Lecturer in Political Science
Hunter College, CUNY
New York, Oct. 29, 1991

HEADLINE: A Nice Stadium, In Any Event

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
An important element in "Trials Face a Hurdle Named David Duke," (The Times, Nov. 6) about the 1992 New Orleans Olympic track and field trials and David Duke's gubernatorial candidacy has been omitted. 
 The New Orleans bid to be host to the trials was considered a million-to-one shot by track and field insiders, especially given the sorry state of the proposed venue, 55-year-old Tad Gormley Stadium. But with one of the most depressed economies in the United States, the New Orleans Sports Foundation raised $7 million in public and private funds -- nearly $5 million more than was required -- to bring the stadium up to minimum specifications.
Whether Louisiana voters vault Duke into political legitimacy or not, the city of New Orleans and the sports community in general will be left with a world-class facility -- thanks to the efforts of the New Orleans Sports Foundation.
 
MATT SCHECKNER
New York
 
The writer is chairman of the National Association of Sports Commissions.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1605 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 3-8

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
The Market Get Jittery Over Maxwell's U.S. Holdings 

Though Robert Maxwell spent his career building a business that spans the globe, 90 percent of the profits of the Maxwell Communication Corporation -- about $352 million -- come from the United States. "The businesses have performed more strongly than Maxwell really had any right to expect," said William Reilly, former president of Maxwell Communication. Still, there is nervousness among investors that Mr. Maxwell paid too much for his American holdings and that his heirs would be forced to sell assets. Interest payments last year were $344.96 million, almost entirely offsetting profits. Last week, David Shaffer was named Maxwell chief executive. Though he has experience in American business, as head of Macmillan since 1990, his appointment did not qualm market jitters over Mr. Maxwell's death. Maxwell share prices fell in London to about $1.20, down almost 50 percent for the week.
 
 
Compaq's New Chief Moves In
 
Eckhard Pfeiffer is moving swiftly to rewire the ailing Compaq Computer Corporation. After just two weeks on the job as Compaq's chief executive, Mr. Mr. Pfeiffer outlined a new business strategy. Costs will be cut and the company will bring out a new line of cheaper PC's. It will also drop the price on some of its notebook computers by 25 percent and set up a new distribution system. Mr. Pfeiffer said he was also putting a new top-management team in place. Wall Street was pleased with Mr. Pfeiffer's remarks. The company's stock (it was in the $50 range in May) gained a little ground. Its shares rose $1.25, to $27.875, on the announcements and closed the week at $26.50.


Another Alliance for I.B.M.
 
Big Blue was once considered aloof. No more. Last summer, the International Business Machines Corporation announced plans to join forces with Apple Computer Company, Thinking Machines Corporation, Germany's Siemens and Japan's NEC. Last week, I.B.M. announced one more. It formed a 10-year pact to jointly design computer chips for PC's with the Intel Corporation. Intel makes the chips that are at the heart of most PC's. The new pact gives I.B.M. the right to buy Intel's chips first. It also allows I.B.M. to modify them. It gives "I.B.M. the flexibility to build things the other guys don't have," said Michael Slater, the publisher of Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter.


An Industry Running on Fumes
 
The automobile industry's octane rating could use a little boost right now. Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America for October were down 8 percent at the end of October. Business has been so bad that Standard & Poor's issued a credit watch "with negative implications" to creditors of the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company.


Can Pepsi Catch Up?
 
When it comes to globalization, no company knows more than the Coca-Cola Company, which gets 80 percent of its profits from abroad. Those profits have been the been the fizz behind Coke's 20 percent annual growth rate over the last five years. For arch-rival Pepsico Inc. -- which outsells Coke in the United States but not elsewhere -- that smarts. So last week Pepsi said it will invest $1 billion in Spain over five years to build plants, fast-food restaurants and distribution system. Is Pepsi trying to be more like Coke? "All companies in the United States are trying to become more like Coke," said David A. Goldman, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.

 
Lockheed's Stock Ploy
 
The Lockheed Corporation said last week it would purchase 6.3 percent of its outstanding shares of common stock. At current prices, that will cost the company $180 million. The announcement came after the company had pared down its debt and won a number of large Pentagon contracts, including one to build the Air Force's next-generation fighter plane. After a tough proxy battle last year with Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, Lockheed's management said it would do more for investors. Last week, it revealed what it would do: Buy them out.


Rating Off at American Express
 
A stellar credit rating is something the American Express Company has rarely been without. But last week, Moody's downgraded about $7 billion of Amex's long-term debt. That was a first. The turmoil at its Shearson Lehman Brothers subsidiary did not help the company. Nor did defaults from its Optima credit card holders. While still investment grade, Amex's borrowing costs are expected to rise slightly from the ratings change.
 
Last week, American Express dropped Ogilvy & Mather, its green-card account ad agency, for Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York.
 
 
Mr. Olasky's Charity Litmus Test
 
Each year, Marvin Olasky, a journalism professor at the University of Texas at Austin, grades corporations on their philanthropy. The worst? Dayton Hudson, one of the most generous corporate contributors in America, got an "F" last week. Dayton Hudson gave money to "groups that lobby for increased government welfare, which increases dependency," he said. Which groups are those? The Children's Defense Fund and the Center for Community Change. Top marks -- a "B plus" -- went to the FMC Corporation. It gave money to the conservative Heritage Foundation, where Mr. Olasky was a resident scholar.
 
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
The Fed Gives It a Try
 
To control the economy, the Fed has two buttons it can push. Last week it pressed them both. First, it lowered the discount rate, the rate it charges member banks to borrow money, to 4 1/2 percent from 5 percent. Then it pulled down the Fed funds rate on overnight loans to 4 3/4 percent from 5 percent. Together, the cuts are designed to add a little pep to the economy. Banks lowered their prime rates to 7 1/2 percent from 8 percent in the aftermath. But some observers remain dubious. "People do not go out and buy a car just because rates are down half a point," said Ezekiel S. Ketchum, of Meridian Bank in Reading, Pa.
 
 
Hope of a Tax Cut?
 
To give the lethargic economy a jolt, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, introduced a bill to cut taxes.

 
The Meaning of Productivity
 
One side of the argument goes like this: Productivity improvement means workers are adding more value to the nation's economy; wages and living standards increase. But the other side says productivity increases when companies shed workers but still sell as many goods; life becomes harsher. So when the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported last week that productivity grew 2.4 percent in the third quarter which side of the argument was supported? "I'm going out on a limb," said Allen Sinai, of the Boston Company. "This could be the beginning of the process of an increase in the standard of living."

 
More Gloom for Workers
 
With the economy's engine ignited, but so far failing to lift off, forecasters are skittish. Once they ignored weekly unemployment statistics. Now they ponder them. When the Labor Department said 14,000 people were added to the jobless lists in late October what did it mean? "We're stagnating." said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities.
 
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Real Soviet Bang for the Buck
 
With the remnants of the Soviet economy spinning closer to the 'abyss' -- a word used by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week -- everything is for sale. Desperate for hard currency, the Soviets are willing to sell once-secret Mig jets, miniature nuclear reactors and possibly the Mir space station (it's still in orbit). They are also offering services involving underground nuclear explosions. For between $300 to $1,200 a kilogram, the International Chetco Corporation in Moscow is prepared to vaporize toxic waste in an underground explosion. Scientists, environmentalists and weapons-control experts around the world have lodged loud complaints. But so far the Soviet Union is undeterred. According to Vladimir B. Dmitriev, Chetco's president, "it will be possible to export services."
 
After hesitating for two weeks, the Ukrainian Parliament voted last week to join with Moscow in a new, looser economic union.

 
Opening More Lines to Europe
 
Right now, 57,750 conversations can be carried on simultaneously between the United States and Europe, not enough capacity to avoid delays. Next February, capacity will jump to about 150,000 simultaneous calls, still too little capacity for this burgeoning market. So last week, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced it would lay two new fiber-optic cables between the United States and Europe. That would add enough capacity to handle 300,000 simultaneous conversations and data transfers. The project, which will cost about $580 million and take a year to complete, still must be cleared by the Federal Communications Commission.

 
Slow Growth in the Philippines
 
This has not been a good year for the Philippines. First Mount Pinatubo erupted, causing hundreds of millions of dollars of damage. Then tropical storm Thelma ravaged the islands that make up the country, killing as many as 5,000 people. Nevertheless, growth is still expected to be positive. Last week, President Corazon Aquino said the official estimate is that the Philippines would grow by just less than 1 percent, compared with 3.6 percent last year. One of the reasons for the slowdown is that thousands of Filipino guest workers living abroad who send their salaries home have traveled back to the Philippines to repair their damaged villages.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report on the Business Diary page last Sunday about the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. misstated the sales ranking of the companies' soft drinks in the United States. Coca-Cola outsells Pepsi.

LENGTH: 1887 words

HEADLINE: Amid Cuts, California Is Curtailing College Dreams

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8

 BODY:
For 30 years now, Californians have had an implied promise from their state government: a high-quality and low-cost public college education for every resident who wanted it. It was a promise the prosperous fast-growing state seldom had much trouble fulfilling.
But suddenly the state that operates the largest system of higher education in the nation may no longer be able to honor that promise. 
 Under intense pressure from a stagnant economy, all 236 campuses in the state's three public college systems face mounting troubles. The vaunted 1960 Master Plan for Higher Education in California that built it all a generation ago is in jeopardy.
At San Diego State University, where 550 part-time instructors have been let go and 662 classes canceled, more than 1,300 students got none of their requested courses when the semester began. Some have perfected the process known as "crashing," by which they attend classes to which they have not been assigned and beg overloaded professors to admit them. And many are "freeway flying," madly dashing by car between the campus and various junior colleges trying to gain the credits they need to graduate.
Janitorial services have been cut back so sharply at California State University, Northridge, in Los Angeles, that students and professors in the Department of Communicative Disorders regularly pick up brooms and mops to clean the clinic and therapy rooms.
Many professors are typing exams in small type to save paper and using tests that can be electronically graded instead of essays to save time. Budgets for phone calls, copier paper and clerical help have been reduced sharply.
The Center for Studies in Higher Education at the University of California at Berkeley can no longer afford a receptionist; it keeps its doors locked and a machine takes phone calls. Across the Bay at San Francisco State University, students sit on the floor in many classes.
"We have reached the point where the there is a fundamental mismatch between the Master Plan assignment and our resource base," said Barry Munitz, Chancellor of the 20-campus California State University system. "We are the gatekeepers for socioeconomic mobility in this state. Many of our students work. For them to be out of a campus is to be put out of the system. Suddenly we are eroding the very reason we created the Master Plan in the first place."
For example, Michelle L. McClure, a 21-year-old junior majoring in English at San Diego State, works 30 hours a week delivering packages for Airborne Express, and has only mornings to attend classes. She requested six classes and got only one of them this semester.
"Seniors told me to go to professors' offices and beg," she said. "I took a day off from work, and they were not there." She "crashed" 15 or 20 classes and ultimately got three courses, one in geology, one in history and one in women's studies -- none counting toward her major. "You end up with bizarre classes because that's all that's left," she said.
 
A Notion of Prosperity
 Budget ills afflict state colleges nationally, but nowhere have they taken more urgent form than in California, where the colleges have long been the route to fulfilling the California dream of egalitarian prosperity and where the American dream has reached its broadest realization. Though never a guarantee, it was based on the notion that even the poorest family could send its children to college if they had the brains.
"It's going to be awfully tough for the Legislature because so many people have been telling their children if you stay through high school you can go to college," said Clark Kerr, the former President of the University of California, who was an architect of the 1960 Master Plan. "That is a promise people keep in mind. It is almost a right now."
But now the California colleges find themselves under the conflicting pressures of drastic state-imposed budget cuts and a fast-growing population, demanding more, not less, access. This has posed some tough questions for California's educators and politicians: Shall quality be sacrificed to maintain universal access? Should faculty teach more and do less research? Should student fees vary according to ability to pay? And can the colleges continue to serve as the economic entryway for the ethnic minorities and immigrants who have gravitated to the largest state?
On Oct. 17 in Los Angeles, the current president of the University of California, David P. Gardner, told the regents the system might have to raise admission standards to cut enrollments and that such cuts could stir ethnic tensions because many whites and Asians might have to be refused admission if access for black and Hispanic students was to be maintained.
 
Climbing Enrollment
 The California Postsecondary Education Commission, a state agency that coordinates the activities of the disparate systems, estimates that the state's three systems will add 700,000 students to the 2 million they now enroll and that 37 new campuses will be needed by the year 2005. But the University of California has delayed building its long-promised 10th campus, and plans for other new campuses are now in doubt.
The Master Plan, most of which was passed by the Legislature in 1960, created three interlocking systems and established admission standards.
It gave the University of California the exclusive right to issue doctoral and professional degrees, designated it as the main research university and gave it authority to select from the top 12.5 percent of high school graduates in the state for undergraduate admission. The Cal State system became the main undergraduate teaching system, allowed to select from the top 33.3 percent of students. The California Community College system, a loosely linked archipelago of two-year colleges, was to be open to all for vocational training and to be a stepping stone to the four-year colleges.
If the economy does not pick up, Mr. Kerr foresees a difficult struggle as the Legislature pressures professors to take on heavier teaching loads and students to pay a larger share of the costs of education. "So one of the implications is more student unrest," he said.
Should substantial numbers of students be barred from University of California and the Cal State system, David Mertes, chancellor of the 107-campus California Community College system, fears that his system will be swamped. Already, he said, the junior colleges last year turned away 50,000 students.
 
Problems Were Unseen
 None of these troubles were foreseen as recently as 1987, when the Master Plan was renewed by two special commissions, one appointed by George Deukmejian, the Republican Governor, and the other by the Democratic-controlled Legislature. Both commissions assumed the state would continue -- indeed greatly expand -- public higher education.
"We were so optimistic, almost naively so," said Lee R. Kerschner, executive director of the governor's commission, now vice chancellor of academic affairs at the Cal State system. "It was assumed California would fund it because it always had. Governor Deukmejian had just returned a $1 billion surplus to the people. Nobody really asked if we can afford this."
Under Governor Pete Wilson's current budget, the colleges took substantial cuts in state support. Each system responded differently.
The University of California's budget was cut by 1.1 percent. Saying it was determined at all costs to preserve quality, it raised student fees by 40 percent, to $2,274 a year, froze all salaries, planned to cut enrollment by 5,500 over the next few years, and gave early retirement to nearly 3,500 employees, including 672 faculty members.
Harder hit, with a 3.2 percent cut, the Cal State system raised fees by 20 percent, to $936 a year, cut more than 4,000 classes, laid off more than 1,000 faculty members and did not rehire more than 2,000 part-time teachers. Eight of the 20 campuses have closed admissions for the spring semester.
 
Students and Teachers Upset
 These cuts have produced rising student anger, particularly at San Diego State, where enrollment dropped by 1,500 students, or 4 percent, this semester because so many students could not get enough classes. The cuts have proved devastating for many of the 32,951 remaining students, many of whom work and who face spending another semester or two in college because general education classes required for graduation have been full.
The experience has hardly been less painful for professors. "Every teacher knows there will be a lot of people in class who are not on the roll," said Clare Colquitt, an assistant professor of English, whose department was particularly hard hit because part-time teachers were let go. "Most just show up, hoping I'll have pity on them."
The cuts have led to a new student organization, the Student Movement for Education. One of its leaders, Merek Findling, a sophomore psychology major, has been battling with the campus president, Dr. Thomas B. Day, for information on how the decisions on cuts were made and for answers to such questions as why the athletic department suffered much lighter cuts than English and women's studies.
Ethan A. Singer, associate vice president for academic resources, said the cuts were forcing the university to re-evaluate its offerings. The assumption is that the cuts are permanent, he said, and to preserve high-priority general education programs it may be necessary to eliminate entire programs and to lay off probationary tenure faculty.
All this means California's historic commitment to access and quality is in jeopardy. M. Brian Murphy, director of external affairs at San Francisco State University, who directed the legislative commission on the Master Plan renewal, said his group was determined to make California's eligibility standards for higher education into an outright entitlement.
 
'Hostage By the Budget'
 This involved requiring the University of California and Cal State systems to admit as transfer students those who completed two-year programs at the community colleges.
"But the capacity to deliver is held hostage by the budget," Mr. Murphy said.
William B. Baker, vice president for budget and university relations at the University of California, said: "We are at the point where we are just barely able to accept all eligible California citizens who want to come. The Master Plan's admission standards are not law. It is an administrative policy. We very strongly support it. But we would have to make a decision whether or not to comply."
And Maureen DiMarco, secretary of child development and education to Governor Wilson, said: "The primary issue is access. This is a very serious business issue. Unless we are able to educate our work force, our competitive edge will really be damaged."
Access is a key issue facing the Legislature. "If the financial situation does not improve, we really ought to be serious about the issue of access," said Senator Gary K. Hart, chairman of the state Senate's Education Committee, adding that political pressure is growing to force members of the University of California faculty, particularly those no longer doing pioneering research, to teach more. "Restricting admission is an option that needs to be looked at very carefully."

 CORRECTION:
A chart with an article last Sunday about the troubles of the public university systems in California misstated the student-to-faculty ratios and the faculty totals at California State University. For the 1966-67 academic year, the ratio was 16.9 to 1, with 7,779 faculty members; for the 1990-91 year, the ratio was 18.4 to 1, with 15,099 faculty members. These figures are adjusted by the university to convert part-time faculty members to their full-time equivalents. The chart also misstated the growth in the student population for that period. It was 112 percent, not 115 percent.

HEADLINE: Potent New Pest Hits California, Harming Crops

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL CENTRO, Calif., Nov. 9

 BODY:
In 30 years of farming the Imperial Valley, Ben C. Abatti and his brother Tony have fought every kind of natural and economic foe, but nothing like the poinsettia sweet potato whitefly.
Mr. Abatti has just finished plowing under his entire melon crop, turned into pitiful shriveled and rotted fruits by the tiny but voracious creature. And, farm experts say, the misfortune of farmers like Mr. Abatti will soon translate into shortages and higher prices in markets as far away as New York in the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. 
 Already, farmers have plowed under about 95 percent of the fall crop of cantaloupes and honeydew melons in Southern California and adjoining areas of western Arizona and northern Mexico. The region supplies the vast bulk of produce to the nation in the winter months.
 
Fear for Other Crops
 Fears are mounting that the winter crop of lettuce, broccoli and other vegetables will also be devastated. The plants are stunted and farmers plan to delay the harvest, which usually begins in early December.
"This is the first time we've seen a pest that will eat just about anything," said Richard C. Weddle, an entomologist with the Imperial County Agricultural Commission. "This is a first-rate natural disaster."
The culprit is a potent new strain of the sweet potato whitefly, an old foe of farmers. The new strain has been dubbed the poinsettia because it first appeared on poinsettia plants in Florida in 1986. It lays about twice as many eggs as earlier strains and eats five times as much, said Thomas M. Perring, professor of entomology at the University of California at Riverside.
The fly seems almost omnivorous, finding hosts in about 500 plants, not only melons but also cotton, alfalfa, squash, carrots, tomatoes, even ornamental plants and weeds. Asparagus and onions are among the few crops it seems to avoid.
 
Shortage of Melons
 The pest colonizes the undersides of leaves and sucks out their juices. It has thus far proved resistant to all chemical pesticides. Experts are furiously searching for natural predators, but for now have been reduced to trying to halt the fly's spread by having farmers quickly plow their infested fields and sow the few crops it does not attack to interrupt the creature's life cycle.
The most immediate effect on consumers will be a shortage of melons. The wholesale price of a carton of cantaloupes in the Imperial Valley has risen from about $6 to about $20, said Arthur M. Verissimo, chief of the market news branch at the California Department of Food and Agriculture. A carton contains 12 to 18 cantaloupes.
This has already more than doubled retail supermarket prices in parts of the country. The outlook for the winter vegetables is unclear, Mr. Verissimo said, but prices of lettuce and broccoli are expected to soar, too.
But Keith Mayberry, a farm adviser at the University of California Cooperative Extension in Holtville, said the advent of cold weather could bring at least some improvement because the insects are sensitive to cold. Thus, he said, later plantings are apt to survive better, meaning steep shortages for Christmas but improved supplies and lower prices in February and March.
If the fly means inconvenience for consumers nationally, it has meant extreme hardship in the Imperial Valley, a wide fertile plain that straddles the Mexican border. Imperial County's 120,000 residents depend mainly on agriculture.
Already, officials tally $85 million in lost revenues from melons alone, not counting business lost to suppliers of cartons, glue and seeds, and to truckers and local retailers. More than 2,500 pickers and packers are out of work; unemployment stands at 20 percent.
"We're working fast and furiously to find a short-term solution," said Stephen Birdsall, the County Agricultural Commissioner. "We have to find something that works or we will be wiped out as an agricultural area."
Clouds of flies have been so thick this fall that it has sometimes been difficult to breathe. The damage is stunning.
At Mr. Abatti's farm, small misshapen fruits lay rotting on the surface. Mr. Abatti showed two visitors a leaf of one of the fallen vines. It was covered with thousands of eggs and nymphs.
 
Tried Every Approved Pesticide
 "At this time we'd be at peak production," he said, adding that he expects to lose about $1.8 million in receipts. "We've been through a lot of battles -- lupers, aphids, crickets, beetles -- but this is one we're not used to."
He tried every approved pesticide, as well as soap, chili pepper and garlic, but nothing worked. He has begun to worry about his vegetable crops now, too. The broccoli, for example, should stand about 18 inches by now but are only 6 to 8 inches, he said.
Imperial and neighboring Riverside Counties have asked Gov. Pete Wilson to declare a state of emergency. He is expected to visit the area next week.
The troubles are only beginning. Already, said Gabriel V. Leyvas, supervisor of cantaloupes for Five Crowns Marketing in Brawley, many farmers are planning to cancel the fall melon crop next year because of the risk.
Experts believe the fly originated in the Middle East, possibly Pakistan, found its way to Florida and ultimately to California. They say it has spread with impunity because it was imported without its natural enemies.
The fly has been detected in small numbers in this area since the summer of 1989, but the number exploded this fall for unknown reasons. The insect spreads easily by wind.
The main question now is whether the infestation can be slowed. The immediate priority of state agricultural officials is to use the coming cold months to interfere with its natural life cycle.
The University of California Cooperative Extension recommends that fields that can be harvested be plowed under within hours of harvest, that cotton be terminated by next July, next fall's melon planting be canceled and other crops delayed. The idea is to deprive the pest of food for the crucial summer months.
But the ultimate solution is finding biological foes of the whitefly, said Tom Bellows, of the University of California at Riverside and a leading specialist in natural means of fighting pests. "U.C. researchers are evaluating the possibility of developing a program to import and test natural enemies against the sweet potato whitefly," he said in a news release from the university.
The fly is vulnerable to certain small wasps. But getting them established in sufficient numbers in time is a daunting task.
"It's almost a plague," said Joseph Colace, owner of Five Crowns Marketing. "We have no means to control them now or to stop them in the near future."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A chart last Sunday with an article about the poinsettia whitefly described its arrival in California incompletely. The whitefly has been in the state since the late 1920's or early 1930's; the poinsettia strain arrived in the mid-1980's and became a problem for agriculture about a year ago.

HEADLINE: 'An Anthology of the World'

BYLINE: By Robert Andersen; Robert Andersen, a native Californian, is writing a book on American political culture since the fall of Saigon.

 BODY:

LOS ANGELES
Capital of the Third World.
By David Rieff.
270 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $20.  
 The old Los Angeles soldiers on in such verdant Westside communities as Brentwood, Bel Air and Pacific Palisades. The new Los Angeles toils on in war zones of ethnic vigilance and random armed visitation in Koreatown and Little El Salvador. Ready or not, says David Rieff, the Los Angeles metropolitan area finds itself "an anthology of the world," in transition from the capital of the Sun Belt to the capital of the third world.
By the year 2000, Mr. Rieff notes in "Los Angeles," the city will be less than 40 percent white, a dramatic reversal from the palmy days of the early 1960's. Already Los Angeles has the second largest populations of Filipinos, Koreans, Mexicans and Salvadorans of any city in the world. Adding, in significant numbers, Chinese, Druze, Ethiopians, Indians, Indonesians, Iranians, Pacific Islanders, Pakistanis, Tamils and Vietnamese, Los Angeles is a distinctively cosmopolitan city. Speaking some 82 languages and representing more than 100 ethnic and cultural backgrounds, this multicultural influx has swept aside the barriers that kept Los Angeles white and well-heeled, an "immense, hypertrophied subdivision."
Seeing the city as a preview of the next American century, Mr. Rieff went to Los Angeles from New York City believing that a "new epoch" had begun. "Could anyone seriously imagine that changes of this magnitude would leave the United States as it had been before?"
Mr. Rieff discovered that contemporary Los Angeles is but an engorged replica of the one he knew "in that distant country called the early sixties." The freeways are gridlocked, the water system is imperiled, the cost of housing is beyond mortal reach, the white middle class is in flight to the Northwest.
But he also found the Los Angeles mystique, the "blond ideal of eros, Arcadia, material wealth, and American exceptionalism," going strong -- only now that myth rests on the hordes of new immigrants willing to support "the pleasure dome of solitude and gleaming careers" of the affluent. During his year in Los Angeles, Mr. Rieff grew increasingly disturbed by Westsiders' indifference to the exploitation of "our new fellow countrymen" and its implications for the future of California dreaming. "My questions failed to impress most people I met," he reports.
"When Angelenos did occasionally take a moment to think about what was going on in the city, they tended toward slogans and formulas that were all but guaranteed to inhibit thought, and ranged from the harmless bromides of self-esteem and the celebration of diversity, to rosy economic scenarios of the type the boosters were peddling, to various leftist or nativist versions of an impending class or race war collectively known as the Blade Runner scenario."
In general, Mr. Rieff looks askance at sunny folk memories of assimilation and vatic pieties of multiculturalism; he argues that the rapidly expanding third-world population poses formidable, perhaps insuperable, problems not only for Los Angeles but for a country no longer sure about its identity or sanguine about its future.
"Los Angeles" is an important study marred by Mr. Rieff's occasional facile prose and conceptual anarchy. At once too ambitious and not ambitious enough, the book is all over the map yet neglects the one locale that matters most, the new Los Angeles. Although he professes to find on the Westside "none of the sharpness . . . that tang which made days I spent in Asian or Hispanic L.A. so vivid, peculiar, and unsettling," it is precisely the Westside that he brings into sharp, scathing focus; the Los Angeles of the third world remains an enigma.
In his fine first book, "Going to Miami," Mr. Rieff rendered that city in vivid, peculiar and even unsettling fashion. He anchored his perceptions in the drama of the Cuban-American community, turning a "personal obsession" into a diverting portrait of a city in the throes of demographic redefinition. In "Los Angeles," Mr. Rieff anchors his perceptions in himself, his reading, his bus riding and his table talk; as a result, the book lacks the heft of his "obsessive theme." Still, Mr. Rieff asks the right questions, and his account of Los Angeles is, more often than not, intrepid and provocative. "Going to Miami" was the better book; "Los Angeles" is the more important one. Mr. Rieff's sensibility is unerring in its assessment of what is important to this country's future. It now is time, he says, for us to stop averting our eyes as "our new fellow countrymen" introduce us to the travails of global history. Demography, as Los Angeles is finding out, is now destiny.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Arthur Miller's 'Price' Is Revived in Norwalk

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
AMONG the plays of Arthur Miller "The Price" (1968) holds a nebulous place, nowhere near the summit or the nadir of his considerable oeuvre, yet not steadily ensconced midway either. Every now and again the play resurfaces in one regional theater or another, not as evidence of endurance, but almost as if in search of reappraisal, real status and critical consensus.
No one is going to pretend that the Rainbow Theater production in Norwalk will establish a niche for "The Price" once and for all. A revival scheduled for May by the Roundabout Theater, now situated on Broadway, with Eli Wallach as star and John Tillinger as director, will provide yet another chance. 
 But in its modest way, the Rainbow Theater production makes a clear and persuasive case for the value of a play that is precisely about values misguidedly based upon wanting and winning. The play investigates relationships within a family, which is to say it is also necessarily about the gnawing power of animosity, the perverse need to keep the grudges going, to not let go.
Just when it looks as though two brothers will clear the air of recriminations, following 16 years of estrangement after the death of their father, they don't, for revelations breed rationalizations. Victor is a police officer with a sense of martyrdom and moral superiority, and with no money; Walter is a rich, successful and "important" doctor who has fulfilled his own ambitions and worked out his own neurotic success drive.
Although Mr. Miller has written that "The Price" is his most "specific" play, in that it ostensibly is more concerned with characterization than abstract or cosmic truths, a Miller play is not a Miller play without a social context, and its impact is derived from one's awareness of the perpetuity -- the continued or suddenly new relevance -- of that context. In the best of Miller's work perception implies prophecy.
When Victor refers to "grass covered with men" during the Depression, the image has a shuddering contemporary resonance. Victor sacrificed the promise of a career in order to care for their father; Walter, ostensibly, abandoned him. What then is Walter's "moral debt"? The damage wrought by the weak, demanding father, himself victimized by false values, recalls the dramatic fallout suffered by the sons of Willie Loman and Joe Keller.
The brothers' dizzying confrontation boils over in an absorbing second act that gives the play unanswerable arguments and dramatic complexity. Mr. Miller conceived "The Price" to be performed in one act, but that is seldom followed; instead, an interval comes at the point of Walter's arrival. Clearly, each brother's chosen life has cost him dearly -- and back and forth as they go, no one is fully vindicated.
With characteristic intertwining of morality and materialism, Mr. Miller's title is multilevel. On the surface, it has to do with how much an attic full of furniture, now to be disposed of, will command. And to establish that price, a wonderful 89-year-old character, Gregory Solomon, a furniture dealer and appraiser, takes over, in a vein of warm comic writing not normally associated with Mr. Miller.
The actor playing Gregory Solomon is expected to give the play's standout, scene-stealing performance, and so why should it be different in the Rainbow production? Stefan Schnabel, the theater's co-founder, is spreading wisdom and cheer, though more studiedly so, with less whimsy than impishness than the role generally invites. Here is a more commanding Solomon than one usually encounters, though he's every bit as shifty. The character is a former vaudevillian and acrobat, but Mr. Schnabel gives the impression that maybe he took a detour to other boards, doing a little Shakespeare on the side.
Given the narrow, constricted and peculiar playing area -- the company's next production is to take place in a new theater -- the glorious, massive clutter intended as the play's actual and symbolic background is hardly imaginable. Under Ugo N. Toppo's mountingly good direction, the performances of Ed Simone (Walter, a bit too watery at first) and Kevin Donnelly (Victor) rise to confrontational heights. And the bright, reactive skill with which Linda Meleck plays Esther, Victor's complaining but strong wife, tempers a character that is as much dramatically unsatisfying as she is personally dissatisfied. It appears that Miller has been so accustomed to writing subservient roles for women who honor or hound their husbands, that he overlooked the possibilities for the accomplished, intelligent Esther to find her own marketable skill, so she could spend less time squawking -- and shopping.
Still, as Esther -- the symbolism in the characters' names is a bit much -- searches for "some crazy kind of forgiveness," Victor and Walter rehash the misunderstandings of a lifetime. And Solomon has the last laugh in a theatrically rich curtain scene.
Throughout, Mr. Miller proves a master builder of tension and conflict, never disregarding how the stuff of irreconcileable family discord is determined by the pull of economic necessity -- or panic. "The Price" is a throwback to strong, well-crafted middle-class plays that hardly come round anymore. And that just might be the play's rightful identity after all. It'll just have to keep coming around.
"The Price," at Norwalk Technical College, Richards Avenue. 831-0411. Remaining performances Friday and Saturday at 8.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1651 words

HEADLINE: Oasis on I-95 Lures Truckers With Hot Coffee and Warm Smiles

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
THE other day at the Mayflower Diner in Milford, Kenny Perkins was mopping the last dollop of chili out of a wide ceramic bowl with a piece of bread while discussing the travails of driving a two-ton diesel truck across the southern Connecticut stretch of Interstate 95. Though he had never received a ticket anywhere, he said, he knew of truckers who had passed through the state and been fined for barely violating weight restrictions and for not tying down their portable refrigerators.
"I don't want to offend anybody or anything," said Mr. Perkins, who wore a blue flannel shirt, jeans and a baseball cap. "But out on the road Connecticut's known as a communist state. The police are too strict here. They harass us and don't make us feel very welcome. They've got no respect for us, plain and simple." 
 As he spoke, Donna Alturi, a waitress, worked in unbroken movements, sweeping past the steady flow of customers, gently setting down plates and saucers on Formica-topped tables, then swirling around to reach for the coffee pot.
"I'll bet you could use a refill," she said to Mr. Perkins.
"There you go, reading my mind again," he replied.
Mr. Perkins, who delivers meat to distributors in the Northeast for Iowa beef processors, added that he stopped at the diner every time he drove through the state, because the food was good and the service was friendly.
"It's sure a nice change from out there," he said, nodding toward Interstate 95.
Established 53 years ago as the first of its kind in Connecticut, the Mayflower Diner and Truck Stop has always aimed to offer truck drivers a little respite from the pressures of the highway, said its owner, Howard Merk. The business originally opened on Route 1 in Mianus, in a two-story Colonial that contained bunk beds, a small restaurant and reading room where truckers could relax and listen to the radio. The truckers' village moved to Old Gate Lane off Exit 40 in Milford in the early 1960's to accommodate the flow of drivers along the newly built highway.
With its orange neon signs that tower above the road and the streamlined diner, the Mayflower has become one of the hallmarks of the state's transportation history, Mr. Merk said. Within the 16-acre complex, which is open 24 hours a day, truckers can park and sleep in their cabs or in a 96-room motel, shop at a store that stocks everything from aspirin to hiking boots and truck lights, get service and fuel their trucks and even purchase a new one from the Kenworth Truck sales office.
But the hub of the complex is the chrome-and-Formica beanery, built in 1963 from two old diners that were welded together and later sided with corrugated metal to look like a truck trailer. Inside, window booths are dressed with silk flowers, and some have telephones. There are video games near the entrance, a coffee station and muffin bar for take-out orders and a glass gift cabinet with pens, mugs and brooches that read "I Love Jesus."
On a recent afternoon, drivers from Ohio, Florida, Tennessee and New York sat at the counter on chrome stools that swiveled and ate corned beef and cabbage served with boiled potatoes and Jell-O. Other specials on that day's menu included chicken-fried steak with gravy, and liver and onions "fried the way you like it." Songs by the Captain and Tennile and James Taylor played over the speaker system. "What'll it be, hon?" Marie Meselli, a waitress, asked Warren Wright, an owner-operator from Long Island, whose oil-stained baseball cap read "Operation Desert Storm." "I have a yellow cake with coconut frosting and a carrot cake that's mighty good," she said.
Mr. Wright politely declined the offer but asked for a refill of coffee. Unlike Mr. Perkins, he said he had no problems with Connecticut highways.
"Come on, already," he said. "I'm from New York!"
He started driving a truck 34 years ago, he said, and has hauled everything from boats to rocks to gasoline, "and I never did get rich on any of them." Back in the late 50's truck stops like the Mayflower were rare, Mr. Wright said, and if a driver happened to stumble across one, "it was always some hole in the wall with fuel."
 
Unfriendly World
 But he said there was more camaraderie in those days among drivers, who drove in convoys and ate and socialized together. Deregulation and hard economic times have changed all that, he said, pausing to take a sip of coffee.
"Then again, I doubt the world in general is as friendly as it used to be," he said. "And TV has a lot to do with it."
Behind the diner, in a small prefabricated building, lies Mr. Merk's office. Decorated with mementoes of his travels, like the ebony sculpture of a Masai warrior that he brought home from Africa, the office also contains awards and certificates that document his 50 years of service to the truck stop business.
Mr. Merk, 78 years old, said he started out as a pharmacist before buying his first gas station on Byram Road in Greenwich in the early 1940's. Soon after, he heard that the manager of the nearby Mayflower Truck Station in Mianus had been called to serve in World War II, leaving the property abandoned.
The Mobil Oil Company had opened the station in 1938, labeling it the first truck stop in the East, according to a company brochure from that period. As part of its service the Mayflower offered customers diesel fuel, wide driveways, sleeping quarters, showers, a recreation room, coffee and food described as home cooked.
Mr. Merk, who lives in Woodbridge, said he began leasing the property in 1941 and soon after sold the Byram Road gas station. In 1949 he purchased the Mayflower name from Mobil and moved the truck stop to Route 1 in Orange, where it remained until 1963. He later bought 16 acres of what was then a pine forest on Old Gate Lane in Milford for $10,000 an acre. In the early 1960's, Mr. Merk said, he had it cleared and moved the truck stop there, speculating that the newly constructed Interstate 95 would be a boon to business.
 
'All Nice Guys'
 Fifty years after he first set eyes on the Mayflower sign, Mr. Merk, who wears a cowboy hat and often surveys the grounds of his operation from a black Lincoln Town Car, said he remained a spokesman and defender of truck drivers, whom he called "gentlemen of the road."
"Truckers are a different breed of cat," said Mr. Merk. "You've got people who've got degrees in just about everything, but just like the open road. Then you've got the middle guys, who've worked for the same company for 30 to 40 years, all nice guys. Then you've got the guy who's barely getting by, and he's on the stuff and drinking and having some real serious problems."
He added that compared to a few years back, drug and alcohol abuse among truckers has declined dramatically.
For the operator of a large truck stop, he said, it helps to know the lingo of the gear jammer. For instance, drivers who haul bananas, oranges and apples are known as fruit jockeys, and those who carry mattresses are called bedbugs. All the drivers like to be greeted with "Hey, good buddy," he said. "That'll always make a trucker feel at home."
In recent years the Mayflower has served as a movie set for the James Bond film "License to Kill" and "Jacknife," with Robert De Niro. "I saw that one in a motel room in Italy," said Mr. Merk.
And the Mayflower has had its share of true drama, he said. Three years ago, Mr. Merk said, he got a call from an F.B.I. agent who said the agency had been tracing a Colombian cocaine smuggler who was on his way to meet a contact at the diner. Before the man arrived, five agents staked out the parking lot and diner, he said, with one agent posing as a 90-year-old man. When the drug dealer walked in the door, "they all whipped into action," Mr. Merk said. "And boy, did that guy have a rude awakening."
 
First Time in a Truck
 But mostly, he said, the Mayflower Diner is simply a good spot for low-key banter or snappy repartee. At a window booth Robert Seagroves of Chattanooga, Tenn., and a friend, Laura Jacoby of Phillipsburg, N.J., sat next to each other eating bacon, lettuce and tomato sandwiches and french fries. A driver for Nobel Trucking Company in Birmingham, Ala., Mr. Seagroves said he delivered some steel rails to a construction company in Wallingford and was awaiting word on his next assignment.
The couple said they had met earlier that week in a bar in Phillipsburg. Ms. Jacoby said she'd never ridden in a diesel truck before and thought the experience would be fun. "It's really neat when they try to park," she said.
Mr. Seagroves said that if he could, he would avoid driving north of the Mason Dixon Line.
"It's a speedway up here," he said. "Which is O.K. if people here knew how to drive. You all seem to have this crazy notion that us truckers are driving Toyotas or something."
In a corner booth Robert Brown was talking on the telephone to his 14-year-old grandson in Ohio, telling the boy he would not be home until the following Saturday. "His father's not around, so I have to watch over him," Mr. Brown said as he hung up the phone.
Mr. Brown, who said he had been stopping at the Mayflower for more than 10 years, was on his way to Warren, Mich., after returning from New Haven, where he went to pick up some old railroad ties. Unlike many truck drivers, who spend weeks away from their families, he said he was lucky, because he got to see his daughter and grandson almost every weekend.
After placing a tip on the table, he walked to the cash register, where Barbara Stowe, an assistant manager, was rearranging the candy shelf. Mr. Brown slapped his check on the counter and helped himself to a toothpick.
"Well, it looks like I'll see ya next time around," he said to Ms. Stowe. "Probably sooner than later."
"Whenever," she said. "We'll be here when you get here. Our lights are always on, and our door is always open."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Mr. Olsen Hangs On . . .

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Kenneth H. Olsen, the 65-year-old president and founder of the Digital Equipment Corporation, is under the gun these days. His company, the nation's second-largest computer maker after the International Business Machines Corporation, is struggling to regain a strong footing during difficult economic times.
Mr. Olsen has faced a series of financial and organizational crises during Digital's 34-year history and each time he has pulled the company out, stronger than before. But analysts say this time is different: he has never had to initiate massive layoffs and cutbacks as he is doing now. 
 In a recent interview from the company's headquarters in Maynard, Mass., Mr. Olsen admitted that the current struggles are painful -- they have cost Digital more than 11,000 employees and $1.6 billion in restructuring charges -- but insisted that his enthusiasm has not waned. "There's an awful lot to learn in times of recession," he said. "When things are going well, you really have no idea what you are doing right and doing wrong."
Mr. Olsen also admitted that with Digital's stock languishing under book value for much of the past year, it was time to think about paying a dividend to shareholders, something the company has never done.
"We aren't doing great in profits but we have a positive cash flow, which in time of a serious recession is an accomplishment," he said. Does this mean the company is going to announce a dividend? "Oh no, I'm talking about sometime in the future."
About his own future, Mr. Olsen is even more hazy. He refuses to anoint a successor, calling it "the kiss of death" for that individual, a view he repeated at the company's annual meeting last week. "What we do do is keep overworking people and see who survives," he explained.
Already a business legend, Mr. Olsen said he would not accept praise if he were to turn Digital around yet again. "There's only one measure of success and that is, five years after I'm gone, how is the company doing," he said. "I will accept no accolades until five years after I'm gone. I may avoid that by not going."

LENGTH: 1263 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Sacramento, Calif.;
A Transit-Oriented Approach to Suburbia

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, CALIF.

 BODY:
FOUR busloads of California city plan ners about 180 of them -- recently traveled to a flat, windy plain 11 miles south of this city to tour Laguna West, which has been touted as the next evolutionary stage of the American suburb.
While home building has just started at the 1,000-acre subdivision, the planners could see the outlines: a designated site for a transit station, surrounded by land soon to be filled with stores, commercial buildings and a day-care center, all within walking distance of about 3,400 planned homes . 
 Laguna West was created by a novel coalition of developers, government officials and nontraditional planners. It is a pilot project to see whether home buyers will accept a new idea of suburbia, intended to encourage pedestrian movement, social interchange and a sense of place more typical of traditional cities than of postwar suburbs.
Much is riding on the success of what local planners call "transit-oriented developments." County planners are trying to control growth in an exploding region; environmentalists are trying to concentrate growth in small areas in an effort to prevent sprawl and preserve open space. And home builders are seeking a politically acceptable formula at a time of growing antidevelopment feeling.
In large part, Laguna West embodies ideas of Peter Calthorpe, a 42-year-old London-born architect and planner who grew up in Palo Alto and saw that city's quick growth in the 60's. He has won recognition for his elegant plans, which echo the 19th-century Beaux-Arts movement, and his critiques of suburban life.
Mr. Calthorpe, who calls himself a reviver rather than an originator of ideas and "an ecologist first and a designer second," has his own firm, Calthorpe Associates, in San Francisco. He says he is "cynical about architecture purely as a formal exercise outside of culture and economic conditions."
He is applying a similar integration of transit, housing and commercial buildings in the 140-acre South Brentwood Village project in Brentwood, 25 miles northeast of Oakland, and at the 1,800-acre Dry Creek Ranch subdivision, 10 miles north of Sacramento.
Mr. Calthorpe has been particularly critical of suburbia as a car-oriented environment that discourages human interaction. In a 1988 essay in "Pedestrian Pocket Book: A New Suburban Design Strategy" (Princeton Architectural Press, $9.95), he says that a "profound mismatch" between the suburbia of the last 40 years and the needs of current society "is generating traffic congestion, a dearth of affordable and appropriate housing, environmental stress, a loss of open space and life styles that burden working families and isolate the elderly and singles living alone."
He says he especially dislikes suburbia's tangle of spaghetti-like streets and cul-de-sacs that lack orientation and circulate poorly. Much of the impetus behind transit-oriented developments, or "pedestrian pockets," as he calls them, is to get people out of their cars, at least those who want to. Transportation engineers say suburban households typically generate 10 automobile trips daily.
"IN our time," Mr. Calthorpe said in an interview, "housing production occurs on a mass scale, so we must work with that." His ideas, he added, "are not for a small elite."
In the pedestrian pockets concept, a rational street system replaces the "spaghetti." Often, streets converge on a neighborhood center, including a transit station. The center offers a supermarket and other neighborhood-oriented stores and services.
Mr. Calthorpe's idea of community revives some traditional, if neglected, ideas in home design, as well. Front yards become shallow as houses are pushed forward to line the street; in Laguna West, each house is to have two trees -- there will be 20 species of disease- and drought-resistant trees, one species to each block. This will eventually provide a continuous canopy of shade under Sacramento's relentless sun.
Front porches on at least half the houses will provide a public face to private housing. The streets themselves are narrow to slow down traffic and are punctuated with "tree wells" -- concrete-walled planters -- that protrude two or three feet into the line of traffic and serve as parking dividers.
Garages, which typically bulge forward in recent suburban homes, are pushed to the side of the house, well behind the front facade, or can be entered through back alleys in some cases. Home buyers also have the option of buying rental units or so-called "granny flats" atop garages. Mr. Calthorpe says the strategy provides another type of affordable housing while counteracting the insularity of suburban life.
Instead of cul-de-sacs, Mr. Calthorpe provides through-streets, sometimes creating urban centers where diagonal streets meet.
"The goal is to provide multiple pathways that lead to the same place," he said. "The notion of a center is reinforced by the formal pattern."
Phil Angelides, president of River West Development of Sacramento and one of three partners in the Laguna West land development, hired Mr. Calthorpe in 1989 after hearing him speak. Shortly after that Mr. Angelides scrapped the original plan for Laguna West, which had already completed a lengthy approval process, and started anew.
Mr. Angelides, who was a housing advocate in the administration of Gov. Jerry Brown in the 1970's, contends that he could have readily sold homes in a conventional subdivision.
"There was no economic incentive for us to change the plan," he said. "But we wanted to do the right thing."
The final plan of Laguna West is unusual in its mix of housing, from three-to-an-acre custom homes perched on the waterfront to 30-to-an-acre apartments. Prices for production housing are to range from $135,000 to $280,000, while homes on custom lots may cost up to $700,000.
In October 1990, Mr. Calthorpe was hired by Kaufman & Broad of Northern California, an affiliate of one of California's largest home builders, and surrounding landowners to design the Dry Creek project. His ideas have achieved a sort of semi-official status with Sacramento County officials, who are rewriting the county's general plan using his ideas as guides.
"PEOPLE here do not want Sacramento County to be like L.A. or San Jose," that is, a limitless sprawl, said Thomas Truskowski, a senior planner for the county. "We needed to abandon the business-as-usual approach to home building. We are trying to bring together those places that we use the most: the places where we shop, where we work and where we recreate."
Not all people find the pedestrian-pocket concept convincing. Some shopping center developers and merchants, in particular, seem unwilling to depart from the successful L-shaped shopping center in favor of buildings lining miniature boulevards.
Local home builders are also hesitant to endorse the transit-oriented development concept.
"The Calthorpe approach is untested," said Kim Dellinger, a lobbyist for the Building Industry Association of Superior, Calif., a home builders' trade group. "For the home builder, it is a big risk."
Mr. Calthorpe, however, said homeowners bought into existing suburbia because they had no choice. The old subdivisions, he said, "were a self-fulfilling prophecy."
Mr. Angelides, the home builder, said he believes that the market, not ideology, will have the last word.
"The risk is genuine," he said. "If Laguna West sells, all the home builders will want to build similar projects." But if the concept fails to attract buyers, he added, "they will become gun-shy."

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
A Transit-Oriented Approach to Suburbia

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN
