HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Manalapan

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
GROWTH is a touchy issue in the 31.2-square-mile Township of Manalapan. Between the 1980 and 1990 censuses, its population soared by 41.2 percent and developers recently sued the town successfully for the right to build 3,400 high-density housing units in the sparsely populated southern section, which will almost double the township's current 4,000 housing units.
"The recession has held them up," said Mayor Lorraine Kulick, "but when these projects come in, they will change the whole township. When I moved in 27 years ago, the old-time residents didn't like the new developments. Now, even two-year residents say, 'Stop development.' " 
 Besides slowing the pace of building, the recession also has depressed housing prices, with some down by 30 percent, said Linda Trott, president of ERA-Trott Realty on Route 9.
Most one-family houses have four bedrooms and are on a third to half an acre, she said. Prices range upward from about $170,000 for some 1,800-square-foot, four-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath houses on Old Queens Boulevard or Kipling Way in the northwestern section of town. At the $650,000 level are five-bedroom, 6,000-square-foot center-hall colonials on two acres on Stonebridge Court and Shira Lane at the southern end of town.
One of the larger developments is the 25-year-old, 685-home Monmouth Heights off Route 9. Deeds obligate buyers to join the Monmouth Heights Community Association, which maintains an olympic-sized swimming pool, a kiddy pool, two tennis courts and a volleyball court on Ryan Road. Annual association dues are $185.
Three-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath colonials and ranches in Monmouth Heights are priced from $185,000 to $200,000. Four-bedroom houses are $15,000 to $25,000 more.
The Covered Bridge retirement community off Route 9 has 1,831 one- and two-bedroom condominium apartments. To buy there, at least one spouse must be 62 or older. One-bedroom units sell for $50,000 to $55,000; two bedrooms go for about $58,000, with ranch-style end units fetching up to about $115,000.
The two other major condominium developments are Oak Knolls, off Longwood Drive, and Southfield, off Symmes Road. There are 266 completed units in Oak Knolls, which eventually will have 330. New units range from $110,000 for a two-bedroom town house with no basement to $130,000 for some three-bedrooms with basements. Resales go for $115,000 to $125,000 for two-bedrooms and about $10,000 more for three-bedrooms. Prices at Southfield start at $130,000 for two-bedrooms and go to $150,000 for some three-bedroom town houses.
MRS. TROTT said it is hard to find rentals in Manalapan. Covered Bridge condominiums rent for $600 to $650 for one bedroom and $700 to $750 for two. Oak Knolls condominiums rent for $900 to $950 for two bedrooms and about $50 more for three.
Howard P. and Pamela K. Dorman moved to the Monmouth County township in 1986. Like many others, they did so to escape the congestion of northern New Jersey.
"We lived in an apartment in Teaneck and were looking to expand our family," said Mr. Dorman. "We had cousins and friends in Manalapan and found that the properties were larger and the housing more affordable."
They bought a four-bedroom colonial on Saupe Drive for $250,000. Mr. Dorman says their boys, Neil, 11, David, 5, and Jeffrey, 2, all have friends on the block.
Mr. Dorman, a partner in an accounting firm in Union, is, like many other local fathers, a volunteer coach in the Manalapan recreation program, which provides baseball, basketball and soccer teams for more than 1,200 children 5 to 18 years old.
Manalapan (pronounced man-AL-a-p'n), which means "land that produces good bread" in the Leni Lenape language, became a farming community when the first English, Dutch and Scottish settlers arrived late in the 17th century.
Among the earliest was John Reid, Surveyor General of the English Province of New Jersey, who bought large tracts from the Indian sachems Pyahekan and Wilgruylas in 1686. Reid deeded most of what is now Manalapan to his son-in-law John Anderson and his grandson John Anderson Jr.
In 1685, three men from nearby Shrewsbury -- Alexander Brown, Samuel Dennes and Thomas Hewett -- bought 3,000 acres from the Indians, subdivided it into more than two dozen farmsteads and sold them off.
Among the attractions for the 17th-century settlers was the abundance of streams and rivers, which were used to power grist, lumber and fulling mills.
Best-known of Manalapan's many historic buildings is the Old Tennent Church on Tennent Road. The Georgian-style 1751 cedar-clad church has a cemetery that dates to 1731, when an earlier church stood on the site. The Rev. John Tennent and his brother, the Rev. William Tennent Jr. were pastors of the churches from 1730 to 1777.
During the Revolution, nearly 30,000 British and Colonial troops fought the Battle of Monmouth on an area that straddles the current Manalapan-Freehold border. Although a clear victor was never established, official records indicate that about 500 men, three-fifths of them British, died in the battle. In 1978, the state bought 1,520 acres of farmland and opened Monmouth Battlefield State Park, 80 percent of which is in Manalapan.
The only other major park is the 93.5-acre Manalapan Recreation Center on the Freehold-Englishtown Road. It has three baseball diamonds, six soccer fields, six basketball courts, a fitness trail, six tennis courts, a roller-hockey rink and playgrounds.
Residents shop at two major supermarkets, at the 22-store Manalapan Mall on Route 9 and at several strip shopping centers on Routes 9 and 33. The town also has three large farm stores and the Englishtown Auction, a giant flea market established in 1929 as a farmer's auction market, on the Freehold-Englishtown Road.
AMONG the well-known restaurants are JJ's on Route 33 and the Battleground Country Club, which serve continental food. On Route 9 are Japantown, Hunan Gourmet and Jesse and David's, a kosher deli.
Children attend the four elementary schools and one middle school in the 4,150-student, k-8 Manalapan-Englishtown Regional School District. Superintendent of Schools Joseph F. Scozzari says that the schools use a whole-language approach, in which reading is taught within the framework of other disciplines, rather than on its own. He also said that the schools try to teach children how to learn and how to work in groups.
Manalapan's growth has brought class sizes to 30, rather than the 22 Mr. Scozzari considers ideal. A new state-of-the-art middle school, with fiber-optic wiring for computer networking, scheduled to be completed in July, is expected to ease some of the overcrowding.
Manalapan High School belongs to the Freehold Regional High School District, which includes four other schools and eight municipalities. The principal, Robert F. Breuche, says the regional approach lets the schools share services and programs and negotiate better purchases with vendors. It also lets them make specialized learning centers available to all students.
Manalapan High provides the science and engineering learning center; other schools have centers for international studies, computer sciences, business, performing arts and humanities.
Mr. Breuche says that 89 percent of Manalapan High School graduates go on to higher education. The school offers advanced placement courses in English, American history, calculus, physics, chemistry and biology.
Manalapan is home to the Monmouth County Library on Symmes Drive. Besides its extensive collection of books and films, the library also serves as a social center, sponsoring lectures, concerts, arts and crafts and movies.

Molly Pitcher: Diaries of at least two Colonial soldiers who fought in the Battle of Monmouth, which took place in and near Manalapan on June 28, 1778, recount the tale of Molly Pitcher, who carried water for the troops and helped operate a cannon after her husband was shot. After much controversy, historians identified Molly as Mary Hays, wife of Pvt. William Hays of the 4th Pennsylvania Artillery.

HEADLINE: For St. John's: Tricentennial and Repairs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
IN a corner of Getty Square here, in the crowded downtown area that has its share of drug problems, homelessness and other ills, there is a quiet place that remains unruffled by the passage of time, despite centuries of sometimes turbulent changes that have taken place outside its gates.
In the churchyard of St. John's Episcopal Church one recent morning, vendors brought fall fruits and vegetables to sell at a farmer's market. Passers-by strolled through the open gates, some to buy homemade jams and jellies or perhaps a bag of fresh-picked apples, and others merely to savor a few moments away from the jostling of the crowds on the street. 
 The oldest house of worship in Yonkers was founded in 1693 on the shores of the Hudson River as a parish of the Church of England. Its rectors have witnessed the Revolutionary War, the growth of a shipping port in the city's harbor, the development of the railroad and the industrialization of the area.
Over the years, as Yonkers flourished, so did the church, counting among its many parishioners during the late 19th century some of the wealthiest industrialists in the Northeast.
And in the middle of this century, when numerous city merchants left to set up new businesses in shopping centers away from the deteriorating downtown, and when the middle- and upper-middle classes moved to less densely populated areas in other parts of the county, the church's congregation, and its coffers, dwindled.
 
Leaky Roof and Crumbling Stone
 But as the current rector of St. John's, the Rev. S. Burtner Ulrich, explained, "It is a policy of the church that we don't pick up and leave, too."
Now approaching its tricentennial anniversary, the brick and fieldstone church, which was built in 1752 and enlarged after the Civil War, is beginning an $855,000 restoration campaign. The old slate roof is leaking, the intricate stonework is crumbling and the lead in many of the stained-glass windows of the chancery -- some of the oldest in the United States -- is giving way.
Although Father Ulrich, the 35th rector at St. John's, estimated that full renovation of the church would cost $2 million and take 10 years to complete, the first stage would involve only "sealing the envelope" of the building -- replacing the roof and resetting the stones to prevent further water damage.
 
Shared Fortunes
 For the St. John's Episcopal Tricentennial Restoration Campaign, the church is seeking funds to match the $300,000 it was awarded last May by the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation under the Environmental Quality Bond Act.
Of 121 applicants, St. John's was one of 23 projects awarded a total of more than $4 million in matching grants to preserve buildings on the state or national registers of historic places. The Getty Square church is on both registers.
"Clearly, the building is one of the most historic structures in the area," said Karl Bertrand, a fund-raising and grant consultant working for St. John's. "But it is also one of the most seriously deteriorated buildings."
"In a sense," Mr. Bertrand said, "St. John's has shared the fortunes of the neighborhood."
In another sense, said Michael P. Rebic, historic preservation planner for the Yonkers Department of Planning and Development, "St. John's has remained a steady force throughout many years and many changes, a pillar of our downtown area."
"The idea that St. John's would undertake this project, instead of leaving, as other institutions have, shows a real commitment to our city," Mr. Rebic added. "It's too easy to wash your hands of an area and move on when things get tough."
The Getty Square section of Yonkers has declined over the last 30 to 40 years, Mr. Rebic said, and the social and economic problems of the working- and middle-class residents who stayed behind have increased. As of August 1991, for example, there were 404 homeless Yonkers families, including 832 children.
 
Taking an Active Role
 To meet the needs of the downtown area, St. John's has taken an active role in providing the city's first shelter for the homeless, a soup kitchen, a battered-women's shelter, community residences for the mentally ill, a shelter for recovering drug-addicted women and a support group for those with AIDS.
Throughout its history, St. John's has been more than a house of worship. In 1869, the church opened a home for the sick on Warburton Avenue that later became St. John's Riverside Hospital, the city's first hospital. A century earlier, during the Revolution, the church building served as a hospital for wounded soldiers fighting for both sides.
"It is our tradition," said Father Ulrich, "to take care of those in need, whether they be Tories, the homeless or people with AIDS."
For years, legend had it that troops from the Revolutionary War were buried on the grounds, although no markers were erected on the graves. But the story took on more credibility during the 1950's, when an entire crew walked off the job after workers excavating earth underneath one of the building's underpinnings found human bones.
 
Inspired by London Churches
 The building, with its Georgian-style detailing, rounded arches and fanlight window above the entrance, was built by Frederic Philipse 2d, an English lord who owned 90,000 acres of land from the Bronx north to Croton-on-Hudson. The small rectangular structure was built of local fieldstone, and its style was inspired by London churches designed by the 17th-century English architect Sir Christopher Wren.
The first major renovation of the church came in 1871, when Yonkers had become large and prosperous. Edward Tuckerman Potter, a well-known architect who also built the Mark Twain House in Hartford, was hired. In a break with tradition, the architect turned away from the Gothic Revival style that was popular in churches of that period, and instead built upon the church's existing Colonial architecture.
"Potter did an unprecedented thing," Mr. Rebic said. "And in doing so, he ushered in a new appreciation for American Colonial architecture.
"At a time when old buildings rarely survived and were torn down to make way for the new, Tucker and the vestry insisted on maintaining the architectural integrity of the existing building," Mr. Rebic said.
 
A Confiscated Tory Manor
 Orin Lehman, Commissioner of the state's Department of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, said recently that St. John's "one of the finest works of Edward Tuckerman Potter."
The restoration campaign officially began in September, with opening ceremonies attended by British Maj. Basil Hugh Phillips Heaton, a direct descendant of the British Loyalist whose manor was confiscated in 1785 by the state.
To match the state grant, the church will seek financing from the parish, the city, corporations, the Episcopal Diocese of New York and foundations specializing in religious properties and historic places, Father Ulrich said.
"Despite the problems, we like being here," the rector said of his church's commitment to renovate the building and remain in Getty Square.
"We feel needed," he said. "I'm never bored in Yonkers, and I have great hopes for this community."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
When Shut-Eye Goes, So Does the Work Day

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
Gail R., a 42-year-old attorney with a New York real estate law firm, could not get a good night's sleep. Day after day, she arrived at her office dog tired. She tried everything -- gallons of coffee, pinching her legs -- and still dozed off at her desk.
"I felt tired and lousy all the time," she said. "My work was uneven because my energy was sapped." 
 And so, at about 10 P.M. on a recent Monday, Gail R. -- all those interviewed refused to be identified by name for fear of hurting their careers -- arrived at Manhattan's Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center to participate in an all-night session at its Sleep Disorders Clinic. Dressed in pink cotton pajamas, she plumped up her pillows, grabbed her teddy bear and adjusted the two-dozen wires taped to her body. For the next eight hours, she was hooked up to an encephalograph monitor and videotaped via infrared camera so that every movement of her brain, eyes, nose, mouth, arms and legs would be analyzed. "I'd do anything for a good night's sleep," she said.
 She's not the only one. Call it the leading sleep indicator: as the economy worsens, more bleary-eyed executives turn up in the office of Neil B. Kavey, the clinic's director. "The recession has had a real impact," Dr. Kavey said. "When people start losing their jobs or fearing they might lose their jobs, they start losing sleep."
It's a vicious cycle: job worries foster stress and depression, which create -- or aggravate -- sleep disorders, which hamper job performance. Along with insomnia, or sleeplessness -- which afflicts 50 million Americans -- come hypersomnia (sleepiness) and parasomnia (sleepwalking), as well as various circadian rhythm disorders. These disruptions in the body's sleep schedule can be caused by changes in routine, such as working until 2 A.M. to close a deal or flying to Europe for a meeting.
Sleep disorders take their toll on business people. "Lack of sleep impacts your memory, your judgment, your concentration -- all of your decision-making powers," Dr. Kavey said. Some 75 percent of his patients are business people; with corporate health insurance, they have the means to seek treatment.
Your dealings with co-workers worsen, too. Linda P., 38, a research analyst with a New York investment banking firm, suffers periodic bouts of insomnia. "My work always gets done," she said, "but my interpersonal relationships bear the brunt. I have to hide in my office so I don't break down and cry if my boss looks at me the wrong way."
In minor cases, Dr. Kavey recommends "sleep consolidation" therapy: limiting sleep to specific intervals and gradually increasing the amount until the patient sleeps uninterrupted. He also advocates improved "sleep hygiene" -- avoiding alcohol, caffeine and other stimulants before bed, and trying to set a regular sleep routine.
For more serious problems, he suggests an evening at the clinic. At $1,000 a visit (covered by most major medical insurance carriers), it's not for those who occasionally stifle a yawn after a late dinner with clients. It's for those who habitually fight to stay awake.
Take Gail R. At the sleep clinic, she registered a whopping 334 respiratory irregularities -- otherwise known as snores. She spent 29 percent of her time in the lightest sleep, which is akin to being partially awake, and never made it into a deep slumber. "No wonder she's tired," Dr. Kavey said. "Her breathing patterns are horrendous."
Gail R. has several options to remedy her physical breathing problems. She might try a plastic mouthguard or a mask with an oxygen tube. They might not seem conducive to sleep, but do help restore normal breathing patterns. If they don't work, surgery may be required to remove excess tissue from her throat that keeps her from breathing easily when she sleeps.
Because sleep disorders are relatively new as a medical specialty, little research exists. And what there is concentrates on manufacturing workers and security guards, for whom dozing spells mean physical danger.
But now, with business having gone global, sleep -- or lack thereof -- is becoming a big issue with executives. As faxes and electronic mail whizz around the world, executives complain to Dr. Kavey of lying awake worrying about work they could be doing. "These people have to pay attention to their bodies," he said. "They can't keep cutting down their sleep to make more money."
Some are resisting the 24-hour trend. When the New York Stock Exchange announced plans last year to start trading a half hour earlier, brokers at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco launched a protest, and their East Coast brethren joined in condemning the idea. "I feel sorry for our people on the West Coast who would have to get up so early," said Alan Greenberg, chairman of New York-based Bear, Stearns & Company. The plan was shelved.
Of course, some executives thrive on little sleep. (Most adults need seven hours; a few require eight or nine but others get by on five or six.) "Aggressive types, like investment bankers, think it's macho to pull all-nighters," Dr. Kavey said. "They brag about surviving without any sleep."
Ultimately, though, it catches up. Mike L., an executive vice president in his 50's at a New York record company, realized he wasn't sleeping properly when he started dozing in meetings. But it was only when he fell asleep at the wheel of his car -- and drove off a highway -- that he sought help. Medical tests revealed several problems, including sleep apnea, a respiratory disorder. Now, with treatment, he is sleeping better -- and colleagues notice the difference. "I think they forget what a nice guy I am when I'm not tired," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Press

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
AS the late Robert Maxwell's son Kevin begins the daunting task of filling his father's huge shoes at The Daily News, there is wide disagreement about just how daunting a task he faces.
Mr. Maxwell said in an interview Friday that The Daily News would be operating profitably by March. But the newspaper has not released any statistics on its operation. 
 Executives at New York Newsday and The New York Post, who have analyzed The Daily News using their own estimates and assumptions, assert that the newspaper is losing a fortune. In an article Thursday in New York Newsday, that paper's president, Douglas Fox, said The Daily News had no prospect of becoming profitable.
The truth?
Without authoritative data, any analysis is -- at best -- informed speculation.
On condition that they not be identified, executives at The Daily News and at the Maxwell organization, union leaders and other newspaper executives provided information about The News's current and past operation.
From these fragments, a mosaic emerges that suggests that The News must still overcome big hurdles if it is to break into the black in 1992.
In 1989, the last full year of operation under the Tribune Company of Chicago, The Daily News had revenues of about $420 million. Of that, about $275 million was from advertising and $145 million from circulation.
The recession of 1990 pushed revenues down. Had there been no strike, revenues for the year were expected to be about $385 million, with $250 million in advertising and $135 million in circulation.
The Daily News's prestrike circulation totaled 1.4 million on Sunday and 1.1 million daily.
Before his death, Robert Maxwell said the paper had advertising revenues in excess of $3 million for the week before Columbus Day, which begins the Christmas season and is usually a very good week for newspaper advertising. Advertising usually dips significantly after Christmas.
But The Daily News expects increased advertising rates and some new advertisers to generate an average of $3 million in ad sales weekly in 1992, which would produce $156 million for the year.
The Daily News claims to have a paid circulation of about 800,000 daily and a million Sunday, although the paper reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations that average circulation for the six months ending Sept. 30 was 762,078 daily and 911,684 Sunday.
Based on the higher numbers, The Daily News would generate circulation revenue of about $90 million.
Therefore, a rough -- and optimistic -- estimate of advertising and circulation revenues for 1992 is $246 million.
In 1989, The News's costs were about $410 million, and the costs were projected before the strike to rise to $420 million in 1990. Of that, about $210 million was in wages, benefits and overtime; $126 million in ink and paper, and $84 million in administration, leases and other expenses.
Mr. Maxwell claimed to have negotiated savings with the paper's unions worth about $80 million, leaving $130 million in labor costs.
The newspaper's lower circulation means that it is using about a third less paper and ink, which makes current costs about $84 million.
If one assumes that administration, lease and other costs declined by $20 million, as Mr. Maxwell boasted, the current cost is about $64 million.
These current annual costs, again viewed optimistically, would total about $278 million.
By this rough analysis, The Daily News would lose $32 million in 1992.
Should advertising revenues fall short of the $3 million a week that is expected, the deficit could be far greater. For instance, should the weekly advertising average be $250,000 less than expected, the annual loss could be $45 million.
In an interview last week, Kevin Maxwell said he hoped to get help and cooperation from the paper's unions, which usually means concessions. There seems little doubt that he will seek to reduce labor costs in a new contract to replace the current one that expires in March.
The Daily News is also seeking to renegotiate the lease on its headquarters building on East 42nd Street in Manhattan, exchanging a long-term commitment for a significant reduction in annual cost.
While Mr. Maxwell has pledged his family's support to The Daily News, he has also made it clear that the family's investment in The News is based on expectation of profit.
Should that profit not appear in 1992, the cost of shutting the paper down -- if it cannot be sold -- would be substantial.
As part of the purchase agreement with Mr. Maxwell, the Tribune Company agreed to be responsible for any shortfall in the paper's pension plan if it were to be closed within five years of the sale.
But the Maxwells would be responsible for severance, which would probably be about $20 million.
In addition, The Daily News has lease obligations and other contractual commitments estimated to be about $20 million.
As such, the total cost for closing The Daily News would probably be roughly $45 million.
Avoiding such an expense could encourage the Maxwells to keep The Daily News alive, even if 1992 does not turn out to be the year the paper turns the profit corner.

HEADLINE: An Effort To Salvage Bank Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
In the face of increasingly partisan wrangling on the verge of an election year, Congress will take one final stab this week at passing banking legislation.
After several days of negotiations last week, Administration officials and lawmakers from both parties said the chances were about 50-50 that a key proposal from President Bush, to allow banks to open branches nationwide, would be enacted. 
 Paradoxically, the main factor in favor of such a measure is not what it would do for banks but that it could provide cover for legislators who have no alternative but to approve billions of dollars to bail out failed banks. If they pass a bill that includes the bailout money and authority for interstate banking, the latter will probably dominate the headlines.
 
Parts of Proposal Are Dead
 Other main parts of the banking proposal, which Mr. Bush said at the beginning of the year was his top domestic priority, are dead at least for this year, and maybe for years to come. They would permit banks to sell insurance and stocks and underwrite securities and allow commercial enterprises like retail chains to own banks.
Last Monday, the House of Representatives voted down comprehensive changes in the nation's banking laws. In the end, the Bush Administration worked against the bill because it had become bogged down with rules limiting the operations of banks.
The next day, the House Banking Committee approved a stripped-down bill that would do little more than provide a $30 billion taxpayer loan to the deposit insurance fund to pay off depositors of failed banks and increase by billions of dollars the ability of the insurance fund to borrow money to buy the assets of banks that fail.
Every responsible lawmaker knows such a bill must be enacted. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's insurance fund is now down to about $2 billion, and with a number of bank failures in the offing, the fund will become insolvent early next year.
Without the new loans, blameless depositors would not be reimbursed when their banks fail next year, and that could lead to a run on banks like the ones in the Depression that led the Government to begin insuring bank deposits.
But the whole situation sounds so much like a replay of the savings and loan disaster that many, perhaps a majority of, lawmakers, including almost all Republican representatives, would vote against a bill like the one that came out of the Banking Committee. "These guys just don't want to vote for a naked bailout bill," said a senior Administration official.
Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, a senior Republican on the Banking Committee, explained the situation this way: "It's a lose-lose proposition for a politician. If you vote no, you turn your back on depositors and risk a recession if not a depression. If you vote yes, you are acknowledging a past Congressional mistake and risk being criticized for one whale of a hit on the taxpayers."
So Congressional leaders and Administration strategists began late last week to try to fatten the bill to give the lawmakers some political protection. The interstate banking provision is one likely sweetener. Another would place new restrictions on the ability of banks to sell insurance, a provision sought by the insurance industry, which is one of the most influential and pervasive lobbies in Washington.
The negotiators were close to agreement on those two matters, but Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is the chief antagonist of big banks in the House, insisted on a moratorium on banks' entering securities underwriting.
This is mostly forbidden now, but in recent years the Federal Reserve has used its regulatory authority to permit a few large banks to do a small amount of underwriting.
The Bush Administration objected to the Dingell moratorium, and the negotiations were deadlocked at the end of the week. "We're in lobbying gridlock," said Edward L. Yingling, chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association.
 
Action in the Senate
 The Senate is also prepared to take up a banking bill next week, but it will probably wait to see what happens in the House. If the House approves the measure allowing nationwide branches, the Senate will probably follow suit.
The Administration has argued that such legislation would strengthen the banking system because it would make banks less vulnerable to economic distress in certain regions of the country and because it would allow banks to merge and take advantage of economies of scale.
Over the years, positions on banking legislation have not generally broken along party lines. The divisions were more likely to be over whether lawmakers came from big cities or small towns, whether they served on the banking committees or on committees with jurisdiction over competing industries and who provided their most important sources of campaign support.
In the last week or two, however, these issues have become sharply partisan. That is mostly because President Bush has decided to make attacks on the Democratic Congress the centerpiece of his re-election campaign and because Democrats are frustrated that Mr. Bush and President Ronald Reagan before him have managed to avoid responsibility for the savings and loan debacle.
These disputes boiled over Wednesday when the Senate Banking Committee, voting along straight party lines, rejected the President's nomination of Robert L. Clarke to a second term as Comptroller of the Currency, one of the top bank regulatory positions.
Some Democrats acknowledged that they had no particular problem with Mr. Clarke but wanted to send a message to the Administration for the string of bank failures that could end up costing the taxpayers a great deal. Speaking at the public meeting, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said: "I've never before cast a vote on the basis of a message. Unfortunately, Mr. Clarke must be the messenger."
Republicans expressed outrage and maintained that the committee's chairman, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat, was trying somehow to cleanse his own record. Mr. Riegle was rebuked by the Ethics Committee this year for having intervened with bank examiners on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., who ran one of the largest savings and loan associations that failed.
At one point, Senator Pete V. Domenici, a New Mexico Republican, looked past Mr. Riegle at the other Democrats on the committee dais and declared: "You don't need a scapegoat for anything. Maybe the chairman does, but you don't."
The banking bill will not end the Congressional misery. The lawmakers must also approve a new $80 billion appropriation for the savings and loan bailout and increase by billions more the amount that can be spent to buy the assets of failed savings institutions.
As is the case with the deposit insurance fund, Congress has no choice but to approve this money. But it is painful to vote to spend a huge amount to make up for mistakes of the past. Some lobbyists believe the legislators may look for a way to sneak this money into the banking bill at the last minute to avoid a separate vote.
Albert V. Casey, head of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency that manages the savings and loan rescue, suggested this week that each month Congress delayed approving the additional money could cost the Government an additional $100 million. That is because the Government's cost rises the longer an insolvent savings institution is allowed to remain open.

HEADLINE: Office Glut Spreads in California

BYLINE: BY RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10

 BODY:
For the last decade, downtown Los Angeles stood as a gleaming testament to Southern California's seemingly boundless economic growth. In rapid succession, new office towers sprouted to house banks, law firms, stock brokerages and others that poured into the city as the region boomed.
But today, downtown Los Angeles stands awash in vacant office space, a grim reminder to developers and lenders that no region, and no real estate market, is immune to economic dowturn. With new buildings still opening and the recession in California showing no signs of ending soon, the vacancy rate here will only worsen in coming months. 
 Developers and building owners are already being forced to slash rents, sometimes to unprofitable levels, to attract the few available tenants. And banks are being forced to write off or renegotiate loans that only a few years ago they were competing with each other to make.
Los Angeles is the largest -- and only the most visible -- example of how the commercial real estate markets throughout California have weakened precipitously, jolting not just the state's own big banks and developers, but lenders and investors from across the country and around the world.
Citicorp, the largest banking company in the United States, has about $4.2 billion worth of commercial real estate loans in the West, mostly in California, comprising nearly a third of its $13 billion commercial real estate portfolio.
"The commercial market in California is wallowing in a really severe slump, and I don't see it turning up yet," said Paul R. Alanis, the president of Koar Inc., a development company that recently put off plans to start a new office building in downtown Los Angeles.
"There was a feeding frenzy here, with significant inflation in property values, partly fueled by foreign capital coming in, especially from Japan," Mr. Alanis said. "It tended to obfuscate what was really happening, which was ever-increasing supply and a softening demand situation."
 
Small Consolation
 No is predicting that the California market will go the way of some of the great real estate disaster areas of the 1980's, like Boston, Dallas or Austin, Tex. Indeed, many analysts predict that California will eventually bounce back, thanks to its role as financial center for the West, a hub for the booming Pacific rim area and the state's diverse and historically resilient economy.
But that is small consolation right now to developers with buildings in the area from San Diego to Irvine to Los Angeles. In downtown Los Angeles, nearly a quarter of all offices stood vacant on Sept. 30, an increase from about 15 percent only a year ago, and about 5.5 percentage points higher than a 35-city average compiled by Cushman & Wakefield Inc., the real estate brokerage firm. Midtown Manhattan's vacancy rate was 16.9 percent, Cushman & Wakefield said.
To make matters worse here, three big office buildings are still being built downtown, offering space almost equivalent to the Empire State Building.
Already, the slump has shown up on the bottom lines of California's big banks. Most, including the Security Pacific Corporation and First Interstate Bancorp, have greatly increased their reserves for losses on commercial real estate loans in recent months. Analysts think that otherwise strong banks like Wells Fargo & Company could face additional large write-offs in the next quarter or two.
 
Still Looking for the Bottom
 "Our feeling is that the loss situation probably has not bottomed yet, because you don't see the problems peak in real estate until maybe 18 months after the trough of the recession," an executive of one of California's largest banks said.
The situation is also threatening the earnings of Japanese and out-of-state banks that lent heavily to California developers in recent years. Citicorp is the main lender on California Plaza II, a 52-story office tower being built in downtown Los Angeles by Metropolitan Structures West Inc. Just a few months before the building's completion, Metropolitan Structures has leased only about 30 percent of its space.
The slump has already claimed some casualties. The Equitable Life Assurance Company is foreclosing on the Westin Bonaventure, a hotel in downtown Los Angeles owned by a partnership including John C. Portman Jr., the Atlanta developer, and the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan. The First National Bank of Boston foreclosed earlier this year on two office buildings adjacent to the John Wayne Airport in Orange County owned by the McLachan Investment Company. Scores of smaller properties across the state, including office buildings, shopping centers and industrial buildings, have been seized by lenders in recent months.
"The volume now is enormous," said Kurt DeMeire of County Records Research of Huntington Beach, which tracks property foreclosures in the previously fast-growing Southern California counties of Orange, Riverside and San Bernardino.
The squeeze is likely to continue for months or even years. "There's no doubt that some owners, whether investors or builder-developers, are experiencing financial problems because cash flows on a lot of properties are insufficient to meet the debt service," said Stan Ross, a managing partner at Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a real estate accounting firm in Los Angeles. "As a result, you're seeing a lot more troubled debt restructurings."
Amid all the gloom, some new projects appear to be relatively successful. A group that includes Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman turned investor, is putting the finishing touches on an office complex in Santa Monica called the Water Garden. The project, financed by Citicorp and the Bank of America, is 65 percent leased and should be 80 percent leased by the end of the year, executives of the development group said.
Most of the new construction downtown is backed by insurance companies, pension funds, Japanese real estate companies and other deep-pocketed investors that can afford to ride out years of weak income from buildings without being forced to sell at depressed prices. Those new buildings are aggressively wooing tenants from older buildings by offering not only spanking-new surroundings but also deeply discounted rents and other incentives.
 
Problems at Older Buildings
 As a result, owners of older buildings are already losing tenants, and analysts said many would be unable to pay their bank loans if they could not find new tenants.
Jonathan Marine, a broker with CB Commercial Real Estate in downtown Los Angeles, said he was negotiating for a large foreign financial institution, which he declined to identified, that wants to move to a new building from an older one.
The developer of the new building is willing to pick up the tenant's existing lease, which has six years to run, at a cost of $8 million, Mr. Marine said, in return for a 10-year lease in the new building. The developer is also willing to give as much as two years' free rent in the new building, and provide the tenant at least $60 a square foot in cash -- or $4.5 million for 75,000 square feet -- to finish the office's interiors and add furnishings.
Those terms are far better than developers were offering just a year or two ago, Mr. Marine said, and much more favorable than anything the owner of the tenant's current building can afford to grant.
Owners of older or less prestigious buildings "are going to have an impossible time," Mr. Marine said. "There is no demand for those buildings at all."
 
Virtually No New Construction
 If there is good news for the Los Angeles and California real estate markets, it is that new construction has virtually halted. Most economists expect California's recovery to lag the nation's, but they think that within a few years the state will resume its steady growth, albeit at a slower pace than during the roaring Eighties. Eventually, they said, the backlog of office and industrial space will be whittled away as economic growth picks up, forcing rents higher, allowing loans to be repaid and increasing property values.
"Longer term, we think the place works," said David Shulman, the head of real estate research at Salomon Brothers. "But in the short run, who knows?"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fear of Political Moves Keeps Bond Rates Up

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A weak economy and a marked slowdown in inflation usually occasion falling long-term interest rates.
Some credit market analysts say those factors could indeed be potent enough to induce bond yields to fall toward 7.75 percent within weeks. 
 But improvement beyond that level seems unlikely, the analysts said, even if the Federal Reserve Board continues to push short-term interest rates lower. The reason: persistent fears about what Washington might do to insure a recovery.
There is little argument that long-term rates have room to come down. Even though yields fell a bit last week, the spread between 30-year Treasury bonds and 2-year Treasury notes was more than 2.2 percentage points, an extraordinarily wide margin.
 
Several Worries
 Concern that the Fed is reinflating the economy through its measured reduction in short-term interest rates is one reason that the yield curve is so steep.
But at the moment the greater worry seems to be that Congress and the Administration will come up with a fiscal-rescue package that will mainly succeed in expanding a Federal budget deficit that some economists now project will reach $400 billion in the current fiscal year.
"One of the things we have learned over the years is that you can't trust Congress on fiscal policy for more than a year at a time," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "Whenever things start to get tough, they bail out, and the deficit goes up."
Mr. Wood, who recently spent a week talking to people in Washington, said the atmosphere was reminiscent of 1981, when Congress gave Ronald Reagan all the tax relief he asked for, and then some. "That is one reason," he said, "why I am pessimistic about the chances of bond yields falling much further."
 
Regulatory Concerns
 Compounding the challenge of coping with mountainous Federal financing needs -- a fact of life in the credit markets for the last decade -- is the cloudier relationship the market now has with its regulators.
Various investigations undertaken since the Salomon Brothers bidding violations were disclosed in August have made market participants highly cautious and have led to greater inefficiencies in the pricing of securities, traders contend.
Those inefficiencies were reflected at last week's refunding auctions, when demand for the new 3-year and 10-year notes was far below expectations.
A letter sent to dealers last week by Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance, is not likely to ease tensions or improve the market's efficiency.
Mr. Markey sent dealers a list of requests for information on why the three-year notes were so poorly received.
 
Types of Information
 Information as to whether dealers had stayed away from the auction as a form of protest against new Treasury bidding regulations was deemed to be of particular interest. So, too, was information about contacts between primary dealers concerning the auction.
The letter, which asked that the information be supplied by Friday, did not sit well with some primary dealers.
"A lot of people who don't understand the securities business are doing what they think is right to insure the integrity of the market," said the chief executive of one primary dealer, who insisted on not being identified. "But in so doing they are risking complicating the lives of market participants to such a degree that results shown at the first two stages of the refunding may become commonplace."
The request for information about who is talking to whom, and about what, "won't make communication more frequent," the executive said, adding that such communication is highly important if a market is to function efficiently.
"A market which functioned extremely well is being tampered with," the Wall Street executive said.
 
Awaiting Statistics
 The bond markets will be closed today in observance of Veterans Day, and the focus for the rest of the week is expected to be on economic and inflation reports scheduled for later this week. Analysts expect the reports to confirm that the economy is extremely soft and that inflation is coming down.
"There can be little doubt that inflation is improving steadily," said Steven Slifer, executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. "Industrial prices, which have been falling since the recession began in August 1990, hit a new low last week. And wage pressures continue to abate."
Further confirmation will arrive in the form of very favorable figures on producer prices and consumer prices, Mr. Slifer said.
According to his forecast, the Producer Price Index, due out on Wednesday, probably rose by just one-tenth of a percent in October. And consumer prices, which are expected to be released on Thursday, increased by only two-tenths of a percent, he said.
Weak retail sales figures and a report on industrial production showing that factory output did not rebound sharply in October are also expected, bolstering the case that the economy remains weak.
"I am getting very fearful for the Christmas season," said Mr. Wood of Bank of America.

HEADLINE: Trade-Talk Progress, but Still No Deal

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Trade negotiations in the Netherlands on Friday and Saturday failed to produce a breakthrough in the deadlocked global trade talks, but American and European officials insisted today that progress had been made.
The sides said in a communique at the end of the discussions that they were in virtual agreement on an accord to protect copyrights, patents, computer chip designs, trade secrets and trademarks. But no compromise was struck on Europe's lavish subsidies to farmers, which have become the biggest sticking point in the five-year, 108-nation negotiations intended to lower trade barriers. 
 President Bush, ending a three-day visit to Europe, said on Saturday that he and top European Community officials had narrowed their differences over agriculturual policies. He provided no details, nor did the Europeans.
 
'Major Areas of Difficulty'
 The United States, Canada, Argentina, Australia and other food-exporting nations have demanded an end to or sharp reductions in the subsidies, which they say have the effect of closing foreign markets to them.
"There are still some major areas of difficulty on both sides," Ray MacSharry of Ireland, the community's farm commissioner, said after the meeting in Europe.
The European Community's agricultural ministers, who are closely allied with farmers and have blocked efforts to reduce subsidies, gather in Brussels next week to discuss the subsidies, said Willard A. Workman, the vice president for international issues at the United States Chamber of Commerce. They are expected to produce a communique on Nov. 20 indicating whether they are willing to compromise.
Senior American trade officials last month put a new priority on the global talks, which are being conducted under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. They set extra negotiators to work after the German and French Governments expressed a willingness to change the community's agricultural policy. The Governments said they might be willing to shift more costs from consumers, who subsidize farmers through high prices, to taxpayers, who would do so directly.
American officials have been hoping to strike a GATT deal within a few weeks because pushing a trade agreement through Congress takes about seven months and because the chairmanship of the European Community Council of Ministers, and with it the politial leadership of the community, will shift from the Netherlands to Portugal on Jan. 1.
This routine rotation of the community's leadership has made United States officials nervous for three reasons: Portugal is not as close an ally of the United States as the Netherlands; Portuguese officials have expressed less enthusiasm for changes in the community's agricultural policies than Dutch officials, who strongly criticize the current system, and Portugal is a fairly new member of the community, with a small and relatively inexperienced team of diplomats that has never tackled the responsibilities of chairmanship.
 
Free-Trade Pact on Hold
 A senior American trade official acknowledged recently that the new priority for the GATT talks has partly impeded talks with Mexico and Canada about a free-trade agreement. Some meetings have been canceled, as American negotiators, and particularly trade lawyers experienced in drafting agreements, have been transferred to the GATT talks.
Many American officials have also said privately in recent weeks that any North American free-trade agreement might be put off until 1993 because a weak domestic economy is undermining President Bush's popularity and might be eroding public support for a trade agreement that would allow more Mexican products into the United States.
But three Administration officials said this weekend that no decision had been reached on whether it was politically feasible to complete an agreement with Mexico next year.
 
Other Tough Issues Remain
 Success in the global talks will not be guaranteed, even if the European agricultural ministers agree to compromise. "The focus has been on agriculture, but there's still a lot of tough neogtiations to do on other issues, especially on dumping and especially on services," Mr. Workman, of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said today.
Japan and many European countries have been seeking the repeal or watering down of American laws that allow companies to seek punitive duties on imports that are "dumped" in the United States at low prices. They contend that the Commerce Department formula for calculating whether goods have been dumped is heavily weighted in favor of Americans.
American lawmakers oppose any such move. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, sent a letter to President Bush on Thursday saying they wanted a trade agreement "that preserves strong remedies against subsidies, dumping, and other unfair trade practices."
Negotiations on services concern the offering of insurance, investment banking, credit cards and other services in foreign countries. The United States and other industrialized countries think they have a competitive advantage in service industries and want to pry open markets in developing countries.

HEADLINE: Kemp Urges A Cut in Taxes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Bush should join Congress in reducing tax rates "to get America growing again," Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today.
In an appearance on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Kemp said he thought such a measure could be enacted this year. 
 Mr. Kemp has suggested a tax cut, but the President said last week that he did not think taxes could be cut within the constrictions of the budget agreement between the White House and Congress.
The President also said the state of the economy "is not recession" and "does not meet the definition of recession."
Asked about that, Mr. Kemp said, "This economy, while technically, perhaps, out of recession, it's limping, it's anemic, and it needs some oxygen in the body economic to create more jobs, to create more growth."
Mr. Kemp said the Administration should embrace some Democratic proposals to stimulate the economy, citing as examples low-income housing tax credits and a program like individual retirement accounts for first-time home buyers.

HEADLINE: Serving in Military May Cut Later Earnings, Studies Say

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A study by two economists has concluded that "the earnings soldiers sacrifice are greater than first appears," continuing a debate over the impact of military service on income.
Joshua D. Angrist of Harvard University and Alan B. Krueger of Princeton University have been comparing the economic fortunes of veterans and nonveterans in a series of recently published papers. 
 For starters, they found that Vietnam veterans earn about 15 percent less a year than similar men who were not drafted. "Earnings rise with experience and these guys missed out on two years of job experience," Professor Angrist said.
The pay gap exists despite the G.I. Bill of Rights, the Government program that has helped pay for veterans' college educations since World War II. While the program has been extremely effective in increasing veterans' education and earnings, its benefits were pared back for a while in the 70's. And "a lot of people didn't use it," Professor Angrist said. "Many had families and couldn't go back to school."
The Vietnam-era draft also contributed to the income gap, the economists recently found, by giving young men who were at risk of being drafted an incentive to use student deferments and stay in college longer. Since they got more schooling than they might have without the draft threat, they ended up with permanently higher pay, on average.
All this confirms the suspicions of many Vietnam veterans themselves. The real surprise, Professors Angrist and Krueger show, is that those veterans are not alone. World War II veterans, who were generally thought to have received a leg up by serving in a popular war, also suffered financially, though only about one-third as much as Vietnam veterans.
Among veterans of various eras, there are disparate views on how their careers were affected by their time away from civilian life.
"I never would have gone to college if I hadn't gone into the service," said Ben V. Luden, a 66-year-old World War II veteran who lives in Westport, Conn.
And Rosalind R. Beech, a 37-year-old veteran from Silver Spring, Md., who joined the Army in 1974, recalled: "I came from a very low economic background. The military was a means of escape."
But others believe their stint in the service set them back. Eugene R. Manfrey, 60, a Korean War veteran and former steelworker who lives in St. Petersburg, Fla., said: "The guy who stayed home and went to college got the better job. I operated a machine. He was probably up in the office."
John J. Fanning, 44, a Vietnam veteran, had a similarly dim view: "There is a tax for all the men and women that served. That tax will be paid for the rest of their lives."
 
'Were Discriminated Against'
 Many other Vietnam veterans cite problems stemming from the unpopularity of the Vietnam war. "We were discriminated against," said James B. Hubbard, a Vietnam veteran in North Potomac, Md. "When my father came back from World War II, they were proud to hire veterans."
Three circumstances may have magnified the perceived contrast between the impact of serving in the Vietnam War, compared with World War II or Korea.
First is the nation's economic performance. World War II and Korean veterans came home to an economy that was on the brink of a two-decade-long boom. Recessions were short, unemployment stayed low and pay grew rapidly. Against that backdrop, whatever losses may have ensued from military service did not loom all that large in anyone's consciousness.
"I feel very good about myself," said Frederick P. Cipoletti, a 71-year-old World War II veteran, who lives on Staten Island.
By contrast, Vietnam veterans were discharged in the early 70s, just in time for the two worst recessions in postwar history; the combination of high unemployment and rapidly rising prices known as stagflation, and a sharp slowdown in real wage growth.
Unlike World War II, Vietnam was more of a poor man's war: Those who served were disproportionately from the working class, and the post-Vietnam economy was particularly harsh toward young blue-collar men. Vietnam veterans, as a result, have fared even worse than other members of their age group -- a generation whose after-tax pay has declined by roughly 20 percent since 1973.
 
Less Demand for the Semiskilled
 Finally, the skills of Vietnam veterans might not have been as useful in the economy of the 70's and 80's as they would have been a couple of decades earlier. For 20 years or so after World War II, the demand for high school-educated, semiskilled workers soared -- and so did their wages, relative to those of more educated workers.
Vietnam vets, by contast, came into a labor market in which manufacturing jobs were shrinking and the demand for less-educated workers within manufacturing was declining.
Richard Flannigan, a Vietnam veteran in Washington, said, "I got out in 1971 and was unemployed for eight months."

Aid for Veterans
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration and a trade group are starting a program aimed at helping military veterans purchase their own businesses.
More than 100 members of the International Franchise Association are offering veterans either a reduced franchise fee or market-rate financing for up to half the fee. The Small Business Administration will provide management and financial counseling and offer loans to eligible Vietnam and disabled veterans.
All veterans have until Aug. 15, 1993, to apply to the program. Armed forces members returning to civilian life between now and that date will have two years from the date of discharge to apply. Information is available from the administration's 110 offices around the nation.

HEADLINE: Marxist Revolt Grows Strong In the Shantytowns of Peru

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Defying the drift of recent world history, a Marxist rebel movement is rapidly expanding in Peru, carrying the fight from its remote Andean strongholds to this coastal capital's impoverished and politically crucial shantytowns.
The rebel group, the Shining Path, has intensifed its program of killing anyone blocking its way -- Roman Catholic priests, Protestant pastors, foreign aid technicians and housewives running slum soup kitchens. It has seriously disrupted aid programs that offered succor to some of Peru's poorest people. 
 The rebels hope that the poor will embrace their cause, even though the terror campaign is making their lives more miserable. And in a society sharply divided on ethnic and income lines, the alienation of these desperately poor people is so great that the rebel strategy appears to be succeeding.
The Shining Path now says it has reached "strategic equilibrium" with Peru's demoralized army, and analysts fear that as early as next year a violent showdown could take place between two radically different visions of the future of South America's fourth most populous nation.
"Shining Path could easily mobilize 5,000 people and take the presidential palace," a rebel sympathizer boasted. "But the army would counterattack with 10,000 and there would be a genocide. So they will wait."
Rebel leaders are open about their goal: strangling the capital "with bands of iron."
Gustavo Gorriti, a journalist who has studied the Shining Path's growth since its first armed actions in May 1980, said, "If they continue this way, they will be able to beat the Peruvian state."
For its part, the civilian, democratically elected Government of President Alberto Fujimori seeks a free-market revolution in Peru. By slashing bureaucracy and adopting one of the hemisphere's most liberal investment policies, Mr. Fujimori hopes to duplicate the capitalist success of Peru's southern neighbor, Chile.
But the immediate effect of the President's radical adjustment program, called "Fuji-shock" by many here, has been increased unemployment and poverty. Peruvian business executives are telling pollsters that terrorism is their No. 1 concern, and foreign investors are discouraged by the rating given Peru by Business Risks International, an American company: "The world's riskiest country for business."
The Shining Path rebels, known in Spanish as Sendero Luminoso, look across the Pacific to the China of an earlier day, where the movement's leader, Abimael Guzman, lived during Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution. Luis Arce Borja, editor of the movement's clandestine newspaper, El Diario, has estimated that it may cost a million lives for the Shining Path to win power and to restructure this nation of 22 million people into a Maoist peasant and worker state.
 
The Toll to Date
 So far, the 11-year-old war has cost about 23,000 lives and about $18 billion in economic damage.
The rebel leaders, believing their movement to be "a beacon for world revolution," hope one day to export Marxist revolution to neighboring Bolivia and Ecuador, nations with the large Indian and mixed-race populations that are Shining Path's power base.
With Peru at a crossroads, Mr. Fujimori is touring the world in search of emergency economic help. In September, he visited Washington. In October, he toured four European capitals. And now he is making appeals in four Asian countries, including Japan, the birthplace of his immigrant parents.
Industrial nations, lauding Mr. Fujimori's efforts to regain international financial standing after his predecessor, Alan Garcia, suspended the country's foreign debt payments, have committed $1.1 billion to help Peru pay its debts to banks, and the Inter-American Development Bank has approved a $425 million loan to Peru.
 
The Shantytowns
Rebels Cement Hold Over Nation's Poor
 Cupped by bone-dry mountains five miles east of Lima's center, Raucana is a model Maoist town. Protected by high walls, watchtowers and trenches, squatters collectively dug wells, raised light poles and laid out streets. A square was designated for "people's trials" and for public whippings of prostitutes, thieves, homosexuals, drug users and wife beaters.
"Long live President Gonzalo," red graffiti proclaim outside the settlment entrance, using Mr. Guzman's nom de guerre. "Fujimori: servant of reaction and imperialism."
Last Sunday afternoon, in a shack made of woven reed mats and plastic sheets, the owner's eye gleamed with more than the homemade corn alcohol he offered a visitor. "If one of us falls, another immediately rises to take his place," he said of the leadership structure implanted by the Shining Path. "It's been 160 years of government by the rich. Now it's our turn."
In August, when the police threatened to carry out an eviction order, 1,000 Raucana residents twice took up rocks, slingshots and firebombs and blocked a one-mile stretch of the nearby Central Highway, Lima's lifeline to food-producing areas in the interior.
Shining Path squads exploded a car bomb in front of a factory owned by an industrialist who holds title to Raucana's land and killed an army general who organized the distribution of medicine in Raucana under a military civic-action program.
 
Tactics of Coercion
 It is in places like Raucana that the country's future is likely to be decided. Sprawling Lima slums of its kind, bereft of Government support and clogged with war refugees from the Andean highlands, are now home to almost one-quarter of the nation's population.
Shining Path militants are spreading their influence through the shantytowns with nighttime marches, killings of political opponents, indoctrination of children in clandestine Schools for Pioneers, seizing of loudspeakers in markets and public squares for political harangues, and intimidation of directors of neighborhood soup kitchens and of Glass of Milk public programs.
Two shantytowns responded with marches against hunger and terror. But increasingly, neighborhood leaders appear too frightened or demoralized to react.
"It's very worrying in the pueblos jovenes," a Western diplomat said, using the local term for shantytowns. "Lots more kids are joining Shining Path."
Acceptance of the radical group now appears to be spreading among those victimized by a deep economic depression. By one estimate, the number of Peruvians living in extreme poverty has nearly doubled in three years, to 13 million.
A graphic indicator of poverty was Peru's cholera epidemic this year. The disease killed 2,540 people and sickened 263,761. Health authorities warn that without money to invest in clean water and sewage disposal, cholera will erupt again soon with the return of the Southern Hemisphere summer.
In a recent poll, 17 percent of those replying said that in today's Peru subversion was "justifiable." Approval of subversion grew as income dropped -- from 2 percent among Lima's wealthiest to 23 percent among the poorest. Among the poor, 38 percent of respondents said the Shining Path would win.
 
The Politics
Widespread Racism Drives the Revolt
 The Shining Path has benefited from the collapse of Peru's once-powerful left-wing parties, mainly the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance of Mr. Garcia, who is accused of destroying the country's economy and is the target of a Congressional corruption investigation. Traditional right-wing parties are also discredited.
The fragmentation of the traditional political order is so complete that Mr. Fujimori's coalition of independent, fiscally conservative technocrats was able to win the June 1990 presidential election despite having the support of only 1 percent of the electorate in a poll taken in March of the same year.
With voters adrift, some political analysts fear that the Shining Path is moving into the vacuum. But the driving force behind the rebellion is a racism that permeates Peruvian society.
When people in this country scrutinize the photographs of arrested guerrillas, few fail to notice their pronounced Indian and mixed-race features, while once again this year Miss Peru looks as is she was plucked off a Spanish beach.
On weekends, Lima's popular television game shows display the nation's rigid class system. The hosts and hostessess, with their milky complexions, invariably look as if they were recruited in Miami. The audiences, with their mixed Indian and Latin features, look as if they were recruited in Lima's shantytowns.
"Sendero doesn't have to prove that they are Andean," said the sympathizer, a mixed-race intellectual. "They speak Quechua and everyone knows it."
Peru's middle and upper classes, sensing that the Shining Path's "new state" holds little promise for them, have been quietly leaving.
Last weekend, swimming pools shimmered in the Andean sun at a golf course in Chaclacay, a mountain resort 40 minutes from Lima. Belying the tranquil image, the renter of condominium walked the links, pointing out the houses that remained unvisited because the owners were afraid to risk a weekend outside Lima.
 
Foreign Aid
Rebels' Message: Keep Out of Peru
 A nondescript brick building here carries no sign identifying its mission. Only after an invisible guard screens visitors does a bombproof street door click open. Stepping inside a steel cage, a visitor waits for approval.
The building holds the Peruvian offices of Catholic Relief Services.
The Shining Path has declared war on foreign aid programs. In part, the opposition is doctrinal. Seeking totalitarian control, the movement rejects competition from church, state or the private sector.
To underline its campaign against foreign aid, the Shining Path chose the 11th anniversary of its armed struggle to kill two directors of World Vision International, a Protestant charity with headquarters in Monrovia, Calif., outside Los Angeles.
"We lost six lives in two months," said Corina Villacorta, acting director of World Vision Peru. Two weeks ago, World Vision decided to end virtually all operations here. In December, aid will be stopped to 136 communities and to 22,000 children it has sponsored.
After the guerrillas killed three Japanese agricultural workers in July, the Japanese Government pulled out its entire mission of 52 aid workers.
In a well-secured building that had been East Germany's Embassy, Karl Ahlers, director of the German aid program here, ran a mental checklist: "We have frozen our level of people. The French, the Swiss, the Dutch, the British -- they have all reduced personnel."
Explaining why some aid missions maintain skeleton staffs here, he said, "Psychologically, it would be fatal for Peru if we pulled totally out of the country."
The terrorists have also started attacking religious leaders.
In August, Shining Path squads shot to death three Catholic priests -- two Poles and an Italian. Many analysts say the intimidation campaign caused the Catholic hierarchy's decision two weeks ago to decline a Government invitation to preside over a National Peace Council.
Even harder hit have been Peru's evangelical Protestant churches, which are strong in rural areas.
As many as 1,200 Protestant pastors and lay leaders have been killed in a decade of violence, said Caleb Meza, director of a human rights commission for the National Evangelical Concilium of Peru.
"The pastors often also serve as civil authorities or as leaders of rural defense militias," he said, adding that Peru's army is responsible for about 20 percent of the killings.
 
The Military
Army Is No Match For Cocaine Trade
 Many Peruvians would like to see more effective counterinsurgency operations by their country's military. But the 120,000-soldier army is demoralized by low salaries and old equipment.
"When a typical colonel has to drive a taxi to make ends meet, you know you have problems," a Western diplomat here said. Officers who make $90 a month have proved incapable of standing up to Peru's $1 billion-a-year cocaine business, some of which is controlled by the Shining Path.
Arms aid from the United States, $24 million this year, is running into Congressional opposition because of the Peruvian armed forces' dismal human rights record. This country leads the world in documented cases of disappearances of people taken prisoner by the security forces. Mr. Fujimori has ordered the military to crack down on human rights violators in its ranks.
