HEADLINE: Rogue or Reformer, Edwards Seeks Louisiana Vindication

SERIES: Louisiana Showdown: Duke vs. Edwards - Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Even in Louisiana, where politics has always resided in a steamy limbo somewhere between stern moral drama and ribald fruitcake theater, there is something extraordinary in the vision of Edwin W. Edwards as penitent seeking redemption.
"I can't tell you how important this is to me," Mr. Edwards, who faces State Representative David Duke in the Nov. 16 election for governor, told a packed fund-raising event in Lake Charles on Monday night. 
 "No person in Louisiana thought four years ago, or two years ago, or even six months ago, I would ever have the opportunity again given me to leave a legacy and leave a good record. I can't tell you how important this is to Edwin Edwards. I'm not going to miss this opportunity."
After dominating Louisiana politics for two decades, first as a colorful populist who symbolized the glories of the oil boom, then as a discredited rogue who was booted out of office when the boom went bust, Mr. Edwards, the only three-time governor in Louisiana history, is back seeking a fourth term.
His is an unlikely comeback in every way. Mr. Edwards's opponent is a former Nazi and Ku Klux Klan leader, which helps explain why Mr. Edwards's longtime enemies in the business establishment are now rallying to his side. And Mr. Edwards has even tried to assume the role of elder statesman after symbolizing the let-the-good-times-roll ethic of the boom years.
Mr. Edwards, who has testified more than 15 times before grand jury investigations and was tried twice, but never convicted, on racketeering charges, has a lot to overcome.
"Just one screw-up, one sleazy friend to get indicted, one more grand jury investigation that sticks, would really turn people against him," said John Maginnis, author of "The Last Hayride," a biography of Mr. Edwards published by Gris Gris Press of Baton Rouge in 1984. "But Edwin Edwards is a very proud man who has everything in life except his good name, and he wants it back, even if he has to give good government to do it."
From the jumbo jets packed with campaign contributors who flew to Paris after his election in 1983 to the racketeering charges, Mr. Edwards symbolized an era when Louisiana was awash in oil money.
 
From City Council To State Capital
 But his story is far more complicated than that. Born poor near Marksville in central Louisiana 64 years ago, Edwin Washington Edwards first ran for office in 1954, when he was elected to the City Council in Crowley, in the Cajun country of southwest Louisiana.
That victory began a string of victories that took him to the State Senate in 1964, to Congress in 1965 and to the governor's mansion in 1971.
That year, he beat a 17-candidate field that included two cousins of Huey Long; Jimmie Davis, the former governor and country western star; David Chandler, a Life magazine writer who was running to write a book about it, and State Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, later to be a United States Senator.
The first Governor of Cajun descent to be elected since Reconstruction, he won with a coalition of blacks, Cajuns and blue-collar whites and took office pledging reform and racial unity. He took the oath in French and English, exchanged a Gallic embrace with his brother Nolan and proclaimed:
"To the poor, the elderly, the unemployed, the thousands of black Louisianans who have not yet enjoyed the full bounty of the American dream, we extend not a palm with alms, but the hand of friendship."
He made breakthroughs in hiring minorities, eliminated a chronic budget crisis and got the Legislature to agree to a constitutional convention that led to a modernization of the State Constitution. He pushed through legislation changing the method of taxing oil from a flat rate to a percentage of value, a change that paved the way for the boom years.
After serving the two consecutive terms allowed by law, he left office in 1979 more popular than when he was first elected -- a feat no one had pulled off since the days of Huey Long.
 
Silvery Good Looks In an Era of Glitter
 With his quick quips, silvery good looks, and bayou charm, Mr. Edwards did more than preside over the boom. He personified the spirit of a time when the biggest crime was to be boring. In one of his most famous quips, he said of his Republican successor, David Treen, "He's so slow, it takes him an hour and a half to watch '60 Minutes.' "
But even during the height of his popularity, Mr. Edwards had a personal record that might have sunk anyone else. His womanizing was so well known that when asked by reporters if he feared that his phone was being tapped, he said no, then added, "Except by jealous husbands."
He gambled tens of thousands of dollars (his own) at the craps tables in Las Vegas, made light of allegations that state offices were sold to campaign contributors, and somehow escaped unscathed from one scandal after another, including his admission in 1976 that the South Korean lobbyist Tongsun Park had given his wife a $10,000 gift.
"There's a big difference between what's illegal and what causes you people to raise your eyebrows," he told reporters. But when he was re-elected to an unprecedented third term in 1983, the boom was already over, and so was its laissez-faire morality.
He was tried twice in Federal court on charges that while out of office he earned $2 million as part of a conspiracy to obtain and sell lucrative hospital and nursing home approvals and then aided the conspiracy when he returned to office in 1984.
Prosecutors said he illegally used his influence to aid the applications of associates, who then sold the permits at huge profits to developers. They also alleged that he furthered the conspirary while in office by calling for a moratorium on further permits.
Mr. Edwards never denied making money on the transaction but denied doing anything illegal.
A 1985 trial ended in a hung jury. A 1986 retrial ended in acquittal. But the image of influence peddling had more sting in tough times than it might have during the boom. And while he was tied up in court, the state's budget, like all those in the Oil Patch, was spinning out of control.
In 1987, Mr. Edwards, who had never lost a political race in his life, finished second to Buddy Roemer in the open primary and withdrew from the runoff, seemingly ending his colorful career.
But Mr. Edwards never considered that the end. In fact, his son Stephen said, Mr. Edwards had begun planning his comeback two weeks before his defeat, when it became obvious that the tide was running against him.
Mr. Edwards got his revenge on Oct. 19, when Mr. Roemer finished third in the primary, behind him and Mr. Duke. But Mr. Edwards is quick to say that he ran not to avenge a defeat but to redeem his good name.
"There's no way I would go through what I've gone through simply to beat somebody," he said. "I have a more important goal, that is to be a good governor and leave a good record."
 
A Political Marriage Is an Uneasy One
 "This last campaign is for him," said his son Stephen, a partner in his father's law firm. "At 64 years old, he doesn't need the work. He doesn't need the money. It's the only chance and the last chance for him to change his image and his place in history."
In the world turned upside down by David Duke, Mr. Edwards now finds himself supported by all the corporate, good-government interests who had always considered him anathema.
It is anything but a natural marriage. In fact, there is widespread fear that a corrupt Edwards administration that could last eight years could be a bigger menace than an ineffective Mr. Duke for four years.
"There are still lots of what I call good people that can't vote for Edwards," said Mark Drennen, president of the business-oriented Public Affairs Research Council in Baton Rouge. "They just know too many political deals that were cut."
But Mr. Edwards has promised to put together a diverse business coalition and keep on State Inspector General Bill Lynch, a former reporter who has dogged him through the years, in an effort to insure clean government.
Even the skeptics admit that no one in Louisiana is a smarter politician or a more adept master of the legislative process than Edwin Edwards. "A lot of us have said, 'Wouldn't it be great if the Governor were a combination of Edwards's political skill and Roemer's integrity and progressive government issues?' " Mr. Drennen said. "If he's sincere, he has the experience and the skills to pull off some major reforms."
Still, some wonder whether Mr. Edwards knows how to mount a real reform agenda even if he wants to, or if he will be committed to resolving the state's enormous environmental problems after a dismal record in the past.
 
Desire Still Bright If the Magic Isn't
 Mr. Edwards has promised that he will attract good jobs and work effectively for reform with the Legislature in a way that eluded Mr. Roemer. But other than a proposal to build a new airport in New Orleans, he has offered few initiatives.
Even the old Edwards personal magic seems to have dimmed.
When Mr. Edwards and Mr. Duke appeared recently at the International Rice Festival in Mr. Edwards's hometown of Crowley, Mr. Edwards looked stiff and subdued as he rode in a blue Chevrolet van. Mr. Duke rode standing up in the front seat of an open bright red 1950's Thunderbird, smiling expansively as the breeze ruffled his blow-dried blond hair.
Mr. Maginnis said that in a state where even good-government types like Mr. Roemer are supposed to be mavericks, Mr. Edwards may look like yesterday's populist.
"Duke is the guy that has the maverick appeal that Edwards had," he said. "Edwards represents the populism of Huey Long and the New Deal, which ran out of gas long ago. Duke has the Reagan agenda, which is so hot."
But Mr. Edwards has shown that he has some passion of his own left. He ended his debate Wednesday night with Mr. Duke with an impassioned evocation of Mr. Duke's history of racial and religious extremism.
"While David Duke was burning crosses and scaring people, I was building hospitals to heal them," he began. "When he was selling Nazi hate literature as late as 1989 in his legislative office, I was providing free textbooks for the children of this state."
He went on: "Don't let him divide us. Don't let him separate us from the rest of the nation. Don't let him make a mockery of Louisiana. We're too important, and too good for that."
If the stakes for Louisiana are huge, they're just as large for Mr. Edwards. If he loses, he adds handing Louisiana over to Mr. Duke to the ignominious finale of his last term.
If he wins, he enters the governor's mansion for a fourth term with a chance for redemption.
Asked how he expects his political obituary to read, he doesn't hesitate for a second.
"He had his last best chance and he used it," said Edwin Edwards.

HEADLINE: U.S. Withholding Drug Aid to Peru

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A United States plan to aid Peruvian Government efforts to reduce coca production, a $1 billion industry with connections to the Shining Path guerrilla group, has stalled over charges that the Peruvian Army and security forces are continuing to take payoffs to protect cocaine traffickers, Administration and Congressional officials say.
United States officials report that Peruvian Army units have repeatedly shot at police helicopters on drug interdiction and herbicide-spraying missions, including once last month when an agent of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency was on board. Although no one was hurt, the incident revived the fears expressed by members of Congress who opposed the Administration's plan to send military advisers to Peru to train its security forces in antidrug techniques. 
 The Government of President Alberto K. Fujimori has been unable to discipline officers and troops who refuse to halt smugglers' flights from Peru, the leading producer of coca, to Colombia, where it is refined into cocaine for export to the United States and Europe. Recognizing the unreliability of the Peruvian security forces, Congress has frozen the $24.9 million military aid program and $60 million more in economic assistance.
"There is a policy gridlock with regard to Peru," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs. "The Administration's entire strategy of using the police and army against the traffickers is flawed because they are totally and completely corrupted."
 
'No Police Inspections'
 Mr. Torricelli reported that on a trip to Peru two weeks ago, drug administration personnel told him that Peruvian military commanders were receiving protection fees from traffickers.
"I saw airplanes leaving municipal airports for Colombia under the instruction of air traffic conptrollers with no police inspections," he added. "They say they don't have jurisdiction to intervene in the cocaine flights."
A State Department official who monitors Peru acknowledged: "We're not ready to disburse the money. Right now, the Peruvians haven't fulfilled the conditions."
But officials say the aid program is critical to their antidrug efforts since most of the cocaine that is consumed in the United States originates in the Peruvian Andes. They say the war on drugs is directly linked to the war on the Shining Path, since the rebels protect growers and may even cultivate coca plants themselves to finance their insurgency.
The divergent priorities of Lima and Washington may work against one another. While the primary objective of the Bush Administration is to reduce cocaine supplies, Peruvian officials fear that eradication of coca cultivation could further impoverish the Indian peasantry. If the army is seen as taking away their incomes, some officers say, more peasants will join the ranks of Shining Path. Such thinking, ironically, sometimes places the army and the guerrillas on the same side of the drug war.
In September, the Administration reluctantly accepted cuts and conditions set by Congress on the proposed aid program, which included sending a few dozen American military trainers to help Peruvian forces improve their antinarcotics abilities and performance on human rights.
 
Military Aid Withheld
 Eager for increased American help, the Peruvian military and police forces have begun to meet the Congressional conditions on human rights, but they are failing to meet the Congressional condition that they improve their performance in the war on drugs. The Administration has not yet released any of the $24.9 million in military aid, and while it is preparing to give Congress a report on Peruvian human rights performance this week and release $22 million in economic aid, it has delayed consultations with Congressional leaders on Peruvian progress in the drug war.
State Department officials said they were still optimistic that United States military aid would eventually flow to Peru, but they acknowledged that it would be politically difficult and perhaps even counterproductive to report to Congress that Peru was improving its performance in the drug war any time soon.
The Peruvian Ambassador, Roberto Maclean, conceded that "corruption in the armed forces is a problem," but he said his country could not address such shortcomings without Washington's help in training the security forces and providing aid to provide crop alternatives to peasants who grow coca to eke out a living.
The Administration originally intended to send Special Forces and Navy personnel to train two Peruvian Army combat battalions, create river patrols and refurbish Peruvian Army helicopters and Air Force combat jets. The trainers were to concentrate on improving coordination between the army and the police in antidrug operations. Congress has already cut the program intended to train the two battalions.
The economic aid program was intended to complement the military aid by providing money for Government programs that encourage growers to substitute beans, tomatoes and other crops for coca. But American officials are now reporting that while coca farmers are planting vegetable and fruit substitutes, they are clearing jungle lands to expand their cocaine crops as well.
 
Growing U.S. Involvement
 The United States has increased its involvement in the war against Peruvian cocaine over the last four years. Since 1987, Drug Enforcement Administration officials and antidrug officers under State Department contract have worked at the American-built Santa Lucia base in the coca-growing Upper Huallaga Valley advising the police on eradication and on maintaining helicopters and other equipment. Beginning in October 1989, United States Army Special Forces have instructed 800 Peruvian police officers in jungle drug interdiction.
State Department officials said they still had confidence that Mr. Fujimori would eventually fulfill their demands that he clean up the military. "He listens to our concerns," said a State Department official, who noted that Lima had made much progress in the last month in improving its human rights record.
In recent weeks, fulfilling major Congressional conditions for aid, military prisons have been opened to inspections by international human rights monitors, and military units have begun to register the detention of all suspects with a central registrar. And last week the army for the first time charged an army officer with murder.

HEADLINE: Health Plans That Cut Costs Gaining Favor

BYLINE: By GLENN KRAMON

 BODY:
With reassuring advertisements starring Snoopy, Gene Kelly and New Yorkers themselves, insurance companies are urging employers and employees in the metropolitan area to join cost-conscious health plans. And after years of resistance, they are finding many takers.
The health plans are built around networks of doctors and hospitals that have agreed to charge lower-than-normal fees and to allow reviews of their methods. 
 The plans offer employers a chance to limit health-care expenses. They offer employees lower costs -- most pay almost nothing beyond what their employers pay -- as well as freedom from burdensome claim forms, coverage for preventive care like cancer screening and insurer review of their treatment.
 
Resistance to Constraints
 Some of these "managed care" networks are simply variations on the health-maintenance and preferred-provider organizations that have been around for years but have never gained wide popularity in the metropolitan region, largely because employers in the region, unlike their counterparts in places like the West Coast and Minneapolis, resisted constraints on the freedom to choose doctors. They offered plans based on networks only as an option, if at all.
Many new plans have met objections about freedom of choice by allowing members to decide whether to use network doctors and be fully covered or go outside the network and pay more themselves.
But with those changes, with the region in the grip of a recession and with medical costs rising sharply, a growing number of employers are forcing their workers into network plans or creating stronger financial incentives to join.
 
Large Corporations
 As a result, "the New York metro area is beginning to look a lot like other parts of the country," said Joseph W. Duva, a partner at Ernst & Young specializing in managed care. "We're seeing a lot of employers adopt managed-care programs." They include large corporations -- among them, A.T.&T., Citicorp, I.B.M., American Express, Grumman, Pepsico, Macy's and Xerox -- as well as government employers -- including New York City and the states of New York and New Jersey.
They also include a growing number of midsized businesses and organizations, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hunts Point Multi-Service Center, and even companies with as few as five employees, like Randall Decorators on Staten Island and Allied Metal in the Bronx.
About a quarter of those insured by employers in the region now use some form of medical network, and the number is expected to grow, said William R. Broyles, publisher of the National Managed Care Newsletter in Washington. Some of that growth may be a result of heavy advertising by a variety of commercial and nonprofit insurers. One of the most aggressive, U.S. Healthcare, has used upbeat commercials featuring Gene Kelly ("Singin' in the Rain"), Maurice Chevalier ("Thank Heaven for Little Girls") and Louis Armstrong ("A Lot of Livin' to Do"). Metropolitan Life has enlisted its spokesman, the "Peanuts" character Snoopy.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, a classic health maintenance organization known as HIP, is countering with lighthearted ads emphasizing the diversity of the people it covers. And Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has used its top executives in full-page advertisements with the slogan "Bet You Didn't Know" to talk about a medical network introduced last summer.
The battle for new insurance customers is being fought as a growing number of people -- the self-employed and those whose small employers do not offer insurance benefits -- are unable to find affordable coverage anywhere.
And it is not clear that the networks will limit medical-cost increases enough to satisfy employers. If they don't, "we will move much more toward government regulation, as every other country has," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health-insurance expert at Princeton University. "This is the last hurrah for the market approach to running the health-care system."
The networks come in several forms. The traditional health maintenance organization receives a fixed, prepaid fee for each enrolled employee, no matter how much treatment that employee requires, and employs doctors or contracts with them for full-time service. An employee must commit to membership at the beginning of the year and choose a doctor -- usually an internist or family practitioner -- who oversees care and makes referrals to specialists. The organization provides no coverage for treatment provided by doctors outside the network. Many employees choose such plans for lower costs.
 
Challenged in Westchester
 The nonprofit HIP, which began in 1944 and now has more than a million members, is the dominant health maintenance organization in New Jersey, New York City, Long Island and Westchester. It is being challenged in Westchester by Kaiser Permanente, a nonprofit giant from the West Coast that will expand in a new health center in White Plains next spring.
Other network health plans try to offer a wide selection of physicians and hospitals in diverse locations as a way of making themselves attractive. Doctors in these plans may work for more than one network. Some of them receive fixed, prepaid fees; others are paid for each service they render. Patients are not covered for treatment outside the network.
U.S. Healthcare, a publicly held company, operates this style of network, as do such big commercial insurers as Metropolitan Life, Prudential, Aetna, Cigna, Travelers and New York Life.
Some independent networks have entered the field. On Long Island, there is ChoiceCare, owned by Winthrop University Hospital and a Buffalo plan. In Westchester and Connecticut, there is Physicians Health Services, largely owned by a group of physicians. And throughout the region is Oxford Health Plans, which recently offered stock to the public.
By far the fastest-growing type of health plan is one that operates a network but will pay something for treatment outside it. Almost every insurer is moving to offer such a plan.
U.S. Healthcare is among the latest to join the trend. One employee it covers is Harvey Hershey, who works in sales at Towne Office Supply in Manhattan. If Mr. Hershey stays within the network, he pays just $2 to visit a specialist, $2.50 for a prescription and nothing to see his primary physician or for a hospital stay or preventive care or a lab test. And he no longer files claims -- that is the doctor's responsibility.
If Mr. Hershey goes outside the network, he must pay a $250 deductible ($500 for family coverage) and 25 percent of the bill beyond that, up to an annual maximum of $2,500, or $7,500 for a family. By offering such escape clauses, insurers hope to persuade people who are wary of network plans to try them out.
 
Limiting Increases
 In theory, if more employees use the cost-effective physicians in a network, the employer saves more. Insurers say networks can limit the annual increase in an employer's medical costs to 10 to 15 percent or even less, compared with more than 20 percent under plans that do not provide cost controls.
Insurers are also trying to prove that they care as much about quality as about price. Like some other insurers, U.S. Healthcare checks physicians' credentials and malpractice records when considering them for its network. It also surveys patients about how satisfied they are and uses these surveys and a twice-a-year audit of medical records to determine the doctor's compensation.
If enough employees can be sold on the networks, or if medical costs continue to climb, insurers are likely to cut back or eliminate the out-of-network coverage. That would save employers money because it would cut administrative costs and because they would be paying only the doctors offering better financial deals.
The networks do have problems. The physicians and hospitals are not always convenient for employees, particularly those living in outlying areas. And physicians sometimes drop out of networks, forcing members to find new doctors.
Networks may complicate life, Mr. Hershey said. "You have to go through your primary-care physician before you can see a specialist," he said.
What is more, the medical networks add administrative expenses, typically equal to 5 percent of the employer's medical bill.
Finally, said Mark V. Pauly, a health economist at the Wharton School, all these efforts to restrain costs may be swamped by the added expense of new kinds of treatments and the eagerness of patients and doctors to try them even if the chance of success is low. For all the new cost-control apparatus, it is still hard to say no to a patient.

HEADLINE: Arriving in Tokyo, Baker Starts 3-Nation Asia Tour

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Tokyo today at the start of a politically risky Asian tour likely to determine whether relations between China and the United States remain strained or can begin to recover in the aftermath of Beijing's violent crackdown on democracy advocates in 1989.
After stops in Japan and South Korea, Mr. Baker is to travel on Friday to Beijing in the highest-level visit by a Bush Administration official since the Tiananmen Square killings of June 1989. Although Mr. Baker's trip is going ahead as planned, President Bush last week responded to domestic political concerns by canceling a planned Asian tour beginning late this month. 
 Administration officials say that secret contacts between Washington and Beijing have assured Mr. Baker that he will not leave China empty-handed or embarrassed. But it is far from certain that members of Congress will be satisfied with what he extracts from the Chinese in the key areas of arms control, human rights and trade.
 
Solarz 'Uneasy'
 "I am uneasy with this trip," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia, and a leader of efforts to punish China for the crackdown. "If Baker comes back and demonstrates that the trip was justified in the areas of our concern, fine. If he comes back as empty-handed as some others in the Administration before him, the trip will be rightly judged as not only a failure, but a mistake."
Mr. Solarz argued that if Mr. Baker "gives the present Chinese leadership gratuitous legitimacy" without getting anything substantial in return, the debate over the Administration's China policy will likely be rekindled. An unimpressive result might also give new impetus to efforts to strip China of "most-favored-nation" trading benefits, which the Administration renewed in June.
 
Movement Is Seen
 An Administration expert involved in planning the trip said, "The Chinese have been doing some things -- not in the human rights area -- in a direction which we see as more positive than negative and we would like to encourage them to continue that movement.
"Look, everyone has mixed feelings about this trip," the official added. "I supported it because you cannot talk credibly about Asia, about Japan becoming a regional power, about the future security architecture in Asia and leave China unattended. It is too important. You avoid China at your peril."
Chinese leaders, the official said, "will want the maximum to give themselves face out of this visit. They will limit their cooperation in the absence of such meetings in order to get that. You go into it aware of that, and it is just a question of how you deal with it."
Bush Administration officials cite several areas where they contend the Chinese are moving in the right direction. The first is their agreement in principle to sign the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons. Others include Beijing's limited cooperation on Middle East arms control -- which primarily involves not yet delivering missiles contracted for by Syria -- and its commitment in principle to join the Missile Technology Control Regime. Finally, on Sept. 23, the Chinese agreed to begin talks on assuring Washington that it will not export to the United States goods produced by prison labor.
 
Cooperation With Iran
 And then there are the areas where Washington will try to prevent further deterioration, like China's increasing nuclear cooperation of with Iran.
What Mr. Baker will apparently try to win from the Chinese is some sort of ironclad commitments not to sell nuclear technology to countries like Iran, Syria or Pakistan, nor any ballistic missiles. Even if the Chinese sign the treaty controlling missile technology, the question is how closely they will abide by it. The treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons is before the Chinese legislature and the Chinese authorities are saying it must be passed there first, although the regime could push it through any time.
"The Chinese are very good at appearing to make concessions and then not doing it," said a Congressional staff expert on China. "That is why the assurances have to be ironclad."
Because so many other issues have captured the headlines in recent years, American trade problems with China have been largely lost from view, but they are extremely serious. To control inflation in recent years the Chinese have clamped down tightly on imports, devalued their currency and erected import-license trade barriers to support their state-owned enterprises -- including those that depend on prison labor. This has led to diminished American exports to China and a trade defict in 1990 of about $10.5 billion.
 
Talks on Market Access
 The United States is already engaged in negotiations with the Chinese over market access. Another yardstick for the success or failure of Mr. Baker's trip will be the extent to which it can speed up these negotiations.
The area where Congress will be most closely watching Mr. Baker's trip, however, will be in the field of human rights. Legislation that would strip China of its preferential trading status is now on hold in Congressional committees; whether the legislation is revived will depend in part on how many political prisoners the Chinese release amonng those arrested since the 1989 crackdown.
Amnesty International estimates that there are roughly 800 such political prisoners, and Congressional experts hope that half will be freed, including some prominent dissidents.
Before Mr. Baker visits Beijing, he will be making his inaugural stopover in Seoul, the South Korean capital.
The most pressing issue now on the Korean-American agenda, say American officials, is what can be done about quickening pace of North Korea's nuclear arms program. Some experts believe North Korea is only 6 to 12 months away from producing a bomb.

HEADLINE: Bishops and Liberals Split on Agendas

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A group of liberal and radical Roman Catholics meeting to discuss changes in church structures only smiled and shrugged when they learned that a major item on the agenda at this week's meeting of Catholic bishops was whether to trim the number of days when the faithful are obliged to attend Mass.
"You can't even explain Holy Days of Obligation to most of our kids," said one of those attending the meeting here, Robert McClory of Evanston, Ill. "It's hard enough to get them to go to church on Sunday." 
 At their semiannual conference in Washington Monday through Thursday, the several hundred bishops will be dealing with a number of substantive issues, like the environment and the needs of American Indians. But they have become extraordinarily cautious when it comes to taking up matters of internal church change. The scope of their actions has steadily narrowed as a result of Vatican pressure and of the appointment of more conservative bishops by Pope John Paul 2d.
 
Issue on Masses
 The bishops are expected to vote on rules that narrowly define the circumstances in which lay people can preach at Masses. But the meeting of Catholics here was more concerned with whether small groups of lay people that formed to worship together or for community action should celebrate Mass without an ordained priest. Such practices have arisen because of a shortage of priests and because of a growing dissatisfaction in some circles with church laws that bar women from ordination and that require celibacy among priests.
The differences in the agendas reflects some of the gaps that exist between the bishops and Catholics who are becoming increasingly outspoken.
The meeting here was sponsored by groups on the liberal-to-radical wing of Catholicism in this country, making the 1,000 people in attendance by no means representative of the nation's 55 million Catholics. But in their ranks are people who have been extremely active in church affairs.
Among them are many who were prominent in the Call to Action of 1976, a national conference in Detroit of Catholic laity and clergy that was sponsored by the bishops in honor of the American Bicentennial. This weekend's meeting observed the 15th anniversary of that conference, which recommended changes in church structures and teachings that the Vatican considered out of bounds.
Although a series of public hearings leading to the 1976 meeting influenced the bishops' 1983 pastoral letter on nuclear arms and 1986 letter on the American economy, most of the recommendations were shelved. It also brought together about 125 members of the hundreds of small Catholic groups that were formed for worship and community action by people who are dissatisfied with their parishes or who are at odds with church policies.
Not long ago, the idea of carrying out the Eucharistic rite without an ordained priest would have been almost universally viewed by Catholics as heretical, if not sacrilegious. Some people at this gathering still appeared to be uncomfortable with the idea of departing from church practices regarding ordination, fearing that it would shock or antagonize most Catholics. But there were virtually no objections, at least in principle, to such practices.
"There's a feeling that a lot of those issues don't really matter anymore or are simply legalistic," said Mary Ann Savard, an officer of Call to Action, a Chicago group that was the chief sponsor of the meeting. "A lot of people have moved beyond where the bishops are and will figure out a way to do Eucharist."
 
A Bid for Change
 Two years ago the group ran advertisements in newspapers nationwide as part of an effort to obtain 100,000 signatures in support of changes in the Catholic church. These included the opening of the priesthood to women and married men, reconsideration of church teachings on sex, establishment of due process in disciplinary actions and financial accountability at all levels, and participation by the laity in the selection of bishops.
The 100,000 signatures have proved hard to obtain. To date, the group has received about 21,000. Call to Action says it has 9,000 members, about 25 percent to 30 percent of them in the Chicago area. The advertisements were sharply criticized by conservative Catholics, many of whom also criticize church officials because they say the hierarchy does not take strong enough measures against Catholics like those meeting here.
Despite the frustration with church leadership -- almost all remarks about conservative bishops drew laughter -- the meeting's mood was subdued rather than angry. Anger did surface in a few workshops, like one entitled "Pedophilia and a Patriarchal Church," linking scandals about church negligence of sexual abuse of children by priests to rules on celibacy and to what was called greater concern for the institution's reputation and clergy than with victims.
In addition, a few speakers noted that the vast majority of people attending the conference were white and middle-class. Many appeared to be between 50 and 60 years old. A large majority were women.
There will be a much larger presence of minorities, although not, of course, women, in the ranks of the bishops and on their agenda. For example, the bishops will consider a statement expressing the concerns of American Indians to next year's commemoration of Columbus's arrival in the Americas as presented in a document that was partially written by two American Indian bishops. It also will discuss plans for a national congress of black Catholics and for a ministry among Hispanic Catholics.
Among other sponsors of the conference here were the Women's Ordination Conference; Corpus, an association promoting a married priesthood; the Association for the Rights of Catholics in the Church; Dignity, an organization of homosexual Catholics, and Network, a liberal Catholic lobbying group.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Catholic laity and clergy participating in the Call to Action National meeting in Chicago. (Jonathan Kirn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Boston Ignores a Trend In Re-Electing a Mayor

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
It was just an impulse, as it often is for Raymond L. Flynn, that prompted him to take a break from campaigning for re-election as Mayor one recent morning to drop in at the Gavin Middle School in South Boston.
How are things going? Mayor Flynn asked the principal, Joseph Lee. Fine, said Mr. Lee, except that the school had no books; the School Department had failed to deliver them. Outraged, Mr. Flynn was soon making a blizzard of phone calls and eventually tracked down the missing volumes. 
 The incident was classic Ray Flynn, who bypassed television and radio advertising in the last election to campaign door to door and who runs several miles a day, making frequent stops to chat with passersby. His strategy paid off: Mr. Flynn won a record-high 75 percent of the vote in his re-election to a third term last Tuesday.
The triumph of the 52-year-old Democrat was all the more remarkable because it came when Boston is mired in its worst economic slump since the Depression and in an election season in which voters around the country vented their anger by ousting incumbents.
 
'An Untypical Politician'
 Mr. Flynn's victory marks him as the most popular politician in Massachusetts, according to John Marttila, a Democratic political consultant here, who cited a variety of private polls that show the Mayor's approval rating surpassing that of Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican.
His impressive showing would make him a strong contender for Governor or possibly as a Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, said Mr. Marttila, who has been a consultant to several of Democratic Presidential aspirants. Mr. Flynn has also gained national recognition as a spokesman on urban issues in his tenure as president of the National Conference of Mayors.
"Ray is really an untypical politician, because he touches average people in the way few politicians these days can," Mr. Marttila said. "He makes people feel that he cares."
Mr. Flynn's appeal, which some critics deride as more style than substance, grows out of a humble boyhood that fixed in him a conviction that "all politics is personal."
Mr. Flynn's father was a longshoreman, often in poor health and out of work, and his mother was a cleaning woman. Mr. Flynn made his way out of poverty by getting a basketball scholarship to Providence College and eventually a tryout with the Boston Celtics. He didn't make the team, and instead got involved in politics, working on Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey's Presidential campaign in 1968 and later being elected to the state legislature to represent his old neighborhood, South Boston. Today he still lives in a modest row house in "Southie," a working-class district on the waterfront.
"I don't have to read memos to know what is going on out there," Mr. Flynn said, sitting in his City Hall office, his feet propped on a coffee table. On the wall is an old campaign poster of his political idol, Mr. Humphrey, who was Mayor of Minneapolis before his terms as a United States Senator and the Vice President.
The Boston press has chided Mr. Flynn for his penchant for showing up at fires or at the scene of racial disturbances, saying that he spends more time getting his picture on television than solving the city's problems.
But voters have reacted differently. "The vast majority of the people who voted for him actually know him," said Ira Jackson, a deputy mayor under Mr. Flynn's predecessor, Kevin H. White, and now a senior vice president of the Bank of Boston. "In today's world, with problems spiraling out of control, that is very reassuring. The voters know Ray will be there."
In fact, a Boston Globe poll last August of 814 registered voters found that 43 percent said they had met Mr. Flynn personally.
 
Challenge of a New Term
 The challenge for the peripatetic Mr. Flynn now, as he enters his third four-year term, is whether personal politics will still be enough.
In his first two terms, Mr. Flynn was widely given credit for easing racial tension that had grown out of a conflict over court-ordered school busing in the mid-1970's. Although he had opposed the busing himself at the time, Mr. Flynn as Mayor made a concerted effort to reach out to Boston's black population, opening predominantly white housing projects to blacks. He restored many of the city's neglected neighborhood parks. And he increased the number of blacks, Hispanics and Asians on the city payroll to 22 percent from 6 percent. Minorities make up 35 percent of Boston's population.
But in the past few years Mr. Flynn has come under growing criticism from some prominent blacks for racial insensitivity.
 
Justice and Education
 In particular, blacks have complained about police behavior, especially in the handling of the investigation of the fatal shooting in 1989 of Carol Stuart and her unborn baby. Her husband, Charles Stuart, claimed the couple had been attacked by a black gunman.
An angry Mr. Flynn called for every available detective to join the investigation, and the police soon disclosed they had a suspect, a black man with a long criminal record. But Mr. Stuart stunned the city a few months later when he apparently committed suicide by jumping off a bridge after one of his brothers implicated him in the killing.
A second issue has developed out of Mr. Flynn's successful drive to replace the elected Boston School Committee with an appointed board. In Mr. Flynn's view, as well as that of some blacks, the quarrelsome School Committee was an obstacle to improving Boston's poor public schools. He will begin appointing the new committee January 1.
But in a city where blacks have held little political power, several prominent blacks believe that Mr. Flynn's dissolution of the old school committee, which had four blacks among its 13 members, was an attack on them, although his aides have indicated that the Mayor may appoint two blacks, a Hispanic person and an Asian to the new, seven-member committee.
"Here is someone not of our community saying, 'I will select your leaders for you,' " said the Rev. Graylan Ellis Hagler, who finished third and was eliminated in the September preliminary election for Mayor.
Mr. Flynn acknowledged that the fight has "caused me some pain." But in his view the schools hold the key to the future of Boston, a city that has been transformed into a center of universities, medical research and investment management. Mr. Flynn wants to streamline what he regards as the bloated bureaucracy of the school system as well as restore athletic programs and improve vocational education.
"School is the ladder out of poverty," he said. "So I will take everyone on to make the schools better."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Defends His Fiscal Plan

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
As he prepared to depart for South Africa yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins strongly defended his long-term fiscal plan against the blunt criticism of Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who urged the Mayor over the weekend to abandon it.
"It is our plan," the Mayor said.
"It's not just Felix." 
 But the Mayor said that "we're willing to talk with all the other players," and in his absence, the Mayor said, First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and Philip R. Michael, the budget director, would meet with Mr. Rohatyn and his aides, among others, to "fine-tune" the plan. The proposal includes a request for $1 billion in M.A.C. funds.
Then the Mayor turned his thoughts ahead and across the ocean to his long-planned and long-awaited mission of solidarity to South Africa's blacks. His luggage bulging with coloring books, balloons and used math and science textbooks for schoolchildren, the Mayor left New York last night with an entourage of more than three dozen city officials and private business people.
As Mayor of the city with the largest black population in the country, Mr. Dinkins has said it is important for him to keep pressing economic sanctions against the white majority government that has subjugated 30 million South African blacks and to lend support to the black majority. Returning to the continent from which, he often notes, his ancestors were brought "chained and whipped in the hold of a slave ship" will be "a profound, singular experience," he has said.
He is traveling under the auspices of Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader whose triumphal reception in New York last year is often cited by Mr. Dinkins as the high point of his mayoralty.

LENGTH: 1950 words

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Foxboro Follies: A Franchise on the Brink

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH

 BODY:
When he was 8 years old, Victor Kiam peddled Cokes to people as they waited for streetcars in New Orleans' sweltering bayou heat. Thus began the career of a man who through years of hustling, ingenuity, diligence and self-promotion crafted himself into a consummate entrepreneur.
Kiam's leveraged buyout of Remington Products from Sperry-Rand for $25 million in March 1979 and the strategies that then sparked Remington's worldwide sales from $43 million to $250 million in nine years are material for business-school courses. But Kiam's purchase of the New England Patriots in October 1988 for $85 million could end up damaging his image as an adept businessman. 
 Last year, the perception of Kiam as the jovial customer-turned-owner of Remington, cultivated through a series of television ads hawking his shavers, suffered heavy damage as he bungled the handling of sexual-harassment allegations by Lisa Olson, then a Boston Herald reporter, against three Patriots players. In the midst of the controversy, Kiam was quoted as using a profane term to describe Olson. He denied doing so, but months later, he openly made her the subject of an off-color joke.
 
Moment of Truth
 The three Patriot players and the team itself were eventually fined by the National Football League in the Olson incident, but as damaging as that decision was to Kiam, he faces an even more crucial moment of reckoning tomorrow.
The 1988 agreement between Kiam and Francis Murray, his partner in taking over the Patriots, stipulated that Kiam, who was buying 51 percent of the team, had to purchase Murray's 49 percent share after three years if Murray demanded it. Murray has made this demand, and is seeking $38 million, which Kiam has had trouble raising.
If Kiam doesn't come up with the money, or someone else to buy out Murray, by tomorrow, the league will in effect take over the team, but Murray will run it from day to day and will be allowed to seek a buyer in order to get his money back.
Murray will then move on to St. Louis, where he is part of a group trying to land an N.F.L. expansion team.
Kiam will be left with nothing but bad memories and, most likely, debts. The proceeds of an eventual sale of the Patriots will go first to covering Murray's share, then to covering a fee for the league. Only if there is something left over will Kiam get back any of the money he borrowed to purchase the team from William (Billy) Sullivan in 1988. As late as Friday, the N.F.L. was trying to help Kiam, who will be 65 years old next month, arrange a financial solution that would enable him to maintain control of the team.
 
Remington Also Under Pressure
 Compounding Kiam's problems is Remington's loss of market share in men's and women's shavers to the industry leader, Norelco, and to Braun, a recent entry in the market for expensive electric shavers.
Rich Dzieruua, the associate editor of Appliance Magazine, said that Remington's share of men's shavers on the market dropped from 30 percent to 28 percent from 1989 to 1990, and that its share of women's shavers dropped from 51 percent to 30 percent from 1989 to 1990.
Dzieruua said his research on market share only reflected the number of units produced for the market and did not track actual sales. But an article in the May 6, 1991, issue of Adweek, which used information from Housewares Executive, a company that follows the manufacturing and sale of household products, reported that Remington's overall sales dropped by an estimated $50 million from the end of 1989 to the end of 1990, to about $200 million.
How Kiam, the son of a lawyer who sold Government bonds on Wall Street, could go from being such a business wizard, and the Patriots' majority owner, to standing on the brink of no return in just three years is a complex study in making a bad deal for a bad team in bad economic times.
Kiam did not return phone calls last week to his office at Remington Products in Bridgeport, Conn. And efforts to arrange an interview through the Patriots were unsuccessful. But at least two people close to the situation were willing to talk about Kiam's predicament.
 
A Victim of Economics
 Norman Braman, the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles and a friend of Kiam, was instrumental in advising Kiam to purchase the Patriots. He also advised Kiam almost a year ago to hire Sam Jankovich away from the University of Miami to become New England's general manager in the wake of the team's 1-15 season in 1990.
Braman said recently that Kiam is a victim of tough economic times.
"It's not just Victor," Braman said. "You see it throughout the United States. The banks are having problems. Companies are having problems obtaining capital from banks. There's no secret to that. Victor's problems are tied into the same problems that are facing our economy."
But Jankovich is trying to stop a financial hemorrhage that has been going on since Kiam took over in 1988. The Feb. 25, 1991, issue of Business Week reported that Kiam lost between $5 million and $6 million on the Patriots in 1989 and 1990, respectively.
"Victor is in very good shape, financially, himself," Jankovich said. "He just doesn't have the collateral that he needs to secure large bank loans."
Kiam certainly did not take a financially solvent team and run it into the ground. The team was losing money before he bought it. Last year, Kiam had to ask the N.F.L. to raise the Patriots' debt limit from $35 million to $45 million. The league agreed, with the provision that Kiam keep the team in the Boston area for the next three years.
If he wasn't facing the deadline tomorrow, perhaps Kiam could engineer a Remington-like turnaround with the Patriots over time, Jankovich said.
 
Sold Bras and Girdles
 Kiam, a Navy veteran, graduated from Yale in two and a half years, attended the Sorbonne in Paris and then received a Master's of Business Administration degree from Harvard in 1951. He was a traveling salesman for Lever Brothers, then sold bras and girdles for Playtex before becoming the company's executive vice president. He left Playtex in 1968 to become president of the Benrus Corporation, a watch manufacturer. Kiam left Benrus in 1977, then in 1979 bought Remington Products for $25 million, using $1 million in stock that he owned and borrowing the rest of the money.
Remington had lost more than $30 million between 1976 and 1979. Kiam turned the company around by eliminating 75 executive positions, slashing corporate perks, consolidating manufacturing at the Bridgeport plant and cutting the cost of the shavers.
The decision to buy the Patriots, a team with a history of debt and management wracked by nepotism and cronyism, now appears to have been a questionable one.
One person in the N.F.L. with knowledge of the Patriots' plight, who did not want to be identified, suggested that Kiam might have been motivated by a desire to attain the high profile that goes along with being the owner of a pro football team. "None of the more recent owners buy teams as moneymakers," he said. "They do it because it puts them in the public eye."
For William Sullivan and nine of his friends who in 1960 paid $25,000 each for the Boston Patriots, the eighth team sold in the American Football League, it was a business venture. In 1966, the A.F.L. merged with the N.F.L., taking the Patriots to a higher financial level. To compete, Sullivan found that he had to spend money he didn't have. So, he borrowed. In 1974, Sullivan borrowed $11 million to buy out his partners.
 
Mounting Losses
 When Kiam bought the team, it was $50 million in debt and Foxboro Stadium, owned by William Sullivan's son Chuck had been placed in bankruptcy court with debts totaling $52.6 million. Chuck Sullivan had lost a reported $8 million promoting Michael Jackson's Victory Tour in 1984. Then, in an attempt to recoup his losses, Chuck Sullivan lost another $18 million trying to sell Michael Jackson souvenirs.
In 1988, the N.F.L. forced a sale. Several prospective buyers looked at the Patriots, but they balked at purchasing the team because the $85 million price tag did not include the stadium, which was in bankruptcy court. Murray, who had an option on the team because he loaned the financially strapped Sullivan $22.6 million in 1986, was close to buying the team along with Paul Fireman, the chairman of Reebok. But the stadium situation was not to Fireman's liking. The deal fell through.
Murray, who did not want to lose his option on the team, then joined with Kiam, the Sullivans' choice buyer, in an uneasy alliance. Kiam was gambling that once he purchased the Patriots, he could buy the stadium out of bankruptcy.
He lost big on that gamble in late 1988 when his offer of $19 million for the stadium was topped by a $25 million bid by the K Corporation, which is owned by Boston businessmen Robert Karp and Steve Kraft. K Corporation assumed the over-generous lease arrangement that William Sullivan had worked out with his son, Chuck. The lease, which has 10 years left on it, is generally regarded as one of the worst in the N.F.L.
Under the arrangement, K Corporation gets all the money generated by luxury boxes, concessions and parking, which amounts to about $2.5 million a year, and it gets $1.2 million in rent from the team, including $125,000 a year for Kiam's box. The Patriots also have to pay for stadium security and cleanup.
Not all N.F.L. teams own the stadiums they play in, but most share in the revenue from concessions, parking, luxury boxes and stadium ads. While the biggest revenue generator for teams is the league's television contract, which amounts to $36 million per team this season, money from stadium-related areas can mean the difference between profit and loss, particularly for teams with high player payrolls and big administrative staffs, both of which New England has.
"It is a big problem," Jankovich said of the Patriots' stadium lease. "It's something that we've had to work around since I arrived. If an N.F.L. team is to succeed, it definitely needs a good stadium lease."
Once he became owner, Kiam fumbled in some situations that could have eased his financial burden. He didn't trim the Patriots' administrative staff the way he did when he took over Remington. And Patrick Sullivan, William Sullivan's youngest son, was kept on as the team's general manager as part of the purchase deal.
After the team finished 9-7 in 1988, Kiam increased ticket prices 17 percent for 1989, alienating season-ticket holders who were already complaining about deteriorating conditions at the stadium. The season-ticket sale has dropped from 37,000 in 1988 to 18,000 this year, and attendance has plummeted by an average of nearly 15,000 fans a game in the same span.
The Patriots have gone through three head-coaching changes in Kiam's three years as owner -- from Raymond Berry to Rod Rust to Dick MacPherson. Jankovich estimates the buyouts on the Berry and Rust contracts cost the team $5 million. Add to that bonus-ladened player contracts linked to individual, rather than team, performance, and the financial drain has been significant. The Patriots' player payroll last season was $19.4 million, which ranked it 12th among the league's 28 teams.
Jankovich hopes that Kiam can somehow keep control of the Patriots. And the general manager adds that this is not because Kiam's ouster could put him out of a job.
"He's a very good person," Jankovich said. "He's a guy who lives at the edge. An eternal optimist, who is very bright and who is constantly selling."
What happens to the consummate salesman when nobody's buying? It appears that Victor Kiam is about to find out.

GRAPHIC: Photo: When Victor Kiam bought the Patriots they were $50 million in debt. Now he needs to raise $38 million to keep his share of the team. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Adlai & Mario & Ike & George

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston is former chief Washington correspondent and executive editor of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After watching Gov. Mario Cuomo flirting with the Presidency and teasing the press with his mystifying soliloquies, one is reminded of how Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois handled similar doubts in the campaign of 1952.
They have some things in common: the most eloquent politicians of their times and the favorite candidates of their political parties. But otherwise they seem quite different. 
 After Dwight Eisenhower entered the race in 1952, Mr. Stevenson not only felt he couldn't win, he asked, with his mocking humor, how could a man named Adlai defeat a man called Ike? But he also felt his party shouldn't win. The Democrats had been in power for 20 years. The U.S., he told me many times, would never be secure unless the Republican Party joined in a common, nonpartisan foreign policy. It was, he insisted in private, clearly time for a change, and while he finally agreed to run, not once but twice, his heart wasn't really in it. He ran because he thought it was his duty to discuss the great issues of his time, win or lose.
Governor Cuomo is not a man of the 1950's, but a different man of the 1990's, when winning is widely regarded not only as the main thing but the only thing. The Governor of Illinois sort of enjoyed losing, but not the Governor of New York, who has had his share of adversity in life, and his doubts have not been the same as Mr. Stevenson's.
He does not admire George Bush as Mr. Stevenson admired Mr. Eisenhower. He does not regard a Republican victory in 1992 as desirable but as detestable, and, unlike Mr. Stevenson, he is not inhibited by self-doubt or modesty. There is yet one other major difference between them. When Mr. Stevenson died of a heart attack on a London street, Frank Sayre, Woodrow Wilson's grandson, delivered the eulogy at a memorial service in the Washington Cathedral, and concluded by saying: "He had the courage to fail."
This was true. Mr. Stevenson knew from the beginning of both campaigns that he would lose. He was an even more private person than Mr. Cuomo is, and hated the roguery of politics and the clatter and hypocrisy of the campaigns. But he came to believe that in a democracy, if his party wanted him to run, he did not have the right to stand aside.
Governor Cuomo clearly does not share this conviction. It is not that he doesn't have an argument against the Republicans' record of the last 10 years. He condemns their deficits, their hypocrisy and their scandals with withering contempt. And there's nothing in his record to suggest he would do anything but rejoice at the thought of debating President Bush about the causes and consequences of the recession and even about the causes and consequences of the gulf war.
No doubt he hates the prospect of a long primary election campaign, when he would seem to be neglecting his duties and deficits in Albany and have to answer awkward questions from nosy reporters, who have never been his favorite companions.
But his hesitations are beginning to irritate his party and bore the country, and lately he has been blaming his hesitations on the absence of celestial guidance. For example, the other day he told my colleague Maureen Dowd that unlike Saul on the road to Tarsus, he hadn't received a signal from on high to lead the way into the Promised Land -- a remark that put a burden on the voters and the Lord.
But he did get a signal from the Pennsylvania voters that the poor and middle class didn't like to be out of work with no health insurance, that they didn't like George Bush's America Last priorities and that they weren't very confident about the future. In fact, they are beginning to mock the President's optimistic predictions about the economy and to resent his complaint that he is "tired" of Democratic "nitpicking."
This seems to have changed the Governor's tune if not his mind, and opened up the possibility, not of failure, but of success.
I don't think, however, that Governor Cuomo really feels he has a duty to run, and in that he clearly differs from Governor Stevenson.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: WORLD'S APPETITE FOR U.S. PRODUCTS IS STILL INCREASING

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The appetite for American goods and services remains robust around the globe, a sign that exports are likely to remain a bright spot in the otherwise lackluster American economy.
Japanese newspaper readers want color photos. Venezuelan households want top-loading washers. The residents of Indonesia want cleaner air. And American companies are reaping the benefits. 
 "We're seeing strong export business that is keeping the wolf away from the door," said Milton Glass, chairman of the International Business Center of New England, an organization that represents 400 or so area exporters.
 
Small Portion of G.N.P.
 Exports alone cannot turn a foot-dragging recovery into a fast-paced one, because they account for just one-tenth of the gross national product. But their strength can provide much-needed support.
Forecasters at Paine Webber expect exports of goods and services to grow at an average rate of 6 percent after inflation over the next four quarters, compared with the 4 percent gain of the last four quarters. And indeed, export orders, a good indicator of future sales of merchandise, have been expanding at a annual rate of better than 9 percent so far this year.
American exports have a number of things going for them right now, executives and economists say. For one, even though demand is soft in some large markets, lots of smaller ones are thriving. Business is surging in South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong; Mexico is booming after nearly a decade of economic decline. And Canada, the biggest customer of the United States, is shaking off recession.
 
Low Production Costs
 The United States also has some of the lowest production costs in the industrialized world. It has sophisticated equipment, materials and services for sale that happen to be in growing demand, including aircraft, specialty chemicals and engineering services. And American companies are displaying a growing worldliness and savoir-faire.
"U.S. companies have found out how to do business overseas," said Paris Nicolaides, vice president of international business development at the Thermo Electron Corporation, a Waltham, Mass., maker of pollution-control devices and other industrial instruments. "Exporters have room to grow just by becoming more proficient in how to sell, how to distribute, how to speak the language. That's the main reason I am optimistic that exports will rise."
During the summer, the three-year boom in American exports paused, reflecting the lingering effects of recessions in Britain and Canada, as well as slowing growth in Germany and Japan. And despite a pickup in many countries, some exports, like food and farm machinery, seem stuck in the doldrums.
Nonetheless, executives and economists alike are hopeful.
"I think 1992 will be an excellent year," said Richard L. Williams, vice president of international dealer networks at Pitney Bowes Inc. in Stamford, Conn.
The resiliency of American exports reflects several trends.
 
Global Slump Mostly Over
 First, the global slump never got so bad as people feared, and now it seems to be mostly over. In Germany and Japan, both major customers for American aircraft, chemicals, paper and other industrial materials, the economies are slowing but seem likely to skirt outright recession.
Worldwide, economic growth slowed from around 3 percent last year to an estimated 2 percent this year, according to DRI/McGraw-Hill, whose economists expect it to reach 3.5 percent next year.
More important, said Robert Gay, an economist at Morgan Stanley, lots of small economies have continued to expand smartly. American exports to Japan and Europe slowed to 4 percent this year, but exports to lesser-developed countries and newly industrialized countries grew at a 14 percent rate.
Despite a deep recession in Brazil, Latin America is growing again after stagnating during the 1980's. The huge trade deficits that South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong used to run with the United States have all but disappeared. Kuwait is slowly rebuilding, and Saudi Arabia is overhauling its oil production.
The mere fact that lots of countries are getting richer and more sophisticated means that they now want -- and can afford -- American brands, said Stephen M. Peterson, a vice president at Giddings & Lewis. The company, based in Fond Du Lac, Wis., is the nation's biggest maker of machine tools and has lately been helping to automate factories in countries like Israel and Taiwan.
The Weyerhaeuser Corporation, for example, expects to ship a quarter of a million metric tons of high-grade newsprint, suitable for color printing, from Tacoma, Wash., to Tokyo this year. The Whirlpool Corporation says its appliance exports to Venezuela and elsewhere will jump 25 percent in 1991. And the Fluor Corporation, the construction giant, is installing anti-pollution devices in Indonesian oil refineries.
Pitney Bowes is helping financial-services companies in South Korea and Taiwan automate their mailings, in place of subcontractors who have stuffed envelopes manually. "These countries are 20 to 30 years behind the U.S. in the state of the mailing process," Mr. Williams of Pitney Bowes said.
The rapid growth of many Asian nations has strained both their infrastructure and environment. Governments are budgeting bigger sums for major projects, from telephone cables to airport runways to sewage treatment plants, Mr. Gay of Morgan Stanley said. Bechtel Group, the San Francisco engineering and construction company, is building a power plant in Indonesia, a subway system in Taiwan and the $16 billion Hong Kong airport.
And thanks to rising environmental consciousness abroad, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, a Norwalk, Conn., maker of instruments that measure emissions and residues, has opened service and distribution offices this year in Taiwan, Thailand and South Korea.
 
Canada and Mexico
 The United States is also poised for a big boost closer to home. Canada typically buys as much as Germany and Japan combined. Its steep recession ended with a bang this spring when its economy spurted at a 4.5 percent annual rate.
Mexico, which has piled up a record $8 billion in foreign exchange reserves, has lately grown at an annual rate of more than 5 percent and is in the midst of an investment boom. Imports, two-thirds of which come from the United States, have recently soared at a 14 percent annual rate.
As Mexico embraces freer markets, it has knocked down decades-old trade barriers. The first to benefit, Mr. Gay said, have been United States makers of consumer goods, followed by makers of machinery and other capital equipment. "Just look at the pattern in Mexico and you'll see the pattern for other countries," he said.
Appliance sales are surging in Mexico, said Alun Wilson, director of sales and distibution of the Whirlpool Overseas Corporation, a subsidiary of Whirlpool based in Benton Harbor, Mich. Sharp tariff reductions and removal of informal trade barriers turned Venezuela into "a very big growth market this year" for American appliances, he added.
In many nations that are selling off state-owned enterprises to private investors, there is a growing appetite for American services. Exports of construction, design and other services have risen 8 percent from a year ago, and the United States services surplus reached an annual rate of $8 billion last spring.
Fluor, the Irvine, Calif., builder, has received hundreds of millions of dollars of work to spruce up Chile's copper industry, which has attracted major equity investments by foreign multinational companies.
"Since the free elections, there's been a lot more interest in having foreign companies take an interest in Chile," said Vic Medina, vice president for mining and metals at Fluor.
United States exports are also riding the coattails of American manufacturing giants like Du Pont, Procter & Gamble and Chrysler, which are busy setting up overseas plants. Expanding multinationals help increase the sales of everything from American insurance policies and engineering services to construction materials and machinery.
Consider what happens when a chain like Toys "R" Us expands overseas. The company's vice chairman, Michael Goldstein, said it expected to scatter 29 more stores across Europe, Canada and Japan next year, bringing the total abroad to 127.
Whenever Toys "R" Us opens new doors, exports of products like Fisher-Price's Little People and Milton Bradley's board games get a lift.
 
Dollar's Weakness Helps
 One big reason American companies are winning a bigger slice of the export pie, especially in Canada and Europe, is that their products remain bargains. "We're very competitive against Asia and hyper-competitive against Europe," said David Rolley, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
The dollar is still weak, up a mere 1 percent from last year against a basket of trading partners' currencies -- and still 40 percent below its 1985 peak. According to DRI/McGraw Hill, the American share of world exports has risen to 27 percent, up from a low of 19 percent in 1985.
"The most important event in the world economy during the 1980's was surely the boom in U.S. manufacturing exports," said Peter F. Drucker, the management consultant.
But American producers' low costs reflect more than the low dollar. United States inflation, which chips away at competitiveness, has declined, especially at the wholesale level. Lower interest rates have made investing in technology cheaper. Wage increases have been smaller than in other nations. And productivity gains on the factory floor keep coming.
 
U.S. Wages Are Below Europe's
 As a result, unit labor costs -- wages at current exchange rates adjusted for output per hour -- are higher in every major European country than in the United States and about the same in Japan. In the mid-80's, unit labor costs were higher in the United States.
And now, even the enormous gap between the United States and the newly industrialized countries like South Korea and Taiwan has shrunk sharply.
"Customers we've never had before are knocking on our door to source products in the U.S.," said Adrian T. Dillon, vice president at the Eaton Corporation, a Cleveland manufacturer whose products include differentials for cars and trucks made in Sweden by Volvo.

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the role of exports in the American economy misstated the number of stores planned abroad by Toys "R" Us. It is 29 this year and 40 in 1992.

HEADLINE: BRIEFS

 BODY:

DEBT
 
*Argentina plans to sell $150 million in bonds later this week, according to a spokesman for Credit Suisse First Boston. The price is expected to be about 350 to 375 basis points above two-year Treasury notes that yielded 5.64 percent yesterday. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
 
COMMON STOCK
 
* Pharmaceutical Marketing Services Inc., of Scottsdale, Ariz. has filed for an initial public offering of 3.5 million common shares, through Lehman Brothers. The company is a subsidiary of Walsh International.
 
RATINGS
 
* Century Communications Corp.'s $500 million shelf registration of debt securities has been given a preliminary rating of B for senior debt and B- for subordinated debt, by Standard & Poor's Corp. Century is based in New Canaan, Conn.
 
*Walt Disney Co.'s $420 million zero-coupon senior notes, due 2006, have been rated A+ by Standard & Poor's, which also affirmed an A rating on about $1 billion of subordinated debt. Disney is based in Burbank, Calif.
